content.question:
A complex aircraft has four independent AC generators, namely:
GEN 1 (ENG 1)
GEN 2 (ENG 2)
APU GEN
EMER GEN
How are the generators connected to a split bus system?

options.A: In parallel, with all 4 generators connected to the same part of the split bus bar. Power is then shared along the length of the split bus bar.
options.B: With 2 or more generators connected in series, so that any increase in power demand can be met.
options.C: In parallel, with one generator at a time supplying individual parts of the split bus bar.
options.D: It varies depending on the type of generator installed.

key_points: Modern twin-engine aircraft employ a split-bus power distribution system
During normal conditions, each engine-driven AC generator powers only one main AC bus
The busses are kept split from each other, and two generators can never power the same bus simultaneously
learning.explanation: Modern twin-engine aircraft employ a split-bus power distribution system. During normal conditions, each engine-driven AC generator powers only one main AC bus. The busses are kept split from each other, and two generators can never power the same bus simultaneously. Split bus bar systems need to have a centralized means of controlling power distribution. If a generator or bus fault develops, the relevant bus tie breakers (BTB) or generator circuit-breakers (GCB) must be configured to protect the remaining generators, whilst still delivering power to essential loads. Generators are connected in parallel to their respective split bus bar through a generator breaker (GB). Split bus bars are connected to each other through bus tie breakers (BTBs).

content.question: The frequency of the current provided by an alternator depends on…

options.A: its phase balance.
options.B: the strength of the excitation current.
options.C: its load.
options.D: its rotation speed.

key_points: Nowadays, commercial aircraft electrical system is supplied by two (or more) engine-driven generators regulated in speed by integrated drives
These generators’ characteristics are: 115/200 Volts, 3-phase AC
400 Hz
learning.explanation: Nowadays, commercial aircraft electrical system is supplied by two (or more) engine-driven generators regulated in speed by integrated drives. These generators’ characteristics are: 115/200 Volts, 3-phase AC. 400 Hz. 90 kVA. 28 V DC is obtained by converting the generators’ output AC via the transformer rectifier units. The APU generator is essentially the same as the main engine-driven generators, so it will provide exactly the same output. The APU will electrically supply the aircraft and other associated systems on the ground when the engines are not running, and the Ground Power unit (GPU) is not connected. As to why nowadays commercial aircraft generators are integrated with a CSD in an IDGU (integrated drive generator unit) and use mainly 400 Hz AC is because a higher frequency allows the manufacturers to make smaller and lighter generators that would allow increasing the payload instead of carrying extra weight from the generators. Because the frequency of an AC generator mainly relies on the number of pairs of poles and the speed of the rotor, it is sufficient to increase the generator’s rotational speed in order to provide a higher frequency, and thus decrease the generator’s size appropriately.

content.question:
If you increase the load on an electric motor, i.e. increase the resistance against rotation (within its working limits), what will happen to the:
(1) Current flow
(2) Power consumption

options.A: (1) increases; (2) decreases
options.B: (1) increases; (2) increases
options.C: (1) decreases; (2) increases
options.D: (1) decreases; (2) decreases

key_points: When a large load (resistance) is put on a motor, the rate of rotation will decrease, meaning that the armature cuts through fewer lines of flux (less magnetic field), and this means that the "back EMF" is reduced
This back EMF is effectively the force which acts against the electricity in a motor, reducing the electrical energy due to it being turned into kinetic energy inside the motor

(Lenz's Law) If this back EMF (resistive force) is reduced, that means that for the same voltage, the current can flow more easily, so the current will increase through the armature, sometimes by a very large amount
learning.explanation: When a large load (resistance) is put on a motor, the rate of rotation will decrease, meaning that the armature cuts through fewer lines of flux (less magnetic field), and this means that the "back EMF" is reduced. This back EMF is effectively the force which acts against the electricity in a motor, reducing the electrical energy due to it being turned into kinetic energy inside the motor. (Lenz's Law) If this back EMF (resistive force) is reduced, that means that for the same voltage, the current can flow more easily, so the current will increase through the armature, sometimes by a very large amount. This can even be enough to melt fuses or wires in some motors. The higher current flow means that there is more power consumed (power = voltage x current), and also the motor will produce higher torque.

content.question: DC generators in a multi-engine aircraft are connected in…

options.A: parallel to provide maximum voltage.
options.B: parallel to provide maximum power.
options.C: series to provide maximum voltage.
options.D: series to provide maximum power.

key_points: Paralleling generators is when two generators supply one bus bar
This allows the load to be shared between the two generators and has the added advantage of maintaining power on the busbar in the event of one of the generators failing

In a parallel configuration, two DC generators (of a multi-engine aircraft for example) will operate as if they were working individually, however this will maximize the power output, provide redundancy
learning.explanation: Paralleling generators is when two generators supply one bus bar. This allows the load to be shared between the two generators and has the added advantage of maintaining power on the busbar in the event of one of the generators failing. In a parallel configuration, two DC generators (of a multi-engine aircraft for example) will operate as if they were working individually, however this will maximize the power output, provide redundancy.

content.question: An inverter is a…

options.A: device for changing mechanical movement into electrical energy.
options.B: unit used to convert DC into AC.
options.C: device for reversing the polarity of the static charge.
options.D: unit used to change AC to DC.

key_points: The inverter is a unit used to convert DC into AC
Essentially receive an 18-30V DC current and they output 115 V, 400 Hz AC
The static inverter consists of all the standard electrical and electronic components such as oscillators, diodes, transistors, capacitors, and transformers
learning.explanation: The inverter is a unit used to convert DC into AC. Essentially receive an 18-30V DC current and they output 115 V, 400 Hz AC. The static inverter consists of all the standard electrical and electronic components such as oscillators, diodes, transistors, capacitors, and transformers. Inverters can also be rotary, by converting the DC to AC using a constant speed DC motor to drive an alternator, thereby producing constant frequency AC. However, the most common inverters fitted into aircraft electrical systems are the static inverters described above.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The symbol below represents which logic gate?

options.A: NOT
options.B: NOR
options.C: NAND
options.D: OR

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.01.08.02: Describe the following five basic logic functions, as used in aircraft FCOM documentation, and recognise their schematic symbols according to the ANSI/MIL standard: AND; OR; NOT; NOR; NAND. Logic gates are the building blocks of computer processing. Computers operate at the deepest level in binary, a series of transistors holding either a value of 1 or 0. Logic gates allow these 1s and 0s to be calculated, and these very simple functions can be combined and programmed at a much higher level that can then become computer programs. For our simple purposes, an integrated circuit may have several gate circuits with several different entries, but only one single output will result. The five basic logic gates are the following: AND gate – All or Nothing gate. Both inputs must be 1 to generate a 1. OR gate – Any or All gate. If at least one input is 1, the output will be 1 as well. The output will be 0 only if both inputs are 0. NAND gate – AND gate + NOT = inverted "AND" output, symbolized by the small circle at the output of the gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOR gate – OR gate + NOT = inverted "OR" output, symbolized again by the small circle at the output of the OR gate along with the bar over the “C”. NOT gate – invert gate, used to reverse the state of the input. If input = 0, then output = 1.

content.question: An AC generator's frequency is measured using which unit, and can be described as what?

options.A: Volts (V), electricity produced per minute.
options.B: Watts (W), the rate of electron flow.
options.C: Hertz (Hz), the number of oscillations per second.
options.D: Cycles (C), the number of repetitions per minute.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.01.03.04: Define frequency and state the unit of measurement. Frequency is a measure of cycles per unit time, meaning how many times does a certain thing happen every second? The unit of frequency is Hertz (Hz), and for an AC generator, it is measuring the amount of times the voltage "flips" backwards and forwards per second. AC (Alternating Current) electricity does not flow straight down the wires like DC does, it actually flows forwards and backwards, many times per second. In Europe, the mains electricity supply is AC, and the frequency of the AC is 50 Hz, meaning that the sine wave of voltage repeats 50 times per second (this is actually 100 "flips" per second, but we measure from peak to peak as 1 wave). In many aircraft, the AC system is 115 V (Volts), with a frequency of 400 Hz.

content.question: Electrical bonding of an aircraft is used to…

options.A: equalise the electrical potential of the different aircraft parts.
options.B: eliminate the need for grounding the aircraft during refuelling.
options.C: prevent the aircraft being struck by lightning.
options.D: ensure the electrical potential of the aircraft structure remains at 0 volts.

key_points: As airplanes fly through the air, the friction of the air particles against the skin of the aircraft creates static electricity
The static may build up unequally between aircraft parts and this could lead to sparks between the components
These sparks could lead to a fire
learning.explanation: As airplanes fly through the air, the friction of the air particles against the skin of the aircraft creates static electricity. The static may build up unequally between aircraft parts and this could lead to sparks between the components. These sparks could lead to a fire. Therefore aircraft bonding between parts is installed to prevent the potential difference from being created between the parts, and therefore preventing any sparks from occurring. Bonding in itself is simply to connect all components of the aircraft with flexible wire strips, creating an easy path for electrons to pass between parts. On top of assuring a equal potential difference, the bonding system can also be used as a earth return system for a unipole circuit. Incorrect answers: “eliminate the need for grounding the aircraft during refuelling.” – The wires create a connection between the aircraft parts, but not to the ground. “prevent the aircraft being struck by lightning.” – Even though the grounding system will help the electrons from the lighting pass through the aircraft, it will not prevent the aircraft from being hit by a lightning strike. “ensure the electrical potential of the aircraft structure remains at 0 volts.” – The bonding system ensures that the potential difference between the components is zero, not that the entire aircraft structure remains at 0 volts.

content.question: A battery capacity of 100 Ah means that the battery can provide...

options.A: 10 Amperes for 10 hours.
options.B: 5 Amperes for 10 hours.
options.C: 10 Amperes for 15 minutes.
options.D: 5 Amperes for 30 minutes.

key_points: Batteries convert chemical energy into electrical energy by a transfer of electrons from one material to another using the potential difference between the materials
The capacity of a battery is the amount of Ampere-hour (Ah) a fully charged battery can supply
For example, a 5Ah capacity means that the battery will be able to deliver 5 amperes in 1 hour or 2
learning.explanation: Batteries convert chemical energy into electrical energy by a transfer of electrons from one material to another using the potential difference between the materials. The capacity of a battery is the amount of Ampere-hour (Ah) a fully charged battery can supply. For example, a 5Ah capacity means that the battery will be able to deliver 5 amperes in 1 hour or 2.5 Amperes in 2 hours, or even 10 amperes in 30 minutes. That is, the current (A) multiplied by time (Hr) in hours equals ampere hours. A. 10 Amperes x 10 hours = 100 Ah (correct) B. 5 Amperes x 10 hours = 50 Ah (wrong) C. 10 Amperes x 0.25 hours (15 minutes) = 2.5 Ah (wrong) D. 5 Amperes x 0.5 hours (30 minutes) = 2.5 Ah (wrong) If two identical batteries are connected in parallel the output voltage will remain the same and the capacity expressed in ampere-hours will double. On the other hand, if the batteries are connected in series, the capacity will remain the same, but the output voltage will double.

content.question: Which of the following components would NOT be found as part of the wet-sump oil system of a piston engine?

options.A: A separate oil reservoir.
options.B: An oil filter with a bypass indicator.
options.C: An integrated oil reservoir.
options.D: A pump to provide oil flow to the engine.

key_points: There are two main types of oil system for engines, dry-sump and wet-sump
The biggest difference between the two is where the oil stored when not in use
In a dry-sump system, the oil is pumped from the bottom of the engine to the oil reservoir
learning.explanation: There are two main types of oil system for engines, dry-sump and wet-sump. The biggest difference between the two is where the oil stored when not in use. In a dry-sump system, the oil is pumped from the bottom of the engine to the oil reservoir. In a wet-sump system, the oil is stored in the "sump", which is just the area at the bottom of the engine, where the oil naturally drains to. We can now go through each option: "A separate oil reservoir." Correct. A separate oil reservoir is part of a dry sump oil system. "An oil filter with a bypass indicator." An oil filter will be in all types of engine oil system, due to the need to clean the oil and remove particulates before they are re-circulated through the engine. The bypass indicator shows clogging of the filter, and indicates when the filter is no longer being used, and the emergency bypass valve has opened to let oil past. "An integrated oil reservoir." Wet sump oil systems use an integrated reservoir that stores the oil in the bottom of the engine casing. "A pump to provide oil flow to the engine." Both types of oil system will include a pump to provide oil flow to the engine. In a wet sump system, it is the only oil pump. In a dry sump system, this is called the pressure pump (there is also a scavenge pump).

content.question: The first indication of carburettor icing during cruise in aeroplanes equipped with a constant-speed propeller is a:

options.A: rough running engine followed by loss in rpm
options.B: decrease in manifold pressure
options.C: decrease in rpm
options.D: rough running engine followed by an increase in manifold pressure

key_points: When ice is building up in the carburetor the venturi duct is narrowing and increases the effects of the venturi tube (further decrease in pressure and temperature)
The dynamic pressure flowing through the tube increases the ice build-up as the venturi-shaped icy duct sees a decrease in temperature and static pressure
This is also the reason why the first indication of ice build-up is going to be a decrease in manifold pressure (=static pressure)
learning.explanation: When ice is building up in the carburetor the venturi duct is narrowing and increases the effects of the venturi tube (further decrease in pressure and temperature). The dynamic pressure flowing through the tube increases the ice build-up as the venturi-shaped icy duct sees a decrease in temperature and static pressure. This is also the reason why the first indication of ice build-up is going to be a decrease in manifold pressure (=static pressure). Therefore, as soon as the carburetor heating is turned on, the ice buildup will melt, and the duct will see an increase in static pressure (=manifold pressure). Obviously, this will be only observed on an airplane fitted with a piston engine and a constant speed propeller since there’s no MAP gauge in a fixed-pitch propeller. In a fixed-pitch propeller, only a drop in RPM will be observed.

content.question: The main purpose of a turbocharger is to…

options.A: maintain power with increasing altitude.
options.B: reduce the fuel flow.
options.C: provide a richer mixture at higher altitudes.
options.D: increase thermal efficiency.

key_points: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude
The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor
The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller
learning.explanation: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude. The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor. The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller. That energy is nothing else than the exhaust gases. The turbocharger consists of two exhaust gas inlets that receive and direct the exhaust gases towards the turbine wheel. The exhaust gases mechanically spin the turbine before leaving the system through an exhaust gas outlet. The turbine is connected through a solid common shaft to a compressor, and the rotating energy gained from the exhaust gases circulation will serve to drive the compressor. At the compressor’s end, there’s also an inlet that will receive and direct ambient air to the compressor’s impeller eye. The air will then leave the impeller almost at a tangent to the periphery and trade velocity for an increase in pressure and temperature. The boost air under pressure obtained from this process will then be ducted to mix with the fuel and follow its path towards combustion. The pressure of the compressed air (boost) can be monitored only on the cockpit MAP gauge.

content.question:
When are the auxiliary fuel pumps installed on single-engine low-wing aeroplanes typically used?
1. during take-off
2. during cruise
3. during landing
4. in emergency situations
5. in case of a suspected vapour lock
6. in case of failure of the engine fuel pump

key_points: Single engine piston aircraft feature additional fuel pumps called auxiliary pumps
Such pumps are not engine-driven but usually require electrical power
Auxiliary pumps are connected in parallel to the main fuel pumps and serve as a backup in case of failure of a main pump
learning.explanation: Single engine piston aircraft feature additional fuel pumps called auxiliary pumps. Such pumps are not engine-driven but usually require electrical power. Auxiliary pumps are connected in parallel to the main fuel pumps and serve as a backup in case of failure of a main pump. They are required to be switched on in normal operation for take-off and landing only and are switched off in cruise. In abnormal conditions, such as a main pump failure or suspected vapour lock, or in any emergency situation, the auxiliary pumps are switched on.

content.question: During cruising flight, when the throttle is pulled back on an aeroplane equipped with a constant speed-propeller, the propeller pitch automatically..

options.A: decreases and the RPM remains the same.
options.B: increases and the RPM increases.
options.C: increases and the RPM remains the same.
options.D: decreases and the RPM decreases.

key_points: In a variable pitch propeller, the engine is governed to run at a set rpm throughout the flight range
The propeller governs the engine at this set rpm by the use of a device known as a constant speed unit (CSU) and by means of a flyweight governor

Any variations in engine power output (throttle pulled back or forward), which would otherwise produce a change in rpm, are sensed by the CSU which alters the propeller pitch angle to keep the rpm constant
learning.explanation: In a variable pitch propeller, the engine is governed to run at a set rpm throughout the flight range. The propeller governs the engine at this set rpm by the use of a device known as a constant speed unit (CSU) and by means of a flyweight governor. Any variations in engine power output (throttle pulled back or forward), which would otherwise produce a change in rpm, are sensed by the CSU which alters the propeller pitch angle to keep the rpm constant. If the throttle is pulled back, the propeller pitch would automatically decrease (fine pitch) but the RPM will remain the same, and vice-versa. The governor controls a hydraulic servo system feeding high-pressure oil, via a pilot valve, to a piston in the pitch change mechanism (PCM). The CSU operates on the principle of balancing a spring pressure against the centrifugal force of rotating governor flyweights, driven directly from the engine or reduction gearbox. Usually, in a piston engine, the governor flyweights are tensioned by a speeder spring, which is controlled from the cockpit by setting the RPM lever. In a turboprop, however, the most efficient engine RPM is maintained by pre-tensioning the speeder spring to give the maximum engine RPM at all times.

content.question: If the ground wire between the magnetos and the ignition switch of a piston engine becomes disconnected the most noticeable result will be that…

options.A: the power developed by the engine will be greatly reduced.
options.B: the engine cannot be started with the ignition switch in the “ON” position.
options.C: the engine cannot be shut down by turning the ignition switch to the “OFF” position.
options.D: a still operating engine will run down.

key_points: Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch
The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth
In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded
learning.explanation: Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch. The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth. In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded. However, if the grounding wire is broken, the magneto will keep working normally and the engine will continue running. Another situation where the engine can keep running is when an excessive carbon deposit has formed in the cylinder head. Because the deposit is still hot enough when you arrive at your parking position after the flight in order to ignite the charge without the spark from the plugs. The effect will be a hardly rumbling engine that is still running. If this ever happens and the engine doesn’t stop, you can simply pull back the mixture control lever (red) and shut off the fuel supply. Caution! Maintenance action should be sought before touching the propeller since the engine can start at any time with one magneto still un-grounded.

content.question: During cruising flight, when the throttle is slightly advanced on an aeroplane equipped with a constant speed-propeller, the propeller pitch automatically…

options.A: increases and the RPM remains the same.
options.B: decreases and the RPM decreases.
options.C: decreases and the RPM remains the same.
options.D: increases and the RPM increases.

key_points: Variable pitch propeller: designed to keep a set rpm throughout the entire flight range
The propeller controls the engine at this set rpm through a device called a Constant Speed Unit (CSU)
Any variations in engine power output, which would normally produce a change in rpm, will be sensed by the CSU that will alter the propeller’s pitch angle to keep the rpm constant
learning.explanation: Variable pitch propeller: designed to keep a set rpm throughout the entire flight range. The propeller controls the engine at this set rpm through a device called a Constant Speed Unit (CSU). Any variations in engine power output, which would normally produce a change in rpm, will be sensed by the CSU that will alter the propeller’s pitch angle to keep the rpm constant. For example, in cruise when power is increased, the propeller pitch angle will be increased by the CSU and move the blade towards the coarse position. To avoid an engine overboost the RPM will be increased before increasing the manifold pressure.

content.question: In reference to piston engines, what is meant by the term 'swept volume'?

options.A: The volume displaced by the piston during a single stroke.
options.B: The volume above the piston when it is at the top dead centre.
options.C: The volume above the piston when it is at the bottom dead centre.
options.D: The volume displaced by the piston during a full cycle.

key_points: The term 'swept volume' is another way to describe the displacement of a cylinder per individual stroke
It is the volume difference within the cylinder between when the piston is at Top Dead Centre (TDC) and Bottom Dead Centre (BDC)
If you filled the cylinder with water at bottom dead centre, then moved it to top dead centre, the 'swept volume' of water would come out
learning.explanation: The term 'swept volume' is another way to describe the displacement of a cylinder per individual stroke. It is the volume difference within the cylinder between when the piston is at Top Dead Centre (TDC) and Bottom Dead Centre (BDC). If you filled the cylinder with water at bottom dead centre, then moved it to top dead centre, the 'swept volume' of water would come out. When multiplied by the number of cylinders, it gives the overall displacement of the engine, for instance a 2 litre engine with 4 cylinders. Each cylinder would have 500 ml of displacement, a swept volume of 500 ml. It can also be calculated by multiplying the stroke distance by the cylinder diameter, known as the bore.

content.question: What are the actions to unfeather a variable pitch prop…

options.A: Push the propeller lever forward into the normal operating range which results in a blade angle with no thrust.
options.B: Push the propeller lever forward into the normal operating range which results in a blade angle producing thrust.
options.C: Pull the propeller lever backward into the normal operating range which results in a blade angle with no thrust.
options.D: Pull the propeller backward into the normal operating range which results in a blade angle producing thrust.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.09.04.03: Describe the operating principle of a variable pitch propeller when feathering and unfeathering, including the operation of cockpit controls. When flying with a variable pitch propeller (the most common type being a "constant speed propeller"), there is often an extra lever in the cockpit near the throttles to control the propeller pitch. In the standard "constant speed propeller" systems, this extra lever (coloured blue) sets the speed of the engine (the RPM), and the black throttle lever then dictates how much fuel and air mixture is allowed into the cylinders, which sets the manifold pressure. Having a constant speed propeller (variable pitch), means that the engine/propeller can run at their best RPM all the time, whether that be at 0 kt at the beginning of the take off roll or at 150 kt in the cruise, for instance. The incoming airflow at 150 kt means that the propeller must be set much more coarse to still cut out the same sized "chunks of air", thereby maintaining the correct angle of attack with the airflow. Fine pitch is when the chord of the propeller is more inline with the plane of rotation, and is more efficient for low speed flying, take-off, go arounds, etc. Coarse pitch is used in the cruise. Going past the coarse pitch until the propeller is pointing directly forwards (near 90° blade angle) is called feathering. It is used to reduce drag when the engine stops. If the engine stops with the propeller in the normal operating range, the airflow actually tries to turn the engine, which is what we call windmilling. This is what we need for restarting the engine, but it is not good for drag. Therefore, to "unfeather" an engine (to try a restart), we need to move the blade angle from feathered to fine (best for windmilling), which will initially provide negative thrust (drag), but as soon as the engine is turning under its own power, will be able to produce forwards thrust, which is not possible when feathered. The way to remember whether to push or pull the blue prop lever is to think of a go around/take off. In these scenarios, we want all three levers forwards, throttle full, propeller fine, mixture rich. Therefore, this means that for the blue lever, forward is fine, so full back must be feathered. This means that to unfeather, we must push the lever forwards.

content.question: Which option is a desired characteristic for piston-engine fuel?

options.A: Good anti-knock properties.
options.B: High viscosity.
options.C: Specific gravity greater than 1.0 kg/l.
options.D: High flash point.

key_points: DETONATION As the name suggests, Detonation is an explosion of the fuel-air mixture inside the cylinder
During detonation, the fuel/air charge explodes rather than burning smoothly
Because of this explosion, the charge exerts a much higher force on the piston and cylinder, leading to increased noise, vibration, and cylinder head temperatures
learning.explanation: DETONATION As the name suggests, Detonation is an explosion of the fuel-air mixture inside the cylinder. During detonation, the fuel/air charge explodes rather than burning smoothly. Because of this explosion, the charge exerts a much higher force on the piston and cylinder, leading to increased noise, vibration, and cylinder head temperatures. The violence of detonation also causes a reduction in power. Mild detonation may increase engine wear, though some engines can operate with mild detonation. However, severe detonation can cause engine failure in minutes. Because of the noise that it makes, detonation is called "engine knock". Detonation and its resulting high heat is detrimental to piston engine operation. Its cumulative effects can lead to piston, ring, and cylinder head failure and place thermal stress on other operating components. Therefore, a good anti-knocking capability is desirable (high octane rating)

content.question: The thermal efficiency of a piston engine is about…

key_points: Thermal efficiency
For a heat engine, such as an internal combustion engine, thermal efficiency is the measure of how efficiently the engine converts thermal heat contained by fuel into useful work
Thermal efficiency = (Heat converted to work ÷ Heat energy available in the fuel) × 100%
learning.explanation: Thermal efficiency. For a heat engine, such as an internal combustion engine, thermal efficiency is the measure of how efficiently the engine converts thermal heat contained by fuel into useful work. Thermal efficiency = (Heat converted to work ÷ Heat energy available in the fuel) × 100%. The average thermal efficiency of a piston engine is approximately 33%. Most of the heat energy is lost to the atmosphere in the exhaust. The remainder heats up the engine components.

content.question: If a manifold pressure gauge consistently registers atmospheric pressure, the cause is probably…

options.A: an aneroid capsule which is not properly calibrated.
options.B: a very high atmospheric pressure.
options.C: a very low atmospheric pressure.
options.D: leak in pressure gauge line.

key_points: The MAP is intimately associated with the pressure created by combustion; therefore it provides a reliable and accurate indicator of the power being generated
It is measured at the diffuser stage of the turbocharger just after leaving the impeller
The pressure measured at that stage is normally higher since this is the whole purpose of the impeller – provide air under pressure to boost the engines capabilities at high altitude
learning.explanation: The MAP is intimately associated with the pressure created by combustion; therefore it provides a reliable and accurate indicator of the power being generated. It is measured at the diffuser stage of the turbocharger just after leaving the impeller. The pressure measured at that stage is normally higher since this is the whole purpose of the impeller – provide air under pressure to boost the engines capabilities at high altitude. Bear in mind that when the engine is stopped on the ground, the MAP gauge indicates the atmospheric pressure, whereas when the engine is running and because of the suction and the differential pressure created, the MAP gauge will indicate a lower value than atmospheric pressure. If the MAP gauge indicates the atmospheric pressure while the engine is running, there is most probably a leak in the pressure gauge line.

content.question: To prevent vapour locking, which can lead to fuel starvation, a common type of limitation imposed by the Minimum Equipment List (MEL) in large transport aeroplanes for complete boost pump failure is…

options.A: No fuel may be carried in the affected fuel tank.
options.B: Maximum operating altitude limitation.
options.C: Minimum fuel temperature limitation.
options.D: Extra reserve fuel has to be carried.

key_points: VAPOUR LOCK Vapor lock results from fuel boiling
Ambient pressure drops at higher altitude
Thus fuel changes to liquid to vapour more easily
learning.explanation: VAPOUR LOCK Vapor lock results from fuel boiling. Ambient pressure drops at higher altitude. Thus fuel changes to liquid to vapour more easily. The operational result is little or no liquid fuel available for injection. If this occurs in a pipe it will block or restrict fuel flow thus creating a vapour lock. In order to prevent a vapour lock, Fuel booster pumps are fitted inside the tanks which will pressurize the fuel in the pipelines from the tank to the engine, pushing fuel towards the engine rather than engine driven pumps sucking fuel from the tanks. In case of complete boost pump failure, large transport aeroplanes will be limited by a Maximum Operating Altitude.

content.question: For a given type of oil, the viscosity depends on the…

options.A: outside pressure.
options.B: oil pressure.
options.C: oil temperature.
options.D: quantity of oil.

key_points: Viscosity, also known as fluid’s internal friction, is the tendency of a liquid or gas to resist flow and is temperature-dependent
When oil is cold, it has a high viscosity and flows slowly, thus making the fluid stream quite difficult

However, if the fluid’s temperature increases, the viscosity might become excessively low to the point where the film between the bearing surfaces breaks down and metal-to-metal contact occurs, resulting in rapid wear, overheating, and ultimately fire
learning.explanation: Viscosity, also known as fluid’s internal friction, is the tendency of a liquid or gas to resist flow and is temperature-dependent. When oil is cold, it has a high viscosity and flows slowly, thus making the fluid stream quite difficult. However, if the fluid’s temperature increases, the viscosity might become excessively low to the point where the film between the bearing surfaces breaks down and metal-to-metal contact occurs, resulting in rapid wear, overheating, and ultimately fire.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding aircraft engine turbochargers?

options.A: The waste-gate is situated in the inlet manifold.
options.B: When the waste-gate is fully open the turbocharger is running at full speed.
options.C: The waste-gate actuator is controlled by the waste-gate.
options.D: The waste-gate diverts exhaust gas to drive the turbine.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.03: Power-augmentation devices: explain the requirement for power augmentation (turbocharging) of a piston engine. Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.04: Describe the function and the principle of operation of the following main components of a turbocharger: turbine; compressor; waste gate; waste-gate actuator. Piston Engines can have their power increased in three main ways, by increasing the size of the engine (displacement), increasing the RPM, or increasing the pressure of the air/fuel mixture (called the Manifold Absolute Pressure, MAP). This last case is why we might use a turbocharger in our car engines, so we can have a small, efficient engine, with extra power available from a turbocharger (which compresses the intake air) when needed. Turbochargers are arguably even more useful in aircraft, where piston engines become less powerful in the thinner air at higher altitudes. This is where turbochargers can compress that air, to make the engine operate with the same power output it would do at a much lower altitude. We call this an "altitude boosted" turbocharger. They are more useful to us by keeping the same power up to higher altitudes, rather than giving us lots more power on the ground, which would put a lot of strain on the engine, which would be a "ground boosted" turbocharger. Turbochargers (and any superchargers, really) increase the amount of air (and therefore fuel) we can ignite in the cylinders, and are measured by the MAP; the higher the MAP, the more air/fuel mixture we can burn in each power stroke. A turbocharger works by using the excess speed and pressure of the exhaust gasses to spin a turbine, which then directly spins a compressor, which compresses the fresh intake air ready for mixing with fuel and then entry into the cylinders (or sent straight into the cylinders where fuel injection takes place). All superchargers compress fresh intake air like this, but turbochargers are special types of superchargers that use the excess energy leftover in the exhaust gasses that we would not otherwise use. The turbochargers we talk about are controlled by waste-gates, which are situated in the exhaust manifold, and decide how much exhaust gas to divert to the turbine; if the MAP is too low (for what has been asked for), then the waste-gate will send more air to the turbine to get a faster spinning compressor, and vice-versa. The movement of the waste-gate is powered by the oil pressure on the waste-gate actuator which is cleverly controlled by a system that measures the MAP and makes changes to the oil pressure accordingly, thereby moving the waste-gate actuator, and the waste-gate position. To go a little deeper, the waste-gate (as per its name) actually controls how much exhaust gas is allowed to bypass the turbine, and by closing the waste-gate and letting no gas escape would mean that all the gas would go through the turbine (to cause a high MAP) and vice versa (open waste-gate for slow turbine/compressor for lower MAP).

content.question: The part of a piston engine that transforms reciprocating movement into rotary motion is called the…

options.A: crankshaft
options.B: piston

In the closed end of the cylinder, known as the 'Cylinder Head', are inlet and exhaust valves and a sparking plug Do not confuse it with the camshaft which is a shaft containing several attached disks of irregular shape that operate the intake and exhaust valves
It is driven at half the crankshaft speed as each valve only requires opening once per working cycle => once every two revolutions of the crankshaft
learning.explanation: The reciprocating engine consists basically of a cylinder that is closed at one end, a piston that slides up and down inside the cylinder, and a connecting rod and crank by which reciprocating movement at the piston is converted to rotary movement of the crankshaft. In the closed end of the cylinder, known as the 'Cylinder Head', are inlet and exhaust valves and a sparking plug Do not confuse it with the camshaft which is a shaft containing several attached disks of irregular shape that operate the intake and exhaust valves. It is driven at half the crankshaft speed as each valve only requires opening once per working cycle => once every two revolutions of the crankshaft.

content.question: The compression ratio of a piston engine is a ratio of…

options.A: pressures.
options.B: area and volume.
options.C: areas.
options.D: volumes.

key_points: The compression ratio is the ratio of the largest volume (total volume) to the smallest volume (clearance volume)
In other words, it is the ratio between the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the BDC to the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the TDC
When the piston is at TDC, the fuel/air mixture is compressed into a very small space between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder
learning.explanation: The compression ratio is the ratio of the largest volume (total volume) to the smallest volume (clearance volume). In other words, it is the ratio between the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the BDC to the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the TDC. When the piston is at TDC, the fuel/air mixture is compressed into a very small space between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder. This is generally labeled as the clearance volume, or to put it simply, the smallest volume. On the other hand, when the piston is at the BDC, the volume of space containing the mixture (the total volume) is much larger. The difference between the total volume and the clearance volume is called the swept volume.

content.question: With regard to a piston engine, the sections of the carburettor where icing would most likely occur are the…

options.A: float chamber and fuel inlet filter.
options.B: main air bleed and main discharge nozzle.
options.C: accelerator pump and main metering jet.
options.D: venturi and the throttle valve.

key_points: The reason why these areas are the most exposed to icing is because the fluid (mixture) is getting the biggest pressure changes at the points mentioned in the correct answer option, i
e
the venturi and the throttle valve
learning.explanation: The reason why these areas are the most exposed to icing is because the fluid (mixture) is getting the biggest pressure changes at the points mentioned in the correct answer option, i.e. the venturi and the throttle valve. The mixture will be subject to a drop in static pressure and temperature. The ice accumulation will further narrow the venturi and the gaps between the chamber’s walls and the throttle, which will further decrease the temperature and increase the ice accretion.

content.question: The swept volume is…

options.A: The length of the stroke × the piston crown area.
options.B: The volume remaining above the piston at TDC.
options.C: The volume of cylinder above BDC.
options.D: The total volume.

key_points: The term 'swept volume' is another way to describe the displacement of a cylinder per individual stroke
It is the volume difference within the cylinder between when the piston is at Top Dead Centre (TDC) and Bottom Dead Centre (BDC)
If you filled the cylinder with water at bottom dead centre, then moved it to top dead centre, the 'swept volume' of water would come out
learning.explanation: The term 'swept volume' is another way to describe the displacement of a cylinder per individual stroke. It is the volume difference within the cylinder between when the piston is at Top Dead Centre (TDC) and Bottom Dead Centre (BDC). If you filled the cylinder with water at bottom dead centre, then moved it to top dead centre, the 'swept volume' of water would come out. When multiplied by the number of cylinders, it gives the overall displacement of the engine, for instance a 2 litre engine with 4 cylinders. Each cylinder would have 500 ml of displacement, a swept volume of 500 ml. It can also be calculated by multiplying the stroke distance by the cylinder diameter, known as the bore: Swept Volume = The length of the stroke × the piston crown area

content.question: The reading on the engine oil pressure gauge is the…

options.A: difference between the pressure pump pressure and the scavenge pump pressure.
options.B: pressure of the oil upstream of the pressure pump.
options.C: pressure of the oil downstream of the pressure pump.
options.D: pressure in the oil tank.

The main reason being that you want to be sure that the pressure at the pump’s output is enough to properly lubricate the engine parts
The pressure of a standard oil pump fitted in a reciprocating engine’s lubrication system is between 50-100 psi, however, this will depend on the size and loading of the engine itself
learning.explanation: The oil pressure is measured downstream (at the outlet) of the engine-driven pump. The main reason being that you want to be sure that the pressure at the pump’s output is enough to properly lubricate the engine parts. The pressure of a standard oil pump fitted in a reciprocating engine’s lubrication system is between 50-100 psi, however, this will depend on the size and loading of the engine itself. The pressure sensor can be either electrical or mechanical (bourdon tube).

content.question: Altitude-boosted turbochargers can be fitted in piston engines as a power-augmentation device, and are used to...

options.A: Increase the engine power output with increasing altitude, as compared to the power output at sea level.
options.B: Compensate for the drop in engine manifold pressure with increasing altitude, as compared to the pressure at sea level.
options.C: Compensate for the drop in engine intake temperature with increasing altitude, as compared to the temperature at sea level.
options.D: Increase the engine power output until reaching the critical altitude, as compared to the power output at sea level.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.03: Power-augmentation devices: explain the requirement for power augmentation (turbocharging) of a piston engine. Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.05: Explain the difference between an altitude-boosted turbocharger and a ground-boosted turbocharger. Piston Engines can have their power increased in three main ways, by increasing the size of the engine (displacement), increasing the RPM, or increasing the pressure of the air/fuel mixture (called the Manifold Absolute Pressure, MAP). This last case is why we might use a turbocharger in our car engines, so we can have a small, efficient engine, with extra power available from a turbocharger (which compresses the intake air) when needed. Turbochargers are arguably even more useful in aircraft, where piston engines become less powerful in the thinner air at higher altitudes. This is where turbochargers can compress that air, to make the engine operate with the same power output it would do at a much lower altitude. We call this an "altitude boosted" turbocharger. They are more useful to us by keeping the same manifold pressure and power output up to higher altitudes, rather than giving us lots more power on the ground, which would put a lot of strain on the engine, which would be a "ground boosted" turbocharger. For this reason, most aircraft use altitude boosted turbochargers, not ground boosted turbochargers. A turbocharger works by using the excess speed and pressure of the exhaust gasses to spin a turbine, which then directly spins a compressor, which compresses the fresh intake air ready for entry into the cylinders. All superchargers compress fresh intake air like this, but turbochargers are special types of superchargers that use the excess energy leftover in the exhaust gasses that we would not otherwise use. As for the other options: The power should not increase with altitude (in any meaningful way), it should either remain roughly the same or decrease above a certain altitude. The reducing temperature of the air increases air density so actually aids power output slightly. Again, the power output shouldn't increase with increasing altitude.

content.question: During a climb in a standard atmosphere with constant MAP and RPM indications and at a constant mixture setting, the power output of a piston engine…

options.A: decreases.
options.B: stays constant.
options.C: increases.
options.D: only stays constant if the propeller lever is pushed.

key_points: The power output will increase with increasing altitude at CONSTANT MAP and RPM only if the engine’s volumetric efficiency increases

Volumetric efficiency is the ratio of the volume of the mixture induced into the cylinder during normal engine operation, to the volume of the mixture which would be required to fill the cylinder at standard temperature and pressure
To make it simple, the bigger the volumetric efficiency of a given engine, the bigger the power produced
learning.explanation: The power output will increase with increasing altitude at CONSTANT MAP and RPM only if the engine’s volumetric efficiency increases. Volumetric efficiency is the ratio of the volume of the mixture induced into the cylinder during normal engine operation, to the volume of the mixture which would be required to fill the cylinder at standard temperature and pressure. To make it simple, the bigger the volumetric efficiency of a given engine, the bigger the power produced. Therefore, the simplest way to increase it, would be to increase the amount of mixture entering the cylinder, which is the exact purpose of the superchargers. Because in this question it is stated that the MAP is maintained CONSTANT, it means that the pressure, and therefore the density inside the engine is higher than in the outside air you’re currently flying in. Additionally, the decrease in temperature further increases the density of the air flowing through the engine. Moreover, in a simple piston engine without turbocharging, the volumetric efficiency only increases by increasing RPM (=increased momentum of the gases) and/or with increasing altitude where the drop in air density produces a drop in exhaust backpressure, which in turn will further increase the mass flow (and density) in the cylinder.

content.question: In a piston engine if the ratio of air to fuel is approximately 9:1 the mixture is:

options.A: too weak to support combustion.
options.B: weak.
options.C: chemically correct.
options.D: rich.

key_points: This question is simply asked to see if you understand how the mixture ratio works
15:1 mixture ratio means that for every 1 gram of fuel, 15 grams of air are required
Therefore, a rich mixture means that there’s less mass of air supplied for one gram of fuel than for a leaner mixture
learning.explanation: This question is simply asked to see if you understand how the mixture ratio works. 15:1 mixture ratio means that for every 1 gram of fuel, 15 grams of air are required. Therefore, a rich mixture means that there’s less mass of air supplied for one gram of fuel than for a leaner mixture. A ratio of 9:1 means that for every gram of fuel, 9 grams of air are required. By comparing it to the chemically correct ratio, you can deduce that a 9:1 ratio represents a rich mixture.

content.question: Consider a variable pitch propeller operating in a high RPM / low pitch condition. To select reverse thrust, the…

options.A: condition lever is moved to the reverse position and the blades move from low pitch through high pitch to reverse pitch.
options.B: condition lever is moved to the reverse position and the blades move from low pitch directly to reverse pitch.
options.C: power lever is moved to the reverse position and the blades move from low pitch directly to reverse pitch.
options.D: power lever is moved to the reverse position and the blades move from low pitch through high pitch to reverse pitch.

key_points: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight
Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm
The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range
learning.explanation: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight. Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm. The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range. However, while maneuvering on the ground, the power required for a turboprop engine is pretty low. Therefore, the controls have been adapted such that the blade pitch angle (therefore the thrust produced) is controlled directly by the pilot, overriding the CSU. This ground range is known as the BETA control range. The flight crew will select a blade pitch angle by moving the power lever fully aft and lifting it up. The first detent of the BETA range will correspond to the ground idle detent that will allow the pilots to produce a minimum level of thrust, just enough power to taxi the aircraft. If the lever is pulled full aft of the BETA range, the pilot will lower the blade pitch angle such that the maximum reverse power is produced (=negative thrust). This will usually be the case at landing in order to assist the aircraft’s deceleration.

content.question: The function of an accelerator pump in the carburettor of a piston engine is to…

options.A: enable proper functioning of a piston engine during throttle advance.
options.B: maintain a constant mixture in a piston engine at low and high power settings.
options.C: enable engine starting.
options.D: enable engine idling.

key_points: The function of an accelerator pump in the carburettor of a piston engine is to enable proper functioning of a piston engine during rapid throttle advance
In fact, a rapid throttle advance will translate into an abrupt huge air intake into the carburettor
However, the fuel metering unit of the carburettor is not as responsive, so there will be less fuel than air, which will result in a temporary weak mixture
learning.explanation: The function of an accelerator pump in the carburettor of a piston engine is to enable proper functioning of a piston engine during rapid throttle advance. In fact, a rapid throttle advance will translate into an abrupt huge air intake into the carburettor. However, the fuel metering unit of the carburettor is not as responsive, so there will be less fuel than air, which will result in a temporary weak mixture. The accelerator pump is mechanically linked to the throttle, so as soon as it is moved, the pump will force fuel into the venturi to achieve the right mixture for the given throttle setting.

content.question: For a piston engine, pre-ignition refers to the condition that may arise when…

options.A: the sparking plug ignites the mixture too early.
options.B: an uncontrolled flame front speed occurs.
options.C: a rich mixture is ignited by the sparking plugs.
options.D: the mixture is ignited by abnormal conditions within the cylinder before the spark occurs at the plug.

key_points: Pre-ignition is different from detonation, even though it may be a consequence of it

During the engine’s operation, it can occasionally become overheated and the temperature of some projections into the combustion chamber, such as the sparking plug endings or a piece of carbon may rise so much that the mixture is prematurely ignited during the compression stroke
Sometimes ignition may not switch off in all cylinders and the engine may continue to run, even though it has been shut down with the ignition switched off
learning.explanation: Pre-ignition is different from detonation, even though it may be a consequence of it. During the engine’s operation, it can occasionally become overheated and the temperature of some projections into the combustion chamber, such as the sparking plug endings or a piece of carbon may rise so much that the mixture is prematurely ignited during the compression stroke. Sometimes ignition may not switch off in all cylinders and the engine may continue to run, even though it has been shut down with the ignition switched off. When pre-ignition occurs, there’s some loss of power, the engine is running roughly, and contributes to further overheating the engine. Unlike detonation which usually diminishes with an increase in RPM, pre-ignition gets worse as the engine speed increases. In order to avoid pre-ignition, you should always use the correct mixture setting.

content.question: Assuming the RPM and throttle levers are not altered, when TAS increases the blade angle of a constant speed propeller will…

options.A: increase.
options.B: decrease.
options.C: decrease, then after a short time increase to its previous value.
options.D: remain constant.

key_points: A variable pitch propeller is designed to keep a set rpm throughout the entire flight range
The propeller controls the engine at this set rpm through a device called a Constant Speed Unit (CSU)

Any variations in engine power output or the TAS, which would normally produce a change in rpm, will be sensed by the CSU that will alter the propeller’s pitch (=blade) angle through the Pitch Change Mechanism to keep the rpm constant
learning.explanation: A variable pitch propeller is designed to keep a set rpm throughout the entire flight range. The propeller controls the engine at this set rpm through a device called a Constant Speed Unit (CSU). Any variations in engine power output or the TAS, which would normally produce a change in rpm, will be sensed by the CSU that will alter the propeller’s pitch (=blade) angle through the Pitch Change Mechanism to keep the rpm constant. For instance, an increase in TAS means that more forward air will hit the propeller, so as a consequence, the blade angle will increase so that it moves a bigger chunk of air without altering the rpm.

content.question:
Which statement(s) is/are true?
I. Fuel injections of the engines can not freeze
II. Carburetor freezing often occurs at 5°C to 20°C and at higher temperatures

options.A: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is correct, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: Aircraft icing can be divided into two general types based on whether it affects power production or aerodynamics
Induction icing affects engine power and includes when ice forms in the carburettor venturi
It can occur when the outside air temperature is between -10°C and +30°C and with a high relative humidity
learning.explanation: Aircraft icing can be divided into two general types based on whether it affects power production or aerodynamics. Induction icing affects engine power and includes when ice forms in the carburettor venturi. It can occur when the outside air temperature is between -10°C and +30°C and with a high relative humidity. Carburettor icing is particularly common, as the air cools down significantly inside the carburettor, not only due to the decreased static pressure in the venturi section (decreasing the temperature adiabatically) but also the evaporation of the fuel inside the carburettor, which requires latent heat input, thereby cooling the air. It is worse when the throttle is low, thereby causing the throttle butterfly valve to have only a small opening, further increasing the venturi effect. As you can see by the graph above, the worst icing happens between about -1°C and +15°C, which shows that the second item is not correct. Fuel injection systems provide uniform and reliable fuel delivery, better icing protection, and quicker throttle response. They work on the principle of feeding fuel under pressure to the engine, therefore they don’t need a venturi in the air intake. Without any ducts that inevitably reduce the temperature by their nature, the fuel injection systems are less prone to air intake icing than the traditional carburetor fuel systems. However, icing still may occur due to precipitation that enters from the external environment and contaminates the ducts. Induction systems are prone to icing in the event of heavy precipitation during winter operations, as snow or freezing rain hitting the filters can block the induction system. The first item is not correct as well.

content.question: A turbocharger in a reciprocating engine consists of a…

options.A: compressor and turbine on individual shafts.
options.B: turbine driving a compressor via a reduction gear.
options.C: compressor driving a turbine via a reduction gear.
options.D: compressor and turbine mounted on a common shaft.

key_points: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude
The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor
The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller
learning.explanation: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude. The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor. The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller. That energy is nothing else than exhaust gases. The turbocharger consists of two exhaust gas inlets that receive and direct the exhaust gases towards the turbine wheel. The exhaust gases mechanically spin the turbine before leaving the system through an exhaust gas outlet. The turbine is connected through a solid common shaft to a compressor, and the rotating energy gained from the exhaust gases circulation will serve to drive the compressor. At the compressor’s end, there’s also an inlet that will receive and direct ambient air to the compressor’s impeller eye. The air will then leave the impeller almost at a tangent to the periphery and trade velocity for an increase in pressure and temperature. The boost air under pressure obtained from this process will then be ducted to mix with the fuel and follow its path towards combustion. The pressure of the compressed air (boost) can be monitored only on the cockpit MAP gauge.

content.question: When the pilot moves the mixture lever of a piston engine towards a leaner position the…

options.A: amount of fuel entering the cylinders is increased.
options.B: amount of fuel entering the cylinders is reduced.
options.C: volume of air entering the carburettor is increased.
options.D: volume of air entering the carburettor is reduced.

key_points: The mixture is controlled by the mixture control lever (red) situated just next to the throttle and condition lever
It is directly linked to the carburetor via a cable
The cable is being pushed or pulled against a needle that operates like a floodgate to adjust the fuel flow being delivered to the cylinders at any throttle setting
learning.explanation: The mixture is controlled by the mixture control lever (red) situated just next to the throttle and condition lever. It is directly linked to the carburetor via a cable. The cable is being pushed or pulled against a needle that operates like a floodgate to adjust the fuel flow being delivered to the cylinders at any throttle setting. When the lever is pushed backward (towards a leaner position), the needle is lowered into the fuel line opening and less fuel is delivered => the mixture is leaned, and vice-versa.

content.question: When applying carburettor heating…

options.A: the mixture becomes richer.
options.B: the mixture becomes leaner.
options.C: no change occurs in the mixture.
options.D: RPM increases immediately.

key_points: When applying the carburettor heating hot air is supplied to the engine
Hot, less dense air will reduce the engine’s power output by roughly 15% and will create a richer mixture
Because the risk of detonation is much higher at high power settings, carburettor heating shouldn’t be selected at power settings greater than 80%
learning.explanation: When applying the carburettor heating hot air is supplied to the engine. Hot, less dense air will reduce the engine’s power output by roughly 15% and will create a richer mixture. Because the risk of detonation is much higher at high power settings, carburettor heating shouldn’t be selected at power settings greater than 80%. It should be used for a sufficient period of time to restore engine’s original RPM, only when icing conditions are observed along with an unexpected drop in RPM. Bear in mind that when applying the carb’ heat the RPM will initially drop and then increase again provided the accumulated ice has been successfully removed.

content.question: Consider a piston-engine aircraft with a constant speed propeller. Upon reaching cruising altitude when less power is required, engine power is…

options.A: reduced by lowering the manifold pressure and increasing the blade angle, to decrease RPM.
options.B: reduced by lowering the manifold pressure while RPM and blade angle are maintained.
options.C: reduced by lowering the manifold pressure and decreasing the blade angle, to decrease RPM.
options.D: maintained but the blade angle is decreased, to decrease RPM.

key_points: The throttle controls the power output of the engine which is registered on the manifold pressure
The propeller control regulates the engine RPM and, in turn, the propeller RPM
- During take-off - when the forward motion of the airplane is at low speeds and when maximum power and thrust are required, the constant-speed propeller sets up a low propeller angle (pitch)
learning.explanation: The throttle controls the power output of the engine which is registered on the manifold pressure. The propeller control regulates the engine RPM and, in turn, the propeller RPM. - During take-off - when the forward motion of the airplane is at low speeds and when maximum power and thrust are required, the constant-speed propeller sets up a low propeller angle (pitch). The low blade angle keeps the angle of attack, with respect to the relative wind small and efficient at the low speed. At the same time, it allows the propeller to "slice it thin" and handle a smaller mass of air per revolution. This light load allows the engine to turn at maximum rpm and develop maximum power. Although the mass of air per revolution is small, the number of revolutions per minute is high. - As the airspeed increases after lift-off, the load on the engine is lightened because of the small blade angle. The governor senses this and increases the blade angle slightly. Again => higher blade angle + higher speeds => keeps the angle of attack with respect to the relative wind small and efficient. - For climb (after take-off), the power output of the engine is reduced to climb power => by decreasing the manifold pressure (pretty straight forward) and lowering RPM by increasing the blade angle. (the angle of attack is kept small by increasing the blade angle with an increase in airspeed) - At cruising altitude, when the aeroplane is in level flight => less power is required to produce a higher airspeed than is used in climb. Consequently, engine power is again reduced by lowering the manifold pressure and increasing the blade angle (to decrease RPM). The higher airspeed and higher blade angle enable the propeller to handle a greater mass of air per second at still smaller slipstream velocity.

content.question: The magneto in a piston engine ignition system is switched off by…

options.A: opening the primary circuit and grounding the secondary circuit.
options.B: grounding both the primary and secondary circuits.
options.C: opening both the primary and secondary circuits.
options.D: grounding the primary circuit and opening the secondary circuit.

key_points: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs
This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke
Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch
learning.explanation: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs. This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke. Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch. The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth. In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded. In this condition, it is said to be ‘grounded’. However, if the grounding wire is broken, the magneto will keep working normally and the engine will continue running. Another situation where the engine can keep running is when an excessive carbon deposit has formed in the cylinder head. Because the deposit is still hot enough when you arrive at your parking position after the flight in order to ignite the charge without the spark from the plugs. The effect will be a hardly rumbling engine that is still running. Note: If the primary circuit is grounded, it will automatically ground the secondary circuit as well.

Excessive priming
The use of high-octane fuels in engines not necessarily designed or modified to take advantage of the higher-grade gasoline
learning.explanation: Spark plugs fouling can occur for one of the following reasons: Prolonged time at very low power (idle) such as in descent. Excessive priming. The use of high-octane fuels in engines not necessarily designed or modified to take advantage of the higher-grade gasoline. Continuous climb with a mixture setting fully rich. One thing that could be done to avoid spark plugs and cylinders fouling is clearing the engine in flight at regular intervals by opening not less than intermediate power and altering the engine rpm from cruise setting to maximum several times. This will avoid the fouling problem and will ensure that full power will be available if required (in case of missed approach for example).

options.A: (1) high, (2) aft.
options.B: (1) high, (2) forward.
options.C: (1) low, (2) forward.
options.D: (1) low, (2) aft.

key_points: ALL the levers are full FORWARD during take-off and landing (in case of go-around)
Full forward propeller pitch control lever will provide a low pitch needed for these flight phases

In the same way, the propeller will be required to be in the fine pitch position (full forward) during engine start of a variable-pitch propeller, as doing the opposite would overload the starter motor
learning.explanation: ALL the levers are full FORWARD during take-off and landing (in case of go-around). Full forward propeller pitch control lever will provide a low pitch needed for these flight phases. In the same way, the propeller will be required to be in the fine pitch position (full forward) during engine start of a variable-pitch propeller, as doing the opposite would overload the starter motor. The 2 main types of propellers found in aviation reciprocating engines are the following: Fixed pitch propeller: which is the simplest type of propeller with no additional moving parts fitted to most light general aviation aircraft. The engine RPM, and so, the power generation is controlled by the throttle. The propeller’s pitch angle is fixed and designed to be efficient at the normal maximum cruising speed. Variable pitch propeller: designed to keep a set rpm throughout the entire flight range. The propeller controls the engine at this set rpm through a device called a Constant Speed Unit (CSU). Any variations in engine power output, which would normally produce a change in rpm, will be sensed by the CSU that will alter the propeller’s pitch angle to keep the rpm constant. To avoid an engine overboost the RPM will be increased before increasing the manifold pressure.

content.question: The safest method of priming a piston engine for starting is…

options.A: injection of fuel in the cylinder intake ports.
options.B: injection of fuel through spark plug holes.
options.C: by turning the propeller several times with the throttle wide open.
options.D: pumping the throttle.

key_points: The priming system consists of a priming pump that will deliver fuel to the induction manifold
Its whole purpose is to inject additional fuel in the cylinders intake ports to assist the engine start
In the absence of such a system, it is possible to deliver more fuel to the cylinders by pumping the throttle lever which will act on the accelerator pump and deliver more fuel
learning.explanation: The priming system consists of a priming pump that will deliver fuel to the induction manifold. Its whole purpose is to inject additional fuel in the cylinders intake ports to assist the engine start. In the absence of such a system, it is possible to deliver more fuel to the cylinders by pumping the throttle lever which will act on the accelerator pump and deliver more fuel. The priming pump will be fitted in parallel with the main fuel pump (which is either electric or mechanical) and will take fuel from the filter housing and channel it to the inlet manifold. The necessary amount of priming required will mainly depend on the ambient temperature and how long the engine hasn’t been running. Priming is mostly necessary for the first flight of the day and during cold weather after the engine has been off for a few hours (depending on the engine type). However, sometimes it is not even needed as the engine will perfectly start without priming. Over-priming a hot engine could lead to a buildup of excessive fuel inside the cylinders (flooding), potentially increasing the risk of engine fire, flooding the engine, and fouling the spark plugs.

learning.explanation: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) FADEC is an electronic system that controls an engine, allowing easy usage by the pilot, relieving workload and providing the most efficient power settings through single lever operation. It allows many hundreds of sensor inputs to be fed to the central computer, an EEC (electronic engine controller) or ECU (engine control unit), which then calculates the best outputs for performance and efficiency, and can automatically make such inputs. It has control over every available part of the engine, from fuel-air mixture to ignition timing and even the propeller controller for variable pitch propellers. Ignition timing is the point in the 4 stroke engine cycle where the air/fuel mixture is ignited, and as RPM increases, the ignition timing should get earlier in the cycle to provide the best efficiency. In a diesel engine, this is the point where the fuel is injected, as it immediately ignites. The advantages of FADEC on piston engines include: Reduced weight Optimum efficiency No possibility of exceeding engine limitations Easy engine diagnostics There are also disadvantages to FADEC, which include: High complexity 2 ECUs are required to avoid a single point of failure No ability to gain excess power out of the engine in a crisis (e.g. terrain escape) Complete electrical failure means an engine failure (or uncontrollable engines) This question is on the topic of piston engine FADEC, which is currently used in a few light aircraft, such as the DA40, DA42, etc., but FADEC has been used for many years on turbine engines, and modern turbine engines are almost exclusively FADEC these days.

learning.explanation: The air to fuel ratio that ensures complete combustion is about 15:1 by mass. It is called the chemically correct ratio or the theoretical best economy. In reality, this mixture is not the best suited for normal operations because of the high combustion temperature-induced and the increased risk of detonation. This is why the best is to set the mixture about 10% richer so that the excessive fuel absorbs some of the latent heat and cools the charge below the detonation value.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.03: Describe a wet-sump lubrication system. There are two main types of oil systems for engines, dry-sump and wet-sump. The biggest difference between the two is where the oil is stored when not in use. In a dry-sump system, the used oil is pumped from the bottom of the engine to the oil reservoir. In a wet-sump system, the oil is stored in the "sump", which is just the area at the bottom of the engine, where the oil naturally drains to. For this question then, that means that a pressure pump is still required (to take the oil out of the sump and spray it into the correct engine locations) as well as the internal sump as it is both a sump and the oil reservoir, integrated into the engine block. The external sump and scavenge pump are therefore not required (they are dry sump items).

The working principle of the gas turbine engine is comparable to that of a piston engine as both engines use a cycle made of induction, compression, combustion, and exhaust phases. The only difference is the way these phases will be achieved as the gas turbine engine is capable of dealing with much larger amounts of energy for a given size and weight.
