content.question: Which of the following factors contribute to the process of combustion within a piston engine?

options.A: Spark plug temperature and oil viscosity.
options.B: Atmospheric pressure and carburettor compression.
options.C: Atmospheric pressure and pressure within the cylinder.
options.D: Fuel viscosity and exhaust gas temperature.

key_points: A piston engine operates using a cycle of induction, compression, combustion and exhaust
In the induction stroke, the fresh, unburnt air/fuel mixture enters the cylinder (is pulled in by the retreating piston)
In the compression stroke, all valves are closed and the air/fuel mixture is compressed by the advancing piston
learning.explanation: A piston engine operates using a cycle of induction, compression, combustion and exhaust. In the induction stroke, the fresh, unburnt air/fuel mixture enters the cylinder (is pulled in by the retreating piston). In the compression stroke, all valves are closed and the air/fuel mixture is compressed by the advancing piston. The combustion stroke is where the mixture is set alight by the spark plug, and the pressure generated by this combustion provides the power to push the piston downwards. The final stroke of a 4-stroke engine's "Otto cycle" is the exhaust stroke, where the piston advances one again and the burnt exhaust gasses are forced out through the exhaust valve. The combustion occurs at a higher pressure than the atmospheric pressure, as the air/fuel mixture is compressed by the piston just before ignition. The amount of compression is known as the compression ratio (around 10:1 for petrol engines and around 20:1 for diesel engines), and this is a very important figure that dictates the combustion that occurs in the cylinder. The amount of fuel/air misture that is burnt in each cylinder can be increased also by various types of supercharger, which further increase the pressure above the atmospheric pressure, thereby increasing the power transfer of the combustion. Let's go through the options: "Spark plug temperature and oil viscosity." Spark plugs provide a spark using an electrical arc, which by its very nature is hot enough to ignite the air fuel mixture. Oil should not be part of the combustion (and if it is, that is quite bad), so its viscosity isn't important to the combustion. "Atmospheric pressure and carburettor compression." The atmospheric pressure affects the combustion, yes, but the carburettor simply mixes air and fuel and meters a certain amount of it to the engine, it doesn't compress anything. "Atmospheric pressure and pressure within the cylinder." This is correct, as explained above, these pressures massively affect the combustion within the engine. "Fuel viscosity and exhaust gas temperature." Fuel should be vapourised by this point so viscosity makes little difference. Exhaust gas temperature is an output, and doesn't affect the input or the pressures themselves.

key_points: The reciprocating engine consists basically of a cylinder that is closed at one end, a piston that slides up and down inside the cylinder, and a connecting rod and crank by which reciprocating movement at the piston is converted to rotary movement of the crankshaft
In the closed end of the cylinder, known as the 'Cylinder Head', are inlet and exhaust valves and a sparking plug

content.question: An EGT (Exhaust Gas Temperature) indicator for a piston engine is used to…

options.A: control the fuel temperature.
options.B: control the carburettor inlet airflow.
options.C: control the cylinder head temperature.
options.D: assist the pilot to set the correct mixture.

key_points: Besides being one of the most relevant indicators to monitor the engine’s proper operation, the EGT also assists the pilot in adjusting the correct mixture
Let’s assume you have just arrived at your planned cruising level and you’re ready to lean your engine
Because you were climbing, your mixture was full rich, which was providing extra cooling to the cylinders
learning.explanation: Besides being one of the most relevant indicators to monitor the engine’s proper operation, the EGT also assists the pilot in adjusting the correct mixture. Let’s assume you have just arrived at your planned cruising level and you’re ready to lean your engine. Because you were climbing, your mixture was full rich, which was providing extra cooling to the cylinders. Now that you reached a higher level where the air density is much lower, you need to lean the mixture in order to achieve the perfect fuel/air ratio and achieve a better engine performance. You will therefore start to pull back (lean) the mixture control lever (red). Because you started to deliver less fuel to the cylinders, they will receive less cooling and the EGT will start to rise. The maximum EGT of a piston engine is theoretically associated with a fuel (mass) to air ratio of 1:15. As you will continue leaning, you will start noticing some roughness in the engine’s operation: the engine has been starved of fuel just enough to produce peak power, so the RPM will start dropping. Since the power produced is not enough, the EGT will also start to drop. If the mixture is enriched again by advancing the red lever, the power will surge again, and you will see an increase in RPM and you will reach an EGT that is lower to the peak you’ve found in step (2) and corresponds to the best power production mixture. It will also provide you a small surplus of fuel for cooling and safety buffer.

content.question: The air in a piston engine turbocharger enters the centrifugal compressor at…

options.A: a tangent to the rotor and leaves via the stator.
options.B: the diffuser and is fed to the impeller at the optimum angle of attack.
options.C: the periphery and leaves via the eye of the impeller.
options.D: the eye of the impeller and leaves it almost at a tangent to the periphery.

key_points: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude
The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor
The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller
learning.explanation: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude. The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor. The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller. That energy is nothing else than the exhaust gases. The turbocharger consists of two exhaust gas inlets that receive and direct the exhaust gases towards the turbine wheel. The exhaust gases mechanically spin the turbine before leaving the system through an exhaust gas outlet. The turbine is connected through a solid common shaft to a compressor, and the rotating energy gained from the exhaust gases circulation will serve to drive the compressor. At the compressor’s end, there’s also an inlet that will receive and direct ambient air to the compressor’s impeller eye. The air will then leave the impeller almost at a tangent to the periphery and trade velocity for an increase in pressure and temperature. The boost air under pressure obtained from this process will then be ducted to mix with the fuel and follow its path towards combustion. The pressure of the compressed air (boost) can be monitored only on the cockpit MAP gauge.

content.question: The thermal efficiency of a diesel engine is higher than that of a petrol engine because…

options.A: the EGT is higher.
options.B: the compression ratio is much higher.

key_points: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture
For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs

The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder
learning.explanation: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture. For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs. The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder. The fuel injection system consists of atomizers that will spray the fuel into the pre-chamber, but because not all the fuel droplets burn completely, residual soot will remain in the cylinder. To produce enough heat for the mixture to ignite, the diesel engines operate at a much higher compression ratios than the normal petrol engine: from 14:1 up to 28:1 for the most powerful compared to 9:1 for a petrol engine. Because of this high compression ratio, diesel engines also benefit from a higher thermal efficiency. The amount of power delivered will only be determined by the fuel flow. In the same way as for car engines, diesel engines are less powerful than a petrol engine for the same swept volume.

content.question: In a 4-stroke normally aspirated piston engine at altitude, which of the following causes the air-fuel mixture to enter the cylinders?

options.A: The difference between ambient pressure and pressure inside the cylinder.
options.B: The difference between ambient pressure and exhaust back pressure.
options.C: Compression from devices upstream of the carburettor.
options.D: Compression from devices downstream of the carburettor.

key_points: The intake process of a piston engine 4-stroke cycle happens because the piston is in the process of going down inside the cylinder, which increases the volume of the cylinder and thereby decreases the pressure
As the intake valve is open, it allows the air/fuel mixture in the intake manifold to flow into the cylinder
Normally aspirated engines do not have any superchargers fitted
learning.explanation: The intake process of a piston engine 4-stroke cycle happens because the piston is in the process of going down inside the cylinder, which increases the volume of the cylinder and thereby decreases the pressure. As the intake valve is open, it allows the air/fuel mixture in the intake manifold to flow into the cylinder. Normally aspirated engines do not have any superchargers fitted. A supercharger is a device after the air intake (but before the carburettor) that compresses the intake air, increasing the manifold air pressure to allow an increased density of fuel/air mixture to enter the cylinders. It is particularly important for aircraft as they fly at high altitudes where the air density is low, causing a low engine power, as there is less air/fuel to burn. A turbocharger is a special type of supercharger that uses exhaust gas to power the compressor. To answer this question then, the force which causes the air/fuel mixture to enter the cylinders in a normally aspirated engine is simply the pressure difference between ambient pressure (manifold pressure) and the pressure in the cylinder, which is decreasing throughout the intake stroke. At altitude, the ambient pressure is lower than at sea level, so there is less of a pressure differential, and lower mass flow into the cylinder, but the system of air intake is the same.

learning.explanation: A variable pitch propeller is designed to keep a set rpm throughout the entire flight range. The propeller controls the engine at this set rpm through a device called a Constant Speed Unit (CSU). Any variations in engine power output or the TAS, which would normally produce a change in rpm, will be sensed by the CSU that will alter the propeller’s pitch (=blade) angle through the Pitch Change Mechanism to keep the rpm constant. For instance, an increase in TAS means that more forward air will hit the propeller, so as a consequence, the blade angle will increase so that it moves a bigger chunk of air without altering the rpm.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.04: State the differences between a wet- and a dry-sump lubrication system and their advantages and disadvantages. A dry sump engine is one where the oil is not allowed to sit in the engine sump for too long, and is instead "scavenged" back to a separate reservoir. This is the opposite of a "wet sump" engine, where the sump (within the engine casing) is the reservoir, and a lot less systems are required, but with reduced engine power due to energy losses, and inability to perform many aerobatic manoeuvres. With a dry sump engine, the oil enters from the "external" reservoir, where it is stored when not at work in the engine, via a pressure pump, getting it up to a suitable pressure to spray inside the engine. The oil then lubricates, cools and cleans the engine components, finally ending up at the bottom of the engine, where it gathers in the sump, and is collected up by a scavenge pump, which returns it to the reservoir. The oil is often quite aerated and foamy by this point, so is less dense, and the scavenge pump needs a larger volume to cope with this oil, and not let it mount up in the sump. In comparison to the wet sump system, dry sump oil systems have: Better control of cooling, as the oil does not have to stay sat in the bottom of the hot engine; The ability to perform aerobatics and keep the engine correctly oiled; Less oil oxidation and contamination; Higher capacity for oil, as it limited by the external reservoir, which can be made larger than the engine sump.

The pressure will drop proportionally to the mass airflow and is used to make fuel flow from the float chamber by placing a ‘U’-shaped jet into the Venturi

As the air passes through the convergence of the Venturi duct, its velocity increases causing a drop in pressure and temperature. The pressure will drop proportionally to the mass airflow and is used to make fuel flow from the float chamber by placing a ‘U’-shaped jet into the Venturi. Engine suction creates a difference in air pressure at the throat of the Venturi duct and the air inlet resulting in a sucking effect. Besides the drop in pressure and temperature at the Venturi’s throat, the latter will increase again within the induction manifold as the throttle is opened.

learning.explanation: When ice is building up in the carburetor the venturi duct is narrowing and increases the effects of the venturi tube (further decrease in pressure and temperature). The dynamic pressure flowing through the tube increases the ice build-up as the venturi-shaped icy duct sees a decrease in temperature and static pressure. This is also the reason why the first indication of ice build-up is going to be a decrease in manifold pressure (=static pressure). Therefore, as soon as the carburetor heating is turned on, the ice buildup will melt, and the duct will be an increase in static pressure (=manifold pressure).

content.question: What could be said about exhaust back pressure when using a supercharged (but not turbocharged) engine?

options.A: Exhaust back pressure is a result of increased humidity.
options.B: Increased exhaust back pressure at altitude improves scavenging.
options.C: Increased back pressure increases engine power slightly.
options.D: Exhaust back pressure reduces with altitude and increases engine power slightly.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.10: Explain the purpose of a supercharger and the basic differences from a turbocharger. Piston Engines can have their power increased in three main ways, by increasing the size of the engine (displacement), increasing the RPM, or increasing the pressure of the air/fuel mixture (called the Manifold Absolute Pressure, MAP). This last case is why we might use a turbocharger in our car engines, so we can have a small, efficient engine, with extra power available from a turbocharger (which compresses the intake air) when needed. Turbochargers are arguably even more useful in aircraft, where piston engines become less powerful in the thinner air at higher altitudes. This is where turbochargers can compress that air, to make the engine operate with the same power output it would do at a much lower altitude. We call this an "altitude boosted" turbocharger. They are more useful to us by keeping the same power up to higher altitudes, rather than giving us lots more power on the ground, which would put a lot of strain on the engine, which would be a "ground boosted" turbocharger. In reality, a turbocharger is a particular type of supercharger. All superchargers compress the fresh intake air so more fuel/air mixture can be burnt in each power stroke, thereby making the engine more powerful (or allowing it to maintain its power to higher altitudes). Supercharger is technically the umbrella term that covers all such devices, but in reality, most people refer to power augmentation devices as follows. Supercharger: An engine driven compressor which allows an increase in MAP. Turbocharger: A device where the excess heat and speed of the exhaust gasses drive a turbine which drives the compressor, allowing for increased MAP. There are various reasons for using each; superchargers do not suffer from turbo-lag, but do take power directly away from the crankshaft, whereas turbochargers are more efficient by taking energy away from the otherwise wasted exhaust gasses. In aircraft, turbochargers are far more widely used, but the learning objectives do ask us to understand the key differences between the two. Turbochargers do cause a small power loss that is not often talked about, and that is due to exhaust back pressure. Essentially, in an non-turbocharged engine, the exhaust gasses are allowed to flow freely from the cylinders during the exhaust stroke, but when a turbocharger is added (and the waste-gate is closed, meaning that all air goes through the turbine), there is some back pressure from the more restrictive flow through the turbine. This means that exhaust gasses are not removed as effectively, and the engine does lose out on a small amount of power. It is not a lot though, as the extra MAP means that the power increases massively for this small loss. On normally aspirated and supercharged (not turbo-) engines, though, the exhaust gasses are allowed to leave the engine without restriction, and technically, the higher we fly, the lower the ambient pressure, so the lower the exhaust back pressure. This is a very small gain of course, but it can make a difference, especially when a supercharger makes the engine perform like it is at a low altitude, but with even better exhaust gas removal.

content.question: The operating principle of magnetos in a piston engine ignition system consists of…

options.A: creating a brief high intensity magnetic field that will be sent through the distributor at the appropriate time.
options.B: obtaining a high amperage, low voltage current in order to generate the spark.
options.C: accumulating in a capacitor a low voltage current from the battery and inducing it as a high voltage current at the moment the spark is generated.
options.D: opening the primary circuit in order to induce a low amperage, high voltage current, which is distributed to the spark plugs.

key_points: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs
This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke

In order to break the gap between the sparking plug electrodes, the magnetos consist of a rotating permanent magnet surrounded by a U-shaped stator of soft iron, around which a thick primary and a thin secondary winding can be found
learning.explanation: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs. This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke. In order to break the gap between the sparking plug electrodes, the magnetos consist of a rotating permanent magnet surrounded by a U-shaped stator of soft iron, around which a thick primary and a thin secondary winding can be found. The thick winding (primary) is the low-tension element of the circuit and consists only of a few turns of thick wire. Whereas the thin winding (secondary) is the high-tension element of the circuit consisting of numerous thin windings that act as a step-up transformer. As a consequence of this arrangement, any electrical current in the primary circuit (thick winding) will induce a higher voltage in the secondary winding. Both windings will be supplied with alternating current from the permanent set of magnetos as they’re driven by the engine. Another important aspect you need to understand in the principle of magnetos operation is that the primary winding will be continuously broken and then restored by a contact breaker. The contact will be broken by a permanently rotating breaker cam which main task is to break the primary circuit. The reason why we need the primary circuit to get broken is because this will create a collapse in the primary’s winding magnetic field that will produce an increase in energy in the secondary winding. The second reason is that the normal AC produced in the primary winding will be converted into a series of pulses. The general outcome of this sequence of actions will result in a series of very high voltage, low current pulses of electricity that will be fed to a distributor. Distributor’s task will be then to spread these pulses through a high-tension leads to the spark-plugs.

content.question: Regarding a normally aspirated piston engine, which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Power output depends, amongst other things, on the mass of the mixture entering the cylinder.
options.B: Power available will increase with altitude.
options.C: High atmospheric humidity increases power.
options.D: Power available will increase with density altitude.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.01: Describe the effect on power output of a petrol and diesel engine taking into consideration the following parameters: ambient pressure, exhaust back pressure; temperature; density altitude; humidity. Piston Engines can have their power increased in three main ways, by increasing the size of the engine (displacement), increasing the RPM, or increasing the pressure of the air/fuel mixture (called the Manifold Absolute Pressure, MAP). This last case is why we might use a turbocharger in our car engines, so we can have a small, efficient engine, with extra power available from a turbocharger (which compresses the intake air) when needed. The more air (and therefore fuel/air mixture) we can get into each cylinder, the more intense the flame, producing a much stronger power stroke. A turbocharger (or any supercharger, really) would run a compressor to increase the pressure of the fresh intake air, so more fuel/air mixture can enter the cylinders and provide more power during each power stroke. When an engine does not have one of these, it is referred to as being "normally aspirated", or "naturally aspirated". This means that the MAP will only ever be as high as the ambient pressure outside, and the mass flow (and power) through the engine depends completely on the density of the ambient air. The higher the aircraft flies, the lower the air density becomes, which means that the lower mass flow through a normally aspirated engine will produce less power. This is the same in hot conditions and also in high atmospheric humidity, where air density is low, and maximum power output is therefore reduced.

content.question: Which of the following might be the cause of a higher than normal oil pressure indication?

options.A: Low oil temperature.
options.B: High oil temperature.
options.C: A leak in the oil lines.
options.D: Cowl flaps fully closed.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.06: Describe the interaction between oil pressure, oil temperature and oil quantity. Oil pressure is a very important indication to monitor during engine start and in-flight. High oil pressure may indicate a blockage in the system, whereas a low oil pressure would likely indicate a loss of oil through oil leak or damage, but may also indicate a pump failure. Oil temperature (another very important indication to monitor as a pilot) actually affects oil pressure quite a lot. On a cold morning, you will often find that the oil pressure rises higher than normal during engine start, and may stay that way for a couple of minutes whilst the oil warms up. This is because the oil starts at a temperature much colder than its usual operating temperature, and is much more viscous when cold (leading to slower fluid flow and higher pressure buildup). For this reason, some engines use thinner oils in winter to counteract the colder oil temperatures and avoid oil overpressure. As for the other options, high oil temperature is obviously the opposite of the correct answer, an oil leak would cause a small reduction, and eventual loss of oil pressure completely. Cowl flaps are more interesting: They are fitted to some aeroplanes to change how much airflow is available to cool the engine. With them closed, there is less airflow to cool the oil, so the oil will be warmer, and will not give a higher oil pressure indication.

learning.explanation: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) FADEC is an electronic system that controls an engine, allowing easy usage by the pilot, relieving workload and providing the most efficient power settings through single lever operation. That being said, the pilot still has a few engine controls on the flight deck. As well as the throttle/power lever to each engine, which digitally tells the FADEC computer what power setting is required from the engine, the pilot has a master switch for each engine, and often engine mode selectors are able to tell the engine which ECU to use, etc. In terms of levers, as mentioned, there is only a throttle/power lever present, as opposed to the throttle lever, prop control lever and the mixture lever of manually controlled aircraft, where these extra tasks are now completed by the computer. content.question: The pilot of a turbocharged MEP aircraft is climbing with Maximum Continuous Power set until reaching the cruising altitude of 10 000 ft. The pilot levels off and initially maintains power to accelerate to cruise speed. Which of the following actions are required to reduce fuel consumption?

options.A: Decrease power by reducing manifold pressure and decrease the propeller blade angle using the RPM lever.
options.B: Decrease power by reducing manifold pressure and increase the propeller blade angle using the RPM lever.
options.C: Decrease power by reducing manifold pressure and maintain constant RPM.
options.D: Maintain the same power and reduce the propeller RPM by increasing the blade angle.

key_points: Note: We have chosen the answer that fits the "generic" view that EASA take, as the question is a little vague

The answer has not been confirmed by feedback, and therefore we ask for any further exam feedback that anyone might have, thank you! When the pilot reaches the top of climb (especially when climbing at Max Continuous Power), they must reduce their power output and set the aircraft up for the cruise
This is usually done by bringing backwards both throttle and RPM levers (and sometimes the mixture lever also)
learning.explanation: Note: We have chosen the answer that fits the "generic" view that EASA take, as the question is a little vague. The answer has not been confirmed by feedback, and therefore we ask for any further exam feedback that anyone might have, thank you! When the pilot reaches the top of climb (especially when climbing at Max Continuous Power), they must reduce their power output and set the aircraft up for the cruise. This is usually done by bringing backwards both throttle and RPM levers (and sometimes the mixture lever also). Pilots who fly aircraft fitted with constant speed (variable pitch) propellers, will choose a power setting to fly at, which includes an RPM setting and a manifold pressure setting. When retarding the thrust from climb to cruise, the pilot will first reduce the MAP (manifold absolute pressure) by retarding the throttle, then reducing the RPM lever to the cruise setting after this (usually less than the climb RPM, primarily for the reason of better fuel economy at lower RPMs), then re-adjust the MAP if necessary. This order of operations avoids an overboost scenario. The answer to this question is therefore a decrease of both the MAP and RPM, and the RPM is decreased by increasing the blade angle of the propeller. The RPM is usually retarded more than the MAP is in this process (as this contributes to better fuel economy), so the increase in blade angle from reduced RPM outweighs the increased blade angle from decreased MAP, and the blade angle is increased overall.

content.question: Assuming incompressible flow, when considering streamlines in the vicinity of an aerofoil, which of the following answers is correct?

options.A: Converging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is increasing and that the static pressure is decreasing.
options.B: Diverging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is decreasing and that the static pressure is decreasing.
options.C: Diverging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is increasing and that the static pressure is increasing.
options.D: Converging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is decreasing and that the static pressure is increasing.

key_points: When considering streamlines, we can say that converging streamlines indicate an increasing airflow velocity, and diverging lines indicate a decreasing airflow velocity
Now when considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow
Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure
learning.explanation: When considering streamlines, we can say that converging streamlines indicate an increasing airflow velocity, and diverging lines indicate a decreasing airflow velocity. Now when considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow. Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure. Now what is the dynamic pressure and what is static pressure: Dynamic pressure is equal to: q = ½ rho V2. Therefore we can say that the dynamic pressure is proportional to the velocity of the airflow. Static pressure is the pressure that any object feels even when not moving. This pressure is caused by the force of gravity forcing particles closer together and pushing against each other and any objects around them. Knowing that dynamic pressure is basically the velocity of the airflow, we can say that if the velocity increase, hence increasing the dynamic pressure, there has to be a reduction in static pressure. This is known as Bernoulli’s principle! What this means for our question is that: Converging streamlines indicate a speed increase Diverging streamlines indicated a speed decrease A decrease in static pressure occurs with an increasing speed And an increase in static pressure occurs with a decreasing speed

content.question:
Excessive priming of a piston engine should be avoided because:
1. it drains the carburettor float chamber
2. the risk of engine fire
3. the risk of flooding the engine
4. it fouls the spark plugs
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The priming system consists of a priming pump that will deliver fuel to the inductn manifold
Its whole purpose is to inject additional fuel in the cylinders intake ports to assist the engine start
In the absence of such a system, it is possible to deliver more fuel to the cylinders by pumping the throttle lever which will act on the accelerator pump and deliver more fuel
learning.explanation: The priming system consists of a priming pump that will deliver fuel to the inductn manifold. Its whole purpose is to inject additional fuel in the cylinders intake ports to assist the engine start. In the absence of such a system, it is possible to deliver more fuel to the cylinders by pumping the throttle lever which will act on the accelerator pump and deliver more fuel. The priming pump will be fitted in parallel with the main fuel pump (which is either electric or mechanical) and will take fuel from the filter housing and channel it to the inlet manifold. The necessary amount of priming required will mainly depend on the ambient temperature and how long the engine hasn’t been running. Priming is mostly necessary for the first flight of the day and during cold weather after the engine has been off for a few hours (depending on the engine type). However, sometimes it is not even needed as the engine will perfectly start without priming. Over-priming a hot engine could lead to a buildup of excessive fuel inside the cylinders (flooding), potentially increasing the risk of engine fire, flooding the engine, and fouling the spark plugs.

content.question: Which one of the following situations might cause a higher-than-normal oil pressure indication?

key_points: The oil pressure is measured downstream (at the outlet) of the engine-driven pump
The main reason being that you want to be sure that the pressure at the pump’s output is enough to properly lubricate the engine parts
The pressure of a standard oil pump fitted in a reciprocating engine’s lubrication system is between 50-100 psi, however, this will depend on the size and loading of the engine itself
learning.explanation: The oil pressure is measured downstream (at the outlet) of the engine-driven pump. The main reason being that you want to be sure that the pressure at the pump’s output is enough to properly lubricate the engine parts. The pressure of a standard oil pump fitted in a reciprocating engine’s lubrication system is between 50-100 psi, however, this will depend on the size and loading of the engine itself. The pump is delivering the oil at a slightly higher than needed pressure in order to ensure that there’s always enough pressure delivered to the engine irrespective of the engine speed. The extra pressure is dumped via a pressure relief valve. Therefore, a higher-than-normal oil pressure indication will be displayed on the gauge if one of these pressure relief valves gets stuck and cannot properly regulate the oil pressure.

content.question: After start of a piston engine, correct operation of the pitch adjustment system of a constant speed propeller can be confirmed by altering the propeller control lever and checking indications on the…

options.A: manifold pressure gauge.
options.B: engine oil pressure indicator.
options.C: exhaust gas temperature gauge.
options.D: tachometer.

key_points: The question is basically asking you how to check the proper operation of the pitch adjustment system (i
e
the CSU) of your variable pitch propeller just after engine start up
learning.explanation: The question is basically asking you how to check the proper operation of the pitch adjustment system (i.e. the CSU) of your variable pitch propeller just after engine start up. The engine is started with the condition lever (blue) in the low pitch-high RPM position in order to reduce the load on the propeller and facilitate the starting sequence and warm-up. While the engine warm-up, the constant speed unit of the propeller should be operated carefully and smoothly through its whole range to determine whether the system is working properly and as expected. It is also the right moment to distribute some warm oil through the CSU’s governor and warm it up before take-off. In a constant speed propeller piston engine, you will find 3 levers in the cockpit: the throttle lever, the condition lever, and the mixture control lever. The throttle lever controls the power output of the engine and is monitored on the MAP gauge (in inches of mercury). The mixture control lever varies the fuel flow and corrects for variations in the fuel/air ratio. Finally, the condition lever will control the pitch of the propeller to increase its efficiency and will be monitored on the tachometer as the RPM will change. Therefore, the pitch adjustment mechanism of the propeller will be checked by moving the blue lever to high pitch – low RPM, and then by moving it back to a low pitch setting, ready for take-off. All the RPM variations during this testing sequence will be monitored on the tachometer.

A high-performance supercharger may require an intercooler to be placed between the supercharger and the inlet valve (manifold) because of the high temperatures at which the supercharger brings the compressed air
The higher the temperatures inside the engine, the bigger the risk of detonation
learning.explanation: The purpose of an intercooler is to minimize the risk of detonation. A high-performance supercharger may require an intercooler to be placed between the supercharger and the inlet valve (manifold) because of the high temperatures at which the supercharger brings the compressed air. The higher the temperatures inside the engine, the bigger the risk of detonation. Therefore, the intercooler will cool the air compressed by the supercharger and minimize the risk of detonation while increasing the density of the air supplied to the cylinders.

content.question: A piston engine has failed to stop with the magneto switch in the OFF position, what may have caused this?

options.A: Excessive carbon build-ups in the cylinder head.
options.B: A defective condenser.
options.C: Fouled spark plugs.
options.D: A fully grounded switch wire.

key_points: Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch
The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth
In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded
learning.explanation: Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch. The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth. In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded. However, if the grounding wire is broken for instance, the magneto will keep working normally and the engine will continue running. Another situation where the engine can keep running is when an excessive carbon deposit has formed in the cylinder head. This is because the deposit is still hot enough when you arrive at your parking position after the flight in order to ignite the charge without the spark from the plugs. The effect will be a rough, rumbling engine that is still running. If this ever happens and the engine doesn’t stop, you can simply pull back the mixture control lever (red) and shut off the fuel supply (many aircraft engines are normally shutoff by removing the fuel supply anyway). Caution! Maintenance action should be sought before approaching the propeller since the engine can start at any time with these conditions. As for the other options: A grounded switch wire in the magneto primary circuit will turn the magnetos off, so that is not a cause of the engine continuing to run. Fouled spark plugs are more likely to stop a running engine, and are unlikely to continue running an engine that has been switched off. A defective condenser will most likely make the engine run rough or stop in normal operations.

This should suck the flames back through the carburetor and extinguish the blaze, and if the engine starts, let it run for a minute or so, then shut it down and inspect the damage

This should suck the flames back through the carburetor and extinguish the blaze, and if the engine starts, let it run for a minute or so, then shut it down and inspect the damage. It is a system designed to take the task of managing engine parameters away from the pilot and have a computer do the job instead

learning.explanation: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) FADEC is an electronic system that controls an engine, allowing easy usage by the pilot, relieving workload and providing most efficient power settings through single lever operation. It is a system designed to take the task of managing engine parameters away from the pilot and have a computer do the job instead. This has many advantages, such as weight saving and "care free" handling of the engine, as well as increased efficiency and reduced chance of overspeed/overtorque. They do have some disadvantages, in the fact that a FADEC failure can fail the whole engine, and a full electrical failure would have the same effect. These disadvantages can be reduced by creating redundancy within the system. The main source of redundancy is that each engine is fitted with 2 seperate FADEC systems, that can either operate the engine perfectly well. Each is usually fed by a seperate electrical system as well, with backup batteries, reducing the chance of total failure.

content.question:
Which of the following statements regarding turbochargers is correct/incorrect?
1. The waste gate continuously closes with increasing altitude to increase turbocharger boost. Once fully closed, the maximum boost is delivered
2. The exhaust gas stream drives a radial turbine, which is connected to a centrifugal compressor; air enters the compressor, the exhaust drives turbine

options.A: 1 is correct; 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is correct; 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is incorrect; 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is incorrect; 2 is correct.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.04: Describe the function and the principle of operation of the following main components of a turbocharger: turbine; compressor; waste gate; waste-gate actuator. Turbocharger compresses the intake air when needed. Turbochargers are very useful in aircraft, where piston engines become less powerful in the thinner air at higher altitudes. This is where turbochargers can compress that air, to make the engine operate with the same power output it would do at a much lower altitude. They are more useful to us by keeping the same power up to higher altitudes, rather than giving us lots more power on the ground, which puts a lot of strain on the engine. A turbocharger works by using the speed and pressure of the exhaust gasses to spin a turbine, which then uses that energy to spin the compressor, which compresses the fresh intake air ready for entry into the cylinders. We cannot allow the turbocharger to run wild though, as too much pressure (MAP) can cause the engine to "overboost", and even fail quite spectacularly. The way we regulate the turbocharger is by varying how much air gets to the turbine, this is via a wastegate system. the exhaust gasses can go down two different tubes, one is a standard exhaust, straight out of the aircraft (bypassing the turbine). The other is a tube to the turbine, to spin up the turbocharger. The wastegate is a butterfly valve that can block the exhaust tube, so when it is closed, all the exhaust gasses go to the turbine, making the compressor/turbine spin fastest. As altitude rises, the waste gate gradually closes to enhance turbocharger boost. When fully closed, the turbocharger delivers maximum boost at the critical altitude.

content.question: You are flying a multi-engine propeller aircraft. During the cruise, the critical engine fails. Which configuration creates the most stress on the rudder?

options.A: Aft CG, skid toward the critical engine.
options.B: Aft CG, skid away from the critical engine.
options.C: Fwd CG, skid toward the critical engine.
options.D: Fwd CG, skid away from the critical engine.

key_points: CRITICAL ENGINE One of the factors influencing the yawing moment following engine failure on a multi-engine aircraft is the length of the thrust arm (distance from the CG to the thrust line of the operating engine)
In the case of a propeller engine aircraft the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller
At a positive angle of attack, the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller, when viewed from the rear, is displaced to the right of the engine centre line
learning.explanation: CRITICAL ENGINE One of the factors influencing the yawing moment following engine failure on a multi-engine aircraft is the length of the thrust arm (distance from the CG to the thrust line of the operating engine). In the case of a propeller engine aircraft the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller. At a positive angle of attack, the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller, when viewed from the rear, is displaced to the right of the engine centre line. This is because the down-going blade generates more thrust than the up-going blade. If both engines rotate clockwise, the starboard (right) engine will have a longer thrust arm than the port (left) engine. The critical engine is the engine, the failure of which would give the biggest yawing moment. If the left engine fails, the thrust of the right engine acts through a longer thrust arm and will give a bigger yawing moment; a higher IAS (VMC) would be necessary to maintain directional control. At a given IAS, the situation would be more critical if the left engine failed. The rudder is used to prevent yaw, and the wings are maintained level with aileron. The fore and aft CG location has no effect on the yawing moment from a failed engine, but will influence the rudder arm, hence the rudder moment. CG on the aft limit will give the smallest rudder arm and the least ability to oppose the yawing moment from a failed engine. Video Explanation:

content.question: A piston engine`s compression ratio is the ratio of…

options.A: piston travel during the compression stroke to travel during the intake stroke.
options.B: the cylinder volume with the piston at bottom dead centre to the cylinder volume at top dead centre.
options.C: the fuel to air mixture in the combustion chamber.
options.D: degrees of crankshaft rotation of compression stroke to power stroke.

key_points: The compression ratio is the ratio of the largest volume (total volume) to the smallest volume (clearance volume)
When the piston is at TDC, the fuel/air mixture is compressed into a very small space between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder
This is generally labeled as the clearance volume, or to put it simply, the smallest volume
learning.explanation: The compression ratio is the ratio of the largest volume (total volume) to the smallest volume (clearance volume). When the piston is at TDC, the fuel/air mixture is compressed into a very small space between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder. This is generally labeled as the clearance volume, or to put it simply, the smallest volume. On the other hand, when the piston is at the BDC, the volume of space containing the mixture (the total volume) is much larger. The difference between the total volume and the clearance volume is called the swept volume.

content.question: The kind of compressor normally used in a piston engine as a turbocharger is…

options.A: a hybrid compressor.
options.B: an axial compressor.
options.C: a piston compressor.
options.D: a centrifugal compressor.

key_points: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude
The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor
The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller
learning.explanation: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude. The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor. The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller. That energy is nothing else than exhaust gases. The turbocharger consists of two exhaust gas inlets that receive and direct the exhaust gases towards the turbine wheel. The exhaust gases mechanically spin the turbine before leaving the system through an exhaust gas outlet. The turbine is connected through a solid common shaft to a compressor, and the rotating energy gained from the exhaust gases circulation will serve to drive the compressor. At the compressor’s end, there’s also an inlet that will receive and direct ambient air to the compressor’s impeller eye. The air will then leave the impeller almost at a tangent to the periphery and trade velocity for an increase in pressure and temperature. The boost air under pressure obtained from this process will then be ducted to mix with the fuel and follow its path towards combustion. The pressure of the compressed air (boost) can be monitored only on the cockpit MAP gauge.

To prevent vapor locking and cavitation, a low-pressure pump is fitted to the feed line and will supply fuel from the tanks at suitable pressure and flow

Under certain circumstances when the engine is very hot, vapor lock can also occur in the injector lines and prevent the fuel from being correctly delivered to the cylinders. The maximum RPM is achieved when the wastegate valve is closed
The wastegate valve controls the amount of exhaust gases that bypass the turbine, by diverting some of the exhaust gases away from the turbine
learning.explanation: The wastegate of a turbocharger is typically located in the turbine housing. The maximum RPM is achieved when the wastegate valve is closed. The wastegate valve controls the amount of exhaust gases that bypass the turbine, by diverting some of the exhaust gases away from the turbine. When the valve is closed, the turbine is able to spin at a higher RPM, allowing the compressor to produce more boost pressure and increase engine power. When the valve is open, the exhaust gas is bypassed, which reduces the turbine's RPM, and the compressor produces less boost pressure and engine power is reduced.

content.question: What is the recommended step to take in case you experience detonation during take-off?

options.A: Partially close the cowling flap.
options.B: Increase rate of climb.
options.C: Lean the mixture.
options.D: Reduce throttle.

key_points: Detonation occurs when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that they ignite spontaneously at an earlier stage than they should do during the power stroke
In fact, the rate of pressure rise will sometimes occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to be forced downwards
Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat
learning.explanation: Detonation occurs when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that they ignite spontaneously at an earlier stage than they should do during the power stroke. In fact, the rate of pressure rise will sometimes occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to be forced downwards. Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat. The cylinder walls, the piston head, the sparking plugs, and the exhaust valves are put under a sudden "shock load" when detonation occurs, and this will sound like a knocking inside the engine. Detonation puts an engine under intense shock loading which can quite quickly cause engine failures. The conditions in which detonation is most likely in a piston engine are a high manifold pressure, high cylinder head temperature and low RPM. if you ever experience detonation during flight, the following corrective action should be carried: Reduce the manifold pressure (the action is to retard the throttle) Fully enrich the mixture.

content.question: The ignition system of a running piston engine receives electrical energy from…

options.A: capacitors.
options.B: rotating permanent magnets.
options.C: batteries.
options.D: generators.

key_points: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs
This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke

In order to break the gap between the sparking plug electrodes, the magnetos consist of a rotating permanent magnet surrounded by a U-shaped stator of soft iron, around which a thick primary and a thin secondary winding can be found
learning.explanation: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs. This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke. In order to break the gap between the sparking plug electrodes, the magnetos consist of a rotating permanent magnet surrounded by a U-shaped stator of soft iron, around which a thick primary and a thin secondary winding can be found. The thick winding (primary) is the low-tension element of the circuit and consists only of a few turns of thick wire. Whereas the thin winding (secondary) is the high-tension element of the circuit consisting of numerous thin windings that act as a step-up transformer. As a consequence of this arrangement, any electrical current in the primary circuit (thick winding) will induce a higher voltage in the secondary winding. Both windings will be supplied with alternating current from the permanent set of magnetos as they’re driven by the engine. Another important aspect you need to understand in the principle of magnetos operation is that the primary winding will be continuously broken and then restored by a contact breaker. The contact will be broken by a permanently rotating breaker cam whose main task is to break the primary circuit. The reason why we need the primary circuit to get broken is that this will create a collapse in the primary’s winding magnetic field that will produce an increase in energy in the secondary winding. The second reason is that the normal AC produced in the primary winding will be converted into a series of pulses. The general outcome of this sequence of actions will result in a series of very high voltage, low current pulses of electricity that will be fed to a distributor. The distributor’s task will be then to spread these pulses through a high-tension leads to the spark plugs.

content.question: The power of a piston engine measured by a friction brake is…

options.A: frictional horse power.
options.B: heat loss power.
options.C: brake horse power.
options.D: indicated horse power.

key_points: The Indicated Horsepower (IHP) is the total power the engine can deliver based on the volumetric characteristics

IHP is the function of: Mean cylinder pressure Swept volume of all cylinders RPM However, it is not the output power of the engine, as the movement of components (shafts and the piston) require' power that is called friction horsepower

learning.explanation: The Indicated Horsepower (IHP) is the total power the engine can deliver based on the volumetric characteristics. IHP is the function of: Mean cylinder pressure Swept volume of all cylinders RPM However, it is not the output power of the engine, as the movement of components (shafts and the piston) require' power that is called friction horsepower. Deducting friction horsepower from indicated horsepower results in the total power output of the engine, called brake horsepower (BHP). Brake Horse Power (BHP) = Power available at crankshaft. BHP = IHP - Friction Horsepower Indicated Horse Power (IHP) = Power developed in the cylinder. Mechanical Efficiency = Brake Horse Power × 100% ÷ Indicated Horse Power. Friction Horsepower (FHP) = the frictional and power losses due to engine driven accessories. Power Output = torque × RPM (power = rate of doing work; work done per unit of time).

content.question: What is correct regarding the fuel system?

options.A: A strainer collects unwanted particles in the fuel system.

key_points: Considering each option; "A strainer collects unwanted particles in the fuel system
" → It is true
A strainer is designed to be fitted in the fuel systems just before (=upstream) the needle valve (the fuel metering device) to prevent foreign matter from entering and blocking the valve
learning.explanation: Considering each option; "A strainer collects unwanted particles in the fuel system." → It is true. A strainer is designed to be fitted in the fuel systems just before (=upstream) the needle valve (the fuel metering device) to prevent foreign matter from entering and blocking the valve. "The vent lines are installed to allow the excess fuel to flow out of the tank after refueling." → It is false. "The tank pressure is indicated in the cockpit for the fuel system." → It is false. Aircraft Fuel System Indicators are Fuel Temperature, Fuel Pressure, and Fuel Quantity. "A ventilation system in a fuel tank prevents the fuel from freezing during flight in icing conditions." → It is false. Fuel tank vents allow air into the fuel tank to replace the volume of fuel consumed by the engine and to allow for equalization of pressure (avoiding negative pressure) as the aircraft climbs or descends which helps to reduce evaporation and aids fuel transfer.

learning.explanation: The 2 main types of propellers found in aviation reciprocating engines are the following: Fixed pitch propeller: which is the simplest type of propeller with no additional moving parts fitted to most light general aviation aircraft. content.question: An aircraft is performing a go-around having had a critical engine failure. Which of the following combinations gives the BIGGEST stress on the rudder?

options.A: Aft CG, no slip indication.
options.B: Aft CG, 1/2 slip ball deflection towards the operative engine.
options.C: Forward CG, no slip indication.
options.D: Forward CG, 1/2 slip ball deflection towards the inoperative engine.

key_points: Note: This should really be a Principle of Flight question, but we have feedback that there are a few questions like this being asked in AGK also
Any further exam feedback is always useful, and can be put in the comments or emailed directly to info@atplquestions
com, thank you
learning.explanation: Note: This should really be a Principle of Flight question, but we have feedback that there are a few questions like this being asked in AGK also. Any further exam feedback is always useful, and can be put in the comments or emailed directly to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. This question is similar to 213150, but asking about the other end of the spectrum. Also, this is a different question altogether from the similar looking question 219782, which is asking about yawing, where this question is more focused on maintaining continuous stable flight. They can be easily mistaken in an exam, but have different reasoning and answers. The critical engine part of the question does not really matter, either engine would have the same answer. Firstly, we are looking for anything that either increases the yawing moment caused by the engine failure (which we have to counteract using the rudder), or anything that reduces the effectiveness of our rudder, so we would have to use more of it to produce the same effect. Initially, we can say that the further forward our centre of gravity (CG), the larger the moment arm from the rudder to the CG, and the more effective our rudder is. Therefore, our rudder is least effective at an aft CG and we would need to put more stress through it to produce the same amount of moment. SIDESLIP Next, we have to consider the sideslip configuration of the aircraft, as well as how that is indicated on our instruments. Remember that the sideslip ball indicator is not useful in the usual sense when we have an engine failure, as it only really measures the direction of the "local gravity", the G-forces on the aircraft. 1) Wings-level flight The moment (turning force) of the asymmetric thrust must be counteracted by the rudder, which makes the aircraft maintain its heading, but causes it to track with a sideslip towards the dead engine (meaning that the airflow is coming at the aircraft from the side of the dead engine). This requires a lot of rudder to maintain, and leaves us in a sideslip condition with a lot of drag. Our sideslip ball indicator will be central in this configuration, therefore, even though this is a sideslip condition, it has "no slip indication". 2) Banking towards the live engine A small bank angle towards the operative engine (up to 5° AoB, "five to the live") can reduce or even remove the sideslip using the weight of the aircraft to counteract the tendency to fly away from the live engine. It is a commonly used configuration to acquire slightly more aircraft performance during an engine failure, but not too much bank angle, as that begins to negate the effect and reduce performance again. This reduces the required moment of the rudder (mostly because it is no longer having to fight the weather-cocking effect of the fin and aft fuselage) This reduces the aircraft's actual sideslip but a slip ball indicator would show approximately 1/2 a ball deflection to the operative engine. This is because there is no turning force and so the only G-force that the ball detects is straight down, and as we are banked, that means slightly towards whichever way we have banked (the live engine). Therefore, the correct answer to cause the most strain on the rudder is to have an aft CG and no slip indication (wings-level flight).

learning.explanation: The air to fuel ratio that ensures complete combustion is about 15:1 by mass. It is called the chemically correct ratio or the theoretical best economy. In reality, this mixture is not the best suited for normal operations because of the high combustion temperature-induced and the increased risk of detonation. This is why the best is to set the mixture about 10% richer so that the excessive fuel absorbs some of the latent heat and cools the charge below the detonation value.

content.question: What should the air/fuel ratio be during a take-off at sea level in a piston engine?

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.08.01.02: State the typical fuel-to-air ratio values or range of values for the above mixtures. For a gasoline (petrol) engine, the chemically correct air/fuel mixture to burn for maximum combustion efficiency is 15:1, so 15 grams of air for each 1 gram of fuel. This is called the stoichiometric ratio. This is not the best mixture to run a piston engine at though, as it leads to very hot combustion and can heat up the cylinders and pistons too much, causing damage. The weaker we run the mixture (more air, less fuel, for instance 16:1), the less fuel there is able to combust, so the engine runs slightly cooler, but produces less power. This is called running "lean of peak", and it is often the most economical way of flying piston engines in the cruise. Running an engine slightly richer than 15:1, say for instance 14:1, gives increased power (but less efficient combustion) due to slightly more fuel available for burning. It is still cooler than running at the chemically correct 15:1 ratio, though, as the extra fuel adds to cooling the engine. Running the mixture full rich, around 10:1 mixture, has a small reduction in maximum power, but gives increased engine reliability as the extra fuel not being burnt is used for engine cooling, and is very effective for keeping the cylinders and pistons cool. It is therefore what we use for take-off and landing, and any changes in power during flight.

content.question: What is a turbocharger used for in a piston aero-engine?

options.A: To compensate for the decrease in MAP with increasing altitude.
options.B: To increase the engine power output with altitude.
options.C: To increase the engine power output at sea level.
options.D: To reduce the stress on all the engine components.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.03: Power-augmentation devices: explain the requirement for power augmentation (turbocharging) of a piston engine. Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.05: Explain the difference between an altitude-boosted turbocharger and a ground-boosted turbocharger. Piston Engines can have their power increased in three main ways, by increasing the size of the engine (displacement), increasing the RPM, or increasing the pressure of the air/fuel mixture (called the Manifold Absolute Pressure, MAP). This last case is why we might use a turbocharger in our car engines, so we can have a small, efficient engine, with extra power available from a turbocharger (which compresses the intake air) when needed. Turbochargers are arguably even more useful in aircraft, where piston engines become less powerful in the thinner air at higher altitudes. This is where turbochargers can compress that air, to make the engine operate with the same power output it would do at a much lower altitude. We call this an "altitude boosted" turbocharger. They are more useful to us by keeping the same power up to higher altitudes, rather than giving us lots more power on the ground, which would put a lot of strain on the engine, which would be a "ground boosted" turbocharger. Turbochargers (and any superchargers, really) increase the amount of air (and therefore fuel) we can ignite in the cylinders, so if we used full turbocharger at take-off, for instance, the forces on the engine would be enormous, and would put too much strain on an engine. We do this in road cars, because we can make engines stronger/heavier, and if they fail it is not life threatening, but with aircraft engines, we cannot afford to gain the extra power for fear of failure, so we simply use it to compensate for the reduction in air density. A turbocharger works by using the excess speed and pressure of the exhaust gasses to spin a turbine, which then directly spins a compressor, which compresses the fresh intake air ready for entry into the cylinders. All superchargers compress fresh intake air like this, but turbochargers are special types of superchargers that use the excess energy leftover in the exhaust gasses that we would not otherwise use.

content.question: In the event of an engine failure during flight in a single-engine aeroplane not fitted with a feathering system, the blades of a constant speed propeller tend to move…

options.A: towards the smallest blade angle by centrifugal twisting moment and/or spring force.
options.B: towards the highest blade angle by oil pressure created by the windmilling propeller.
options.C: to a blade angle dependent on windmilling RPM.
options.D: towards the highest blade angle by the aerodynamic twisting moment.

key_points: When the engine fails, it cannot drive anymore the generators and hydraulic/oil pumps that it would normally supply
Therefore, since the CSU also works on oil pressurized by the engine, it will become inoperative as well
Because of this, only two outside forces will act on the propeller’s blades: the centrifugal and the aerodynamic turning moment
learning.explanation: When the engine fails, it cannot drive anymore the generators and hydraulic/oil pumps that it would normally supply. Therefore, since the CSU also works on oil pressurized by the engine, it will become inoperative as well. Because of this, only two outside forces will act on the propeller’s blades: the centrifugal and the aerodynamic turning moment. The aerodynamic force will tend to move the blade pitch angle towards a coarse pitch, whereas the centrifugal force tends to turn the blade to a fine pitch. Since the centrifugal force is greater than the aerodynamic force, the propeller will be pushed to fine pitch by the centrifugal twisting moment and will create a solid resistive propeller disk that will resist against the relative airflow, creating a lot of drag. Additionally, the system also consists of a speeder spring that is directly linked to the RPM selection controller (blue lever). When there’s no more oil pressure, the spring will automatically move until the fine pitch stop by pushing all the oil out of the propeller hub and resulting in a drop in RPM.

content.question: In an engine equipped with a float-type carburettor, the low temperature that causes carburettor ice is normally the result of…

options.A: vaporisation of fuel and expansion of the air in the carburettor
options.B: freezing temperature of the air entering the carburettor
options.C: low volatility of aviation fuel
options.D: compression of air at the carburettor venturi

key_points: The operating principle of float-type carburetors is based on the Bernoulli’s theorem which states that the energy per unit mass of a moving fluid is constant
As the air passes through the convergence of the Venturi duct, its velocity increases causing a drop in pressure and temperature
The pressure will drop proportionally to the mass airflow and is used to make fuel flow from the float chamber by placing a ‘U’-shaped jet into the Venturi
learning.explanation: The operating principle of float-type carburetors is based on the Bernoulli’s theorem which states that the energy per unit mass of a moving fluid is constant. As the air passes through the convergence of the Venturi duct, its velocity increases causing a drop in pressure and temperature. The pressure will drop proportionally to the mass airflow and is used to make fuel flow from the float chamber by placing a ‘U’-shaped jet into the Venturi. Engine suction creates a difference in air pressure at the throat of the Venturi duct and the air inlet resulting in a sucking effect. Besides the drop in pressure and temperature at the Venturi’s throat, the later will increase again within the induction manifold as the throttle is opened. “freezing temperature of the air entering the carburettor” – carburettor icing doesn’t necessarily occur only when freezing temperatures are prevailing. As long as you have visible moisture and the temperature is below +10°C (but also higher under certain conditions), the risk of icing becomes significant. “Low volatility of aviation fuel” – this property is not linked at all to carburetor icing. “Compression of air at the carburettor venturi” – compression will have the opposite reaction, the temperature and pressure will increase. Whereas the venturi decreases the temperature and the pressure of the flowing fuel and air.

content.question: The main advantage of a constant speed propeller compared to a fixed pitch propeller is that a constant speed propeller…

options.A: does not require propeller blade twist.
options.B: has a lower propeller blade stress.
options.C: has a higher maximum propeller efficiency.
options.D: maintains its maximum propeller efficiency over a wider range of airspeeds.

key_points: In a variable pitch propeller, the engine is governed to run at a set rpm throughout the flight range, using the propeller efficiently at all times
The propeller governs the engine at this set rpm by the use of a device known as a constant speed unit (CSU) and by means of a flyweight governor

Any variations in engine power output (throttle pulled back or forward), which would otherwise produce a change in rpm, are sensed by the CSU which alters the propeller pitch angle to keep the rpm constant
learning.explanation: In a variable pitch propeller, the engine is governed to run at a set rpm throughout the flight range, using the propeller efficiently at all times. The propeller governs the engine at this set rpm by the use of a device known as a constant speed unit (CSU) and by means of a flyweight governor. Any variations in engine power output (throttle pulled back or forward), which would otherwise produce a change in rpm, are sensed by the CSU which alters the propeller pitch angle to keep the rpm constant. If the throttle is pulled back, the propeller pitch would automatically decrease (fine pitch) but the RPM will remain the same, and vice-versa. The governor controls a hydraulic servo system feeding high-pressure oil, via a pilot valve, to a piston in the pitch change mechanism (PCM). The CSU operates on the principle of balancing a spring pressure against the centrifugal force of rotating governor flyweights, driven directly from the engine or reduction gearbox. Usually, in a piston engine, the governor flyweights are tensioned by a speeder spring, which is controlled from the cockpit by setting the RPM lever. In a turboprop, however, the most efficient engine RPM is maintained by pre-tensioning the speeder spring to give the maximum engine RPM at all times.

content.question: Aircraft fuel tanks should be checked for water…

options.A: before the first flight of the day because condensation may arise overnight.
options.B: immediately after every refuelling.
options.C: during refuelling.
options.D: before each flight.

key_points: Aviation fuel can only be efficient enough if it is delivered to the engine free of water

Besides the fact that fuel can be delivered to your aircraft tanks already contaminated with water (leaks in the underground tanks, seals, covers), it can also form and/or accumulate in your tanks through various leaks in the vents and seals, or because of improper fuel cap placing that led to precipitation falling in or even condensation
This is why it is recommended that the fuel tanks should be filled as much as practicable overnight
learning.explanation: Aviation fuel can only be efficient enough if it is delivered to the engine free of water. Besides the fact that fuel can be delivered to your aircraft tanks already contaminated with water (leaks in the underground tanks, seals, covers), it can also form and/or accumulate in your tanks through various leaks in the vents and seals, or because of improper fuel cap placing that led to precipitation falling in or even condensation. This is why it is recommended that the fuel tanks should be filled as much as practicable overnight. The indicated correct answer is not wrong since the fuel should be drained before the first flight of the day. However, it is recommended to drain the fuel tanks before your flight as well. You never know where the previous pilot has refueled the airplane and how good is the quality of the fuel there. In the same way, you will never know exactly if the fuel has been drained before the first flight of the day.

content.question: The power output of a diesel engine without a turbo charger is regulated by…

options.A: mixture.
options.B: airflow only.
options.C: fuel flow only.
options.D: fuel flow and airflow.

key_points: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture
For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs

The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder
learning.explanation: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture. For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs. The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder. The fuel injection system consists of atomizers that will spray the fuel into the pre-chamber, but because not all the fuel droplets burn completely, residual soot will remain in the cylinder. To produce enough heat for the mixture to ignite, the diesel engines operate at a much higher compression ratios than the normal petrol engine: from 14:1 up to 28:1 for the most powerful compared to 9:1 for a petrol engine. Because of this high compression ratio, diesel engines also benefit from a higher thermal efficiency. The amount of power delivered will only be determined by the fuel flow. In the same way as for car engines, diesel engines are less powerful than a petrol engine for the same swept volume.

content.question: In a piston engine, the purpose of an altitude mixture control is to…

options.A: enrich the mixture due to decreased air density at altitude.
options.B: weaken the mixture because of reduced exhaust back pressure at altitude.

At altitude, the density of the air decreases, therefore if the mixture is left fully rich as it should be during the climb phase, the mixture will be too rich for the cruise phase. Therefore, the pilot will use the mixture control lever to correct for variations in the fuel/air ratio encountered at higher altitudes.

content.question: To enable proper functioning of a piston engine during rapid throttle advance a carburettor is fitted with:

options.A: a mixture control.
options.B: a diffuser (compensating jet).

options.B: ice was forming in carburettor.
options.C: the mixture was too lean.

key_points: When ice is building up in the carburetor the venturi duct is narrowing and increases the effects of the venturi tube (further decrease in pressure and temperature)
The dynamic pressure flowing through the tube increases the ice build-up as the venturi-shaped icy duct sees a decrease in temperature and static pressure
This is also the reason why the first indication of ice build-up is going to be a decrease in manifold pressure (=static pressure)
learning.explanation: When ice is building up in the carburetor the venturi duct is narrowing and increases the effects of the venturi tube (further decrease in pressure and temperature). The dynamic pressure flowing through the tube increases the ice build-up as the venturi-shaped icy duct sees a decrease in temperature and static pressure. This is also the reason why the first indication of ice build-up is going to be a decrease in manifold pressure (=static pressure). Therefore, as soon as the carburetor heating is turned on, the ice buildup will melt, and the duct will see an increase in static pressure (=manifold pressure).
