options.B: (1) scavenge; (2) larger; (3) pressure
options.C: (1) pressure; (2) larger; (3) scavenge
options.D: (1) pressure; (2) smaller; (3) scavenge

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.02: Describe the working principle of a dry-sump lubrication system and describe the functions of the following components: oil tank (reservoir) and its internal components: hot well, de-aerator, vent, expansion space; check valve (non-return valve); pressure pump and pressure-relief valve; scavenge pump; filters (suction, pressure and scavenge); oil cooler; oil cooler bypass valve (anti-surge and thermostatic); pressure and temperature sensors; lines. A dry sump engine is one where the oil is not allowed to sit in the engine sump for too long, and is instead "scavenged" back to a separate reservoir. This is the opposite of a "wet sump" engine, where the sump (within the engine casing) is the reservoir, and a lot less systems are required, but with reduced engine power due to losses. With a dry sump engine, the oil enters from the reservoir via a pressure pump (along with filters, coolers, and some sensors), getting it up to a suitable pressure to spray inside the engine. The oil then lubricates, cools and cleans the engine components, finally ending up at the bottom of the engine, where it gathers in the sump, and is collected up by a scavenge pump (more filters as well), which returns it to the reservoir. The oil is often quite aerated and foamy by this point, so is less dense, and the scavenge pump needs a larger volume to cope with this oil, and not let it mount up in the sump. The scavenge pump also needs to be a higher volume than the pressure pump, as the other way around would force more and more oil into the engine, and would create a potential flooding of the sump, which is supposed to hold oil only for a short amount of time, potentially damaging the engine by having too much oil.

key_points: Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch
The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth
In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded
learning.explanation: Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch. The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth. In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded. However, if the grounding wire is broken, the magneto will keep working normally and the engine will continue running. Another situation where the engine can keep running is when an excessive carbon deposit has formed in the cylinder head. Because the deposit is still hot enough when you arrive at your parking position after the flight in order to ignite the charge without the spark from the plugs. The effect will be a hardly rumbling engine that is still running. If this ever happens and the engine doesn’t stop, you can simply pull back the mixture control lever (red) and shut off the fuel supply. Caution! Maintenance action should be sought before touching the propeller since the engine can start at any time with one magneto still un-grounded.

content.question: Where is the engine oil stored in a wet-sump oil system?

options.A: The bottom of the engine.
options.B: A seperate tank.
options.C: Inside the engine cylinders.
options.D: There is no oil storage.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.03: Describe a wet-sump lubrication system. There are two main types of oil system for engines, dry-sump and wet-sump. The biggest difference between the two is where the oil stored when not in use. In a dry-sump system, the oil is pumped from the bottom of the engine to the oil reservoir. In a wet-sump system, the oil is stored in the "sump", which is just the area at the bottom of the engine, where the oil naturally drains to. There are advantages and disadvantages to both. Wet-sump systems are quite common on ground vehicle engines and older aircraft engines, as they are less complex than dry-sump systems, and therefore are less prone to failure. They do have a fair few disadvantages, though. These include not being able to properly oil the engine during some aerobatic manoeuvres, and a reduced amount of oil capacity, and reduced cooling capacity, due to the oil only being stored in the bottom of the engine. There are also some small performance losses due to more oil splashing about in the bottom of the engine.

options.A: an electrically-activated hydraulically-powered clutch.

key_points: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude
The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor
The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller
learning.explanation: A turbocharger’s main task is to maintain power with increasing altitude as air density is decreasing, therefore making the power available less affected by altitude. The typical compressor usually fitted in a piston engine’s turbocharger is a centrifugal compressor. The turbocharger is an externally driven supercharger that main advantage over the simpler supercharger is the usage of energy that would otherwise be lost to drive its impeller. That energy is nothing else than exhaust gases. The turbocharger consists of two exhaust gas inlets that receive and direct the exhaust gases towards the turbine wheel. The exhaust gases mechanically spin the turbine before leaving the system through an exhaust gas outlet. The turbine is connected through a solid common shaft to a compressor, and the rotating energy gained from the exhaust gases circulation will serve to drive the compressor. At the compressor’s end, there’s also an inlet that will receive and direct ambient air to the compressor’s impeller eye. The air will then leave the impeller almost at a tangent to the periphery and trade velocity for an increase in pressure and temperature. The boost air under pressure obtained from this process will then be ducted to mix with the fuel and follow its path towards combustion. The pressure of the compressed air (boost) can be monitored only on the cockpit MAP gauge.

content.question: A piston engine aeroplane with a fixed pitch propeller is flying at normal cruising speed when one magneto fails completely. The initial response of the engine is…

options.A: a significant increase in cylinder head temperature.
options.B: excessive vibration.
options.C: an additional load on the other magneto.
options.D: a loss of approximately 100 RPM.

key_points: The ignition system is duplicated so both halves must be fully operative to ensure a safe handling of the engine should one of them fail during flight
This is why you have to perform a magneto check before departure, also called mag drop
You will perform this twice, at different power settings: idle and about 75% of maximum
learning.explanation: The ignition system is duplicated so both halves must be fully operative to ensure a safe handling of the engine should one of them fail during flight. This is why you have to perform a magneto check before departure, also called mag drop. You will perform this twice, at different power settings: idle and about 75% of maximum. After you set your engine at one of these power settings, you will switch off each magneto in turn and check that the RPM drops within specific limits (usually 100 RPM) and the engine runs smoothly. As a result you will find out that if one of the magnetos fails during flight, engine power is not significantly compromised. If, however, during the mag drop checks you notice that the engine stops it would indicate that one half of the magnetos isn’t properly working, whereas if there’s no drop in RPM it means that one half of the ignition system is not being earthed and maintenance support should be seek.

key_points: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) FADEC is an electronic system that controls an engine, allowing easy usage by the pilot, relieving workload and providing most efficient power settings through single lever operation

It allows many hundreds of sensor inputs to be fed to the central computer, an EEC (electronic engine controller) or ECU (engine control unit), which then calculates the best outputs for performance and efficiency, and can automatically make such inputs
It has control over every available part of the engine, from fuel-air mixture to ignition timing and even the propeller controller for variable pitch propellers
learning.explanation: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) FADEC is an electronic system that controls an engine, allowing easy usage by the pilot, relieving workload and providing most efficient power settings through single lever operation. It allows many hundreds of sensor inputs to be fed to the central computer, an EEC (electronic engine controller) or ECU (engine control unit), which then calculates the best outputs for performance and efficiency, and can automatically make such inputs. It has control over every available part of the engine, from fuel-air mixture to ignition timing and even the propeller controller for variable pitch propellers. Ignition timing is the point in the 4 stroke engine cycle where the air/fuel mixture is ignited, and as RPM increases, the ignition timing should get earlier in the cycle to provide best efficiency. In a diesel engine this is the point where the fuel is injected, as it immediately ignites. The advantages of FADEC on piston engines include: Reduced weight Optimum efficiency No possibility of exceeding engine limitations Easy engine diagnostics There are also disadvantages to FADEC, which include: High complexity 2 ECUs are required to avoid a single point of failure No ability to gain excess power out of the engine in a crisis (e.g. terrain escape) Complete electrical failure means an engine failure (or uncontrollable engines)

content.question: When detonation is recognised in a piston engine, the correct procedure is to…

options.A: increase manifold pressure and fully enrich the mixture.
options.B: reduce manifold pressure and lean the mixture.
options.C: reduce manifold pressure and fully enrich the mixture.
options.D: increase manifold pressure and lean the mixture.

key_points: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that it ignites spontaneously at an early stage of the power stroke
In fact, the rate of pressure rise will occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to move downwards
Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat
learning.explanation: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that it ignites spontaneously at an early stage of the power stroke. In fact, the rate of pressure rise will occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to move downwards. Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat. The cylinder walls, the piston’s head, the sparking plugs and the exhaust valves are being hardly damaged when detonation occurs as this will cause a sudden knock. The conditions in which detonation is most likely in a piston engine are a high manifold pressure leading to a high cylinder head temperature and low RPM. The risk of detonation can be reduced by: First of all, always using the correct grade of fuel designed for your aircraft’s engine. Using a toolow octane rating will greatly increase the likelihood of detonation. Making sure the proper mixture is being supplied to the engine in any conditions. The greater the amount of fuel for a given amount of air, the greater the power that can be obtained without detonation. Avoid situations where the temperature and pressure of the mixture raise before it burns, such as applying carburetor heating at high power settings (takeoff/climb). However, if you ever experience detonation during flight, the following corrective action should be carried: Reduce the manifold pressure (= retard the throttle) Fully enrich the mixture.

content.question: A waste gate controls the output of a turbocharger by varying the amount of exhaust gasses passing through the turbocharger's (1) _____. A fully (2) _____ waste gate will achieve the maximum turbocharger RPM.

options.A: (1) turbine; (2) open
options.B: (1) compressor; (2) open
options.C: (1) compressor; (2) closed
options.D: (1) turbine; (2) closed

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.04: Describe the function and the principle of operation of the following main components of a turbocharger: turbine; compressor; waste gate; waste-gate actuator. Piston Engines can have their power increased in three main ways, by increasing the size of the engine (displacement), increasing the RPM, or increasing the pressure of the air/fuel mixture (called the Manifold Absolute Pressure, MAP). This last case is why we might use a turbocharger in our car engines, so we can have a small, efficient engine, with extra power available from a turbocharger (which compresses the intake air) when needed. Turbochargers are arguably even more useful in aircraft, where piston engines become less powerful in the thinner air at higher altitudes. This is where turbochargers can compress that air, to make the engine operate with the same power output it would do at a much lower altitude. They are more useful to us by keeping the same power up to higher altitudes, rather than giving us lots more power on the ground, which puts a lot of strain on the engine. A turbocharger works by using the speed and pressure of the exhaust gasses to spin a turbine, which then uses that energy to spin the compressor, which compresses the fresh intake air ready for entry into the cylinders. We cannot allow the turbocharger to run wild though, as too much pressure (MAP) can cause the engine to "overboost", and even fail quite spectacularly. The way we regulate the turbocharger is by varying how much air gets to the turbine, this is via a wastegate system. the exhaust gasses can go down two different tubes, one is a standard exhaust, straight out of the aircraft (bypassing the turbine). The other is a tube to the turbine, to spin up the turbocharger. The wastegate is a butterfly valve that can block the exhaust tube, so when it is closed, all the exhaust gasses go to the turbine, making the compressor/turbine spin fastest. When the engine reaches its maximum MAP, the oil system which regulates the wastegate begins to open it, letting some of the "waste" air straight out of the aircraft, so it does not continue to run the turbine, which might overboost the engine.

content.question: A piston engine compression ratio is the ratio of the…

options.A: total volume to the swept volume.
options.B: clearance volume to the swept volume.
options.C: swept volume to the clearance volume.
options.D: total volume to the clearance volume.

key_points: The compression ratio is the ratio of the largest volume (total volume) to the smallest volume (clearance volume)
In other words, it is the ratio between the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the BDC to the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the TDC
When the piston is at TDC, the fuel/air mixture is compressed into a very small space between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder
learning.explanation: The compression ratio is the ratio of the largest volume (total volume) to the smallest volume (clearance volume). In other words, it is the ratio between the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the BDC to the volume of the cylinder with the piston at the TDC. When the piston is at TDC, the fuel/air mixture is compressed into a very small space between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder. This is generally labeled as the clearance volume, or to put it simply, the smallest volume. On the other hand, when the piston is at the BDC, the volume of space containing the mixture (the total volume) is much larger. The difference between the total volume and the clearance volume is called the swept volume.

content.question: When comparing petrol engines with diesel engines, petrol engines..

options.A: Have a lower compression ratio than diesel engines.
options.B: Have an injection system; diesel engines have a carburettor.
options.C: Are compression ignition engines; diesel engines have a glow plug for ignition.
options.D: Have a lower specific fuel consumption than diesel engines.

key_points: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture
For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions), and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs

The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder
learning.explanation: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture. For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions), and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs. The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder. The fuel injection system consists of atomizers that will spray the fuel into the pre-chamber, but because not all the fuel droplets burn completely, residual soot will remain in the cylinder. To produce enough heat for the mixture to ignite, the diesel engines operate at much higher compression ratios than the normal petrol engine: from 14:1 up to 28:1 for the most powerful compared to 9:1 for a petrol engine. Because of this high compression ratio, diesel engines also benefit from higher thermal efficiency. The amount of power delivered will only be determined by the fuel flow. In the same way, as for car engines, diesel engines are less powerful than a petrol engine for the same swept volume.

It is also used as a substance to clean the interior of the engine and accumulate the deposits gathered along the way for removal
Piston engines are very dependent on their lubrication oil
learning.explanation: The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts. content.question: Assume an initial condition at a high cruise altitude with a constant speed propeller. What will happen if the altitude is decreased while the throttle remains fully open and the waste gate is seized in the cruise position?

options.A: The power of the engine will decrease.
options.B: The manifold absolute pressure (MAP) value will stay constant.
options.C: The manifold absolute pressure (MAP) value may exceed the maximum allowed value.
options.D: The blade angle may reach the full fine limit.

key_points: The waste gate is a butterfly valve located in the exhaust flow, upstream of the turbocharger, and controlled by a separate hydraulic actuator
It is connected in parallel with the turbocharger
A constant MAP at the diffuser stage (after leaving the impeller) can be maintained by controlling the amount of gas directed to the turbine
learning.explanation: The waste gate is a butterfly valve located in the exhaust flow, upstream of the turbocharger, and controlled by a separate hydraulic actuator. It is connected in parallel with the turbocharger. A constant MAP at the diffuser stage (after leaving the impeller) can be maintained by controlling the amount of gas directed to the turbine. The waste gate hydraulic actuator is continuously supplied with engine oil and returns back to the engine through a variable restrictor. When the restrictor is closed, the actuator will be pressurized with engine oil pressure, that will force the actuator’s piston to move, and thus closing the waste gate. When the waste gate fully closes, it directs all the exhaust gases to the turbine, causing it to accelerate. This is exactly what will happen at a high cruising altitude. The waste gate will be fully closed, and the turbine will accelerate to its maximum causing an excessive increase in pressurized air, and thus, a potential exceedance of the maximum allowed MAP.

content.question: To maintain a constant mixture in a piston engine at low and high power settings, a carburettor is fitted with…

options.A: a power jet.
options.B: a mixture control.
options.C: an accelerator pump.
options.D: a diffuser (compensating jet).

key_points: The main purpose of the diffuser is to maintain the constant mixture ratio across a wide range of engine speeds (low and high power settings)
It is fitted right after the main jet linking the carburettor’s floating chamber and the venturi
If there’s a larger mass of air entering the venturi, the pressure drop will be excessive at the venturi throat, which will result in a larger addition of fuel making the mixture too rich
learning.explanation: The main purpose of the diffuser is to maintain the constant mixture ratio across a wide range of engine speeds (low and high power settings). It is fitted right after the main jet linking the carburettor’s floating chamber and the venturi. If there’s a larger mass of air entering the venturi, the pressure drop will be excessive at the venturi throat, which will result in a larger addition of fuel making the mixture too rich. To avoid this imbalance, air from the pressure balance duct is fed through a drilled tube (tube with holes) which is the diffuser. The diffuser’s openings are precisely dimensioned to guarantee that the correct mixture ratio is maintained across the entire engine’s speed range. When the engine is running at idle, the levels in the diffuser and float chamber are almost equal. However, when the engine is running, the fuel level in the diffuser drops because of the slight restraint caused by the carburettor’s jet. This will uncover some of the diffuser’s openings allowing air from the pressure balance duct to flow in. This reduces the pressure at the nozzle, thus reducing the fuel flow and allowing a balanced mixture.

content.question: "Vapour lock" is the phenomenon by which…

options.A: burned gas bubbles are formed and remain in the exhaust manifold following an overheat, thereby disturbing the exhaust.
options.B: vapour bubbles block the fuel line.
options.C: water vapour bubbles are formed in the intake fuel line following the condensation of water in fuel tanks that have not been recently drained.
options.D: abrupt and abnormal enrichment of the mixture following an inappropriate use of carburettor heat.

key_points: ‘Vapour lock’ is the phenomenon by which fuel vapour bubbles block the fuel feed line
In fact, it is mainly caused by the fuel vaporizing prior to it entering the engine
To prevent vapour locking and cavitation, a low-pressure pump is fitted to the feed line and will supply fuel from the tanks at a suitable pressure and rate flow
learning.explanation: ‘Vapour lock’ is the phenomenon by which fuel vapour bubbles block the fuel feed line. In fact, it is mainly caused by the fuel vaporizing prior to it entering the engine. To prevent vapour locking and cavitation, a low-pressure pump is fitted to the feed line and will supply fuel from the tanks at a suitable pressure and rate flow. Under certain circumstances when the engine is very hot, vapour lock can also occur in the injector lines and prevent the fuel from being correctly delivered to the cylinders.

content.question: The crank assembly of a piston engine comprises the…

options.A: crankcase, crankshaft, connecting rods and pistons.
options.B: crankshaft, camshaft, valves, valve springs and push rods.
options.C: crankshaft, connecting rods and pistons.
options.D: propeller, crankshaft, pistons and connecting rods.

key_points: The major components of a piston engine are: Cylinder and cylinder’s head – consisting of a gas-tight barrel and a head assembled together
Usually, the barrel is made of steel and is fitted with fins that will help to disperse heat, whereas the head is made of alloy
Spark plugs – there’re usually two plugs per cylinder for redundancy and for more uniform combustion on either side of the cylinder to improve combustion efficiency
learning.explanation: The major components of a piston engine are: Cylinder and cylinder’s head – consisting of a gas-tight barrel and a head assembled together. Usually, the barrel is made of steel and is fitted with fins that will help to disperse heat, whereas the head is made of alloy. Spark plugs – there’re usually two plugs per cylinder for redundancy and for more uniform combustion on either side of the cylinder to improve combustion efficiency. Pistons – made of aluminum alloy and consisting of the head (top part) and the ‘skirt’ (lower part. It is carefully designed to improve its efficiency and safe operation – it has compression rings that prevent the gases from escaping toward the lower part of the cylinder and oil control rings to ensure oil is spread evenly all over the inner surface of the cylinder. Connecting rod – stiff ‘H’ shaped important element that connects the piston to the crankshaft by means of a hinged axle. Crankshaft - a linear assembly consisting of rotary components that will convert the piston’s linear movement into a rotary movement transmitted to the propeller. Among others, you could find the following components in a crankshaft: the crank web, the crankpin, the journal, and the balance weights. Camshaft - a shaft containing several attached disks of irregular shape that operate the intake and exhaust valves Crankcase – it is the structural ‘box’ within which the engine is located. It serves as a mounting point for the cylinders, the accessory gearbox, the engine. It is carefully designed to lubricate itself and all the related components (bearings, pistons, etc.) via its numerous internal passages. Usually, it is made of a strong alloy such as magnesium.

content.question: Which statement is correct with regards to ice accretion in piston engine induction systems?

options.A: Induction system icing affects only engines equipped with carburettors.
options.B: Fuel ice is normally formed in the induction system of fuel injected engines.
options.C: Ice on the throttle valve is only found in the induction system of fuel injection systems.
options.D: Ice accretion affects both fuel injection systems and engines equipped with carburettors.

key_points: Piston Engines have always suffered from icing problems in some of the conditions that aircraft require them to be operated
There are two type of piston engine induction system, they both suffer from induction icing differently
Carburettors - The original method for mixing fuel and air prior to the cylinder, the carburettor uses the venturi effect to "suck" fuel out of the tube, into the airstream
learning.explanation: Piston Engines have always suffered from icing problems in some of the conditions that aircraft require them to be operated. There are two type of piston engine induction system, they both suffer from induction icing differently. Carburettors - The original method for mixing fuel and air prior to the cylinder, the carburettor uses the venturi effect to "suck" fuel out of the tube, into the airstream. For icing considerations, this has two problems; the fuel vaporising requires latent heat to be input, removing heat from the surrounding air, and the low pressure in the venturi (and throttle valve) which further cools the air. In certain conditions, These could make the air colder than 0ºC, and it would then be possible to form ice on the walls of the carburettor, and on the throttle valve, especially at low throttle settings where the throttle valve only has a small gap for the air to pass through, which will cause even lower pressure (annexes above). This is on top of the usual icing that can form, such as on air filters or wherever the air impacts a cold metal surface, similar to airframe icing. Carburettor heat can be used intermittently to provide hot air to the induction system and melt any ice. Fuel Injection - A system where the exact amount of fuel is injected into the intake air, either just before the intake valve, or inside the cylinder. As there is no venturi and no fuel evaporation in this system, the usual "carburettor icing" concerns are no longer an issue. However, icing may still form, such as at any bends in the system, or where the air has to impact a cold surface such as the air filter, similar to airframe icing. Fuel icing is also possible (but it is possible in a carburettor system also, so that is not the correct answer). Fuel injected engines have an "alternate air" system which will bypass any such problems if required. Therefore, from those options, the answer is actually quite simple, ice accretion affects both types of induction system.

content.question: The octane rating of a fuel indicates its…

options.A: resistance to detonation.
options.B: electrical conductivity.
options.C: volatility.
options.D: capability for pre-ignition.

key_points: Airplanes’ piston engines are reciprocating engines, similar to your car’s engine, with the difference that they use special aviation fuel to run
However, a failure of an airplane engine due to fuel issues can be potentially fatal, so safety dictates that aviation fuel must conform to very stringent requirements
It is made of various selected grades of gasoline, combined to give high anti-knock ratings
learning.explanation: Airplanes’ piston engines are reciprocating engines, similar to your car’s engine, with the difference that they use special aviation fuel to run. However, a failure of an airplane engine due to fuel issues can be potentially fatal, so safety dictates that aviation fuel must conform to very stringent requirements. It is made of various selected grades of gasoline, combined to give high anti-knock ratings. The octane rating of a fuel indicates its resistance to detonation. The use of too low octane gasoline in a piston engine will increase the chances of detonation. However, using fuel with a higher-octane grade is perfectly normal provided it is designed to take advantage of a higher-grade fuel. In fact, using a higher-grade fuel in a low-performance engine will not benefit you as this may cause fouling of the cylinders and eventual mechanical failure. For your general knowledge, the octane rating is based on the knock resistance difference between two spirits, iso-octane (which is very good) and heptane (very poor). By degrading iso-octane with heptane until the blend detonated in a variable compression engine under the same standard conditions as the fuel under test, it was possible to classify that fuel by a number representing the percentage of iso-octane in the test mixture. In this way, 89-octane fuel corresponded to a mixture of 89% iso-octane and 11% heptane.

content.question: Which of the following indications related to engine lubrication is most important to monitor during start-up of a piston engine?

options.A: The filter bypass warning.
options.B: A warning from the chip detector.
options.C: A low oil temperature indication or warning light.
options.D: A low oil pressure indication or warning light.

key_points: Oil is the primary fluid used to lubricate an engine
It also assists with cleaning, cooling and detecting engine problems
The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts
learning.explanation: Oil is the primary fluid used to lubricate an engine. It also assists with cleaning, cooling and detecting engine problems. The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts. In a gas turbine engine, the largest and some of the most important moving parts are the ball and roller main bearings of the main driveshafts, which would also crucially require an oil supply. In a piston engine, the cylinders require oil to stop metal rubbing directly against metal, as well as the bearings from the crankshafts, camshafts, etc. Oil pressure in particular is one of the most important parameters to monitor during engine start. If you don’t observe an increase in oil pressure, it means the oil isn't flowing properly, and the moving parts of the engine will generate a lot of heat due to friction, quickly resulting in engine damage, a fire, or eventually the engine welding itself together, causing a complete seizure. The oil pressure transmitter is usually located just after the engine pressure pumps, before the oil reaches the engine components. As for the other options: A low oil temperature is fine as the oil needs time to heat up in a cold engine. The filter bypass warning means that the filter is clogged and the oil has bypassed it, so is now unfiltered. It is an issue, but not quite as urgent as a low pressure indication (dirty oil is still better than no oil). The chip detector is a magnetic part of the oil lines that collects any ferrous metal particles that are in the oil, which sometimes has a sensor that can go off if too many metal shavings are picked up. This indicated damage to internal engine components, and is a big problem, but again, not as urgent as a low pressure indication.

content.question:
Given the following statements about diesel engines:
1. power is set by the mixture control
2. there is no mixture control
3. the amount of power is determined by the fuel flow only
4. thermal efficiency is higher than that for a petrol engine
5. diesel fuel is more inflammable than petrol
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture
For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs

The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder
learning.explanation: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture. For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs. The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder. The fuel injection system consists of atomizers that will spray the fuel into the pre-chamber, but because not all the fuel droplets burn completely, residual soot will remain in the cylinder. To produce enough heat for the mixture to ignite, the diesel engines operate at a much higher compression ratios than the normal petrol engine: from 14:1 up to 28:1 for the most powerful compared to 9:1 for a petrol engine. Because of this high compression ratio, diesel engines also benefit from a higher thermal efficiency. The amount of power delivered will only be determined by the fuel flow. In the same way as for car engines, diesel engines are less powerful than a petrol engine for the same swept volume.

options.C: ram air.

key_points: Air-cooled reciprocating engines use ram air from the atmosphere to cool the cylinders and all the other critical heated engine parts
The cylinders’ outside structure is made of fins to increase the surface in contact with the cool air, thus improving the cooling effect
The ram air is derived from the propeller slipstream and the aircraft’s forward movement through the air
learning.explanation: Air-cooled reciprocating engines use ram air from the atmosphere to cool the cylinders and all the other critical heated engine parts. The cylinders’ outside structure is made of fins to increase the surface in contact with the cool air, thus improving the cooling effect. The ram air is derived from the propeller slipstream and the aircraft’s forward movement through the air. In order to properly spread the cool ram air over each cylinder and reduce the drag generated the engine is cowled. Along with a cowl flap or gills, it will avoid having excessive cooling over the cylinders situated at the front of the engine in comparison to those situated slightly backward. Because of the lower maintenance costs, ram air cooling is the preferred method to cool the simple general aviation aircraft.

content.question: The use of too low an octane fuel may cause…

options.A: higher manifold pressure.
options.B: detonation.
options.C: a cooling effect on cylinders.
options.D: vapour locking.

key_points: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that it ignites spontaneously at an early stage of the power stroke
In fact, the rate of pressure rise will occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to move downwards
Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat
learning.explanation: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that it ignites spontaneously at an early stage of the power stroke. In fact, the rate of pressure rise will occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to move downwards. Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat. The cylinder walls, the piston’s head, the sparking plugs and the exhaust valves are being hardly damaged when detonation occurs as this will cause a sudden knock. The conditions in which detonation is most likely in a piston engine are a high manifold pressure leading to a high cylinder head temperature and low RPM. The risk of detonation can be reduced by: First of all, always using the correct grade of fuel designed for your aircraft’s engine. Using a toolow octane rating will greatly increase the likelihood of detonation. Making sure the proper mixture is being supplied to the engine in any conditions. The greater the amount of fuel for a given amount of air, the greater the power that can be obtained without detonation. Avoid situations where the temperature and pressure of the mixture raise before it burns, such as applying carburetor heating at high power settings (takeoff/climb). However, if you ever experience detonation during flight, the following corrective action should be carried: Reduce the manifold pressure (= retard the throttle) Fully enrich the mixture.

content.question: The "slipstream effect" of a propeller is most prominent at…

options.A: high airspeeds with low power setting.
options.B: high airspeeds with high power setting.
options.C: low airspeeds with low power setting.

However, in any other flight phases than cruise, you will always feel a residual yawing moment
learning.explanation: The propeller slipstream has a rotational moment and rotates as it passes over the aircraft, inducing a yawing force on the fin. To cope with this imperfection, the fin will be offset to line up with the wash in cruise flight. However, in any other flight phases than cruise, you will always feel a residual yawing moment. This will be at a maximum at low speed and high power setting (take-off), but will gradually reduce as airspeed is increasing.

content.question: Consider a variable pitch propeller operating in a low RPM / high pitch condition. When feather is selected, the…

key_points: The condition lever is a complex electro-mechanical device that controls several functions
The various positions of the lever are either located by ‘stops’ or ‘detents’ or are only selectable on the application of pressure against a spring
When the lever is moved to the feather position, fuel is mechanically shut off and the electrical feathering pump is operated to move the blades from high pitch directly to the feather position
learning.explanation: The condition lever is a complex electro-mechanical device that controls several functions. The various positions of the lever are either located by ‘stops’ or ‘detents’ or are only selectable on the application of pressure against a spring. When the lever is moved to the feather position, fuel is mechanically shut off and the electrical feathering pump is operated to move the blades from high pitch directly to the feather position. It is true that normally an oil pump driven by the engine (or a reduction gearbox) operates the propeller. However, for redundancy purposes and for a faster operation, a separate electrically-driven oil pump is usually incorporated to complete the feathering operation whilst the propeller is slowing down or has stopped. The feathering pump also enables the propeller to be un-feathered during an engine re-start sequence. Movement from negative to feathered: negative fine (low) coarse (high) feathered (90°)

If there’s a larger mass of air entering the venturi, the pressure drop will be excessive at the venturi throat, which will result in a larger addition of fuel making the mixture too rich

This will uncover some of the diffuser’s openings allowing air from the pressure balance duct to flow in. This reduces the pressure at the nozzle, thus reducing the fuel flow and allowing a balanced mixture.

content.question: One of the primary purposes of a propeller reduction gearing system is to…

options.A: change the propeller blade pitch angle so as to obtain efficient operation.
options.B: limit the propeller rotation speed to a value below which efficient operation can be obtained.
options.C: provide an increased horsepower output from the engine.
options.D: limit the engine rotation speed to prevent excessive engine temperatures.

key_points: One of the main purposes of a propeller reduction gearing system is to reduce the rotational speed of the engine and increase the torque transmitted to the propeller
By limiting the propeller rotation speed, the propeller can operate more efficiently and reduce the noise generated by the propeller tips
Option b) "limit the propeller rotation speed to a value below which efficient operation can be obtained
learning.explanation: One of the main purposes of a propeller reduction gearing system is to reduce the rotational speed of the engine and increase the torque transmitted to the propeller. By limiting the propeller rotation speed, the propeller can operate more efficiently and reduce the noise generated by the propeller tips. Option b) "limit the propeller rotation speed to a value below which efficient operation can be obtained." correctly describes this purpose. Option a) "change the propeller blade pitch angle so as to obtain efficient operation." is incorrect because changing the propeller blade pitch angle is typically done by a separate mechanism such as a variable pitch propeller. Option c) "provide an increased horsepower output from the engine." is incorrect because while the gearing system can provide increased torque to the propeller, it does not necessarily increase the engine's horsepower output. Option d) "limit the engine rotation speed to prevent excessive engine temperatures." is also incorrect because the reduction gearing system is not primarily designed to limit the engine rotation speed to prevent excessive engine temperatures.

content.question: An impulse coupling is installed on a magneto of a piston engine to…

options.A: facilitate the quick removal and installation of magnetos.
options.B: allow the ignition to automatically advance as RPM increases.
options.C: provide a stronger spark on top dead centre for engine starting.
options.D: absorb starting loads and ensure a dead cut on stopping.

key_points: The impulse magneto coupling consists of a spring-loaded clutch mounted between the drive spindle from the engine and the magneto shaft
The main purpose of the impulse magneto coupling in a piston engine is to retard the spark during the engine starting via the spring-loaded clutch mechanism
As soon as the engine starts rotating, the drive spindle winds up the spring-loaded clutch so that when the clutch is released, the spring unwinds rapidly which in turn rapidly spins the magneto
learning.explanation: The impulse magneto coupling consists of a spring-loaded clutch mounted between the drive spindle from the engine and the magneto shaft. The main purpose of the impulse magneto coupling in a piston engine is to retard the spark during the engine starting via the spring-loaded clutch mechanism. As soon as the engine starts rotating, the drive spindle winds up the spring-loaded clutch so that when the clutch is released, the spring unwinds rapidly which in turn rapidly spins the magneto. The rapid clutch release takes place every half revolution of the engine and provides a stronger spark at the Top Dead Center for engine starting. After the engine has started, pawls within the mechanism move out under centrifugal force to prevent the coupling from operating.

content.question: For piston engines, mixture ratio is the ratio between the…

options.A: mass of fuel and mass of air entering the cylinder.
options.B: mass of fuel and volume of air entering the carburettor.
options.C: volume of fuel and volume of air entering the carburettor.
options.D: volume of fuel and volume of air entering the cylinder.

key_points: In a piston engine, the mixture ratio is the ratio between the mass of fuel and mass of air entering the cylinder (NOT volume)
The mixture is controlled by adjusting the fuel flow only, as for standard reciprocating engines (with no turbo/supercharger) the air entering the cylinders cannot be directly controlled
This is why in order to maintain a constant air/fuel ratio with increasing altitude, the fuel flow will be reduced
learning.explanation: In a piston engine, the mixture ratio is the ratio between the mass of fuel and mass of air entering the cylinder (NOT volume). The mixture is controlled by adjusting the fuel flow only, as for standard reciprocating engines (with no turbo/supercharger) the air entering the cylinders cannot be directly controlled. This is why in order to maintain a constant air/fuel ratio with increasing altitude, the fuel flow will be reduced. This will compensate for the decreasing air density with increasing altitude. You always need to climb with a fully rich mixture because this will provide you adequate cooling and will lower the cylinder head temperature. In fact, since the forward speed of the airplane is not high enough to collect enough air for engine cooling, the extra (unburnt) fuel will be the main cooling element during climb segments.

content.question: The first indication of carburettor icing on an aeroplane with a piston engine and a constant speed propeller during cruise is…

options.A: loss of manifold pressure.
options.B: increase in manifold pressure.
options.C: decrease in RPM.
options.D: abnormal cylinder head temperature.

key_points: When ice is building up in the carburetor the venturi duct is narrowing and increases the effects of the venturi tube (further decrease in pressure and temperature)
The dynamic pressure flowing through the tube increases the ice build-up as the venturi-shaped icy duct sees a decrease in temperature and static pressure
This is also the reason why the first indication of ice build-up is going to be a decrease in manifold pressure (=static pressure)
learning.explanation: When ice is building up in the carburetor the venturi duct is narrowing and increases the effects of the venturi tube (further decrease in pressure and temperature). The dynamic pressure flowing through the tube increases the ice build-up as the venturi-shaped icy duct sees a decrease in temperature and static pressure. This is also the reason why the first indication of ice build-up is going to be a decrease in manifold pressure (=static pressure). Therefore, as soon as the carburetor heating is turned on, the ice buildup will melt, and the duct will see an increase in static pressure (=manifold pressure). Obviously, this will be only observed on an airplane fitted with a piston engine and a constant speed propeller since there’s no MAP gauge in a fixed-pitch propeller. In a fixed-pitch propeller, only a drop in RPM will be observed.

However, if you ever experience detonation during flight, the following corrective action should be carried: Reduce the manifold pressure (= retard the throttle) Fully enrich the mixture.

content.question: Consider a fuel injection system. Which is the central point from where fuel is distributed to the individual cylinders?

options.A: Manifold valve
options.B: Fuel pump selecator valve
options.C: Discharge nozzle
options.D: Injection valve

key_points: Fuel injection systems are one where fuel gets pressurized by an engine driven pump and/or an electric pump and then injected either directly into the cylinder or the intake
As opposed to engines fed by a carburetor which uses pressure as a means to mix the fuel with the air
As you can see in the diagram, the fuel first passes from the tanks through the pumps, then the flow proceeds to be controlled by the throttle and mixture control
learning.explanation: Fuel injection systems are one where fuel gets pressurized by an engine driven pump and/or an electric pump and then injected either directly into the cylinder or the intake. As opposed to engines fed by a carburetor which uses pressure as a means to mix the fuel with the air. As you can see in the diagram, the fuel first passes from the tanks through the pumps, then the flow proceeds to be controlled by the throttle and mixture control. After this the fuel continues to the manifold valve where it gets sent to all the different cylinders. The other answers are incorrect: “Fuel pump selector valve”: this is a valve that is located before the fuel pumps, and is responsible for allowing the flow to go to either the engine driven and/or the electric pump. Therefore it has no role in sending the fuel to the cylinders. “Discharge nozzle”: this is the nozzle that sprays the fuel into the intake/cylinder. It is responsible for mixing the fuel with the air for efficient combustion. “Injection valve”: these are valves mounted before the discharge nozzle to provide positive back pressure and prevent backflow.

key_points: The major components of a piston engine are: Cylinder and cylinder’s head – consisting of a gas-tight barrel and a head assembled together
Usually, the barrel is made of steel and is fitted with fins that will help to disperse heat, whereas the head is made of alloy
Spark plugs – there’re usually two plugs per cylinder for redundancy and for more uniform combustion on either side of the cylinder to improve combustion efficiency
learning.explanation: The major components of a piston engine are: Cylinder and cylinder’s head – consisting of a gas-tight barrel and a head assembled together. Usually, the barrel is made of steel and is fitted with fins that will help to disperse heat, whereas the head is made of alloy. Spark plugs – there’re usually two plugs per cylinder for redundancy and for more uniform combustion on either side of the cylinder to improve combustion efficiency. Pistons – made of aluminum alloy and consisting of the head (top part) and the ‘skirt’ (lower part. It is carefully designed to improve its efficiency and safe operation – it has compression rings that prevent the gases from escaping toward the lower part of the cylinder and oil control rings to ensure oil is spread evenly all over the inner surface of the cylinder. Connecting rod – stiff ‘H’ shaped important element that connects the piston to the crankshaft by means of a hinged axle. Crankshaft - a linear assembly consisting of rotary components that will convert the piston’s linear movement into a rotary movement transmitted to the propeller. Among others, you could find the following components in a crankshaft: the crank web, the crankpin, the journal, and the balance weights. Camshaft - a shaft containing several attached disks of irregular shape that operate the intake and exhaust valves Crankcase – it is the structural ‘box’ within which the engine is located. It serves as a mounting point for the cylinders, the accessory gearbox, the engine. It is carefully designed to lubricate itself and all the related components (bearings, pistons, etc.) via its numerous internal passages. Usually, it is made of a strong alloy such as magnesium.

key_points: The impulse magneto coupling consists of a spring-loaded clutch mounted between the drive spindle from the engine and the magneto shaft
The main purpose of the impulse magneto coupling in a piston engine is to retard the spark during engine starting via the spring-loaded clutch mechanism
As soon as the engine starts rotating, the drive spindle winds up the spring-loaded clutch so that when the clutch is released, the spring unwinds rapidly which in turn rapidly spins the magneto
learning.explanation: The impulse magneto coupling consists of a spring-loaded clutch mounted between the drive spindle from the engine and the magneto shaft. The main purpose of the impulse magneto coupling in a piston engine is to retard the spark during engine starting via the spring-loaded clutch mechanism. As soon as the engine starts rotating, the drive spindle winds up the spring-loaded clutch so that when the clutch is released, the spring unwinds rapidly which in turn rapidly spins the magneto. The rapid clutch release takes place every half revolution of the engine and provides a stronger spark at the Top Dead Center for engine starting. After the engine has started, pawls within the mechanism move out under centrifugal force to prevent the coupling from operating.

learning.explanation: DRY-SUMP LUBRIFICATION SYSTEMS Many reciprocating and turbine aircraft engines have dry sump lubrication systems. The oil supply in this type of system is carried in a tank. It includes a stack pipe at the bottom of the tank which will supply the main feed system via a pressure pump which will then circulate the oil through the engine. Scavenger pumps then return it to the tank as quickly as it accumulates in the engine sumps. A second stack pipe is generally fitted at the bottom of the tank to supply and emergency supply system. content.question: Apart from flight into known icing conditions, the intake system of a diesel engine…

options.A: is never heated because diesel engines operate at very high temperatures.
options.B: needs to be heated to prevent ice on the air filter.
options.C: needs to be heated at low power settings, due to vaporisation heat.
options.D: is never heated because a diesel engine is a injection engine.

key_points: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture
For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs

The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder
learning.explanation: Diesel engines are sometimes labeled as ‘compression ignition’ engines as it uses the heat generated during the compression stroke to ignite the mixture. For this reason, diesel engines are not fitted with spark plugs and are not heated (except in icing conditions) and require less maintenance and spare parts which ultimately reduces costs. The mixture creation is also different from the standard petrol engines as the diesel engines use direct fuel injection systems to mix the fuel and the air in a pre-chamber before supplying it to the cylinder. The fuel injection system consists of atomizers that will spray the fuel into the pre-chamber, but because not all the fuel droplets burn completely, residual soot will remain in the cylinder. To produce enough heat for the mixture to ignite, the diesel engines operate at a much higher compression ratios than the normal petrol engine: from 14:1 up to 28:1 for the most powerful compared to 9:1 for a petrol engine. Because of this high compression ratio, diesel engines also benefit from a higher thermal efficiency. The amount of power delivered will only be determined by the fuel flow. In the same way as for car engines, diesel engines are less powerful than a petrol engine for the same swept volume.

content.question: Which of the following is the safest way to prime a piston engine for start-up?

options.A: Pumping the throttle a few times.
options.B: Injecting fuel straight into the inlet valves.
options.C: Injecting fuel straight onto the sparkplugs.
options.D: Excercising the carburretor heat during start.

key_points: Starting a piston engine (especially on a cold day with a cold engine) can be difficult
It requires the input of the correct mixture of fuel and air into the cylinders
Too much fuel, the mixture will be too rich to start (flooded engine); too little fuel and there is not enough fuel to burn, and the aircraft will not start
learning.explanation: Starting a piston engine (especially on a cold day with a cold engine) can be difficult. It requires the input of the correct mixture of fuel and air into the cylinders. Too much fuel, the mixture will be too rich to start (flooded engine); too little fuel and there is not enough fuel to burn, and the aircraft will not start. The perfect ratio of Fuel : Air is approximately 15:1 (by mass). Priming an engine is a way to enrich the mixture for start, by firing atomised fuel directly into the cylinder intake valve area. The best way to do this is by using a fitted primer system. This is a hand operated pump that bypasses the standard aircraft carburettor, and the pilot can decide how much fuel to add directly into the cylinders, by how many pumps of the primer they decide to do. Too few, and the engine might not have enough fuel to start; too many and the cylinders will become flooded and cause a large risk of fire during start. Another way to "prime" an engine is to exercise the throttle prior to engine start. This uses the "accelerator pump" inside the carburettor (made to stop the engine getting too lean if full power is applied suddenly) to pump some fuel into the carburettor box. This can be effective on a lot of engines, but it is much less safe and effective than the dedicated primer pump, as the fuel is not atomised as well, and is not in the engine at all, in fact, it is often quite a distance before (and much below) the intake valves of the engine. This means that it requires airflow through the carburettor during start to pull the extra fuel up into the engine, and there is chance of backfiring due to the high amount of fuel sat in the carburettor. It could also lead to over-priming by using this technique, as only a small amount of the fuel is atomised, and the rest forms puddles in the carburettor box. To address the other options, the primer does not spray fuel directly onto the spark plugs, it atomises it just behind the intake valve of one or more cylinders (this is the best place to put the fuel for immediate entry to the correct cylinders). Carburettor heat will not help with this, as there is no heat to make the air different from normal, and the carburettor heat should not be used in excess on the ground due to the lack of sufficient air filter.

content.question: A piston engine may use a fuel of a different grade than the recommended…

options.A: never
options.B: provided that it is an aeronautical petrol
options.C: provided that the grade is lower
options.D: provided that the grade is higher

key_points: Airplanes’ piston engines are reciprocating engines, similar to your car’s engine, with the difference that they use special aviation fuel to run
However, a failure of an airplane engine due to fuel issues can be potentially fatal, so safety dictates that aviation fuel must conform to very stringent requirements
It is made of various selected grades of gasoline, combined to give high anti-knock ratings
learning.explanation: Airplanes’ piston engines are reciprocating engines, similar to your car’s engine, with the difference that they use special aviation fuel to run. However, a failure of an airplane engine due to fuel issues can be potentially fatal, so safety dictates that aviation fuel must conform to very stringent requirements. It is made of various selected grades of gasoline, combined to give high anti-knock ratings. The octane rating of a fuel indicates its resistance to detonation. The use of too low octane gasoline in a piston engine will increase the chances of detonation. However, using fuel with a higher-octane grade is perfectly normal provided it is designed to take advantage of a higher-grade fuel. In fact, using a higher-grade fuel in a low-performance engine will not benefit you as this may cause fouling of the cylinders and eventual mechanical failure. For your general knowledge, the octane rating is based on the knock resistance difference between two spirits, iso-octane (which is very good) and heptane (very poor). By degrading iso-octane with heptane until the blend detonated in a variable compression engine under the same standard conditions as the fuel under test, it was possible to classify that fuel by a number representing the percentage of iso-octane in the test mixture. In this way, 89-octane fuel corresponded to a mixture of 89% iso-octane and 11% heptane.

content.question:
Which of the following statements are correct, with regards to a dry sump oil system in comparison to a wet sump system?
1. Temperature control is more difficult in a dry sump system
2. The oil quantity in a dry sump system depends on the external oil reservoir

options.A: 1 is correct; 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 and 2 are both correct.
options.C: 1 is incorrect; 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 and 2 are both incorrect.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.04: State the differences between a wet- and a dry-sump lubrication system and their advantages and disadvantages. A dry sump engine is one where the oil is not allowed to sit in the engine sump for too long, and is instead "scavenged" back to a separate reservoir. This is the opposite of a "wet sump" engine, where the sump (within the engine casing) is the reservoir, and a lot less systems are required, but with reduced engine power due to energy losses, and inability to perform many aerobatic manoeuvres. With a dry sump engine, the oil enters from the "external" reservoir, where it is stored when not at work in the engine, via a pressure pump, getting it up to a suitable pressure to spray inside the engine. The oil then lubricates, cools and cleans the engine components, finally ending up at the bottom of the engine, where it gathers in the sump, and is collected up by a scavenge pump, which returns it to the reservoir. The oil is often quite aerated and foamy by this point, so is less dense, and the scavenge pump needs a larger volume to cope with this oil, and not let it mount up in the sump. In comparison to the wet sump system, dry sump oil systems have: Better control of cooling, as the oil does not have to stay sat in the bottom of the hot engine; The ability to perform aerobatics and keep the engine correctly oiled; Less oil oxidation and contamination; higher capacity for oil, as it limited by the external reservoir, which can be made larger than the engine sump.

content.question: The use of too low octane gasoline in a piston engine would cause…

options.A: excessive low cylinder head temperature.
options.B: fouled plugs.
options.C: detonation.
options.D: no difference except at high RPM.

key_points: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that it ignites spontaneously at an early stage of the power stroke
In fact, the rate of pressure rise will occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to move downwards
Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat
learning.explanation: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that it ignites spontaneously at an early stage of the power stroke. In fact, the rate of pressure rise will occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to move downwards. Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat. The cylinder walls, the piston’s head, the sparking plugs and the exhaust valves are being hardly damaged when detonation occurs as this will cause a sudden knock. The conditions in which detonation is most likely in a piston engine are a high manifold pressure leading to a high cylinder head temperature and low RPM. The risk of detonation can be reduced by: First of all, always using the correct grade of fuel designed for your aircraft’s engine. Using a too low octane rating will greatly increase the likelihood of detonation. Making sure the proper mixture is being supplied to the engine in any conditions. The greater the amount of fuel for a given amount of air, the greater the power that can be obtained without detonation. Avoid situations where the temperature and pressure of the mixture raise before it burns, such as applying carburetor heating at high power settings (takeoff/climb). However, if you ever experience detonation during flight, the following corrective action should be carried: Reduce the manifold pressure (= retard the throttle) Fully enrich the mixture.

content.question: In a piston engine, if the ground wire between one of the magnetos and the ignition switch becomes disconnected, the most noticeable result will be that the engine…

options.A: cannot be started with the switch in the ON position.
options.B: will run but maximum power will be unobtainable.
options.C: cannot be shut down by turning the switch to the OFF position.
options.D: will run but the faulty magneto will be earthed out.

key_points: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs
This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke
Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch
learning.explanation: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs. This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke. Each magneto is controlled by its own ignition switch. The switch isolates the magneto’s ignition circuit by connecting the circuit to Earth. In order to completely switch off the ignition system, the primary circuit needs to be grounded. In this condition, it is said to be ‘grounded’. However, if the grounding wire is broken, the magneto will keep working normally and the engine will continue running. Another situation where the engine can keep running is when excessive carbon deposit has formed in the cylinder head. Because the deposit is still hot enough when you arrive at your parking position after the flight in order to ignite the charge without the spark from the plugs. The effects will be a hardly rumbling engine that is still running.

content.question:
Which of the following will you find in a "wet sump" lubrication system?
1. Pressure pump
2. Separate oil reservoir
3. Scavenge pump
4. Integrated oil reservoir

options.A: 1 and 4
options.B: 1, 2 and 3
options.C: 2 and 3
options.D: 3 and 4

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.06.02.03: Describe a wet-sump lubrication system. There are two main types of oil system for engines, dry-sump and wet-sump. The biggest difference between the two is where the oil is stored when not in use. In a dry-sump system, the used oil is pumped from the bottom of the engine to the oil reservoir. In a wet-sump system, the oil is stored in the "sump", which is just the area at the bottom of the engine, where the oil naturally drains to. For this question then, that means that a pressure pump is still required (to take the oil out of the sump and spray it into the correct engine locations) as well as the integrated oil reservoir, which is just the sump itself, as it is both a sump and the oil reservoir, "integrated" into the engine block. The separate oil reservoir and scavenge pump are therefore not required (they are dry sump items).

content.question: If detonation occurs in a normally aspirated piston engine during climb-out, the normal corrective action is to…

options.A: lean the mixture.
options.B: increase the rate of climb.
options.C: partially close cowling flaps.
options.D: retard the throttle.

key_points: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that they ignite spontaneously at an earlier stage than they should do during the power stroke
In fact, the rate of pressure rise will sometimes occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to be forced downwards
Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat
learning.explanation: Detonation is when unburnt parts of the mixture reach such a high temperature that they ignite spontaneously at an earlier stage than they should do during the power stroke. In fact, the rate of pressure rise will sometimes occur too early in the power stroke for the piston to be forced downwards. Therefore, most of the chemical energy created will be wasted as heat. The cylinder walls, the piston head, the sparking plugs, and the exhaust valves are put under a sudden "shock load" when detonation occurs, and this will sound like a knocking inside the engine. Detonation puts an engine under intense shock loading which can quite quickly cause engine failures. The conditions in which detonation is most likely in a piston engine are a high manifold pressure, high cylinder head temperature and low RPM. The risk of detonation can be reduced by: First of all, always using the correct grade of fuel designed for your aircraft’s engine. Using a too low octane rating will greatly increase the likelihood of detonation. The octane is actually a measure of detonation resistance, higher octane fuel will detonate less readily. Making sure the proper mixture is being supplied to the engine in any conditions. The greater the amount of fuel for a given amount of air, the greater the power that can be obtained without detonation. This is primarily due to the extra cooling effect of excess fuel. Avoid situations where the temperature and pressure of the mixture raise before it burns, such as applying carburettor heating at high power settings (take-off/climb). However, if you ever experience detonation during flight, the following corrective action should be carried: Reduce the manifold pressure (the action is to retard the throttle) Fully enrich the mixture. Of course, retarding the throttle seems counterintuitive during the climb, especially with an engine problem, but detonation is really inefficient and could cause an engine failure, so it is better to retard the throttle slightly until detonation stops, allowing a climb, albeit at a shallower gradient (rather than no climb at all). Also, it is useful to increase airspeed to allow better cooling of the engine.

content.question: The operating principle of float-type carburettors is based on the…

options.A: difference in air pressure at the venturi throat and the air inlet
options.B: increase in air velocity in the throat of a venturi causing an increase in air pressure
options.C: automatic metering of air at the venturi as the aircraft gains altitude
options.D: measurement of the fuel flow into the induction system

key_points: The operating principle of float-type carburetors is based on Bernoulli’s theorem which states that the energy per unit mass of a moving fluid is constant
As the air passes through the convergence of the Venturi duct, its velocity increases causing a drop in pressure and temperature
The pressure will drop proportionally to the mass airflow and is used to make fuel flow from the float chamber by placing a ‘U’-shaped jet into the Venturi
learning.explanation: The operating principle of float-type carburetors is based on Bernoulli’s theorem which states that the energy per unit mass of a moving fluid is constant. As the air passes through the convergence of the Venturi duct, its velocity increases causing a drop in pressure and temperature. The pressure will drop proportionally to the mass airflow and is used to make fuel flow from the float chamber by placing a ‘U’-shaped jet into the Venturi. Engine suction creates a difference in air pressure at the throat of the Venturi duct and the air inlet resulting in a sucking effect. Besides the drop in pressure and temperature at the Venturi’s throat, the latter will increase again within the induction manifold as the throttle is opened.

In many aircraft, FADEC uses power from a separate generator connected to the engine

In many aircraft, FADEC uses power from a separate generator connected to the engine. In either case, there must be a backup electrical source available because failure of a FADEC system could result in a complete loss of engine thrust. content.question: For internal cooling, reciprocating engines are especially dependent on…

options.A: a lean fuel/air mixture
options.B: a rich fuel/air mixture
options.C: a properly functioning thermostat
options.D: the circulation of lubricating oil

key_points: The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts
It is also used as a substance to clean the interior of the engine and accumulate the deposits gathered along the way for removal
Piston engines are very dependent on their lubrication oil
learning.explanation: The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts. It is also used as a substance to clean the interior of the engine and accumulate the deposits gathered along the way for removal. Piston engines are very dependent on their lubrication oil. Serious damage will occur quickly through overheating (and eventually fire) or failure of the lubrication system; therefore, the limitations should be strictly observed. Frequent checks should be made of the oil temperature and pressure, and the power should be adjusted when necessary to keep them within limits. Lubrication oil is the most predominant cooling component of the engine’s internal parts because, without it, friction between metallic parts will immediately spark a fire considering the immense rotational speeds.

content.question:
Consider two twin-engine airplanes:
Airplane 1 has clockwise-rotating propellers.
Airplane 2 has inward-rotating propellers.
If, on both airplanes, the left engine fails, which will give the largest yawing moment, and from which side will it be?

options.A: Airplane 1 will have the greatest yaw moment, and it will produce a yaw to the right.
options.B: Airplane 1 will have the greatest yaw moment, and it will produce a yaw to the left.
options.C: Airplane 2 will have the greatest yaw moment, and it will produce a yaw to the right.
options.D: Airplane 2 will have the greatest yaw moment, and it will produce a yaw to the left.

key_points: Note: This is a Principles of Flight question that has been reported as seen in AGK recently
That is all we know at the moment, but it should not be seen in this subject, as it is not on the learning objectives

Please let us know if you see it or any similar questions in your AGK exam, thank you! When an engine fails on a multi-engine aircraft, there will be a decrease in thrust and an increase in drag on the side of the failed engine
learning.explanation: Note: This is a Principles of Flight question that has been reported as seen in AGK recently. That is all we know at the moment, but it should not be seen in this subject, as it is not on the learning objectives. Please let us know if you see it or any similar questions in your AGK exam, thank you! When an engine fails on a multi-engine aircraft, there will be a decrease in thrust and an increase in drag on the side of the failed engine. Primarily there will be a yawing moment towards the failed (dead) engine. The critical engine is the engine which would give the biggest yawing moment if it fails. One of the factors influencing the yawing moment following an engine failure on a multi-engine aircraft is the length of the thrust arm (i.e., distance from the aircraft's CG to the thrust line of the operating engine). In case of a propeller engine aircraft, the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller. When the aircraft is flying with a positive angle of attack (which is normal), the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller (when viewed from the rear) is displaced to the right of the engine centre line. This is because the down-going blade generates more thrust than the up-going blade (P-factor). If both engines rotate clockwise, the starboard (right) engine will have a longer thrust arm than the port (left) engine. If the left engine fails, the thrust of the right engine acts through a longer thrust arm and will give a larger yawing moment. If both engines rotate inward, they will have the same (shorter) thrust arm (counter-rotating propellers). Of course, no matter the direction of the propellers, a failure of the left engine will always produce a yaw to the left, it is just bigger if the aircraft has clockwise rotation propellers.
