key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.03: Power-augmentation devices: explain the requirement for power augmentation (turbocharging) of a piston engine. Learning Objective 021.10.10.01.04: Describe the function and the principle of operation of the following main components of a turbocharger: turbine; compressor; waste gate; waste-gate actuator. Piston Engines can have their power increased in three main ways, by increasing the size of the engine (displacement), increasing the RPM, or increasing the pressure of the air/fuel mixture (called the Manifold Absolute Pressure, MAP). This last case is why we might use a turbocharger in our car engines, so we can have a small, efficient engine, with extra power available from a turbocharger (which compresses the intake air) when needed. Turbochargers are arguably even more useful in aircraft, where piston engines become less powerful in the thinner air at higher altitudes. This is where turbochargers can compress that air, to make the engine operate with the same power output it would do at a much lower altitude. We call this an "altitude boosted" turbocharger. They are more useful to us by keeping the same power up to higher altitudes, rather than giving us lots more power on the ground, which would put a lot of strain on the engine, which would be a "ground boosted" turbocharger. Turbochargers (and any superchargers, really) increase the amount of air (and therefore fuel) we can ignite in the cylinders, and are measured by the MAP; the higher the MAP, the more air/fuel mixture we can burn in each power stroke. A turbocharger works by using the excess speed and pressure of the exhaust gasses to spin a turbine, which then directly spins a compressor, which compresses the fresh intake air ready for mixing with fuel and then entry into the cylinders (or sent straight into the cylinders where fuel injection takes place). All superchargers compress fresh intake air like this, but turbochargers are special types of superchargers that use the excess energy leftover in the exhaust gasses that we would not otherwise use. The turbochargers we talk about are controlled by waste-gates, which decide how much exhaust gas to divert to the turbine; if the MAP is too low (for what has been asked for), then the waste-gate will send more air to the turbine to get a faster spinning compressor, and vice-versa. The movement of the waste-gate is powered by oil pressure which is cleverly controlled by a system that measures the MAP and makes changes to the wastegate position accordingly.

content.question: With regard to piston engines, once the engine has started, the ignition system is…

options.A: dependent on the AC generator.
options.B: dependent on the DC generator.
options.C: independent of the aircraft`s electrical system.
options.D: dependent on the battery.

key_points: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs
This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke

In order to break the gap between the sparking plug electrodes, the magnetos consist of a rotating permanent magnet surrounded by a U-shaped stator of soft iron, around which a thick primary and a thin secondary winding can be found
learning.explanation: A magneto is a self-contained, engine-driven electrical generator designed to supply a high voltage to the sparking plugs. This is achieved in a timely sequence for a precise compression stroke. In order to break the gap between the sparking plug electrodes, the magnetos consist of a rotating permanent magnet surrounded by a U-shaped stator of soft iron, around which a thick primary and a thin secondary winding can be found. The thick winding (primary) is the low-tension element of the circuit and consists only of a few turns of thick wire. Whereas the thin winding (secondary) is the high-tension element of the circuit consisting of numerous thin windings that act as a step-up transformer. As a consequence of this arrangement, any electrical current in the primary circuit (thick winding) will induce a higher voltage in the secondary winding. Both windings will be supplied with alternating current from the permanent set of magnetos as they’re driven by the engine. Another important aspect you need to understand in the principle of magnetos operation is that the primary winding will be continuously broken and then restored by a contact breaker. The contact will be broken by a permanently rotating breaker cam which main task is to break the primary circuit. The reason why we need the primary circuit to get broken is that this will create a collapse in the primary’s winding magnetic field that will produce an increase in energy in the secondary winding. The second reason is that the normal AC produced in the primary winding will be converted into a series of pulses. The general outcome of this sequence of actions will result in a series of very high voltage, low current pulses of electricity that will be fed to a distributor. Distributor’s task will be then to spread these pulses through a high-tension leads to the spark-plugs.

key_points: The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts
It is also used as a substance to clean the interior of the engine and accumulate the deposits gathered along the way for removal
Piston engines are very dependent on their lubrication oil
learning.explanation: The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts. It is also used as a substance to clean the interior of the engine and accumulate the deposits gathered along the way for removal. Piston engines are very dependent on their lubrication oil. Serious damage will occur quickly through overheating (and eventually fire) or failure of the lubrication system; therefore, the limitations should be strictly observed. Frequent checks should be made of the oil temperature and pressure, and the power should be adjusted when necessary to keep them within limits.

content.question: Consider a climb with a piston engine aeroplane. What will happen to the fuel flow if the pilot maintains the same power setting?

options.A: The temperature decreases and thereby compensates for the decreasing air density which is caused by the decreasing pressure. Therefore the fuel flow remains the same.
options.B: The temperature decreases and thereby over-compensates for the decreasing air density which is caused by the decreasing pressure. This results in a decreasing fuel flow.
options.C: With increasing altitude air density decreases and the power output of the engine decreases. This has to be compensated for by an increased fuel flow.
options.D: With increasing altitude air density decreases, therefore less fuel is required for combustion, so the fuel flow decreases.

key_points: As altitude increases, the air density decreases, which means there is less oxygen available for combustion
Therefore, less fuel is required to maintain a constant power output
So, the fuel flow will decrease, not increase
learning.explanation: As altitude increases, the air density decreases, which means there is less oxygen available for combustion. Therefore, less fuel is required to maintain a constant power output. So, the fuel flow will decrease, not increase. Increasing the fuel flow in an effort to compensate for the decrease in air density would result in an over-rich mixture and potentially cause engine damage. What exactly do they mean by “maintaining the same power setting”? We believe it is referring to the amount of power the pilot is requesting from the engine, not the actual power output of the engine. In order to maintain the same power setting, the pilot will likely have to lean the mixture (decrease the fuel flow) to compensate for the decrease in air density at higher altitude. So, even though the pilot is requesting the same amount of power, the engine will produce less power due to the decrease in air density, and the fuel flow will decrease to match the decrease in oxygen available. Note: We are deciding that "power setting" means constant RPM/MAP for this question. Please let us know if you come across this question in your official exam.

content.question: For a piston engine, specific fuel consumption is defined as the…

options.B: designed fuel consumption for a given RPM.
options.C: quantity of fuel required to run the engine for one minute at maximum operating conditions.
options.D: maximum fuel consumption of the aircraft.

key_points: The Specific Fuel Consumption is the mass of fuel required to produce a unit horsepower per unit time
In other words, it is the ratio of fuel used in kg/hour per kN thrust or kW of shaft power
This variable is related to the thermal and propulsive efficiency of any given engine
learning.explanation: The Specific Fuel Consumption is the mass of fuel required to produce a unit horsepower per unit time. In other words, it is the ratio of fuel used in kg/hour per kN thrust or kW of shaft power. This variable is related to the thermal and propulsive efficiency of any given engine. The ideal engine would produce as much power as possible for a minimum of weight of fuel burnt.

content.question: A multi-engine piston aircraft both the propellers rotate clockwise as seen from the cockpit. In a go-around, one of the engines fails. Which of the following situations will most probably need the pilot to use full rudder deflection?

options.A: Left engine failure, left crosswind.
options.B: Left engine failure, right crosswind.
options.C: Right engine failure, left crosswind.
options.D: Right engine failure, right crosswind.

key_points: For a propeller aircraft the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller

At a positive angle of attack and when viewed from the rear, the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller is displaced to the right of the engine centre line because the down going blade generates more thrust than the up going blade
Therefore, if both engines rotate clockwise, the right engine will have a longer thrust arm than the left engine
learning.explanation: For a propeller aircraft the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller. At a positive angle of attack and when viewed from the rear, the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller is displaced to the right of the engine centre line because the down going blade generates more thrust than the up going blade. Therefore, if both engines rotate clockwise, the right engine will have a longer thrust arm than the left engine. Thus, if the left engine fails, the thrust of the right engine acts through a longer thrust arm and will give a bigger yawing moment. The critical engine is the engine, the failure of which would give the biggest yawing moment. Consequently, we can safely say that with clockwise rotating propellers, the critical engine is the left one. The aircraft has the natural tendency to swing its nose into the wind in response to a sideslip (left wind results in left yaw). This will add to the already existent tendency to yaw towards the left due to the left engine failure and will increase the difficulty to control and the need for a larger rudder deflection. Note: This question was reported for AGK, however it should not appear in this subject. We would kindly ask that you inform us if you come across this question in your AGK/PoF exam.

An engine is composed of several cylinders and the volume is calculated by multiplying the area and the length together
When speaking about the cylinder’s motion, the area we need to consider is the piston’s area and the length is the linear length from TDC to BDC the piston is traveling (stroke)
learning.explanation: The displacement of a cylinder corresponds to the volume of air a piston is ‘moving’ during its linear translation. learning.explanation: The Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) lives up to its name by possessing complete authority over the engine's operation. FADEC then assumes control, utilizing your inputs along with data from various other sources to manage throttle settings, fuel flow, ignition timing, valve timing, and, if the engine is powered by gasoline, the air-fuel mixture ratio. FADEC connects the flight crew inputs to the engine via a digital control interface, reducing pilot workload and optimising engine performance.

options.A: volume
options.B: temperature
options.C: energy
options.D: pressure

key_points: A gas turbine engine is basically a heat engine using air as a fluid to produce thrust
The working principle of the gas turbine engine is comparable to that of a piston engine as both engines use a cycle made of induction, compression, combustion, and exhaust phases
The only difference is the way these phases will be achieved as the gas turbine engine is capable of dealing with much larger amounts of energy for a given size and weight
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine is basically a heat engine using air as a fluid to produce thrust. The working principle of the gas turbine engine is comparable to that of a piston engine as both engines use a cycle made of induction, compression, combustion, and exhaust phases. The only difference is the way these phases will be achieved as the gas turbine engine is capable of dealing with much larger amounts of energy for a given size and weight. The other great advantage of the gas turbine engine is that the whole working cycle is continuous and entirely rotational providing an overall smoother operation, whereas the piston engine uses an intermittent reciprocating motion which is converted to rotary motion by means of cranks. Summary: Piston engine -Process is intermittent -Combustion is at constant volume Jet engine -Process is continuous -Combustion is at constant pressure.

content.question: Which of the following can be used to start an APU?

options.A: Hydraulic pressure from the ram air turbine.
options.B: Ground power from an external unit.
options.C: Pneumatic air from gas bottles.
options.D: Pneumatic pressure from the ram air turbine.

key_points: An APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) is a small jet engine in the back of most large transport jet aircraft

It is used for "auxiliary" purposes, mostly on the ground, such as running the air conditioning system, pressurising the hydraulic system and most importantly, providing an air source to start the main engines when a GPU (Ground Power Unit) is not available

A ground power unit (GPU) is an external unit that provides either electricity to an aircraft (so it does not need to use its own batteries) or a pneumatic air source for air conditioning and starting engines
learning.explanation: An APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) is a small jet engine in the back of most large transport jet aircraft. It is used for "auxiliary" purposes, mostly on the ground, such as running the air conditioning system, pressurising the hydraulic system and most importantly, providing an air source to start the main engines when a GPU (Ground Power Unit) is not available. A ground power unit (GPU) is an external unit that provides either electricity to an aircraft (so it does not need to use its own batteries) or a pneumatic air source for air conditioning and starting engines. Jet engines require quite a lot of initial engine input to start up, as the compressors need to spinning quite rapidly to allow stable continuous combustion. There are two main ways to provide this energy, air starting and electrical. Air starting utilises the pneumatic supply in an aircraft, which is usually the most powerful system. This is the reason than most aircraft main engines can only be air started. Electrical starting requires a powerful, very fast spinning starter motor (and a lot of available electricity), so is usually only able to start the much smaller APU engine. There is an exception to this rule, the Boeing 787 actually has such a powerful electrical system, it also uses electrical starting for its main engines. Specifically for APUs, they are meant to be used to start the main engines when a GPU is not available, meaning that they need to be able to start themselves off the aircraft's stored energy alone. Therefore, the APU must be able to start off batteries only, if required. The APU can also be started off GPU electricity, as not to drain the on-board batteries. Air starting of the APU depends on the aircraft. The Boeing 737 can only electrically start its APU, but the Boeing 777 is capable of starting its APU from electricity (from GPU or Battery) and also air-starting (from GPU or main engine bleed-air). The RAT (ram air turbine) is a little wind turbine that drops out of the aircraft to provide hydraulic pressure and even electricity if there are no other electrical or hydraulic sources available on the aircraft. This is to use essential items such as the flight controls in case of a multiple engine and electrical failure. It is not nearly powerful enough to start an engine, and the APU is also not hydraulically started anyway.

content.question:
Which statement is correct about the flow in a divergent jet engine inlet?
1. The speed increases in flow direction
2. The total pressure increases in flow direction

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.D: Both 1 and 2 are correct.

key_points: Both statements are incorrect
The intake geometry is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect
It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed
learning.explanation: Both statements are incorrect. The intake geometry is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect. It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed. That’s why the intake is slightly divergent in order to reduce the airflow’s velocity (=dynamic pressure) and increase the static pressure and temperature just before the fan and compressor’s first stages. Caution, the total pressure (and temperature) will remain constant - it is only a trade of dynamic pressure for static pressure. Compression (=increase in static pressure) is a process where heat is released, which explains why the temperature behaves in the same way through a divergent duct as pressure. This geometry is also called the ‘pitot intake’, and it has thick, smoothly rounded lips to prevent flow separation under any flight conditions/maneuvers.

It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent flow separation
That’s why most of the time it is converging so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher thrust
learning.explanation: The propelling nozzle directs the exhaust gas aft and regulates the gas streamflow. It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent flow separation. That’s why most of the time it is converging so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher thrust. The acceleration of the flow by the propelling nozzle can somehow disturb the airflow, so it is positioned at a distance from the jet pipe where the disturbances won’t cause flow separation.

content.question: One of the main functions of inlet guide vanes in gas turbine engines is to...

options.A: prevent turbine stalls during low engine RPM.
options.B: prevent compressor stalls during high engine RPM.
options.C: prevent turbine stalls during engine acceleration and deceleration.
options.D: prevent compressor stalls during engine acceleration and deceleration.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.02.02.11: State the tasks of inlet guide vanes (IGVs). Axial gas turbine engine compressors are made up of a set of spinning compressor blades and static "stator vanes". They direct a complex dance of very accurately placed airflow, and have the job of increasing pressure gradually, but over many stages, until the pressure is many times higher than ambient. Similar to a wing or propeller blade, the incoming airflow onto each blade matters a lot, and each blade has an optimum angle of attack, as well as less-than optimum angles of attack, and stalled angles of attack. The angle of attack is based on the incoming airflow and the rotational speed of that section of blade. If a blade section stalls, then it is no longer able to accomplish its job of increasing the pressure, and it can have a knock-on effect onto other blades and the later stages of the compressor. Compressor stalls are most common at low RPM and during engine RPM changes, so acceleration and deceleration. Eventually, if this disrupts enough blades, the whole airflow within the engine can become disrupted, and the backwards pressure gradient from the combustion chamber will overpower the compressor, causing a surge. A surge is a complete breakdown of the airflow through the engine, and often results in a reversal of the airflow in the engine, as the compressor is no longer managing to keep the back pressure from the combustion chamber at bay. Therefore, we need to make sure that the airflow always hits the compressor blades in the correct way. We do this initially by using inlet guide vanes (IGVs) or variable inlet guide vanes (VIGVs), which sit in front of the first LP compressor stage, and have their angle set to make sure the air hits the compressor blades correctly. After this point, stalls could still occur, so variable stator vanes (VSVs) can be used between compressor stages to make sure the airflow is pointing in exactly the correct direction onto the next compressor stage. Even later than this, during the start sequence (when the compressor is most likely to stall) we can use bleed air outlets just after the compressor to let out excess pressure, which reduces the overall backwards pressure gradient force causing a stall.

content.question: A vent valve in the combustion chamber of a gas turbine engine…

options.A: prevents a wet start.
options.B: allows leftover fuel to drain out of the bottom of the combustion chamber.
options.C: allows for a pilot to take a fuel sample directly from the engine.
options.D: allows the fuel tanks to be emptied for maintenance.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.02.03.06: State the function of the drain valves. VENT/DRAIN VALVE In a gas turbine engine combustion chamber, the fuel and air mixture usually burn at the chemically correct mixture, in order to burn hotter and more efficiently, in theory burning all of the fuel perfectly. Sometimes, however, there can be deposits of unburnt fuel that build up on the walls of the combustion chamber, which will need to drain from the engine somehow. A much more common usage of a vent/drain valve is after a "wet start", where a start malfunction has occured that stopped the engine from igniting the fuel, and the fuel has been sprayed out of the nozzles but not burned, so is now sat in the bottom of the combustion chamber. This situation could be made very dangerous if the engine is started again, this time with a pool of fuel at the bottom, and could lead to a "hot start", with the potential for large flames to be sent out of the back of the engine. This could also overheat the turbine, as there is not enough cooling airflow during start to counteract the large fire. In aircraft with no vent/drain valve, the pilots would usually run the starter without running the igniters to blow the fuel away, but a vent/drain valve is much easier and can drain the fuel out of the combustion chamber quickly and safely. Note: we would usually refer to this as a drain valve, and so do EASA, but in this question, the feedback says that they have called it a "vent valve", which is the same thing.

learning.explanation: Both statements are correct. The intake geometry is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect. It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed. That’s why the intake is slightly divergent in order to reduce the airflow’s velocity (=dynamic pressure) and increase the static pressure and temperature just before the fan and compressor’s first stages. Caution, the total pressure (and temperature) will remain constant - it is only a trade of dynamic pressure for static pressure. Compression (=increase in static pressure) is a process where heat is released, which explains why the temperature behaves in the same way through a divergent duct as pressure. This geometry is also called the ‘pitot intake’, and it has thick, smoothly rounded lips to prevent flow separation under any flight conditions/maneuvers.

content.question: Concerning the fuel system high-pressure shut-off valve (HPSOV) of a gas turbine engine…

options.A: the HPSOV is located between the HP fuel pump and the fuel control unit.
options.B: manual HPSOV control from the cockpit is not possible with FADEC equipped engines.
options.C: the HPSOV is mounted in the wing front spar near the pylon.
options.D: ignition is activated before fuel is delivered by the HPSOV to the fuel nozzles.

key_points: The typical start sequence of a gas turbine engine on the ground would be the following: Start selected: the start valve admits air supplied by the pneumatic system to operate the starter
In nowadays commercial aircraft, the FADEC controls the start valve electrically and operates it pneumatically with bleed air
Ignition ON: the igniters are selected ON and are ready to light the mixture
learning.explanation: The typical start sequence of a gas turbine engine on the ground would be the following: Start selected: the start valve admits air supplied by the pneumatic system to operate the starter. In nowadays commercial aircraft, the FADEC controls the start valve electrically and operates it pneumatically with bleed air. Ignition ON: the igniters are selected ON and are ready to light the mixture. High-pressure fuel ON: after fuel is delivered by the high-pressure shut-off valve (HPSOV) it is sprayed into the combustion chamber by fuel nozzles under high-pressure where it is mixed with compressed air and lights up. Light-up: the mixture starts burning and the flame spreads all along with the combustion chamber (since it is interconnected). The flame becomes self-sustainable. Self-sustaining speed: all the engine’s spools have reached a self-sustaining speed where assistance from the air starter is not needed anymore. The air starter is disengaged by the coupling between engine N2 spool and starter by the use of centrifugal forces. Starter circuit canceled. As you can see, ignition occurs just before fuel is supplied to the combustion chamber. If you think about it, it makes sense to have already the spark before supplying the fuel. If the spark is supplied after the fuel is being delivered, some fuel will be unburnt and will accumulate at the bottom of the combustion chamber case and would potentially result in a wet start.

content.question:
Which of the following statements is/are correct for a gas turbine engine with a constant speed propeller and free power turbine, when the power setting is decreased?
1. The HP spool speed decreases.
2. The EGT remains constant.

options.A: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: Both 1 and 2 are correct.

key_points: A gas turbine engine-free turbine does not drive a compressor, i
e
there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine-free turbine does not drive a compressor, i.e. there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft. The energy delivered by the free turbine stages is only dependent on the rotational speed of the HP spool. In this configuration, the engine will simply act as a gas generator to supply high-energy gases to an independent free power turbine driving a propeller or rotor via a reduction gearbox. This is why this type of turbine is often used on turboprop engines and helicopters. In fact, there will be two major assemblies: one shaft known as the HP spool and connecting the compressor and the compressor-driving turbine, and a free turbine placed after the compressor-driving turbine that is connected to a propeller. Because these two assemblies are not interconnected in any way, the propeller and free turbine assembly will be able to rotate at an independent speed from that of the HP spool. The most suitable control system for a turboprop fitted with a free turbine is the direct control of fuel flow. In this system, the gas generator (the core of the engine) is controlled in the same manner as a turbojet, and the power available to the free turbine assembly is governed by the fuel flow. For instance: If the power setting is increased (due to an increased fuel flow), the RPM of the HP spool will also increase and the axial airflow will be momentarily lagging, causing the EGT to increase. However, the free turbine and propeller assembly will be maintained at constant RPM by the Constant Speed Unit (CSU) that will do so by increasing the propeller’s blade angle. If the power setting is decreased, the RPM of the HP spool and the EGT will also decrease. However, the free turbine and propeller assembly will be maintained at constant RPM by the Constant Speed Unit (CSU) that will do so by decreasing the propeller’s blade angle.

This temperature is one of the most important of the overall parameters in a gas turbine engine, as this is the hottest point in the cycle

It must be ensured that turbine entry temperature remains below the maximum limit uniformly within the flow, otherwise asymmetric overheating may cause deformation and eventual catastrophic disintegration of the turbine
learning.explanation: The temperature at the outlet of the combustor is limited by the capability of the turbine blades to withstand heat. This temperature is one of the most important of the overall parameters in a gas turbine engine, as this is the hottest point in the cycle. It must be ensured that turbine entry temperature remains below the maximum limit uniformly within the flow, otherwise asymmetric overheating may cause deformation and eventual catastrophic disintegration of the turbine. During start-up, shut down and when accelerating/decelerating, the temperature changes can be very large. A cooling down period at idle before closing down is often established by the manufacturers, which helps preventing thermal shock. Thus, extending engine life.

content.question:
Under which of the following circumstances would continuous ignition be automatically triggered in a turbine engine without the requirement for crew input?
1. Engine anti-ice selected on
2. Airframe anti ice selected on
3. Stick shaker activation
4. Throttle at idle
5. Speed at or above Mach 0.8
6. When the aircraft is climbing

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.03.05.04: Explain the different modes of operation of the ignition system. Gas turbine engines are different from piston engines in many ways, one of which is their continuous nature. Whilst the intake, compression, combustion and exhaust cycle happens intermittently, many times per second in a piston engine, it is a continuous cycle in a gas turbine engine. This means that the flame(s) in the combustion chamber(s) should never go out from starting up to shutting down. Sometimes, conditions can occur which bring the engine close to a "flame-out", which is where the flame in the engine is extinguished, and the engine will likely begin to slow down, with no flame to keep it alive. This situation can be stopped by using continuous ignition, where low power igniters run many times per minute to re-ignite the fuel/air mixture instantly if the flame goes out. These do not need to be the same extremely high voltage sparks as used during start-up, as the engine is already running, they just need to be enough to re-light the fuel quickly to keep the engine running. When the engines are running, continuous ignition can be selected either manually by the flight crew or automatically by the FADEC to maintain engine combustion. The FADEC will automatically turn ON continuous ignition when the engine anti-ice is ON, maximum/flex thrust is selected, idle thrust is selected during approach, or a thrust control malfunction is detected (risk of flame-out), etc. On some aircraft, it can even be automatically activated when the stall warning system/stick shaker alerts of an impending stall. The flight crew will manually select continuous ignition when passing through a heavy precipitation area, moderate or severe turbulence, high ambient air temperatures, or anytime a lack of sufficient airflow or fuel into the engine is expected. learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.04.01.07: Explain the purpose of engine trending. Engine trending is incredibly common in the modern age of aviation. Due to the immense cost of new engines and maintenance, each engine is continuously monitored to establish "trending". That simply means that the engine's expected performance data, speeds, temperatures, airflow, etc. are known, and the engine's actual data can be compared against that to diagnose many problems and inadequacies before they become an issue for the engine. Minute differences in engine behaviour and performance can be picked up and the operator can be informed immediately about this future problem, so preventative maintenance can take place. content.question: In an axial compressor with 20 stages, the pressure rise is equal to 20% across every single stage. What is the overall compression ratio of such engine?

2 (120%) times initial pressure
Across the second stage, the pressure increase is 20% of 1
learning.explanation: The overall compression ration can be calculated as follows: Across the first stage, the pressure increase is 20% => total pressure of 1.2 (120%) times initial pressure. Across the second stage, the pressure increase is 20% of 1.2 => total pressure of 1.22 times initial pressure We can therefore conclude that across the last stage, the pressure increase will be 1.220 = 38.34 Compression ratio: 38:1

options.A: The last part of the HP compressor and front part of the HP turbine.
options.B: The turbine and exhaust nozzle.
options.C: The combustion chamber and front part of the HP turbine.
options.D: The combustion chamber and exhaust nozzle.

key_points: Combustion chambers, the first turbine stage (HP), and their associated parts are very prone to deterioration because of the high stresses and temperatures to which they are subjected
A deteriorated combustion chamber has various cracking and buckling that will distort the flame pattern and eventually burn the outer case, causing a flow disruption

To control and minimize the stress on the combustion chamber’s components and avoid high-temperature stress over the HP turbine, some of the compressed air from the HP compressor is ducted via a secondary path for cooling of the inner casing
learning.explanation: Combustion chambers, the first turbine stage (HP), and their associated parts are very prone to deterioration because of the high stresses and temperatures to which they are subjected. A deteriorated combustion chamber has various cracking and buckling that will distort the flame pattern and eventually burn the outer case, causing a flow disruption. To control and minimize the stress on the combustion chamber’s components and avoid high-temperature stress over the HP turbine, some of the compressed air from the HP compressor is ducted via a secondary path for cooling of the inner casing. Considering that combustion occurs at around 2000°C, the supply of cooler air could drop the temperature at the outlet of the combustion chamber down to 1000°C-1500°C, which would be within the limits for the HP turbine. Additionally, turbine blades can be film cooled by passing a small film of cold air over the surface of the blades, or internally cooled where cold air passes inside the turbine blades through several ducts.

content.question: The bypass air in a turbo fan engine has the effect of a lower specific fuel consumption by causing an overall…

options.A: decrease in average exhaust gas flow velocity and a higher mass flow.
options.B: increase in average exhaust gas flow velocity thus increasing engine pressure ratio.
options.C: decrease in combustion chamber temperature and higher thermal efficiency.
options.D: increase in the mean jet temperature and increase in thermal efficiency.

key_points: Older single spool turbojet engines did not have any bypass air
All the air that enters the engine goes directly through every compressor stage (except any bleed air), then is combusted, and passes through the turbine and the exhaust
This type of engine relies on the speed and excess pressure of the exhaust gas to provide thrust
learning.explanation: Older single spool turbojet engines did not have any bypass air. All the air that enters the engine goes directly through every compressor stage (except any bleed air), then is combusted, and passes through the turbine and the exhaust. This type of engine relies on the speed and excess pressure of the exhaust gas to provide thrust. It accelerates a small amount of air up to a high speed. This does lose a lot of energy to heat, friction, noise and other inefficiencies. More modern jet engines are called turbofans, because of the big fan at the front. They use a bypass design, where only some of the inlet air passes through the core of the engine (compressor, combustion chamber and turbine), but most of the air actually goes around the core of the engine, blown by the front fan only. This has many benefits over the single spool turbojet design, particularly at lower speeds. This type of engine accelerates a large amount of air (high mass flow) up by a smaller amount (lower velocity). This means that there are less hot exhaust gasses, and that the noise is reduced, as well as there being extra cooling, so the combustion can burn hotter. For commercial aviation, high bypass engines are much more efficient. A lower specific fuel consumption means that less fuel is used to produce the same amount of thrust. Lower SFC means higher efficiency

options.A: Both the rotor and the stator increase only the speed of the airflow.
options.B: The rotor increases the pressure and the speed of the airflow, the stator increases only the pressure.
options.C: Both the rotor and the stator increase only the pressure of the airflow.
options.D: The rotor increases only the pressure of the airflow, the stator increases the pressure and the speed of the airflow.

key_points: Gas Turbine Engines – Axial-Flow Compressors The axial-flow compressor has two main elements: a rotor and a stator
The principle of the compressor stage is to convert kinetic energy into pressure (potential) energy
A stage consists of one row of rotor blades, fastened to discs on a rotor drum, followed by a row of stator blades, which are fastened to the compressor outer casing
learning.explanation: Gas Turbine Engines – Axial-Flow Compressors The axial-flow compressor has two main elements: a rotor and a stator. The principle of the compressor stage is to convert kinetic energy into pressure (potential) energy. A stage consists of one row of rotor blades, fastened to discs on a rotor drum, followed by a row of stator blades, which are fastened to the compressor outer casing. On both the rotor and the stator the spaces between the blades form divergent passages. In the rotor, which is turned continuously at high speed by the turbine, mechanical energy is added and converted into both kinetic (velocity) energy and potential (pressure) energy. Within the stator, the pressure is increased by the conversion of the kinetic energy into pressure energy - The job of the stators is to increase pressure and keep the flow from spiraling around the axis by bringing the flow back parallel to the axis.

content.question:
With regards to a gas turbine engine combustion chamber, which of the following statements are correct/incorrect?
1. Within the combustion chamber, the air/fuel mixture coming from the diffuser section of the engine is ignited and burned
2. The combustion process in the combustion chamber of a turbine engine is continuous. Under normal operation, the ignition system is only required during engine start

options.A: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 and 2 are correct.
options.D: 1 and 2 are incorrect.

key_points: The combustion chamber is the part of a gas turbine engine where the air and fuel are burned

The combustion chamber receives air from the compressor, via the diffuser, which is a diverging area that increases the pressure of the air, and slows it down to a good speed for mixing with fuel and burning

The fuel is added as a constant spray in the early part of the combustion chamber, producing a continuous flame, which happens at a constant pressure, producing an increase in volume that pushes the air through the following turbine with great force
learning.explanation: The combustion chamber is the part of a gas turbine engine where the air and fuel are burned. The combustion chamber receives air from the compressor, via the diffuser, which is a diverging area that increases the pressure of the air, and slows it down to a good speed for mixing with fuel and burning. The fuel is added as a constant spray in the early part of the combustion chamber, producing a continuous flame, which happens at a constant pressure, producing an increase in volume that pushes the air through the following turbine with great force. In reality, the ignition is only required for starting the engine, and the flame should the run continuously until shutdown, however, the igniters are run on a low voltage continuous mode in most engines during take-off and landing, and when flying in visible moisture and other conditions, to avoid a flame-out of the engine. You could argue that statement 2 is incorrect because of this, but we think that it is more correct than incorrect, and our feedback shows it to be considered correct in the exam. Not all the air that flows through the compressor will get mixed with fuel and burned in the combustion chamber. The flame front gets so hot that it needs the majority of air to provide cooling airflow to stop the combustion chamber melting.

content.question:
Which statement is correct, as regards a jet engine?
1. The maximum thrust increases as the pressure altitude decreases
2. The specific fuel consumption is proportional to pressure altitude, at constant TAS

options.A: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.B: Both 1 and 2 are correct.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.

key_points: The maximum thrust increases as the pressure altitude decreases
" CORRECT
learning.explanation: "1. The maximum thrust increases as the pressure altitude decreases." CORRECT. As altitude increases, the air gets thinner. The increase in altitude causes a decrease in pressure, thus a decrease in density and corresponding decrease in thrust – since less air is entering the gas turbine engine. As altitude decreases, the air gets thicker. The decrease in altitude causes an increase in pressure, thus an increase in density and corresponding increase in thrust – since more air is entering the gas turbine engine. "2. The specific fuel consumption is proportional to pressure altitude, at constant TAS." INCORRECT. Specific fuel consumption reduces proportionally to the temperature => If temperature is decreasing, specific fuel consumption decreases. That being said, specific fuel consumption depends on temperature and not on pressure altitude. Thus saying that "the specific fuel consumption is proportional to pressure altitude, at constant TAS" is vague because, even though normally temperature increases with reducing pressure altitude, there can be inversions. Anyhow, we assume standard conditions => temperature decreasing with increasing pressure altitude => specific fuel consumption, therefore, decreases with increasing pressure altitude (inversely proportional).

Going from the front to the rear of the engine you have: the combustion chamber, the turbine, and the entry of the exhaust unit
The cooling airflow around the flame tube is going to be around the core of the engine, so it will not be directly affected by the highest temperatures of the combustion chamber
learning.explanation: To answer this question, try to locate the different answer options and visualize their place within the engine. Going from the front to the rear of the engine you have: the combustion chamber, the turbine, and the entry of the exhaust unit. The cooling airflow around the flame tube is going to be around the core of the engine, so it will not be directly affected by the highest temperatures of the combustion chamber. “At the turbine entrance” – INCORRECT. options.B: It reduces the gas velocity, and ensure a high static pressure.

That’s why most of the time it is converging so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher thrust
learning.explanation: The exhaust system directs the exhaust gas aft and regulates the gas streamflow. It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent flow separation. That’s why most of the time it is converging so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher thrust. content.question: The exhaust noise of a jet engine can be reduced by…

options.A: lowering the jet exhaust velocity.
options.B: lowering the engine bypass ratio and increasing the exhaust gas temperature.
options.C: increasing the jet exhaust velocity.
options.D: decreasing the fan diameter and increasing the fan rotation speed.

key_points: The propelling nozzle directs the exhaust gas aft and regulates the gas streamflow
It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent flow separation
That’s why most of the time it is converging so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher thrust
learning.explanation: The propelling nozzle directs the exhaust gas aft and regulates the gas streamflow. It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent flow separation. That’s why most of the time it is converging so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher thrust. However, a higher thrust will necessarily induce more noise. Therefore, a balance should be found between the desired thrust to be achieved and the noise print of the engine. The lower the velocity of the exhaust gases, the lower the noise produced.

content.question: In a gas turbine engine, how do the stators in an axial flow compressor affect the speed of the airflow?

options.A: They increase the speed of the airflow.
options.B: They decrease the speed of the airflow.
options.C: They do not change the speed of the airflow.
options.D: They introduce turbulence into the airflow, with no change to the speed.

key_points: Gas Turbine Engines - COMPRESSOR SECTION The compressor section of the engine has the important task of providing a sufficient quantity of compressed air to satisfy the requirements of combustion
It increases the pressure of the mass of air that is received at the inlet and provides it to the combustion section at the required pressure
Pressure increases: In the figure it can easily be seen that the pressure increases along the compressor section of the graph
learning.explanation: Gas Turbine Engines - COMPRESSOR SECTION The compressor section of the engine has the important task of providing a sufficient quantity of compressed air to satisfy the requirements of combustion. It increases the pressure of the mass of air that is received at the inlet and provides it to the combustion section at the required pressure. Pressure increases: In the figure it can easily be seen that the pressure increases along the compressor section of the graph. The compressor also raises the temperature of the air as the air is compressed. The high temperature air that is produced by the compressor section is then bled off and used for various functions. Axial velocity decreases, as shown in the attached figure. In particular, the stator vanes are the second part of each compressor stage. They reduce any lateral velocity given to the air by the rotor blades, increasing the pressure of the air even further.

content.question: How can a jet engine be started?

options.A: From an APU and RAM air turbine.
options.B: From two external power sources and/or an APU.
options.C: From two external sources only.
options.D: From two batteries or an APU generator.

key_points: Note: This is similar to question 215432, but with different options
This question is less commonly reported, and sometimes with slight differences, so it may be slightly different in the exam
A gas turbine engine requires a lot of energy to start
learning.explanation: Note: This is similar to question 215432, but with different options. This question is less commonly reported, and sometimes with slight differences, so it may be slightly different in the exam. A gas turbine engine requires a lot of energy to start. This is mostly in the form of getting the compressor rotating to a speed where it can feed enough air into the combustion chamber to run self-sufficiently. For this, compressors can be spun up in two ways, electrically or by air starter (pneumatic). Electric starting is as it sounds, an electric starter motor runs for the compressor to get up to speed. This used to be reserved for small turbine engines only, and the APUs (Auxiliary Power Units) of larger aircraft, so they can be started from battery power. However, the B787 uses a very high power electrical system, and can start its large main engines using electrical starter generators. This is not a usual method of starting large engines, so we believe the examiner is not talking about it. The more common method (for large engines) is via air starters, which shoot high pressure air at a certain place within the engine compressor, which gets the compressor spinning fast enough to run the engine itself. The source of this high pressure air is the aircraft's pneumatic system, and the 3 places this air can come from are the APU bleed air, from a ground cart that is connected to the aircraft, or from the other main engine's bleed air, if it is running. It is also important to note that even an air start needs electrical power to feed the engine igniters and often the electronic engine controllers that control the engines. This has to come from a source. Lets go through each option: "From an APU and RAM air turbine." The RAM air turbine (RAT) is never used for engine starting. "From two external power sources and/or an APU." We see this as the most correct answer. The APU alone is enough to start the main engines, providing AC/DC power and pneumatic air. Also, the aircraft can be connected to a GPU (ground power unit providing AC power) and an air cart at once (2 external sources), which would mean that the engines can be started without needing the APU at all. "From two external sources only." The APU can start the engines with no external power source. "From two batteries or an APU generator." Most jet engines cannot be started from electrical power alone.

content.question: Regarding the aircraft gas turbine engines, the supplemental gearbox is connected to the _____, and the external gearbox is connected to the _____.

options.A: LP shaft, LP shaft.
options.B: LP shaft, HP shaft.
options.C: HP shaft, LP shaft.
options.D: HP shaft, HP shaft.

key_points: The auxiliary gearbox of most gas turbine engine is driven by the HP compressor shaft via an internal gearbox to an external gearbox
It provides the drive for a wide variety of services
It can even serve as mounting support for the engine
learning.explanation: The auxiliary gearbox of most gas turbine engine is driven by the HP compressor shaft via an internal gearbox to an external gearbox. It provides the drive for a wide variety of services. It can even serve as mounting support for the engine. For example, the internal gearbox assembly of the CFM 56 contains a core engine thrust bearing, and a core engine roller bearing. Like all the other engine’s moving parts, oil is used to lubricate and clean the accessory gearbox elements. The accessory units of a turbo-jet engine auxiliary gearbox are the following: AC generator through its constant speed drive (CSD) Oil pumps, Hydraulic pumps, High-pressure fuel pumps. Some engines also have a second gearbox, in order to share the load of the accessory units, and this is operating at a much lower speed, connected to the LP compressor shaft, in the same way as the main gearbox.

content.question: You are flying a turbine-engined aircraft when the warning message "ENG OIL PRESS" appears, What are the most probable instrument indications in this scenario?

options.A: High engine oil pressure and high engine oil temperature.
options.B: Low engine oil pressure and high engine oil temperature.
options.C: High engine RPM and high engine oil pressure.
options.D: A clogged scavenge filter and bypass flow of engine oil.

key_points: The main purposes of oil in piston and turbine engines are lubrication, cooling and cleaning
Without oil, the engines would create immense heat through friction, and there would be no way to distribute this heat evenly, nor to remove the deposits that gather during operation
When oil cannot be sufficiently distributed within an engine, serious damage can occur
learning.explanation: The main purposes of oil in piston and turbine engines are lubrication, cooling and cleaning. Without oil, the engines would create immense heat through friction, and there would be no way to distribute this heat evenly, nor to remove the deposits that gather during operation. When oil cannot be sufficiently distributed within an engine, serious damage can occur. Some of the most common oil-related issues in any engine, including turbine engines, are lack of oil flow, usually due to lack of oil, leaks, blockages, faulty pumps, etc. In this case, the oil pressure will drop in the engine, and, because less oil is flowing around the engine (and especially in the case of low oil quantity, leaks, etc.), the oil remaining will still take as much heat from the engine, but will less ability for cooling, meaning that the oil will heat up until the oil temperature is too high. This is why low oil pressure so often coincides with high oil temperature, and this occurrence is probably the most common oil-related issue in piston and turbine engines. Certainly, when the ENG OIL PRESS warning shows, the likelihood is that lack of oil flow is the cause, and therefore the above scenario will take place.

content.question: The compressor blades in a rotating gas turbine engine are held in position by…

options.A: the mountings and thermal expansion only.
options.B: a centrifugal latch.
options.C: abradable seals and aerodynamic forces.
options.D: the mountings, and centrifugal force.

key_points: The rotor blades of an axial flow compressor are held in position by the mountings, the aerodynamic force, and centrifugal force
The mounting connecting the blades at their root is of the ‘fir tree’ type
The blades are subject to very high centrifugal loads and high-temperature variations that unavoidably cause thermal expansion of the blades
learning.explanation: The rotor blades of an axial flow compressor are held in position by the mountings, the aerodynamic force, and centrifugal force. The mounting connecting the blades at their root is of the ‘fir tree’ type. The blades are subject to very high centrifugal loads and high-temperature variations that unavoidably cause thermal expansion of the blades. That’s why they are fitted on a disk or drum using a ‘loose fit’ design that will avoid them blocking in their mounting under high thermal loads and vibrations. The ‘fir tree’ root connection allows the blades to be loosely fitted and to be replaced more easily, as each blade has its own independent connection to the rotor disk. The loose fit gives the rotor blades some room for expansion. Sometimes when the aircraft is on the ground and a strong wind is blowing towards the engine and keeps it rotating along with the compressor (the engine is windmilling) you will be able to hear a clicking noise. This is due to the rotor blades being loose in their mounting on the drum without any centrifugal loads acting on them.

content.question:
Which of these statements about compressor stall in a gas turbine engine are correct or incorrect?
I. A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at low RPM
II. A compressor stall is most likely to occur when the air flow stagnates in the front stages of the compressor

options.A: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is correct.

key_points: "I
A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at low RPM
" CORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the air flow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM
learning.explanation: "I. A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at low RPM." CORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the air flow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM. As a result, smooth airflow is interrupted and pressure fluctuations are created within the turbine. It occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack (just like a wing). Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing a stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Usually this is followed by a complete compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. "II. A compressor stall is most likely to occur when the air flow stagnates in the front stages of the compressor." INCORRECT As mentioned above, air stagnates in the REAR stages, which results in a lack of air in the FRONT stages with subsequent low axial velocity in front stages. This will lead to a high angle of attack of the rotor blades determining a STALL. To avoid such situation, turbine engines are fitted with VIGV (variable inlet guide vanes) and VSV (variable stator vanes) that ensure correct airflow through the stages of the engine.

content.question: On a FADEC gas turbine engine during normal flight, the power for the FADEC`s sensors comes from…

options.A: the aircraft battery.
options.B: the FADEC power source(s) on the engine.
options.C: the APU generator.
options.D: the aircraft generator.

key_points: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks
The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby
If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions
learning.explanation: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks. The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby. If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions. In addition to the ECU, all the FADEC peripherals such as actuators, solenoids, electrical wiring, sensors, and fuel metering are also part of the FADEC system and are used for control and monitoring. The system has a three-phase permanent magnetic alternator for an internal power source. This independent alternator is also the electrical power source for all the FADEC sensors as well as the ECUs. By interfacing with other aircraft systems and its own engine sensors, the FADEC system provides the following functions: Automatic thrust rating control. Engine operation within safe limits. Fully automatic engine starting. Thrust Reverser Control. Engine overspeed and/or an EGT protection function. Engine monitoring and help for maintenance and troubleshooting. To make the FADEC’s operation more reliable, the system uses the dual inputs logic. All control inputs to the FADEC system are dual, with the exception of some secondary parameters used for monitoring and indicating (that are single). To increase the fault-tolerant design where the engine will still be able to operate within a required reliability and safety range, the parameters are exchanged between the two control channels (inside the ECU) via a cross-channel data link. Therefore, if one input parameter fails to be delivered, the input parameter from the other channel will be used to allow the correct computation of the engine parameters by the FADEC. This means that the FADEC is a single fault-tolerant, and it will ensure the efficient and correct running of the engine even in case of a detected malfunction.

content.question:
Consider a jet engine whose control is based on the Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR):
1. with a constant EPR, the thrust decreases when the altitude increases
2. with a constant EPR, the thrust is independent of the Mach number
3. at same environmental conditions, a given EPR setting maintains the thrust irrespective of engine wear due to ageing
4. the EPR is determined by the total pressure difference between the turbine outlet and the compressor inlet
5. on take-off, in the event of icing not detected by the crew, the indicated EPR is lower than the real EPR
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: with a constant EPR, the thrust decreases when the altitude increases" CORRECT
⇒ As altitude increases, the air gets thinner
learning.explanation: "1. with a constant EPR, the thrust decreases when the altitude increases" CORRECT. ⇒ As altitude increases, the air gets thinner. The increase in altitude causes a decrease in pressure, thus a decrease in density and a corresponding decrease in thrust since less air is entering the gas turbine engine. "2. with a constant EPR, the thrust is independent of the Mach number" INCORRECT. ⇒ A higher Mach number results in a higher compression at the inlet. Therefore, thrust is dependent of the Mach number. "3. at same environmental conditions, a given EPR setting maintains the thrust irrespective of engine wear due to ageing." CORRECT. ⇒ The engine maintains the thrust corresponding to a given EPR, irrespective of engine wear due to aging. "4. the EPR is determined by the total pressure difference between the turbine outlet and the compressor inlet" INCORRECT. ⇒ The EPR is the ratio (not the difference) between the low-pressure turbine exhaust pressure (the engine’s last stage) and the engine inlet pressure (the fan’s pressure). "5. on take-off, in the event of icing not detected by the crew, the indicated EPR is lower than the real EPR." INCORRECT. ⇒ When the compressor inlet pressure probe is blocked with ice, the compressor inlet pressure value will drop to zero. In the meantime, the turbine proble will continue to sense. This will result in a higher EPR reading than what is actually being produced.

content.question: The turboprop alpha-range power level is the range of power lever positions between…

options.A: flight idle and maximum power.
options.B: ground idle and flight idle.
options.C: maximum reverse and ground idle.
options.D: flight idle and maximum reverse.

key_points: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight
Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm
The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range, and the power lever positions corresponding to the ALPHA range are between flight idle and maximum power
learning.explanation: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight. Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm. The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range, and the power lever positions corresponding to the ALPHA range are between flight idle and maximum power. However, while maneuvering on the ground, the power required for a turboprop engine is pretty low. Therefore, the controls have been adapted such that the blade pitch angle (therefore the thrust produced) is controlled directly by the pilot, overriding the CSU. This ground range is known as the BETA control range. The flight crew will select a blade pitch angle by moving the power lever fully aft and lifting it up. The first detent of the BETA range will correspond to the ground idle detent that will allow the pilots to produce minimum level of thrust, just enough power to taxi the aircraft. If the lever is pulled full aft of the BETA range, the pilot will lower the blade pitch angle such that the maximum reverse power is produced (=negative thrust). This will usually be the case at landing in order to assist the aircraft’s deceleration.

content.question: In a gas turbine combustion chamber…

options.A: secondary air is required for cooling of the inner casing.
options.B: the gas temperature is highest at the chamber outlet.
options.C: the gas pressure increases in an axial (downstream) direction.
options.D: the axial velocity of the gas stream is greatest behind the swirl vanes.

key_points: Combustion chambers and their associated parts are very prone to deterioration because of the high stresses and temperatures to which they are subjected
A deteriorated combustion chamber has various cracking and buckling that will distort the flame pattern and eventually burn the outer case, causing a flow disruption
To control and minimize the stress on the combustion chamber’s components, some of the compressed air from the HP compressor is ducted via a secondary path for cooling of the inner casing
learning.explanation: Combustion chambers and their associated parts are very prone to deterioration because of the high stresses and temperatures to which they are subjected. A deteriorated combustion chamber has various cracking and buckling that will distort the flame pattern and eventually burn the outer case, causing a flow disruption. To control and minimize the stress on the combustion chamber’s components, some of the compressed air from the HP compressor is ducted via a secondary path for cooling of the inner casing. Considering that combustion occurs at around 2000°C, the supply of cooler air could drop the temperature at the outlet of the combustion chamber down to 1000°C-1500°C, which would be within the limits for the turbine.

content.question:
Which of the following describes the correct order of components as air flows through a free-power turbine engine, after the intake?
1. Gas Generator Turbine
2. Exhaust
3. Combustion Chamber
4. Free-Power Turbine
5. Compressor

key_points: Free-power turbines are turbine engines that can be used for turboprop powered aircraft or turboshaft powered helicopters, and have a variety of benefits over direct drive alternatives

The main feature of them is that the power output shaft (to the rotors or propeller) is not physically connected to any part of the "gas generator", which is the set of compressors fed by the normal turbines

Instead of linking the propeller to one of the standard turbine spools, an extra turbine is added to the engine after the standard turbines, which absorbs most of the remaining energy to use solely for the turning of the propeller, before the air gets sent out of the exhaust
learning.explanation: Free-power turbines are turbine engines that can be used for turboprop powered aircraft or turboshaft powered helicopters, and have a variety of benefits over direct drive alternatives. The main feature of them is that the power output shaft (to the rotors or propeller) is not physically connected to any part of the "gas generator", which is the set of compressors fed by the normal turbines. Instead of linking the propeller to one of the standard turbine spools, an extra turbine is added to the engine after the standard turbines, which absorbs most of the remaining energy to use solely for the turning of the propeller, before the air gets sent out of the exhaust. This means that the propeller can be governed to go at any speed the pilots requires, which will mean that the free-power turbine will also have to go at the corresponding speed (they are connected via a reduction gearbox to go from the turbine's 50 000-ish RPM to the propeller's 2000-ish RPM), but without making the rest of the engine components go at that speed, allowing the standard turbine-compressor spools (known as the "gas generator") to stay at their optimum speed, where they can be most efficient, and longer lasting. The engine (gas generator) then becomes far simpler to operate as well, as it is almost self regulating in its speeds, etc. with no outside influence. All we do is harness the left-over pressure and velocity of the air - of which there should be plenty - to put through our propellers. There must be a constant speed unit to regulate propeller RPM, and particular care must be paid to over-torquing the engine. Therefore, just like a normal gas turbine engine, you have: Intake - Compressor - Combustion Chamber - Turbine - Exhaust However, you now have two separate sets of turbines, one set which drives the compressor (gas generator turbines) and the free-power turbine which takes the left over energy and turns the propeller with it. It therefore becomes: Intake - Compressor(5) - Combustion Chamber(3) - Gas Generator Turbine(1) - Free-Power Turbine(4) - Exhaust(2). 5-3-1-4-2
