content.question: What are the potential air sources for engine start in a turbine aircraft?

options.A: Fuel or hydraulic systems.
options.B: Ground air unit or other engine.
options.C: Cabin pressurisation or electrical system.
options.D: Engine oil or navigation systems.

key_points: A gas turbine engine requires a lot of energy to start
This is mostly in the form of getting the compressor rotating to a speed where it can feed enough air into the combustion chamber to run self-sufficiently
For this, compressors can be spun up in two ways, electrically or by air starter (pneumatic)
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine requires a lot of energy to start. This is mostly in the form of getting the compressor rotating to a speed where it can feed enough air into the combustion chamber to run self-sufficiently. For this, compressors can be spun up in two ways, electrically or by air starter (pneumatic). Electric starting is as it sounds, an electric starter motor runs for the compressor to get up to speed. This used to be reserved for small turbine engines only, and the APUs (Auxiliary Power Units) of larger aircraft, so they can be started from battery power. The B787 has a high voltage system that can start its main engines, but that is quite a new system, and this question asks about air sources anyway. The more common method (for large engines) is via air starters, which shoot high pressure air at a certain place within the engine compressor, which gets the compressor spinning fast enough to run the engine itself. The source of this high pressure air is the aircraft's pneumatic system, and the 3 places this air can come from are the APU bleed air, from a ground air cart that is connected to the aircraft, or from the other main engine's bleed air, if it is running. This question is a lot easier than some of the other similar questions we have seen over the last couple of years, as the other options here are not even remotely close to being correct.

content.question: What is the correct sequence during the in-flight wind-milling start of a turbine engine?

options.A: Rotation, ignition, fuel.
options.B: Ignition, rotation, fuel.
options.C: Starter, rotation, fuel, ignition.
options.D: Starter, rotation, ignition, fuel.

key_points: STARTING AND IGNITION The start sequence is initiated by an electrical starter motor or high-pressure air-starter motor powered by bleed air
In-flight restarting uses fuel and ignition selection only as the wind-milling engine supplies the rotation of the engine
There are three elements to achieving a successful engine start in-flight: Rotation
learning.explanation: STARTING AND IGNITION The start sequence is initiated by an electrical starter motor or high-pressure air-starter motor powered by bleed air. In-flight restarting uses fuel and ignition selection only as the wind-milling engine supplies the rotation of the engine. There are three elements to achieving a successful engine start in-flight: Rotation. Provides air for combustion and also to clear the engine of fuel if the engine does not light up. Ignition. Fuel. Supplied as an atomized vapour in the flame tube by individual fuel spray nozzles. GROUND: Starter => Rotation => Ignition => Fuel IN-FLIGHT: Rotation => Ignition => Fuel

content.question: In a turbine engine, what is the parameter N1, which is used to represent thrust?

options.A: N1 refers to the rotational speed of the high speed spool which consists of the high pressure compressor and the high pressure turbine.
options.B: N1 refers to the rotational speed of the low speed spool which consists of the fan, the low pressure compressor and the low pressure turbine.
options.C: The indication is usually calibrated in percent RPM.
options.D: N1 is the ratio of the turbine discharge and the compressor inlet pressure.

key_points: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow
On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR
The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed
learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed. In a modern gas turbine engine such as the CFM 56 fitted to the B737 or A320, the engine has two compressor turbine assemblies. Each assembly is mounted on a common shaft. The first one is a Low-Pressure compressor turbine assembly, and the second one is a High-Pressure compressor turbine assembly. The first part of the engine is the fan, which divides the incoming airflow into two streams. The first stream is directed to the next compressor stages for further compression and combustion. The rest of the airflow is accelerated around the core, providing most of the engine thrust.

content.question: Specific fuel consumption for a turbojet engine is the mass of fuel burned per (1) _____ divided by the (2) _____ produced.

options.A: (1) mile; (2) thrust
options.B: (1) hour; (2) speed
options.C: (1) mile; (2) speed
options.D: (1) hour; (2) thrust

key_points: Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) is the measure of fuel consumed per unit of power produced
It is a measure of how much input is required to produce a unit of output power or thrust
SFC = ratio of mass of fuel required to produce an unit of power or thrust per unit of time (kg per unit of shaft power)
learning.explanation: Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) is the measure of fuel consumed per unit of power produced. It is a measure of how much input is required to produce a unit of output power or thrust. SFC = ratio of mass of fuel required to produce an unit of power or thrust per unit of time (kg per unit of shaft power).

content.question: What are the possible causes and indications of a tailpipe fire?

options.A: Fuel mis-scheduling or strong tailwinds can cause fuel ignition in the tailpipe. The turbine temperature increases above the certified limit.
options.B: Fuel may puddle in the turbine casings and exhaust during start-up or shutdown, and then ignite. This can result in a highly visible jet of flame out of the back of the engine.
options.C: Fuel may puddle in the turbine casings and exhaust during start-up or shutdown, and then ignite. On the flight deck, an engine fire warning is generated.
options.D: Fuel may puddle in the turbine casings and exhaust during start-up or shutdown, and then ignite. However, the EGT remains unchanged.

key_points: An engine tailpipe fire can only occur at engine start or at engine shutdown
It is the result of an excess of fuel in the combustion chamber, in the turbine, or in the exhaust nozzle, that ignites
A tailpipe fire is an internal fire in the engine, compared with an engine fire that occurs outside the engine core and gas path
learning.explanation: An engine tailpipe fire can only occur at engine start or at engine shutdown. It is the result of an excess of fuel in the combustion chamber, in the turbine, or in the exhaust nozzle, that ignites. A tailpipe fire is an internal fire in the engine, compared with an engine fire that occurs outside the engine core and gas path. No critical areas are affected in the engine in the case of a tailpipe fire. However, it can have an effect on the aircraft systems, and precisely damage the wing and the flaps. The first thing to consider when a tailpipe fire is detected (abnormally high EGT) is to stop the fuel flow and ventilate the engine.

content.question: One reason to fit a tip shroud to a turbine blade is to…

options.A: increase turbine efficiency.
options.B: reduce turbine temperatures.
options.C: provide a seal for the cooling airflow.
options.D: prevent blade creep.

key_points: The rotating parts of the engine fitted with blades (compressors and turbines) suffer from tip losses because of air leaking around the blade tips, reducing the working air around the blades that would’ve otherwise been used to be converted to kinetic energy
This is a big problem in the turbine section since it suffers from the cyclic expansion of the blades due to the high-temperature variations throughout its flight envelope
To avoid this problem, or at least to minimize it, tip shrouds are fitted to the turbine’s blades
learning.explanation: The rotating parts of the engine fitted with blades (compressors and turbines) suffer from tip losses because of air leaking around the blade tips, reducing the working air around the blades that would’ve otherwise been used to be converted to kinetic energy. This is a big problem in the turbine section since it suffers from the cyclic expansion of the blades due to the high-temperature variations throughout its flight envelope. To avoid this problem, or at least to minimize it, tip shrouds are fitted to the turbine’s blades. The shrouds will grant the airflow to be directed exactly through the blades, not around them. This method of increasing turbine efficiency is sometimes combined with the active clearance control that is a bit more sophisticated since it dynamically controls the gap between the turbine blade tips and the casing to permanently ensure the smallest gap possible.

learning.explanation: The ECU interfaces with many aircraft system computers, either directly, or via the Engine Interface Unit (EIU). The EIU is an interface concentrator that serves as the communication link, between the aircraft systems and the FADEC. The ECU of a FADEC checks all input and output data. In most modern commercial transport aircraft, the ECU receives inputs from: ADC + IRS units, Flight Control Unit, Landing gear control unit, Faults Display interface unit, Other cockpit engine controls including fire, anti-ice systems, and throttle lever angle (TLA). The outputs the ECU sends are directed to the: Flight data interface, Flight warning computers, Display management computers, FMGC, Faults display interface units, etc.

content.question: Which of the following options are pneumatic sources for engine starting?

options.A: Two batteries and another engine.
options.B: Battery and Auxiliary Power Unit.
options.C: External power source and another engine.
options.D: Auxiliary Power Unit and Power Transfer Unit.

key_points: A gas turbine engine requires a lot of energy to start
This is mostly in the form of getting the compressor rotating to a speed where it can feed enough air into the combustion chamber to run self-sufficiently
For this, compressors can be spun up in two ways, electrically or by air starter (pneumatic)
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine requires a lot of energy to start. This is mostly in the form of getting the compressor rotating to a speed where it can feed enough air into the combustion chamber to run self-sufficiently. For this, compressors can be spun up in two ways, electrically or by air starter (pneumatic). Electric starting is as it sounds, an electric starter motor runs for the compressor to get up to speed. This used to be reserved for small turbine engines only, and the APUs (Auxiliary Power Units) of larger aircraft, so they can be started from battery power. However, the B787 uses a very high power electrical system, and can start its main engines using electrical starter generators. The more common method (for large engines) is via air starters, which shoot high pressure air at a certain place within the engine compressor, which gets the compressor spinning fast enough to run the engine itself. The source of this high pressure air is the aircraft's pneumatic system, and the 3 places this air can come from are the APU bleed air, from a ground cart that is connected to the aircraft, or from the other main engine's bleed air, if it is running. The usual way of starting a twin engined jet is via the APU for both engines, but if the APU is inoperative, the first engine can be started from a ground air cart, and the second engine can then start from bleed air from the already running first engine (known as a cross-bleed start on many aircraft). A Power Transfer Unit (PTU) is a component of the hydraulic system, and transfers hydraulic pressure between separate system, without transferring fluid. It has nothing to do with pneumatic air.

content.question: When a turbo-prop aeroplane decelerates during the landing roll, a constant speed propeller within the beta range…

options.A: produces zero thrust.
options.B: produces negative thrust.
options.C: produces positive thrust.
options.D: is feathered.

key_points: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight
Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm
The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range
learning.explanation: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight. Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm. The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range. However, while maneuvering on the ground, the power required for a turboprop engine is pretty low. Therefore, the controls have been adapted such that the blade pitch angle (therefore the thrust produced) is controlled directly by the pilot, overriding the CSU. This ground range is known as the BETA control range. The flight crew will select a blade pitch angle by moving the power lever fully aft and lifting it up. The first detent of the BETA range will correspond to the ground idle detent that will allow the pilots to produce a minimum level of thrust, just enough power to taxi the aircraft. If the lever is pulled full aft of the BETA range, the pilot will lower the blade pitch angle such that the maximum reverse power is produced (=negative thrust). This will usually be the case at landing in order to assist the aircraft’s deceleration.

key_points: The typical start sequence of a gas turbine engine on the ground would be the following: Start selected: the start valve admits air supplied by the pneumatic system to operate the starter
In nowadays commercial aircraft, the FADEC controls the start valve electrically and operates it pneumatically with bleed air
Ignition ON: the igniters are selected ON and are ready to light the mixture
learning.explanation: The typical start sequence of a gas turbine engine on the ground would be the following: Start selected: the start valve admits air supplied by the pneumatic system to operate the starter. In nowadays commercial aircraft, the FADEC controls the start valve electrically and operates it pneumatically with bleed air. Ignition ON: the igniters are selected ON and are ready to light the mixture. High-pressure fuel ON: after fuel is delivered by the high-pressure shut-off valve (HPSOV) it is sprayed into the combustion chamber by fuel nozzles under high-pressure where it is mixed with compressed air and lights up. Light-up: the mixture starts burning and the flame spreads all along with the combustion chamber (since it is interconnected). The flame becomes self-sustainable. Self-sustaining speed: all the engine’s spools have reached a self-sustaining speed where assistance from the air starter is not needed anymore. The air starter is disengaged by the coupling between engine N2 spool and starter by the use of centrifugal forces. Starter circuit canceled.

options.B: Compression ratio 1: 8.6.
options.C: A rotor and a stator.
options.D: A stator and a rotor.

key_points: The principle of operation of an axial flow compressor is to add kinetic energy to the air and then convert it into pressure energy
This is achieved through a series of aerofoil section blades called ‘rotors’ mounted on a rotating rotor disc that accelerate the air towards a set of ‘stator’ blades
Each set of rotor-stator sequence is called a stage
learning.explanation: The principle of operation of an axial flow compressor is to add kinetic energy to the air and then convert it into pressure energy. This is achieved through a series of aerofoil section blades called ‘rotors’ mounted on a rotating rotor disc that accelerate the air towards a set of ‘stator’ blades. Each set of rotor-stator sequence is called a stage. The transition between the rotors and the stators is shaped into a divergent duct in order to convert the kinetic energy of the airflow into pressure energy. Because of the small pressure increase at each compressor stage, numerous stages are required to achieve the desired delivery pressure at the combustion chamber. Each compressor stage consists of rotor blades followed by a row of stator blades and will provide a pressure ratio of about 1.1 or 1.2:1.

key_points: With fewer spools, the air intake needs to be larger in order to reach the desired efficiency and pressure ratio

By dividing the gas turbine engine into different spools (two or more) they will be working at various speeds independently, thus increasing each spool’s and ultimately, the engine’s overall efficiency

This will consequently give greater stall margins from one stage to the other, therefore, the need for variable stator vanes and variable inlet guide vanes will be less prominent to prevent compressor stall at low rotor speeds

By dividing the gas turbine engine into different spools (two or more) they will be working at various speeds independently, thus increasing each spool’s and ultimately, the engine’s overall efficiency. This will consequently give greater stall margins from one stage to the other, therefore, the need for variable stator vanes and variable inlet guide vanes will be less prominent to prevent compressor stall at low rotor speeds.

content.question: The blades in an axial flow compressor decrease in size from the…

key_points: The blades in an axial flow compressor decrease in size from the front stages to the rear stages, giving the compressor an overall converging shape
The purpose of this geometry is to sustain axial velocity as the pressure increases from the low pressure to the high-pressure stages
In the same way, the converging shape of the compressor assembly will result in the HP shaft rotating faster than the LP shaft
learning.explanation: The blades in an axial flow compressor decrease in size from the front stages to the rear stages, giving the compressor an overall converging shape. The purpose of this geometry is to sustain axial velocity as the pressure increases from the low pressure to the high-pressure stages. In the same way, the converging shape of the compressor assembly will result in the HP shaft rotating faster than the LP shaft.

key_points: Most high bypass ratio engines are fitted with a blocker-type system

These are special, because, unlike the bucket and clamshell doors, the blocker type is designed to only reverse the bypass air (cold section) that is accelerated by the inlet fan, and not both the bypass air and the air passing through the core of the engine (hot section)

Considering that the latest aircraft, like the 777x have a 10:1 bypass ratio, which means that the mass of air going around the core of the engine is 10 time that going through the core, it makes sense to use the blocker reverse thrust system and reverse the flow of the bypass air (=fan flow) only
learning.explanation: Most high bypass ratio engines are fitted with a blocker-type system. These are special, because, unlike the bucket and clamshell doors, the blocker type is designed to only reverse the bypass air (cold section) that is accelerated by the inlet fan, and not both the bypass air and the air passing through the core of the engine (hot section). Considering that the latest aircraft, like the 777x have a 10:1 bypass ratio, which means that the mass of air going around the core of the engine is 10 time that going through the core, it makes sense to use the blocker reverse thrust system and reverse the flow of the bypass air (=fan flow) only. Only a little will be lost by not reversing the core section airflow while allowing great cost savings by fitting a simpler system.

content.question:
Which statement is correct for a gas turbine engine with constant speed propeller and free power turbine, when the power setting is decreased?
I. The propeller blade angle decreases
II. The free power turbine speed increases

options.A: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.D: I is correct, II is correct.

key_points: A gas turbine engine free turbine does not drive a compressor, i
e
there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine free turbine does not drive a compressor, i.e. there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft. The energy delivered by the free turbine stages is only dependent on the rotational speed of the HP spool. In this configuration, the engine will simply act as a gas generator to supply high-energy gases to an independent free power turbine driving a propeller or rotor via a reduction gearbox. This is why this type of turbine is often used on turboprop engines and helicopters. In fact, there will be two major assemblies: one shaft known as the HP spool and connecting the compressor and the compressor-driving turbine, and a free turbine placed after the compressor-driving turbine that is connected to a propeller. Because these two assemblies are not interconnected in any way, the propeller and free turbine assembly will be able to rotate at an independent speed from that of the HP spool. The most suitable control system for a turboprop fitted with a free turbine is the direct control of fuel flow. In this system, the gas generator (the core of the engine) is controlled in the same manner as a turbojet, and the power available to the free turbine assembly is governed by the fuel flow. For instance: If the power setting is increased (due to an increased fuel flow), the RPM of the HP spool will also increase and the axial airflow will be momentarily lagging, causing the EGT to increase. However, the free turbine and propeller assembly will be maintained at constant RPM by the Constant Speed Unit (CSU) that will do so by increasing the propeller’s blade angle. If the power setting is decreased, the RPM of the HP spool and the EGT will also decrease. However, the free turbine and propeller assembly will be maintained at constant RPM by the Constant Speed Unit (CSU) that will do so by decreasing the propeller’s blade angle.

The auxiliary gearbox of most gas turbine engine is driven by the HP compressor shaft via an internal gearbox to an external gearbox

The auxiliary gearbox of most gas turbine engine is driven by the HP compressor shaft via an internal gearbox to an external gearbox. It provides the drive for a wide variety of services. The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs
Secondary advantages include fuel savings and that, under certain circumstances, it may be possible to increase the maximum takeoff weight for a specific runway by using a reduced thrust profile
learning.explanation: Advantages of using reduced take-off thrust Using reduced thrust lowers the jet engine's internal operating pressure and temperature. The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs. Secondary advantages include fuel savings and that, under certain circumstances, it may be possible to increase the maximum takeoff weight for a specific runway by using a reduced thrust profile. key_points: A gas turbine engine is generally providing minimal vibration
Therefore, even a small increase in the level of vibration is a clear indicator of a potential impending failure

An Engine Vibration Monitoring system is fitted to detect mechanical deficiencies in the rotating parts (such as the bearings and spools) of an engine so that corrective action is taken before greater damage occurs
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine is generally providing minimal vibration. Therefore, even a small increase in the level of vibration is a clear indicator of a potential impending failure. An Engine Vibration Monitoring system is fitted to detect mechanical deficiencies in the rotating parts (such as the bearings and spools) of an engine so that corrective action is taken before greater damage occurs. The vibration monitoring unit measures the radial and transverse vibrations using accelerometers operating on the piezo-electric principle. The frequencies of the detected vibrations will be filtered so that only those indicating a potential malfunction are considered. After being filtered, the frequencies are then amplified before being sent to the vibration indicator.

key_points: The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is a small gas turbine engine located on the tail of the aircraft able to deliver pressurized air and electrical power
It can also deliver air for cabin air conditioning and for main engine starting
An APU has its own electric starter motor powered either by the airplane’s main batteries or by the Ground Power Unit (if connected)
learning.explanation: The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is a small gas turbine engine located on the tail of the aircraft able to deliver pressurized air and electrical power. It can also deliver air for cabin air conditioning and for main engine starting. An APU has its own electric starter motor powered either by the airplane’s main batteries or by the Ground Power Unit (if connected). The APU uses fuel from the main fuel tanks (the left main tank on the A320) and burns about 130 kg/h on the ground (A320 APU). In order to use the APU in flight, it needs to be certified and guarantee that the starting sequence can be carried out at high altitudes and operate under load at even higher altitudes. A dedicated flight deck APU control panel consists of a master switch button and a start button. The master switch will simply energize the APU system and its internal computer. It will also open the air intake flap and open the fuel isolation valve. The start switch is putting the ignition ON and starts the automatic start sequence. Either some lights, or a separate fault panel, or an electronic APU monitoring page will display and announce any APU faults. The APU will automatically shut down in one of the following cases: Overspeed, No acceleration, Low oil pressure, EGT overtemperature, High oil temperature, Underspeed, Reverse flow, etc.

content.question: When starting a turbine engine, the igniters were incorrectly left off and a wet start occurred. After ignition in the second start sequence, what will happen?

options.A: A wet start will happen again, because the excessive fuel from the previous start attempt has not been removed.
options.B: The fuel deposits from the previous start attempt in the combustion chamber will burn up instantaneously, resulting in an explosion and a rapid rise of TGT.
options.C: The engine will operate with significantly lower TGT value, until all the excessive fuel from the previous start attempt has been burnt.
options.D: The turbine engine will continue to operate within normal range, since the excessive fuel is drained by drain valves in the combustion section.

key_points: DRAIN VALVE In a gas turbine engine combustion chamber, the fuel and air mixture usually burn at the chemically correct mixture, in order to burn hotter and more efficiently, in theory burning all of the fuel perfectly
Sometimes, however, there can be deposits of unburnt fuel that build up on the walls of the combustion chamber, which will need to drain from the engine somehow

A much more common usage of a vent/drain valve is after a "wet start", where a start malfunction has occurred that stopped the engine from igniting the fuel, and the fuel has been sprayed out of the nozzles but not burned, so is now sat in the bottom of the combustion chamber
learning.explanation: DRAIN VALVE In a gas turbine engine combustion chamber, the fuel and air mixture usually burn at the chemically correct mixture, in order to burn hotter and more efficiently, in theory burning all of the fuel perfectly. Sometimes, however, there can be deposits of unburnt fuel that build up on the walls of the combustion chamber, which will need to drain from the engine somehow. A much more common usage of a vent/drain valve is after a "wet start", where a start malfunction has occurred that stopped the engine from igniting the fuel, and the fuel has been sprayed out of the nozzles but not burned, so is now sat in the bottom of the combustion chamber. This situation could be made very dangerous if the engine is immediately started again, this time with a pool of fuel at the bottom, and could lead to a "hot start", with the potential for large flames to be sent out of the back of the engine. This could also overheat the turbine if there is not enough cooling airflow during start to counteract the large fire. In aircraft with no vent/drain valve, the pilots would usually run the starter without running the igniters to blow the fuel away, but in the vast majority of engines, a vent/drain valve is fitted, and automatically drains the fuel from the area. This is much easier and can drain the fuel out of the combustion chamber quickly and safely. Seen as the question mentions the pilot has waited a while, we have no problems saying that the fuel should have drained by that point, and therefore the next start should be uneventful.

options.B: The fuel flow remains constant, the CSU adjusts the propeller. The propeller and turbine RPM increase before the CSU responds.
options.C: The fuel flow will reduce, the CSU adjusts the propeller to a lower pitch. The propeller and turbine RPM increase before the CSU responds.
options.D: The fuel flow will reduce, the CSU adjusts the propeller towards a lower pitch. The propeller and turbine RPM decrease before the CSU responds.

key_points: In a variable pitch propeller, the engine is governed to run at a set RPM throughout the flight range
The propeller governs the engine at this set rpm by the use of a device known as a constant speed unit (CSU) and by means of a flyweight governor

Any variations in engine power output (throttle pulled back or forward), which would otherwise produce a change in RPM, are sensed by the CSU which alters the propeller pitch angle to keep the rpm constant
learning.explanation: In a variable pitch propeller, the engine is governed to run at a set RPM throughout the flight range. The propeller governs the engine at this set rpm by the use of a device known as a constant speed unit (CSU) and by means of a flyweight governor. Any variations in engine power output (throttle pulled back or forward), which would otherwise produce a change in RPM, are sensed by the CSU which alters the propeller pitch angle to keep the rpm constant. If the throttle is pulled back, the propeller pitch would automatically decrease (fine pitch) but the RPM will remain the same, and vice-versa. Free turbine engine here refers to free-turbine turboshaft which is a form of turboshaft or turboprop gas turbine engine where the power is extracted from the exhaust stream of a gas turbine by an independent turbine, downstream of the gas turbine. The power turbine is not mechanically connected to the turbines that drive the compressors, hence the term "free", referring to the independence of the power output shaft (or spool). This is opposed to the power being extracted from the turbine/compressor shaft via a gearbox. Note: We placed this question in this sub-section since it is about propeller properties. How the power is generated is not very relevant.

content.question: Which of the following best describes the aerodynamic principle of reaction type turbine blades?

options.A: It is based on Newton's Third Law, stating that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
options.B: It relies on the generation of lift through the pressure difference between the upper and lower surfaces of an aerofoil.
options.C: It involves the use of jet propulsion to produce forward thrust by expelling air or gases backward.
options.D: It is the principle used in rotorcraft to generate lift by creating a spinning airflow.

key_points: Impulse turbines use a convergent duct in the NGV to accelerate the airflow first, then use the "water wheel" bucket style design of the turbine to turn that fast airflow the other way
This is a change in momentum, called an impulse
We would say that this is a prime example of Newton's third law in action, as there really isn't much else going on
learning.explanation: Impulse turbines use a convergent duct in the NGV to accelerate the airflow first, then use the "water wheel" bucket style design of the turbine to turn that fast airflow the other way. This is a change in momentum, called an impulse. We would say that this is a prime example of Newton's third law in action, as there really isn't much else going on. Reaction turbines use much simpler (non convergent) NGVs, which direct the airflow at the proper angle into the turbine blades, which then turn and accelerate the air through convergent blades, which produces the majority of the turbine movement. The angle of the airflow on the turbine blades provides some of the turning force on the turbine, but the majority appears to come from the aerodynamic effects of the aerofoil shape as well as the converging section, which trades the high pressure for velocity, providing quite a good axial flow design for a multi-stage turbine. In reality, all gas turbine engines use a combination impulse-reaction turbine these days, as it is better to mix the two. Note: The correct answer is not verified for this question yet, and whilst we believe the aerofoil answer is certainly most correct, it would be easy to choose the answer about Newton's third law, either due to mixing the two types up, by the name "reaction", or simply due to the fact that everything obeys Newton's third law, however, the reaction type turbine blades are not "based on it" like impulse type turbines are.

learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine is basically a heat engine using air as a fluid to produce thrust. Summary: Piston engine Process is intermittent. Combustion is at constant volume. Jet engine Process is continuous. Combustion is at constant pressure.

content.question:
The function of the swirl vanes round the fuel nozzles in a gas turbine engine is to:
1. increase air pressure at the fuel nozzles
2. reduce the average axial flow speed in order to stabilise the flame front
3. generate a swirl of incoming air to enhance mixing of the fuel with air
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The fuel nozzles of the gas turbine combustion chamber provide a continuous supply of fuel to ensure continuous combustion
The fuel delivered at high pressure to the atomizers (nozzles) goes through tangential grooves/holes into a concentric conical or cylindrical swirl chamber situated just before the final orifice
As the fuel enters the swirl vane, its average axial flow velocity decreases to stabilize the flame front
learning.explanation: The fuel nozzles of the gas turbine combustion chamber provide a continuous supply of fuel to ensure continuous combustion. The fuel delivered at high pressure to the atomizers (nozzles) goes through tangential grooves/holes into a concentric conical or cylindrical swirl chamber situated just before the final orifice. As the fuel enters the swirl vane, its average axial flow velocity decreases to stabilize the flame front. The second crucial effect is that the fuel spins around causing its angular velocity to increase as the radius of swirl decreases, thus converging all the fluid pressure energy into kinetic energy. The fuel, in its passage through the swirl chamber to the final orifice, generates a swirl with both axial and tangential velocity components, and it therefore, emerges from the orifice as a hollow cone-shaped spray.

content.question: When would a gas turbine engine's igniters be used continuously and at what intensity?

options.A: High intensity and they are used during engine start-up.
options.B: Low intensity and they are used during engine start-up.
options.C: High intensity and they are used in situations where there's a risk of engine flameout.
options.D: Low intensity and they are used in situations where there's a risk of engine flameout.

key_points: When the engines are running, continuous ignition can be selected either manually by the flight crew or in some aircraft, automatically by the FADEC to maintain engine combustion

The FADEC will automatically turn ON continuous ignition when the engine anti-ice is ON, maximum thrust is selected, idle thrust is selected during approach, or a thrust control malfunction is detected (risk of flame-out), etc
On some aircraft, it can even be automatically activated when the stall warning system alerts of an impending stall
learning.explanation: When the engines are running, continuous ignition can be selected either manually by the flight crew or in some aircraft, automatically by the FADEC to maintain engine combustion. The FADEC will automatically turn ON continuous ignition when the engine anti-ice is ON, maximum thrust is selected, idle thrust is selected during approach, or a thrust control malfunction is detected (risk of flame-out), etc. On some aircraft, it can even be automatically activated when the stall warning system alerts of an impending stall. The flight crew will manually select continuous ignition when passing through a heavy precipitation area, moderate or severe turbulence, high ambient air temperatures, or anytime a lack of sufficient airflow or fuel into the engine is expected. These conditions could potentially stop the engine's combustion, causing a flameout, so igniters are set to continuous to stop this. The continuous ignition is low-energy-level since there’s no need for such a strong spark as during engine start, but only to ensure combustion is continuous.

content.question: A pilot in the cruise notices abnormal fluctuations in RPM and a drop in EPR, accompanied by a high ITT (Interstage Turbine Temperature) and popping noises coming from engine number one. Which of these could be the cause?

options.A: Turbine overspeed.
options.B: Compressor stall.
options.C: Engine fire.
options.D: FADEC control unit failure.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.02.02.18: Describe the indications of stall and surge. A compressor stall is a phenomenon that can happen in a gas turbine engine where some sort of local disruption of airflow occurs, and causes a change in the aerodynamics of the compressor. It is so named, because it is usually made up of the individual compressor blades stalling. This can vary in its effect on the engine, from a transient stall that has no major effect, to a stall that spreads to other turbine blades and stages, causing a full surge of the compressor, when it can no longer maintain the high pressure gradient from inlet to combustion chamber. The disruption of airflow in a compressor stall reduces the cooling airflow into the turbine (the point in the engine closest to its maximum temperature), causing a rise in TGT (Turbine Gas Temperature), both before the turbine stage (TIT - Turbine Inlet Temperature) and between the individual turbines (ITT - Interstage Turbine Temperature). Alongside these temperature rises (which could cause the temperature limits to be exceeded, the RPM of the turbines/compressors will fluctuate, and the EPR (engine pressure ratio) will drop, as the engine is no longer working optimally. A compressor stall can cause pops or bangs to be heard from the cabin, particularly if it leads to a surge, which is a full breakdown of the airflow through the compressor, often requiring the engine to be brought down to idle in order to fix the problem. None of the other options in this question would cause fluctuations and pops/bangs, only severe damage, shutdown, or maybe constant RPM (in the case of a FADEC control unit failure).

content.question: One of the purposes of compressor bleed valves in a gas turbine engine is to…

options.A: decrease the airflow across the rear compressor stages, whilst that across the early stages is increased.
options.B: decrease the load on the compressor when the engine is approaching maximum rpm.
options.C: limit the acceleration period of the engine.
options.D: increase the airflow across the rear compressor stages, whilst that across the early stages is decreased.

key_points: A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand
Due to a low rotor speed, airflow velocity becomes very small and air stagnates in the REAR stages (increase of back pressure), which results in a lack of air in the FRONT stages
This further induces a subsequent low axial velocity in front stages and will lead to a high angle of attack of the rotor blades determining a STALL (at the front stages first)
learning.explanation: A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand. Due to a low rotor speed, airflow velocity becomes very small and air stagnates in the REAR stages (increase of back pressure), which results in a lack of air in the FRONT stages. This further induces a subsequent low axial velocity in front stages and will lead to a high angle of attack of the rotor blades determining a STALL (at the front stages first). Usually, this is followed by a complete compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. That’s why the tapped excessive pressure is relieved by means of a bleed valve that will open at the front stages and recirculate the bleed air towards the air conditioning unit and other systems. This is determined by the engine operating regime so that any unwanted rise in air pressure can be relieved and prevent the conditions which will cause a surge.

content.question: Which of these is a possible issue that may arise in a turbine engine when flying in very turbulent conditions?

options.A: Compressor surge due to disturbed airflow.
options.B: Increased specific fuel consumption.
options.C: Reduced cabin pressurisation.
options.D: Increased risk of ice accretion.

key_points: Heavy in-flight turbulence may oscillate the aircraft so rapidly in a perpendicular direction to the airflow that occasional flow separation may occur, as unstable flow feeds the engine

The intake is designed to accept air that arrives from ahead, but if air has to "turn the corner" to get into the intake, it can separate from the intake walls and become turbulent, causing "dead spots" on the compressor disc where the airflow isn't fast enough to feed the compressor
Stall and surge may occur as a consequence of the severe in-flight turbulence
learning.explanation: Heavy in-flight turbulence may oscillate the aircraft so rapidly in a perpendicular direction to the airflow that occasional flow separation may occur, as unstable flow feeds the engine. The intake is designed to accept air that arrives from ahead, but if air has to "turn the corner" to get into the intake, it can separate from the intake walls and become turbulent, causing "dead spots" on the compressor disc where the airflow isn't fast enough to feed the compressor. Stall and surge may occur as a consequence of the severe in-flight turbulence. A compressor stall occurs when the pressure demand outweighs the ability of the compressor stages; in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM, and a stall on a few blades can quickly de-stabilise the whole multi-stage compressor, causing a full surge, and the air may even begin to flow the wrong way.

content.question: The re-light envelope defines the optimum conditions for when a turbine-engine can be re-ignited following a flame-out. It is based on…

options.A: groundspeed and engine rotation speed.
options.B: aircraft mass and outside air temperature.
options.C: airspeed and altitude.
options.D: wind direction and humidity.

key_points: The normal starting system (including the starter motor) is not used when relighting in flight, as the engine will be normally turning sufficiently fast due to the forward speed of the aircraft
This will ensure a continuous and sufficient mass flow is entering the compressor to turn it at a normal RPM so that only the igniters and fuel supply need to be activated
Besides airspeed, the mass flow of air will also greatly be impacted by altitude
learning.explanation: The normal starting system (including the starter motor) is not used when relighting in flight, as the engine will be normally turning sufficiently fast due to the forward speed of the aircraft. This will ensure a continuous and sufficient mass flow is entering the compressor to turn it at a normal RPM so that only the igniters and fuel supply need to be activated. The Aircraft Flight Manual will publish the re-light envelope tables/graphs along with the necessary procedures to guarantee a successful inflight relight.

After experiencing a loud bang, a master caution annunciator and a large yawing moment to the right which you correct by pushing left rudder. The Pilot Flying in a twin engine jet aircraft asks the Pilot Monitoring to "State the malfunction" and get the following reply; "Number 2 Engine" "NO N1 Rotation" "NO N2 Rotation" "NO Fuel Flow" "High EGT" "High Oil TEMP" "LOW Oil Pressure" "High Vibration".
What has most likely happened?

options.A: The aircraft suffered a rapid decompression and the loud bang was from a cockpit window bursting.
options.B: A tyre on the main wheel has bursted and the aircraft is skidding off the runway.
options.C: The aircraft has ingested FOD in to the right engine.

key_points: Foreign object damage (FOD) is a big problem in aviation maintenance industry that reduces the level of safety for an aircraft
In fact, it can only be controlled and minimized properly by using the right and precise control method
Basically, FOD is known as foreign object (FO) that can cause severity and destruction to the aircraft such as engine failure and loss of human life
learning.explanation: Foreign object damage (FOD) is a big problem in aviation maintenance industry that reduces the level of safety for an aircraft. In fact, it can only be controlled and minimized properly by using the right and precise control method. Basically, FOD is known as foreign object (FO) that can cause severity and destruction to the aircraft such as engine failure and loss of human life. FOD is a severe hazard for gas turbine engines, as solid objects can cause serious structural damage that can lead to disintegration and even fire. The RPM is very high, and there is a large momentum of moving parts, so a collision with solid objects releases a lot of impact energy. The indications of FOD ingestion would be: "NO N1 Rotation"; "NO N2 Rotation"; "NO Fuel Flow"; "High EGT"; "High Oil TEMP"; "LOW Oil Pressure"; "High Vibration". In this case, NO 2 (right engine) has ingested FOD. To further confirm this, a large yawing moment to the right, possibly indicates a right engine failure.

content.question: Which of the following sequences correctly describes the order to start a gas turbine engine?

options.A: Compressor rotation, ignition on, fuel injection.
options.B: Ignition on, compressor rotation, fuel injection.
options.C: Compressor rotation, fuel injection, ignition on.
options.D: Fuel injection, ignition on, compressor rotation.

key_points: STARTING AND IGNITION The start sequence is initiated by an electrical starter motor or high-pressure air-starter motor powered by bleed air
In-flight restarting uses fuel and ignition selection only as the wind-milling engine supplies the rotation of the engine
There are three elements and a particular order to achieving a successful engine start in-flight: Rotation
learning.explanation: STARTING AND IGNITION The start sequence is initiated by an electrical starter motor or high-pressure air-starter motor powered by bleed air. In-flight restarting uses fuel and ignition selection only as the wind-milling engine supplies the rotation of the engine. There are three elements and a particular order to achieving a successful engine start in-flight: Rotation. Provides high pressure air into the combustion chamber and introduces cooling airflow to stop the combustion from melting the turbine. Also used to clear the engine of excess fuel if it has a start malfunction. Ignition. The high voltage sparks for igniting the air/fuel mixture must start before the fuel is introduced. Fuel. Supplied as an atomized vapour in the flame tube by individual fuel spray nozzles. With the air and sparks, this should ignite immediately and begin turning the turbine.

content.question:
Which of the following statements is correct about the flow in a divergent (subsonic) gas turbine engine intake?
1. The dynamic pressure increases in flow direction
2. The static temperature increases in flow direction

options.A: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.
options.B: Both 1 and 2 are correct.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.

key_points: Statement 1 is incorrect, but statement 2 is correct
The intake geometry is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect
It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed
learning.explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect, but statement 2 is correct. The intake geometry is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect. It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed. That’s why the intake is slightly divergent in order to reduce the airflow’s velocity (=dynamic pressure) and increase the static pressure and temperature just before the fan and compressor’s first stages. Caution, the total pressure (and temperature) will remain constant - it is only a trade of dynamic pressure for static pressure. Compression (=increase in static pressure) is a process where heat is released, which explains why the temperature behaves in the same way through a divergent duct as pressure. This geometry is also called the ‘pitot intake’, and it has thick, smoothly rounded lips to prevent flow separation under any flight conditions/maneuvers.

content.question: If a twin spool gas turbine engine is controlled by a conventional N2 control system, rupture of the LP shaft may result in…

options.A: N1 decrease and EPR increase.
options.B: N1 and N2 increase.
options.C: overspeed of the LP turbine.
options.D: N2 and EPR increase.

key_points: The turbine drives the compressor mounted on a common shaft
It generates the required energy, known as shaft power, using the expansion of hot gases, and then by converting the kinetic energy of the gases (velocity) into mechanical work
In case of rupture of the shaft that links the LP compressor and LP turbine, the turbine won’t have anything to drive anymore while still being driven by the gases exiting the combustion chamber
learning.explanation: The turbine drives the compressor mounted on a common shaft. It generates the required energy, known as shaft power, using the expansion of hot gases, and then by converting the kinetic energy of the gases (velocity) into mechanical work. In case of rupture of the shaft that links the LP compressor and LP turbine, the turbine won’t have anything to drive anymore while still being driven by the gases exiting the combustion chamber. Therefore, all the energy that would be normally used to drive the LP compressor will instead further accelerate and increase the rotational speed of the turbine, causing it to eventually overspeed.

content.question: A turbofan engine with an inlet air mass flow of 220 kg/s and a bypass mass flow of 200 kg/s has a bypass ratio of…

key_points: Formulas: Bypass mass flow = inlet mass flow - HP compressor mass flow HP compressor mass flow = 220 kg/s - 200 kg/s = 20 kg/s Bypass ratio = bypass mass flow / HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio = 200 kg/s / 20 kg/s = 10

content.question: In a single stage of a gas turbine axial compressor the sequence of blades is…

options.A: stator – rotor.
options.B: rotor – stator.
options.C: stator – stator – rotor.
options.D: rotor – rotor – stator.

key_points: The principle of operation of an axial flow compressor is to add kinetic energy to the air and then convert it into pressure energy
This is achieved through a series of aerofoil section blades called ‘rotors’ mounted on a rotating rotor disc that accelerate the air towards a set of ‘stator’ blades
Each set of rotor-stator sequence is called a stage
learning.explanation: The principle of operation of an axial flow compressor is to add kinetic energy to the air and then convert it into pressure energy. This is achieved through a series of aerofoil section blades called ‘rotors’ mounted on a rotating rotor disc that accelerate the air towards a set of ‘stator’ blades. Each set of rotor-stator sequence is called a stage. The transition between the rotors and the stators is shaped into a divergent duct in order to convert the kinetic energy of the airflow into pressure energy. Because of the small pressure increase at each compressor stage, numerous stages are required to achieve the desired delivery pressure at the combustion chamber. Each compressor stage consists of rotor blades followed by a row of stator blades and will provide a pressure ratio of 1.1 to 1.2.

content.question: When operating a turbine engine in flight, if you observe fluctuations in RPM, elevated temperatures between turbine stages, and hear clicking sounds, the most probable scenario is…

options.A: A compressor turbulence.
options.B: An engine overspeed.
options.C: A compressor buffet.
options.D: Compressor surge.

key_points: Compressor stall arises from a reduction in axial velocity across the compressor
Stall represents a partial breakdown of airflow within the engine, while surge indicates a complete breakdown
Compressor stall typically progresses, starting from a single blade and potentially affecting an entire stage before spreading to the entire engine if unaddressed
learning.explanation: Compressor stall arises from a reduction in axial velocity across the compressor. Stall represents a partial breakdown of airflow within the engine, while surge indicates a complete breakdown. Compressor stall typically progresses, starting from a single blade and potentially affecting an entire stage before spreading to the entire engine if unaddressed. Ultimately, this progression leads to surge, potentially causing an instantaneous reversal of engine gases, often accompanied by a loud noise. Indicators of stall include heightened engine vibration and increased exhaust gas temperature (EGT). The rise in EGT results from reduced airflow to the combustion chambers, limiting the cooling effect on exhaust gases. Signs of surge encompass: Loud noise; RPM fluctuations; Significant increase in EGT, and a resultant loss of thrust that may cause the aircraft to yaw. If surge occurs, it's crucial to gradually close the throttle of the affected engine.

content.question: The axial compressor of a gas turbine engine usually has more stages than its driving turbine because…

options.A: the power output of a turbine stage is higher than the power consumption of a compressor stage.
options.B: bleed air is taken from the compressor.
options.C: turbine speed is much higher than compressor speed.

key_points: The compressor’s main task is to increase the mass flow through the engine by pressurizing the air
Its efficiency depends mostly on the aerofoil sections, pitch angles, and the length/chord ratios of the blades
The compressor is an annular duct through which the air passes and across which are arranged a series of small blades of aerofoil section that will compress the incoming air
learning.explanation: The compressor’s main task is to increase the mass flow through the engine by pressurizing the air. The compressor is an annular duct through which the air passes and across which are arranged a series of small blades of aerofoil section that will compress the incoming air. Because of the small pressure increase at each compressor stage, numerous stages are required to achieve the desired delivery pressure at the combustion chamber. Another reason is that the power output of a turbine stage is higher than the power consumption of a compressor stage, therefore by fitting several compressor stages the power generated by the turbine can be efficiently used.

content.question: When the outside air temperature (OAT) is (1) _____ than the flat rated temperature of the engine, the maximum available thrust of a turbine engine is restricted by the maximum (2) _____ the turbine blades can withstand.

options.A: (1) less; (2) pressure
options.B: (1) higher; (2) pressure
options.C: (1) higher; (2) temperature
options.D: (1) less; (2) temperature

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.05.01.03: Explain the term ‘flat-rated engine’ by describing the change of take-off thrust, turbine inlet temperature and engine rpm with outside air temperature (OAT). Turbine engines operate with very fine margins, and contain incredible heat and immense rotational speeds. They are, however, still reliant on the outside air for their oxygen, without which they cannot burn fuel. When the outside air is colder, or when the aircraft is at low altitudes, they are very powerful, as there is plenty of air available to compress and then burn. Of course, at higher altitudes and/or in warmer air, the air is less dense, so the engine has to work harder to produce the same thrust output, and therefore has a lower maximum thrust. There is a second effect of extra heat in the air though, and that is on the turbine. The turbine is the most highly stressed area of a gas turbine engine, and is also located in the hottest section of the engine. That means that there is a maximum Turbine Gas Temperature (TGT) that cannot be exceeded, as the turbine blades could become permanently deformed. When the air outside is hotter, there is a certain point at which the TGT becomes the limiting factor to how much thrust the engine can produce, and this is usually around the region of ISA +15°C. As the OAT gets hotter than that, the engine thrust continues to reduce, as we are not able to burn as hot, without potentially damaging the turbine blades. We call this the "temperature limited" or "TGT limited" range. Below this range is the "flat-rated range", and the temperature where the two ranges meet is the flat rated temperature. In this range, the air is cool enough to be limited by the maximum mass flow of the engine, rather than by any temperature considerations. For summary; OAT below the flat rated temperature = flat rated OAT above the flat rated temperature = temperature limited.

Therefore, there is no change in speed or pressure across them, only a change in direction
Therefore, correct option: INCORRECT, INCORRECT IMPORTANT NOTE: Please note that we received initial feedback from students confirming that the correct answer was "correct, incorrect

Therefore, there is no change in speed or pressure across them, only a change in direction. Therefore, correct option: INCORRECT, INCORRECT IMPORTANT NOTE: Please note that we received initial feedback from students confirming that the correct answer was "correct, incorrect." content.question: In a subsonic convergent duct the…

options.A: temperature increases, velocity increases and pressure decreases
options.B: pressure increases, velocity decreases and temperature increases
options.C: pressure increases, velocity decreases and temperature decreases
options.D: velocity increases, pressure decreases and temperature decreases

key_points: Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) Total Pressure = Dynamic Pressure (½ρV2) + Static Pressure = Constant The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure)
The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy
Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other
learning.explanation: Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) Total Pressure = Dynamic Pressure (½ρV2) + Static Pressure = Constant The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q= 1/2* ρ* V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. In Conclusion: In a convergent duct, flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure (= velocity). If dynamic pressure increases, static pressure and static temperature decrease. In a divergent duct, flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (=velocity). If dynamic pressure decreases, static pressure and static temperature increase.

content.question: Which parameters are most commonly used to set and monitor a turbo-propeller engine`s power?

options.A: The ratio of engine fuel flow to the engine fuel pressure.
options.B: The turning moment, which is proportional to the horse power.
options.C: The helix rotational speed compared to the outside air temperature.
options.D: The engine pressure ratio, defined by the turbine inlet and outlet pressures.

key_points: Power Output = torque × RPM (power = rate of doing work; work done per unit of time)
Brake Horse Power (BHP) = Power available at the crankshaft
Indicated Horse Power (IHP) = Power developed in the cylinder
learning.explanation: Power Output = torque × RPM (power = rate of doing work; work done per unit of time). Brake Horse Power (BHP) = Power available at the crankshaft. Indicated Horse Power (IHP) = Power developed in the cylinder. Mechanical Efficiency = Brake Horse Power × 100% ÷ Indicated Horse Power. Friction Horsepower (FHP) = the frictional and power losses due to engine-driven accessories. Indicated Horsepower (IHP) takes no account of any work done within the engine to overcome friction. The indicated horsepower is a purely theoretical value and is reduced by the friction horsepower to give brake horsepower (BHP). This is the power actually delivered by the crankshaft to the propeller gearing.

content.question: A free turbine in a gas turbine engine is a turbine…

options.A: that drives the high pressure compressor of a twin-spool engine.
options.B: that can be decoupled with a free-wheel clutch.
options.C: in a twin-spool aircraft gas turbine driving a fan.
options.D: that does not drive a compressor.

key_points: A gas turbine engine free turbine does not drive a compressor, i
e
there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine free turbine does not drive a compressor, i.e. there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft. The energy delivered by the free turbine stages is only dependent on the rotational speed of the HP spool. In this configuration, the engine will simply act as a gas generator to supply high-energy gases to an independent free power turbine driving a propeller or rotor via a reduction gearbox. The efficiency of the free turbine engine comes from its flexibility since it is very easy to start thanks to the absence of any propeller drag, and the propeller and gas generator can assume their optimum speeds independently.

content.question: Which of the following statements regarding variable inlet guide vanes (VIGVs) and variable stator vanes (VSVs) on a high-bypass turbine engine is correct?

key_points: The Variable Stator Vane system (VSV) controls the primary airflow through the HP compressor by varying the angle of the Inlet Guide Vanes (IGVs) and three stages of variable vanes to direct the airflow at the optimal angle to the compressor’s first stage
The VSVs provide aerodynamic matching of the LP stages of compression with the HP stages to prevent engine surge
Some multi-spool engines (typically fitted with 3 spools) require fewer IGVs and VSVs since the different spools rotate at different speeds and provide greater overall efficiency
learning.explanation: The Variable Stator Vane system (VSV) controls the primary airflow through the HP compressor by varying the angle of the Inlet Guide Vanes (IGVs) and three stages of variable vanes to direct the airflow at the optimal angle to the compressor’s first stage. The VSVs provide aerodynamic matching of the LP stages of compression with the HP stages to prevent engine surge. Some multi-spool engines (typically fitted with 3 spools) require fewer IGVs and VSVs since the different spools rotate at different speeds and provide greater overall efficiency.

content.question: EPR can be defined as the ratio of…

options.A: the total turbine outlet pressure to the total compressor outlet pressure.
options.B: the total turbine inlet pressure to the total compressor inlet pressure.
options.C: the total turbine outlet pressure to the total compressor inlet pressure.
options.D: the total turbine inlet pressure to the total compressor outlet pressure.

key_points: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow
On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR
The EPR is the ratio between the low-pressure turbine exhaust pressure (the engine’s last stage) and the engine inlet pressure (the fan’s pressure)
learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The EPR is the ratio between the low-pressure turbine exhaust pressure (the engine’s last stage) and the engine inlet pressure (the fan’s pressure). It is a very precise parameter, so very gentle adjustments on the thrust levers must be made to achieve the desired power setting. EPR indicator pressure sensors can either be of the electromechanical type (bellows) or systems that transform a mechanical movement into an electric signal (transducer).

content.question: A hung (abortive) start of a gas turbine engine may be caused by…

options.A: compressor surging.
options.B: the starter cutting out early in the starting sequence before the engine has accelerated to the required rpm for ignition.
options.C: a too low pneumatic starter pressure.
options.D: failure of the fuel to ignite in the starting sequence after the engine has been accelerated to the required rpm by the starter.

key_points: Hung start - will result in N2 speed stabilizing at a lower than normal rpm and a subsequent increase in EGT
The engine fails to accelerate sufficiently because of a too low pneumatic starter pressure before the fuel is supplied to sustain combustion
Upon recognition of the hung start conditions, the flight crew needs to shut down the engine, conduct a cranking and initiate a cooling sequence before attempting a new engine start
learning.explanation: Hung start - will result in N2 speed stabilizing at a lower than normal rpm and a subsequent increase in EGT. The engine fails to accelerate sufficiently because of a too low pneumatic starter pressure before the fuel is supplied to sustain combustion. Upon recognition of the hung start conditions, the flight crew needs to shut down the engine, conduct a cranking and initiate a cooling sequence before attempting a new engine start. Hot start – usually caused by an early starter cut-out, fuel mis-scheduling (leading to excess fuel in the combustor), or strong tailwinds. Intermittent light-up at very low rpm (sub-idle) will be observed, followed by a very sudden increase in EGT. That’s why EGT monitoring is one of the most important parameters to monitor during the engine start sequence, which will allow you to abort the start immediately. Dry start – fuel fails to be delivered to the engine and light-up will not take place. The compressor will only reach a given RPM (rather low) because it will be driven only by the starter motor.

content.question: The primary reason for a limitation being imposed on the temperature of gas flow in a gas turbine is to…

options.A: ensure that the maximum acceptable temperature within the combustion chamber is not exceeded.
options.B: ensure that the maximum acceptable temperature at the turbine blades is not exceeded.
options.C: prevent overheating and subsequent creep of the nozzle guide vanes.
options.D: prevent damage to the jet pipe from overheating.

key_points: The turbine provides energy to increase the pressure of the airflow in the compressors and to power all the accessories needed for the aircraft
The turbine generates this energy, known as shaft power, using the expansion of hot gases, and then by converting the kinetic energy of the gases (velocity) into mechanical work
When the combustion gases pass through the turbine, the pressure drops
learning.explanation: The turbine provides energy to increase the pressure of the airflow in the compressors and to power all the accessories needed for the aircraft. The turbine generates this energy, known as shaft power, using the expansion of hot gases, and then by converting the kinetic energy of the gases (velocity) into mechanical work. When the combustion gases pass through the turbine, the pressure drops. The higher the temperature resulting from combustion, the greater the gas expansion and energy transfer to the turbine. However, because the materials used in the turbine assembly are temperature limited, temperature limitations are usually imposed on the turbine section to avoid its complete damage. Creep is the permanent and cumulative physical extension of a component under loads. The extend of the creep is mostly affected by the temperature and the centrifugal loadings, where the higher the temperature the greater the amount of creep. Therefore, the VSV system, the blades, and their rotors (where the creep phenomenon is the most severe) must be cooled to permit them to withstand the high turbine entry temperatures.

options.B: compressor accelerates the air in a rearward direction.
options.C: convergent duct accelerates the air in a rearward direction.

key_points: The propelling nozzle directs the exhaust gas aft and regulates the gas streamflow
It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent flow separation
That’s why most of the time it is converging so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher thrust
learning.explanation: The propelling nozzle directs the exhaust gas aft and regulates the gas streamflow. It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent flow separation. That’s why most of the time it is converging so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher thrust. The acceleration of the flow by the propelling nozzle can somehow disturb the airflow, so it is positioned at a distance from the jet pipe where the disturbances won’t cause flow separation.

The temperature of the spark is around 60 000 K and therefore heats the gases rapidly ensuring ignition in conditions of high altitude and low temperature.

content.question: One of the purposes of the bleed valves fitted to axial flow compressors is to…

options.A: reduce the tendency to compressor stall.
options.B: spill compressor air should the engine overspeed thus controlling the speed.
options.C: enable an external air supply to spin up the compressor for engine starting.
options.D: control the acceleration time of the engine.

key_points: Aircraft bleed is used for systems like the anti-icing of the wings and engines, providing air for the cabin pressurization, but also very importantly a way to reduce the stagnation in the rear of the compressor that leads to a stall in the engine, which potentially can lead to a surge
Therefore the correct answer is: “reduce the tendency to compressor stall” The other answers are incorrect: “spill compressor air should the engine overspeed thus controlling the speed
”: If the engine is in a overspeed conditions, removing air inside the compressor will only work against the objective
learning.explanation: Aircraft bleed is used for systems like the anti-icing of the wings and engines, providing air for the cabin pressurization, but also very importantly a way to reduce the stagnation in the rear of the compressor that leads to a stall in the engine, which potentially can lead to a surge. Therefore the correct answer is: “reduce the tendency to compressor stall” The other answers are incorrect: “spill compressor air should the engine overspeed thus controlling the speed.”: If the engine is in a overspeed conditions, removing air inside the compressor will only work against the objective. The compressor is having to force air backwards and pressurize it into the combustion chamber which requires a large amount of force. Removing the air will remove that force required and make the compressor turn even faster. “enable an external air supply to spin up the compressor for engine starting.”: Although this may seem correct, remember that the engine can be started with the use of bleed air and the air starter that is connected to the accessory box. Therefore bleed air from an APU, another engine, or a GPU will never enter the engine itself. “control the acceleration time of the engine.”: The acceleration of the engine is controlled with the fuel flow. Using engine bleed for engine control will only be used to prevent an over-pressurization in the rear of the compressor hence preventing a stall/surge.

content.question: Which of the following ensures correct functioning during the start of the engine at high altitude and in cold temperatures?

options.A: Heat intense spark.
options.B: Two independent sets of igniter systems.
options.C: Two sets of igniter plugs.
options.D: Continuous ignition operation.

key_points: Each gas turbine engine has two separate high-energy igniters able to deliver up to 25 000 V
The ignition system consists of a capacitance high energy ignition unit and an igniter plug designed to deliver the high voltage, high current discharge from a low AC or DC supply
The most common ignition unit is the DC trembler operated unit
learning.explanation: Each gas turbine engine has two separate high-energy igniters able to deliver up to 25 000 V. The ignition system consists of a capacitance high energy ignition unit and an igniter plug designed to deliver the high voltage, high current discharge from a low AC or DC supply. The most common ignition unit is the DC trembler operated unit. The trembler operates an induction coil and facilitates the generation of a higher voltage to the igniters by providing a DC current to the transformer through a high voltage rectifier. The rectifier will avoid any discharge back into the coil winding while the capacitor will charge up to a value that will break down the sealed discharge gap. The current will then discharge through the sealed discharge gap, the choke, and the igniter plugs, which are all connected in series. The capacitor is then recharged and the cycle is repeated.

content.question: In a gas turbine engine, compressor surge during engine acceleration is prevented by…

options.A: variable setting type nozzle guide vanes.
options.B: outlet guide vanes.
options.C: controlling the fuel flow.

key_points: As one of your colleges very accurately explained in the comments, compressor surges occur due to excess fuel being injected into the combustion chamber
The pressure can get so high that the airflow in the compressor stage gets reversed

The pressure can get so high that the airflow in the compressor stage gets reversed. The reversal of airflow causes the angle of attack of the compressor blades to exceed their maximum, which further worsens the surge. To avoid this, modern engine have a FADEC unit which accurately interprets the pilots input and safely translates this to outputs of the engine, such as fuel flow. This prevents a flooding of the combustion chamber during hard accelerations. content.question: In a gas turbine engine lubrication system fitted with an oil to fuel heat exchanger the…

options.A: fuel is cooled to prevent vapour locking interrupting the fuel supply to the nozzles.
options.B: oil is heated through thermal exchange with the fuel.
options.C: fuel is heated as required whenever fuel filter clogging is detected.
