key_points: The oil to fuel heat exchanger is a really smart system invented to save energy and prevent complexity in aircraft

Aircraft very commonly fly at thirty to forty thousand feet where temperature can reach as low as -57°C, now considering that Jet A-1 freezes at roughly -47°C, we know we have to create a system that keep the fuel warm and therefore liquid
Now we could install electric heaters but they would add extra load on the accessory gearbox of the engines and thus increase fuel burn
learning.explanation: The oil to fuel heat exchanger is a really smart system invented to save energy and prevent complexity in aircraft. Aircraft very commonly fly at thirty to forty thousand feet where temperature can reach as low as -57°C, now considering that Jet A-1 freezes at roughly -47°C, we know we have to create a system that keep the fuel warm and therefore liquid. Now we could install electric heaters but they would add extra load on the accessory gearbox of the engines and thus increase fuel burn. We could also use bleed air but that would again decrease the effectiveness of the engine requiring a higher fuel flow. At the same time, we have oil flowing through an engine that reaches temperatures of 1700°C that needs to be cooled. So we could install radiators around the engine to exchange the heat from the oil with the cold outside air but that would create extra drag and therefore increase fuel burn. Instead, we could connect both systems and prevent any waste of energy and prevent the operators of the aircraft to have to car for another component/system in an already complex aircraft. What we are left with is a system that cools the oil and heats the fuel at the same time. The other answers are incorrect: “fuel is cooled to prevent vapour locking interrupting the fuel supply to the nozzles.”: Fuel is heated to prevent freezing “oil is heated through thermal exchange with the fuel.”: Oil is cooled and fuel is heated. They are performing a thermal exchange but it’s the opposite of the statement. “fuel is heated as required whenever fuel filter clogging is detected.”: The system is constantly running, it does not only turn on when clogging is detected.

content.question: The aircraft turbine jet engine exhaust is constructed in a way to increase exhaus gases flow velocity. How is it designed?

options.B: A divergent duct.
options.C: A convergent duct/nozzle.
options.D: It includes an exhaust cone fitted just behind the turbine.

key_points: The exhaust of a jet engine directs the exhaust gasses aft and regulates the gas streamflow

It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent internal friction and flow separation in order to provide the highest total thrust during normal operation, for lowest noise and best efficiency

Initially, the air leaving the turbine section will undergo a diverging section (due to the exhaust cone), to slow the air down and help to allow the airflow to straighten out (removing some of the air turbulence)
learning.explanation: The exhaust of a jet engine directs the exhaust gasses aft and regulates the gas streamflow. It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent internal friction and flow separation in order to provide the highest total thrust during normal operation, for lowest noise and best efficiency. Initially, the air leaving the turbine section will undergo a diverging section (due to the exhaust cone), to slow the air down and help to allow the airflow to straighten out (removing some of the air turbulence). This slower air has higher pressure, but lower friction with the walls of the exhaust section. The exhaust section is made long to reduce the turbulence, decreasing noise and often increasing efficiency. At the end of the exhaust section comes the [propelling] nozzle, which is usually converging, to induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher total thrust. As the question is asking about the exhaust nozzle, and about increasing the exhaust gas velocity, then the convergent section is the correct answer.

options.A: BETA control range.

key_points: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight
Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm
The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range, and the power lever positions corresponding to the ALPHA range are between flight idle and maximum power
learning.explanation: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight. Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm. The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range, and the power lever positions corresponding to the ALPHA range are between flight idle and maximum power. However, while maneuvering on the ground, the power required for a turboprop engine is pretty low. Therefore, the controls have been adapted such that the blade pitch angle (therefore the thrust produced) is controlled directly by the pilot, overriding the CSU. This ground range is known as the BETA control range. The flight crew will select a blade pitch angle by moving the power lever fully aft and lifting it up. The first detent of the BETA range will correspond to the ground idle detent that will allow the pilots to produce minimum level of thrust, just enough power to taxi the aircraft. If the lever is pulled full aft of the BETA range, the pilot will lower the blade pitch angle such that the maximum reverse power is produced (=negative thrust). This will usually be the case at landing in order to assist the aircraft’s deceleration.

The FADEC (Full Authority Digital Engine Control):

2 – modifies aircraft airspeed in order to allow for the lowest fuel consumption

The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks
The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby
If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions
learning.explanation: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks. The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby. If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions. In addition to the ECU, all the FADEC peripherals such as actuators, solenoids, electrical wiring, sensors, and fuel metering are also part of the FADEC system and are used for control and monitoring. The system has a three-phase permanent magnetic alternator for an internal power source. This independent alternator is also the electrical power source for all the FADEC sensors as well as the ECUs. By interfacing with other aircraft systems and its own engine sensors, the FADEC system provides the following functions: Automatic thrust rating control. Engine operation within safe limits. Fully automatic engine starting. Thrust Reverser Control. Engine overspeed and/or an EGT protection function. Engine monitoring and help for maintenance and troubleshooting. To make the FADEC’s operation more reliable, the system uses the dual inputs logic. All control inputs to the FADEC system are dual, with the exception of some secondary parameters used for monitoring and indicating (that are single). To increase the fault-tolerant design where the engine will still be able to operate within a required reliability and safety range, the parameters are exchanged between the two control channels (inside the ECU) via a cross-channel data link. Therefore, if one input parameter fails to be delivered, the input parameter from the other channel will be used to allow the correct computation of the engine parameters by the FADEC. This means that the FADEC is a single fault-tolerant, and it will ensure the efficient and correct running of the engine even in case of a detected malfunction.

content.question: The average stage compression ratio of an axial compressor is approximately…

key_points: Compressors are used to compress air to create more efficient combustion in the combustion chamber
They come in two forms: Axial compressor and Centrifugal compressor
The axial compressor increases the air's kinetic energy and then converts it into pressure energy
learning.explanation: Compressors are used to compress air to create more efficient combustion in the combustion chamber. They come in two forms: Axial compressor and Centrifugal compressor. The axial compressor increases the air's kinetic energy and then converts it into pressure energy. It consists of a series of aerofoil section blades, called rotors, mounted on a rotating rotor disc, which accelerate the air towards stationary stator blades. Each set of rotors and stators is known as a stage. An axial flow compressor comprises many stages, with each stage typically providing a pressure rise of about 10% to 20% (1.1 to 1.2:1). The pressure rise per stage is kept small to prevent blade stalling and excessive drag. Consequently, an axial flow compressor requires multiple stages to achieve a usable compression level. Axial flow compressors generally achieve pressure ratios of 35:1 to as high as 50:1.

key_points: Note: We have had some confusing feedback about this question in the past, but we think this is the most current version of it
The answer is somewhat misleading, but we believe it is the most correct, although it is not verified
Please put any further exam feedback in the comments or send it by email to info@atplquestions
learning.explanation: Note: We have had some confusing feedback about this question in the past, but we think this is the most current version of it. The answer is somewhat misleading, but we believe it is the most correct, although it is not verified. Please put any further exam feedback in the comments or send it by email to info@atplquestions.com, so we can verify the question, thank you! A gas turbine engine requires a lot of energy to start. This is mostly in the form of getting the compressor rotating to a speed where it can feed enough air into the combustion chamber to run self-sufficiently. For this, compressors can be spun up in two ways, electrically or by air starter (pneumatic). Electric starting is as it sounds, an electric starter motor runs for the compressor to get up to speed. This used to be reserved for small turbine engines only, and the APUs (Auxiliary Power Units) of larger aircraft, so they can be started from battery power. However, the B787 uses a very high power electrical system, and can start its main engines using electrical starter generators. This is not a usual method of starting large engines, so we believe the examiner is not talking about it. The more common method (for large engines) is via air starters, which shoot high pressure air at a certain place within the engine compressor, which gets the compressor spinning fast enough to run the engine itself. The source of this high pressure air is the aircraft's pneumatic system, and the 3 places this air can come from are the APU bleed air, from a ground cart that is connected to the aircraft, or from the other main engine's bleed air, if it is running. To go through each answer: "two external sources or other engines." Correct. Whilst this is somewhat misleading (what is considered to be an external source?), the sources for engine air starting are the other engine(s), the APU and a ground cart, which you could class as two "external sources". We think it is very much debatable, and that the examiner should not write questions in this way, to deliberately mislead the students. "two batteries or the APU generator." Notwithstanding the Boeing 787, large turbine engines (the main engines of jets) are not electrically started. "the APU and RAM air turbine." The RAM air turbine (RAT) is never used for engine starting. "the APU, RAM air turbine or ground power unit." The RAM air turbine (RAT) is never used for engine starting. The ground power unit (GPU) would be correct, as they provide pneumatic air to start the engines (ground cart).

content.question: Why does the speed of the airflow not decrease significantly in an axial flow compressor?

options.A: The compressor blades are very large and retain the high speed of the incoming air.
options.B: The compressor incorporates a diffuser that increases the speed of the airflow.
options.C: A conversion into kinetic energy takes place.

key_points: This is a bit of a strange question
The speed of airflow does decrease through an axial flow compressor, but the question is asking why it doesnt decrease more
The pressure within a gas turbine compressor increases massively, (up to 60x atmospheric pressure in the most modern engines), but the velocity doesn't completely feed that increase, of course
learning.explanation: This is a bit of a strange question. The speed of airflow does decrease through an axial flow compressor, but the question is asking why it doesnt decrease more. The pressure within a gas turbine compressor increases massively, (up to 60x atmospheric pressure in the most modern engines), but the velocity doesn't completely feed that increase, of course. The compressor introduces a significant amount of energy in the form of kinetic energy (both pressure and speed) into the air (taken from the kinetic and heat energy from the exhaust gases going over the turbine), so therefore the speed of the airflow doesn't decrease that much. It does decrease a bit, helping to feed the increase in static pressure, but the air slows down greatly in the diffuser after the compressor, just before the combustion chamber.

options.C: Each channel controls the engine on that side, and data is sent to the other channel.
options.D: One channel is in command, and the other channel can take over in case of fault or failure.

key_points: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks
The FADEC has a dual channel Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby
If the active channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions
learning.explanation: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks. The FADEC has a dual channel Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby. If the active channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions. In addition to the ECU, all the FADEC peripherals such as actuators, solenoids, electrical wiring, sensors, and fuel metering are also part of the FADEC system and are used for control and monitoring. FADEC allows for a large reduction in pilot workload and also protects the engines from incorrect operation, always making sure that the engine is operated in the correct way, to produce the most thrust, at highest efficiency, and with the lowest engine wear. This includes many protections and controls, such as fully automatic starting, engine overspeed protection, engine monitoring/troubleshooting, etc. FADEC was initially just used in gas turbine engines for the aviation industry, but modern piston engines are now being controlled in this way too.

content.question:
The characteristics of an axial compressor in a gas turbine engine compared to a centrifugal compressor with the same engine diameter are:
1. a low pressure ratio by stage
2. a high pressure ratio by stage
3. the possibility of compressing a large mass airflow
4. the inability of compressing a large mass airflow
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: Compressor are used to compress air to create more efficient combustion in the combustion chamber
They come in two forms: Axial compressor Centrifugal compressor The axial compressor is usually found on traditional jet engine that have axial flow
Each stage of the compressor usually increases the pressure by 1
learning.explanation: Compressor are used to compress air to create more efficient combustion in the combustion chamber. They come in two forms: Axial compressor Centrifugal compressor The axial compressor is usually found on traditional jet engine that have axial flow. Each stage of the compressor usually increases the pressure by 1.2, but as there are many stages, the pressure after an entire compressor section is usually much higher than the single stage. Due to their design which allows flow to continue flowing in the same direction, axial compressors allow for more mass flow than a centrifugal compressor. The centrifugal compressor is usually found on turboshaft engine, such as those powering turbo propellor aircraft or turbine helicopters. In the diagram you can see that instead of compressing the air coming into the compressor backwards, the centrifugal compressor works by pressing air outwards compared to the axis of the engine. The centrifugal compressor usually creates a pressure differential of 4 per stage. Unfortunately because of the change of direction of flow as you can see in the picture and the design of the compressor blades, the mass flow is reduced compared to a axial compressor. Therefore: Axial compressors have a lower ratio by stage (even if they might create a higher pressure ratio after all the stages!) Axial compressors have the ability to compress more airflow than a centrifugal compressor. Hence the correct answers are: 1, 3.

content.question: In a gas turbine engine, a diffuser is used to reduce the velocity of gas entering the combustion chamber, to...

options.A: reduce the gas pressure and ensure that the combustion does not stop.
options.B: increase the gas pressure and ensure that the combustion does not stop.
options.C: increase the gas velocity through the combustion chamber.
options.D: reduce gas temperatures and decrease the risk of overheating the combustion chamber.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.02.02.21: Describe the function of the diffuser. DIFFUSER The diffuser is the divergent section of the engine after the compressor and before the combustion chamber. The diffuser increases the cross-section of the duct, for a constant mass flow, the velocity drops. This increases the static pressure of the air. Additionally, it decelerates the approx. 350 m/s flow to an approx. 50 m/s flow before fuel injection in some engines. This deceleration is crucial for optimal fuel burning conditions. It prepares the air for entry into the flame burning area of the combustion section at a lower velocity (and with much higher pressure) so that the flame of combustion can burn continuously. If the air passed through the flame area at a high velocity, it could extinguish the flame. Therefore, it stops the flame being extinguished by the high dynamic pressure of the air, by turning a lot of that into static pressure.

content.question: In an engine equipped with dual channel FADEC, what happens in the event of total FADEC failure?

options.A: Erratic engine behaviour.
options.B: The engine will remain at the last thrust setting.
options.C: The engine will fail.
options.D: Thrust control will be lost.

key_points: NOTE: This is not really an item discussed in the learning objectives, and is a very new question, so we have quite limited feedback about it

Please do let us know in the comments or in the question reporting section if you see this in our real exam, and anything you can remember about it, thank you! Due to the nature of FADEC (Full Authority Digital Engine Control) systems, failures must be well protected against
This means that FADEC engines need back up systems for redundancy
learning.explanation: NOTE: This is not really an item discussed in the learning objectives, and is a very new question, so we have quite limited feedback about it. Please do let us know in the comments or in the question reporting section if you see this in our real exam, and anything you can remember about it, thank you! Due to the nature of FADEC (Full Authority Digital Engine Control) systems, failures must be well protected against. This means that FADEC engines need back up systems for redundancy. This can either be achieved with a single FADEC system and a hydromechanical back up, or more commonly with a dual channel FADEC system. This makes the FADEC system 'single fault tolerant', meaning that any one fault on its own cannot stop the engine completely. However, problems such as a complete power loss to both channels would cause a full FADEC failure, but the chance of this is reduced by having separate power supplies, independent from the aircraft main electrical system in some cases. If there is a full FADEC failure with no backup, then the engine will just fail, as the fuel supply will stop. If the failure is not fixed, there will be no chance of a restart. Most FADEC engines close the fuel valve in the event of a control failure, but all the other engine controls will cease also, so the system shuts down the engine as it is better to have no thrust than uncontrollable or runaway thrust.

content.question: The purpose of a variable bypass valve, fitted between the LP and HP compressor of an axial flow compressor, is to…

options.A: prevent stall in the LP compressor.
options.B: control the acceleration of the engine.
options.C: prevent the engine from an overspeed.
options.D: enable the engine to start with an external air supply.

key_points: A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM
As a result, smooth airflow is interrupted and pressure fluctuations are created within the turbine
It occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack (just like a wing)
learning.explanation: A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM. As a result, smooth airflow is interrupted and pressure fluctuations are created within the turbine. It occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack (just like a wing). Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor (the LP compressor), making it stall first. Usually, this is followed by a complete compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. As mentioned above, air stagnates in the REAR stages, which results in a lack of air in the FRONT stages (LP stage) with subsequent low axial velocity in the front stages. This will lead to a high angle of attack of the rotor blades determining a STALL. That’s why the tapped excessive pressure in the rear stages is relieved by means of a bleed valve that will open at the front stages and recirculate the bleed air towards the air conditioning unit and other systems. This is determined by the engine operating regime so that any unwanted rise in air pressure can be relieved and prevent the conditions which will cause a surge.

content.question:
Which of the following indications are used to monitor a turbine engine:
1. Hydraulic Pressure
2. Oil Temperature
3. Chip Detector Caution Light
4. Fuel Filter Bypass Indication
5. Fuel Flow
6. Oil Pressure
7. Outside Air Temperature

key_points: Note: This has also been seen as a tick box question in the UK CAA exams
Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Note: This has also been seen as a tick box question in the UK CAA exams. Learning Objective 021.11.04.01.17: Give examples of monitoring instruments of an engine. The question is asking for indicators or displays with which we can monitor the engine. This is not very specific, as an engine's performance or its health can be monitored, so we will assume both. To go through each option: 1. "Hydraulic Pressure" We do not know exactly what pressure they are referring to, perhaps they are referring to the hydraulic pressure from the engine driven hydraulic pump, in which case, that is not a useful way to monitor the engine health or performance, as it usually maintains a constant pressure, and there are varying demands of the hydraulic system as well. 2. "Oil Temperature" - Correct As with any engine, oil temperature is a vital indicator of engine health. 3. "Chip Detector Caution Light" - Correct A chip detector is a small magnetic probe that exists in the oil return line, before any scavenge pump and filter (if present). It will collect any small bits of ferrous material (which stick to the magnet), and if a build-up occurs, it is very indicative of internal engine damage. Some can detect a build-up remotely, without being removed, and will notify the flight deck via a light or some other indication. This is of course an engine health monitoring device. 4. "Fuel Filter Bypass Indication" - Incorrect The fuel filter is used to make sure no large particulate contaminants within the fuel can flow into the engines, causing damage to the components. If the fuel filter becomes blocked though, there is a bypass line that allows unfiltered fuel into the engine (It is better to have potentially contaminated fuel than no fuel at all). If the fuel filter is blocked and the bypass line has to be used, an indication of this will be sent to the flight deck, and that tells the pilots that unfiltered fuel is being used. This might require careful engine monitoring and a maintenance inspection on the ground, but in itself this is not telling us anything about the engine, so is NOT an engine monitoring indication. 5. "Fuel Flow" - Correct Fuel flow monitoring is used to monitor both engine health and (moreso) performance. It is also used for monitoring the engine start process. 6. "Oil Pressure" - Correct As with all engines, oil pressure is a vital indication for the pilots to have, as oil is required for the engine to run without causing itself serious damage. Oil pressure indications tell us that the oil pumps are working correctly. 7. "Outside Air Temperature Display" The OAT, whilst important to know for operations, is not a method of monitoring an engine.

Which answer states the correct explanation of the two parts of the right side of the formula?

options.A: m (vj - vv): the thrust of the hot section. A (pj - p0): the thrust of the cold section of a turbofan.
options.B: m (vj - vv): the thrust of the propeller. A (pj - p0): the thrust of the exhaust of a turboprop.

The pressure p and p0 need to be expressed in Pa (pascal)

content.question: The turbine in a gas turbine engine generates shaft power using…

options.A: expansion of hot gas followed by conversion of potential energy (pressure) into (mechanical) work.
options.B: expansion of hot gas followed by conversion of kinetic energy (velocity) into (mechanical) work.
options.C: compression of hot gas followed by conversion of kinetic energy into (mechanical) work.
options.D: compression of hot gas followed by conversion of potential energy (pressure) into kinetic energy (velocity).

key_points: The turbine provides energy to increase the pressure of the airflow in the compressors and to power, all the accessories needed to the aircraft
The turbine generates this energy, known as shaft power, using the expansion of hot gases, and then by converting the kinetic energy of the gases (velocity) into mechanical work
When the combustion gases pass through the turbine, the pressure drops
learning.explanation: The turbine provides energy to increase the pressure of the airflow in the compressors and to power, all the accessories needed to the aircraft. The turbine generates this energy, known as shaft power, using the expansion of hot gases, and then by converting the kinetic energy of the gases (velocity) into mechanical work. When the combustion gases pass through the turbine, the pressure drops. The higher the temperature resulting from combustion, the greater the gas expansion and energy transfer to the turbine. However, because the materials used in the turbine assembly are temperature limited, temperature limitations are usually imposed on the turbine section to avoid complete damage to the turbine.

content.question: The rotor blades of an axial compressor of a gas turbine engine are often mounted on a disk or drum using a `loose fit` because this…

options.A: facilitates easy assembly and removal.
options.B: limits damage to the blades due to vibration.
options.C: limits FOD damage.
options.D: limits damage due to creep.

key_points: The rotor blades of an axial flow compressor are held in position by the mountings, the aerodynamic force, and centrifugal force
The mounting connecting the blades at their root is of the ‘fir tree’ type
The blades are subject to very high centrifugal loads and high-temperature variations that unavoidably cause thermal expansion of the blades
learning.explanation: The rotor blades of an axial flow compressor are held in position by the mountings, the aerodynamic force, and centrifugal force. The mounting connecting the blades at their root is of the ‘fir tree’ type. The blades are subject to very high centrifugal loads and high-temperature variations that unavoidably cause thermal expansion of the blades. That’s why they are fitted on a disk or drum using a ‘loose fit’ design that will avoid them blocking in their mounting under high thermal loads and vibrations. The ‘fir tree’ root connection allows the blades to be loosely fitted and to be replaced more easily, as each blade has its own independent connection to the rotor disk. The loose fit gives the rotor blades some room for expansion. Sometimes when the aircraft is on the ground and a strong wind is blowing towards the engine and keeps it rotating along with the compressor (the engine is windmilling) you will be able to hear a clicking noise. This is due to the rotor blades being loose in their mounting on the drum without any centrifugal loads acting on them.

content.question: One of the advantages of multiple-spool jet engine designs is that…

options.A: a compressor stall cannot occur under any condition.
options.B: a smaller air starter driving only a single spool can be used.
options.C: if one spool seizes, the remaining spool(s) will continue to operate normally.
options.D: engine length can be reduced.

key_points: The starting sequence of a multi-spool jet engine begins when the starter motor is running
This is commonly an engine bleed driven unit that is attached to the accessory unit which is connected to the high pressure compressor shaft

The starter motor will receive high pressure air from either: The auxiliary power unit (APU) A ground power unit (GPU) Another engine With that air, the starter will start turning the high-pressure compressor shaft which will start increasing the mass flow of air through the engine
learning.explanation: The starting sequence of a multi-spool jet engine begins when the starter motor is running. This is commonly an engine bleed driven unit that is attached to the accessory unit which is connected to the high pressure compressor shaft. The starter motor will receive high pressure air from either: The auxiliary power unit (APU) A ground power unit (GPU) Another engine With that air, the starter will start turning the high-pressure compressor shaft which will start increasing the mass flow of air through the engine. Because the air starter motor is only connecting and rotating the HP compressor shaft, which is the smallest and thus, requires a smaller air starter. In a single spool axial-flow engine, the air starter required would be much bigger because the entire assembly to be moved is larger. After the engine has reached a self-sustaining speed (minimum RPM at which the engine will continue operating without any starter motor assistance) the air starter will disengage by the coupling between engine N2 spool and starter by the use of centrifugal forces.

content.question: In a gas turbine engine, the highest gas temperature is reached…

options.A: in the turbine.
options.B: in the cooling airflow around the flame tube.
options.C: at the entry of the exhaust unit.
options.D: within the combustion chamber.

key_points: To answer this question, try to locate the different answer options and visualize their place within the engine
Going from the front to the rear of the engine you have: the combustion chamber, the turbine, and the entry of the exhaust unit
The cooling airflow around the flame tube is going to be around the core of the engine, so it will not be directly affected by the highest temperatures of the combustion chamber
learning.explanation: To answer this question, try to locate the different answer options and visualize their place within the engine. Going from the front to the rear of the engine you have: the combustion chamber, the turbine, and the entry of the exhaust unit. The cooling airflow around the flame tube is going to be around the core of the engine, so it will not be directly affected by the highest temperatures of the combustion chamber. “In the turbine” – INCORRECT. The HP turbine is going to be the very first stage after the combustion chamber. The gases exiting the combustion chamber and hitting the first turbine stage will still be very hot, but in no way they’re going to be hotter than within the combustion chamber where the mixture lights up.

content.question: What is the correct sequence during the start of a turbine engine on the ground?

options.A: Rotation, fuel, ignition.
options.B: Starter, rotation, ignition, fuel.
options.C: Rotation, ignition, fuel.
options.D: Starter, ignition, rotation, fuel.

key_points: The correct start sequence is designed to be safe in case of an abnormality with the fuel ignition
The first step along the sequence is the running of the starter motor
This is commonly an engine bleed driven unit that is attached to the accessory unit which is connected to the high pressure compressor shaft
learning.explanation: The correct start sequence is designed to be safe in case of an abnormality with the fuel ignition. The first step along the sequence is the running of the starter motor. This is commonly an engine bleed driven unit that is attached to the accessory unit which is connected to the high pressure compressor shaft. The starter motor will receive high pressure air from either: The auxiliary power unit (APU) A ground power unit (GPU) Another engine With that air, the starter will start turning the high pressure compressor shaft which will create airflow through the engine. Upon reaching a certain predetermined RPM, the igniters will be activated. This will happen either at the same time as the fuel or before, but never after the fuel. This is to prevent the combustion chamber from being flooded with fuel before the igniters turn on. This could lead to engine damage, a tailpipe fire, or no ignition at all with a lot of fuel left in the ignition chamber. The last step is the fuel, which will be injected into a combustion chamber that has: Good airflow (from the starter) A source of heat to ignite (igniters) These components put together allow for a successful combustion. Note: if the start were to occur during flight, the starter motor might not be required. The dynamic pressure might already be sufficient to create enough airflow through the engine to allow for a successful start. Therefore, on the ground, the correct start sequence is: “Starter, rotation, ignition, fuel” Extra: You can see in the diagram attached that the 737 can start from windmilling above 281 kt depending on the altitude, therefore no starter is required. Below 300 kt depending on the altitude, crossbleed is required from the other engine to engage the starter.

content.question: The average stage compression ratio of a centrifugal compressor is approximately…

key_points: The compressor is an annular duct through which the air passes and across which are arranged a series of small blades of aerofoil section that will compress the incoming air
Because of the small pressure increase at each compressor stage, numerous stages are required to achieve the desired delivery pressure at the combustion chamber

The upper limit for axial compressors is more a matter of stability and complexity, with current values of approximately 10:1 for single-spool compressors, and in excess of 30:1 for multi-spool compressors, the average ratio per stage being 4:1
learning.explanation: The compressor is an annular duct through which the air passes and across which are arranged a series of small blades of aerofoil section that will compress the incoming air. Because of the small pressure increase at each compressor stage, numerous stages are required to achieve the desired delivery pressure at the combustion chamber. The upper limit for axial compressors is more a matter of stability and complexity, with current values of approximately 10:1 for single-spool compressors, and in excess of 30:1 for multi-spool compressors, the average ratio per stage being 4:1. Although higher pressure ratios give higher engine efficiency due to improved specific fuel consumption, a balance must be found between efficiency and the power needed from the turbine to drive the compressor. Sufficient power must remain to move the aircraft, and the turbine has a restricted limit to the power which it can generate. The centrifugal compressor has a maximum pressure ratio of about 4.5:1 for a single stage, and up to 6:1 for a two-stage, single-entry centrifugal compressor.

content.question: The bypass ratio of a turbofan engine is a comparison between the…

options.A: Total air mass drawn into the engine with the air mass that goes through the engine core.
options.B: Total air mass drawn into the engine with the air mass that bypasses the engine core.
options.C: Air mass that bypasses the engine core with the air mass that goes through the engine core.
options.D: Air mass that bypasses the engine core with the total air mass that exits the engine.

key_points: Refer to the following formulas: Bypass ratio = bypass mass flow / HP compressor mass flow Bypass mass flow = inlet mass flow – HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio is defined as the ratio between the mass flow rate of air drawn in by the fan bypassing the engine core (bypass mass flow) to the mass flow rate passing through the engine core (HP compressor mass flow)
learning.explanation: Refer to the following formulas: Bypass ratio = bypass mass flow / HP compressor mass flow Bypass mass flow = inlet mass flow – HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio is defined as the ratio between the mass flow rate of air drawn in by the fan bypassing the engine core (bypass mass flow) to the mass flow rate passing through the engine core (HP compressor mass flow).

content.question:
Which of these statements about a reaction turbine are correct or incorrect?
I. The pressure remains constant across the nozzle guide vanes
II. The pressure drops across the rotor blades

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: IMPULSE TURBINE Nozzle guide vanes (form convergent ducts – accelerate the gas) Velocity increases Pressure decreases Rotor Blades Velocity decreases No change in pressure REACTION TURBINE Nozzle guide vanes Pressure remains constant Rotor Blades (form convergent ducts – accelerate the gas, creating reaction force which drives the turbine) Velocity decreases Both temperature and pressure decrease According to Rolls Royce, in a reaction turbine, the nozzle guide vanes simply direct the gas onto the turbine blades
Therefore, there is no change in speed or pressure across them, only a change in direction
Therefore, correct option: CORRECT, CORRECT IMPORTANT NOTE: These questions have led to a lot of confusion over the years
learning.explanation: IMPULSE TURBINE Nozzle guide vanes (form convergent ducts – accelerate the gas) Velocity increases Pressure decreases Rotor Blades Velocity decreases No change in pressure REACTION TURBINE Nozzle guide vanes Pressure remains constant Rotor Blades (form convergent ducts – accelerate the gas, creating reaction force which drives the turbine) Velocity decreases Both temperature and pressure decrease According to Rolls Royce, in a reaction turbine, the nozzle guide vanes simply direct the gas onto the turbine blades. Therefore, there is no change in speed or pressure across them, only a change in direction. Therefore, correct option: CORRECT, CORRECT IMPORTANT NOTE: These questions have led to a lot of confusion over the years. Please note that we received initial feedback from students confirming that the correct answer was "incorrect, correct." Based on this, we had believed that according to EASA, nozzle guide vanes formed slightly convergent ducts, resulting in pressure drops. However, we have received more recent feedback from Hungary and Slovakia, confirming that the correct answer is "correct, correct." It appears that EASA may have recently rectified this question to align with what we now believe to be the correct answer.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is correct.

options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high-pressure ratio operating at high RPM
" INCORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM

INCORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM. As a result, smooth airflow is interrupted and pressure fluctuations are created within the turbine. It occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack (just like a wing). Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Usually, this is followed by a complete compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. "II. content.question:
The static thrust of a turbo-jet:
1. equals the product of the exhaust gas mass flow and the exhaust gas velocity
2. is obtained by pressure of the exhaust gas on the ambient air
3. produces zero mechanical power since the aeroplane is not moving
4. is independent of the outside air temperature
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: Let study each statement to see which one is accurate: “Equals the product of the exhaust gas mass flow and the exhaust gas velocity” Engine thrust can be determined by the following equation: F = mvj – mvi Where: F = force of thrust m = air mass flow rate vj = exhaust gas velocity vi = intake gas velocity When we consider a stationary turbo jet, we know that the intake airflow is zero due the stationary air around the engine
Therefore we can say that: F = mvj – mvi F = mvj The force of thrust is equal to the mass and velocity of the exhaust

Therefore this statement is correct! “Is obtained by pressure of the exhaust gas on the ambient air” Assuming the pj ≠ pi, we can say that: F = mvj – mvi + (pj – pi)Aj Where: F = force of thrust m = air mass flow rate vj = exhaust gas velocity vi = intake gas velocity pj = pressure at the exhaust pi = pressure at the intake Ai = cross section area at the intake Again, knowing that the turbo jet is stationary (static), we can say that: F = mvj – mvi + (pj – pi)Aj Therefore the thrust is equal to the mass flow times the velocity plus also the pressure difference times the cross section area
learning.explanation: Let study each statement to see which one is accurate: “Equals the product of the exhaust gas mass flow and the exhaust gas velocity” Engine thrust can be determined by the following equation: F = mvj – mvi Where: F = force of thrust m = air mass flow rate vj = exhaust gas velocity vi = intake gas velocity When we consider a stationary turbo jet, we know that the intake airflow is zero due the stationary air around the engine. Therefore we can say that: F = mvj – mvi F = mvj The force of thrust is equal to the mass and velocity of the exhaust. Therefore this statement is correct! “Is obtained by pressure of the exhaust gas on the ambient air” Assuming the pj ≠ pi, we can say that: F = mvj – mvi + (pj – pi)Aj Where: F = force of thrust m = air mass flow rate vj = exhaust gas velocity vi = intake gas velocity pj = pressure at the exhaust pi = pressure at the intake Ai = cross section area at the intake Again, knowing that the turbo jet is stationary (static), we can say that: F = mvj – mvi + (pj – pi)Aj Therefore the thrust is equal to the mass flow times the velocity plus also the pressure difference times the cross section area. Therefore this statement is incomplete and therefore incorrect! “Produces zero mechanical power since the aeroplane is not moving” As shown in statement 1 and 2, even if the aircraft is stationary it will still produce thrust due to air mass flow at the exhaust combined with the pressure differential between the intake and exhaust. However, thrust is not the same as the power. Thrust is a force, and knowing that: Power = work/time And that: Work = Force x distance We can see that if do not travel whilst producing any force, we do not create any work. And not creating any work means we produce no work over a given time, therefore not producing any power. Therefore this statement is correct! “Is independent of the outside air temperature” The mass flow is dependent on the density of the air which in turn is dependent on the outside air temperature. Therefore knowing that: F = mvj – mvi We can see that the thrust is dependent on the outside air temperature, therefore this statement is incorrect!

content.question: What does a FADEC consist of?

options.A: A fuel control system and its accessories (sensors, wiring, sensors,... etc.).
options.B: A fuel control system and gauges shown to the pilots.
options.C: All fuel control systems on board an aircraft.
options.D: A fuel control system only.

key_points: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) is an electronic system that controls an engine, allowing easy usage by the pilot, relieving workload and providing most efficient power settings through single lever operation
That being said, the pilot still has a few engine controls on the flight deck

As well as the power lever to each engine, which digitally tells the FADEC computer what power setting is required from the engine, the pilot has a master switch for each engine, and often engine mode selectors to be able to tell the engine which ECU to use, etc
learning.explanation: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) is an electronic system that controls an engine, allowing easy usage by the pilot, relieving workload and providing most efficient power settings through single lever operation. That being said, the pilot still has a few engine controls on the flight deck. As well as the power lever to each engine, which digitally tells the FADEC computer what power setting is required from the engine, the pilot has a master switch for each engine, and often engine mode selectors to be able to tell the engine which ECU to use, etc. All the FADEC peripherals such as actuators, solenoids, electrical wiring, sensors, and fuel metering are also part of the FADEC system and are used for control and monitoring.

content.question: A FADEC on a gas turbine engine…

options.A: is a single channel system.
options.B: is single fault tolerant.
options.C: is a three channel system.

key_points: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks
The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby
If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions
learning.explanation: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks. The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby. If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions. In addition to the ECU, all the FADEC peripherals such as actuators, solenoids, electrical wiring, sensors, and fuel metering are also part of the FADEC system and are used for control and monitoring. The system has a three-phase permanent magnetic alternator for an internal power source. This independent alternator is also the electrical power source for all the FADEC sensors as well as the ECUs. By interfacing with other aircraft systems and its own engine sensors, the FADEC system provides the following functions: Automatic thrust rating control. Engine operation within safe limits. Fully automatic engine starting. Thrust Reverser Control. Engine overspeed and/or an EGT protection function. Engine monitoring and help for maintenance and troubleshooting. To make the FADEC’s operation more reliable, the system uses the dual inputs logic. All control inputs to the FADEC system are dual, with the exception of some secondary parameters used for monitoring and indicating (that are single). To increase the fault-tolerant design where the engine will still be able to operate within a required reliability and safety range, the parameters are exchanged between the two control channels (inside the ECU) via a cross-channel data link. Therefore, if one input parameter fails to be delivered, the input parameter from the other channel will be used to allow the correct computation of the engine parameters by the FADEC. This means that the FADEC is a single fault-tolerant, and it will ensure the efficient and correct running of the engine even in case of a detected malfunction.

content.question: During the ram recovery process in a gas turbine engine subsonic intake, the…

options.A: static temperature decreases.
options.B: total temperature increases.
options.C: total pressure increases.
options.D: flow velocity decreases.

key_points: The intake geometry of subsonic aircraft engines is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect
It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed

That’s why the intake is slightly divergent in order to reduce the airflow’s velocity (=dynamic pressure) and increase the static pressure and temperature just before the fan and compressor’s first stages
learning.explanation: The intake geometry of subsonic aircraft engines is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect. It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed. That’s why the intake is slightly divergent in order to reduce the airflow’s velocity (=dynamic pressure) and increase the static pressure and temperature just before the fan and compressor’s first stages. Caution, the total pressure (and temperature) will remain constant - it is only a trade of dynamic pressure for static pressure. Compression (=increase in static pressure) is a process where heat is released, which explains why the temperature behaves in the same way through a divergent duct as pressure. This geometry is also called the ‘pitot intake’, and it has thick, smoothly rounded lips to prevent flow separation under any flight conditions/maneuvers.

learning.explanation: Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Bypass valves are installed in large multi-stage compressors to prevent this from happening. During start, when the engine is attempting to accelerate, these valves will open to vent excess pressure and increase axial flow across all stages. The reduction in pressure will reduce the load on the compressor by reducing the blade AoA in the early stages.

learning.explanation: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks. The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby. The ECU interfaces with many aircraft system computers, either directly, or via the Engine Interface Unit (EIU). options.C: 1) is incorrect; 2) is correct.

key_points: Note: One problem with this question is that authorities often disagree (sometimes even with engine manufacturers) about how impulse and reaction turbines work
Another issue is the terrible wording which has a few different interpretations, and does not take into account the incredibly complex nature of turbine blades

learning.explanation: Note: One problem with this question is that authorities often disagree (sometimes even with engine manufacturers) about how impulse and reaction turbines work. Another issue is the terrible wording which has a few different interpretations, and does not take into account the incredibly complex nature of turbine blades. Therefore we require any further feedback about this question that people have, and in particular would like to know what individual authorities are considering to be correct, so please share your exam experiences with us in the comments. As far as we currently know, the following authorities are considering the following options to be correct. France appear to be the outlier here. Authority Reported Answer France Correct/Incorrect Portugal Correct/Correct Hungary Correct/Correct Poland Correct/Correct Greece Correct/Correct UK Correct/Correct Austro Control Correct/Correct Impulse turbines use a convergent duct in the NGV to accelerate the airflow first, then use the "water wheel" bucket style design of the turbine to turn that fast airflow the other way. This is a change in momentum, called an impulse. Reaction turbines use much simpler (non convergent) NGVs, which direct the airflow at the proper angle into the turbine blades, which then turn and accelerate the air through convergent blades, which produces the majority of the turbine movement. The angle of the airflow on the turbine blades provides some of the turning force on the turbine, but the majority appears to come from the converging section (especially at high rotational speeds), which trades the high pressure for velocity. The wording of statement 1 does not make it clear if they are saying the particular angle provides some of the turning force or all of the turning force. We have assumed "some". The answer would change if we assumed "all". There is some debate about statement 2, and it is our belief that the stators (NGVs) do not use airfoil aerodynamics as they are simple guide vanes, and that the rotors do use airfoil aerodynamics, but not in the same way we are used to as pilots, and this quickly gets incredibly complex, and depends on which source you look at, so it is not useful to delve further for the ATPLs. The authorities appear to be mostly saying that the rotors (turbine blades) DO use airfoil aerodynamics. This question does not really work outside the land of ATPL theory though, because all gas turbine engines use a combination impulse-reaction turbine these days, as it is better to mix the two.

content.question: Increasing the power setting of a gas turbine engine with a constant speed propeller and free power turbine causes…

options.A: HP spool speed to increase and EGT to remain constant.
options.B: HP spool speed to decrease and EGT to increase.
options.C: HP spool speed to remain constant and EGT to increase.
options.D: Both HP spool speed and EGT to increase.

key_points: A gas turbine engine-free turbine does not drive a compressor, i
e
there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine-free turbine does not drive a compressor, i.e. there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft. The energy delivered by the free turbine stages is only dependent on the rotational speed of the HP spool. In this configuration, the engine will simply act as a gas generator to supply high-energy gases to an independent free power turbine driving a propeller or rotor via a reduction gearbox. This is why this type of turbine is often used on turboprop engines and helicopters. In fact, there will be two major assemblies: one shaft known as the HP spool and connecting the compressor and the compressor-driving turbine, and a free turbine placed after the compressor-driving turbine that is connected to a propeller. Because these two assemblies are not interconnected in any way, the propeller and free turbine assembly will be able to rotate at an independent speed from that of the HP spool. The most suitable control system for a turboprop fitted with a free turbine is the direct control of fuel flow. In this system, the gas generator (the core of the engine) is controlled in the same manner as a turbojet, and the power available to the free turbine assembly is governed by the fuel flow. For instance: If the power setting is increased (due to an increased fuel flow), the RPM of the HP spool will also increase and the axial airflow will be momentarily lagging, causing the EGT to increase. However, the free turbine and propeller assembly will be maintained at constant RPM by the Constant Speed Unit (CSU) that will do so by increasing the propeller’s blade angle. If the power setting is decreased, the RPM of the HP spool and the EGT will also decrease. However, the free turbine and propeller assembly will be maintained at constant RPM by the Constant Speed Unit (CSU) that will do so by decreasing the propeller’s blade angle.

content.question: Concerning a gas turbine engine, one of the advantages of annular combustion chamber over a multiple can is that…

options.A: the thermal load is more evenly distributed on the HP turbine.
options.B: assembly and disassembly is easier.
options.C: only one igniter is required.
options.D: engine length is shorter because no diffuser is required.

key_points: Can-type (multiple) combustion chamber: consists of several flame tubes surrounded by an individual casing (self-contained)

has only two igniters located in the two lower chambers, even though combustion occurs in every single can separately by interconnecting them via a pivoted tube into a metallic elbow that is connected itself to the next can’s elbow
In this way, the flame is passed through the tubes to every single can, ensuring a uniform ignition
learning.explanation: Can-type (multiple) combustion chamber: consists of several flame tubes surrounded by an individual casing (self-contained). has only two igniters located in the two lower chambers, even though combustion occurs in every single can separately by interconnecting them via a pivoted tube into a metallic elbow that is connected itself to the next can’s elbow. In this way, the flame is passed through the tubes to every single can, ensuring a uniform ignition. Tubo-annular combustion chamber: consists of several tubes radially disposed around the engine between the compressor and turbine section, all sitting in the same annular casing. The advantage of this evolved arrangement is that the airflow is carefully controlled and is more evenly spread over the first stage turbine. Annular combustion chamber: uses the entire annulus casing between the compressor and the turbine for combustion. This helps to provide a better thermal distribution on the HP turbine and reduce turbine wearing. For the same power output, the annular chamber length is 75% of a tubo-annular chamber of a similar diameter. Consequently, the wall area is much smaller and the amount of cooling air required to protect the flame tube wall is also reduced by approximately 15%. Combustion efficiency is increased and air pollution reduced making it the most widespread combustion chamber type on nowadays commercial jets. Annular combustion chambers are not simpler than the other options, and they do have higher maintenance costs usually.

content.question:
Regarding a jet engine, which of the following statements is/are correct?
1. The maximum thrust remains constant as the pressure altitude increases.
2. The specific fuel consumption increases slightly as the pressure altitude increases at constant TAS.

options.A: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: The maximum thrust remains constant as the pressure altitude increases
" INCORRECT
learning.explanation: “1. The maximum thrust remains constant as the pressure altitude increases." INCORRECT. As altitude increases, the air gets thinner. The increase in altitude causes a decrease in pressure, thus a decrease in density and corresponding decrease in thrust – since less air is entering the gas turbine engine. “2. The specific fuel consumption increases slightly as the pressure altitude increases at constant TAS.” INCORRECT. Specific fuel consumption reduces proportionally to the temperature => If temperature is decreasing, specific fuel consumption decreases. That being said, specific fuel consumption depends on temperature and not on pressure altitude. Thus saying that " The specific fuel consumption increases slightly as the pressure altitude increases at constant TAS." is vague because, even though normally temperature increases with reducing pressure altitude, there can be inversions. Anyhow, we assume standard conditions => temperature decreasing with increasing pressure altitude => specific fuel consumption, therefore, decreases with increasing pressure altitude (inversely proportional).

content.question: A gas turbine engine turbine section may employ active clearance control…

options.A: in order to cool the disc.
options.B: in order to reduce “creep” in the blades.
options.C: to provide enhanced clearances between the blade tips and the casing.
options.D: as a method of attaching the stators and rotors to the hub of the disc.

key_points: Active clearance control (ACC) is a method used in gas turbines to improve fuel efficiency
This is achieved by managing the clearance between the gas turbine casing and the tips of the rotating blades, referred to as turbine tip clearance

It monitors and varies the diameter of the turbine engine's casing to minimise the clearance between the rotor and the casing, researchers have found that an increase in tip clearance directly results in a decrease in turbine efficiency
learning.explanation: Active clearance control (ACC) is a method used in gas turbines to improve fuel efficiency. This is achieved by managing the clearance between the gas turbine casing and the tips of the rotating blades, referred to as turbine tip clearance. It monitors and varies the diameter of the turbine engine's casing to minimise the clearance between the rotor and the casing, researchers have found that an increase in tip clearance directly results in a decrease in turbine efficiency. Preventing large fluctuations in the clearance can prevents stalls and surges in the engine by preventing the efficiency of a blade section to change. A blade section that has a very small clearance to the casing will produce a much stronger pressure differential than a blade section with a large clearance. The other answers are incorrect: “in order to cool the disc.”: Even though the system may help cool the blades, and the disk, it is not the task that the active clearance control system was designed for. “in order to reduce “creep” in the blades.”: Again, even though the system might help slightly cool the blades, it’s not the primary objective of the active clearance control system. Therefore the answer is incorrect. “as a method of attaching the stators and rotors to the hub of the disc.”: This answer makes no sense, it’s a cooling system to control clearance inside the engine, and therefore has nothing to do with the construction of the compressor assembly.

Because there’s more air at the inlet than at the outlet of the engine, the EPR will decrease
