It controls the engine to run efficiently with full control of the system
learning.explanation: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) units are commonly installed on gas turbine engines. The aim of FADEC computer controls the engines by reading all input and output parameters of engines themselves and the required performance requested by flight crew. It controls the engine to run efficiently with full control of the system. Since the authority of FADEC is very extensive, losing the correct operation may cause loss of engine control, therefore to ensure sufficient redundancy, engines are normally equipped with two FADEC computers each, with one channel always active and a second one on standby. If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions. As a result, the engines will continue to operate normally should a single input parameter from one of the FADEC computer fail in flight. Therefore, it is said to be single-fault tolerant.

content.question: An aeroplane engine usually has two idle settings: Flight idle and ground idle. Flight idle corresponds to a higher power setting. This is because...

options.A: Flight idle allows for better altitude loss during descent.
options.B: Less fuel is consumed with flight idle, increasing endurance.
options.C: The air is less dense at altitude than on the ground.
options.D: Engine thrust needs to be readily available upon go-around.

key_points: Most engines are set up to produce low idle, denominated "Ground Idle", on the ground and in normal flight; and high idle, called "Flight Idle", in flight
Flight Idle is a higher power setting so that the engine is spooled up in the event of a missed approach
Ground idle takes quite some time (more than 6 s) to accelerate from idle to full thrust, therefore, a higher power setting is used in flight which allows a spool-up time below 6 s
learning.explanation: Most engines are set up to produce low idle, denominated "Ground Idle", on the ground and in normal flight; and high idle, called "Flight Idle", in flight. Flight Idle is a higher power setting so that the engine is spooled up in the event of a missed approach. Ground idle takes quite some time (more than 6 s) to accelerate from idle to full thrust, therefore, a higher power setting is used in flight which allows a spool-up time below 6 s. Logic circuits determine that the aircraft is in the air and in the approach and landing configuration to command the increase to "Flight Idle". The idle setting is returned to the low, or "Ground Idle" value after a predetermined time interval after the landing gear touchdown. Long story, short: by starting at flight idle, the engine achieves higher power settings, faster.

content.question: Considering a jet engine's performance with increase in altitude: Thrust will _____ and SFC will _____.

options.A: Remain fairly constant, decrease.
options.B: Decrease, remain fairly constant.
options.C: Decrease, increase.
options.D: Increase, decrease.

key_points: Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) is a measure of fuel consumed per thrust produced
As altitude increases air mass flow into engine decreases, thrust also decreases for same throttle setting
Since air mass flow rate decreases fuel flow is also reduced proportionately by engine control system
learning.explanation: Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) is a measure of fuel consumed per thrust produced. As altitude increases air mass flow into engine decreases, thrust also decreases for same throttle setting. Since air mass flow rate decreases fuel flow is also reduced proportionately by engine control system. When both thrust and fuel flow are reduced, Specific Fuel Consumption should remain constant.

content.question:
Which option correctly lists the functions (given below) directly provided by the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) of a large jet transport aeroplane while on the ground?
1. Electrical power
2. Air for main engine starting
3. Hydraulic pressure
4. Air for air-conditioning

options.C: 2 and 4 only.
options.D: 1 and 2 only.

key_points: The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is a small gas turbine engine located on the tail of the aircraft able to deliver pressurized air and electrical power
It can also deliver air for cabin air conditioning and for main engine starting
An APU has its own electric starter motor powered either by the airplane’s main batteries or by the Ground Power Unit (if connected)
learning.explanation: The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is a small gas turbine engine located on the tail of the aircraft able to deliver pressurized air and electrical power. It can also deliver air for cabin air conditioning and for main engine starting. An APU has its own electric starter motor powered either by the airplane’s main batteries or by the Ground Power Unit (if connected). The APU uses fuel from the main fuel tanks (the left main tank on the A320) and burns about 130 kg/h on the ground (A320 APU). In order to use the APU in flight, it needs to be certified and guarantee that the starting sequence can be carried out at high altitudes and operate under load at even higher altitudes. A dedicated flight deck APU control panel consists of a master switch button and a start button. The master switch will simply energize the APU system and its internal computer. It will also open the air intake flap and open the fuel isolation valve. The start switch is putting the ignition ON and starts the automatic start sequence. Either some lights, or a separate fault panel, or an electronic APU monitoring page will display and announce any APU faults. The APU will automatically shut down in one of the following cases: Overspeed, No acceleration, Low oil pressure, EGT overtemperature, High oil temperature, Underspeed, Reverse flow, etc.

content.question: A gas turbine engine is run at ground idle for a period of time prior to shutdown to…

options.A: prevent vapour lock in the fuel control and/or fuel lines.
options.B: prevent seizure of the rotor blades in their seals.
options.C: prevent seizure of the engine bearings.
options.D: allow the core to cool down.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.04.01.14: State the possible causes of engine seizure and explain their preventative measures. Gas turbines operate at extremely high temperatures, and the hottest part of the engine is just behind the combustion chamber in the turbine. This is also one of the most highly stressed parts of the engine, and the heat alongside the high rotational speeds mean that the blades (and other components) have to be extremely strong. Also, procedures are used to make sure the engine does not suffer any damage from heating. One such procedure is the cool down, which entails running the engine at low power (ground idle) for a few minutes after landing, in order to cool the components as equally as possible, getting them to a lower temperature so the thermal shock of shutting the engine down is not as bad. The two parts that benefit most from this are the turbine blades and the engine casing. If a hot engine was shutdown, then the engine casing would cool very quickly (due to its thin construction and cooling from both inside and outside the engine), but the blades are much heavier and only get warm air inside the engine, so cool much slower. This means that the casing will shrink faster than the turbine blades, and given that there are such tight tolerances between the end of the blades and the casing itself, this could cause the seals* to be crushed, and the blade will scrape the casing and potentially seize completely. Note: this seems to be written as part of the learning objective stated above, so we can be quite sure that the feedback quoting the "seizure" answer is correct. We are aware that "cooling of the core" could also be aided by this procedures, but that is not specific enough to even be sure which part of the engine they are referring to, so we agree that it is not correct. Also, there are many different seals within an engine, they must be referring to blade tip seals in this answer, given the context. Those are the seals that exist between the end of the turbine blades and the casing that try to stop air escaping around the edge of the turbine. The most common type appears to be a slight cutout of the casing for the blade to fit in. Not all engines appear to have these, but some do.

content.question: In a gas turbine engine using pure reaction-type turbine blades, rotational forces are the direct result of…

options.A: decreased gas velocity caused by convergent areas between turbine stators.
options.B: increased gas velocity caused by divergent areas between turbine blades.
options.C: aerodynamic action caused by divergent areas between turbine blades.
options.D: aerodynamic action caused by convergent areas between turbine blades.

key_points: IMPULSE TURBINE Nozzle guide vanes (form convergent ducts – accelerate the gas) Velocity increases Pressure decreases Rotor Blades Velocity decreases No change in pressure REACTION TURBINE Nozzle guide vanes Pressure remains constant Rotor Blades (form convergent ducts – accelerate the gas, creating reaction force which drives the turbine) Velocity decreases Both temperature and pressure decrease According to Rolls Royce, in a reaction turbine, the nozzle guide vanes simply direct the gas onto the turbine blades
Therefore, there is no change in speed or pressure across them, only a change in direction
learning.explanation: IMPULSE TURBINE Nozzle guide vanes (form convergent ducts – accelerate the gas) Velocity increases Pressure decreases Rotor Blades Velocity decreases No change in pressure REACTION TURBINE Nozzle guide vanes Pressure remains constant Rotor Blades (form convergent ducts – accelerate the gas, creating reaction force which drives the turbine) Velocity decreases Both temperature and pressure decrease According to Rolls Royce, in a reaction turbine, the nozzle guide vanes simply direct the gas onto the turbine blades. Therefore, there is no change in speed or pressure across them, only a change in direction.

content.question: Compressor stall in a gas turbine engine is due to…

options.A: an inadequate fuel flow.
options.B: an excessively low angle of attack of the rotor blades.
options.C: an excessively high axial velocity.
options.D: an excessively high angle of attack of the rotor blades.

key_points: A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM
As a result, smooth airflow is interrupted and pressure fluctuations are created within the turbine
It occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack (just like a wing)
learning.explanation: A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM. As a result, smooth airflow is interrupted and pressure fluctuations are created within the turbine. It occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack (just like a wing). Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Usually, this is followed by a complete compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall.

content.question: During a cold winter day, a jet aircraft performing a short flight is in the cruise at a medium level. The thrust levers remain stationary but both pilots note that the EGT is increasing. What could be the reason for this?

options.A: Because the air is colder, the temperature in the combustion chamber has to be increased to compensate.
options.B: Because of the low outside air temperature, fuel density is higher, so more fuel enters the combustion chamber, causing an increase in EGT.
options.C: Ice is forming on the leading edge of the wings, so more thrust is added to compensate, increasing EGT.
options.D: Ice is forming around the engine intake, causing less air mass flow in the engine, increasing EGT.

key_points: EGT (Exhaust Gas Temperature) is an excellent marker of both engine health and performance
EGT is obviously high when the engine is at high thrust but can also be increased due to long term engine health or due to short term issues

For instance, when flying on an older aircraft, you may notice if one of the engines has been more recently replaced as the EGT will likely be lower on that newer, healthier engine, as it has less ineficiencies and therefore produces the same thrust/N1 using less fuel and lower combustion temperatures, etc
learning.explanation: EGT (Exhaust Gas Temperature) is an excellent marker of both engine health and performance. EGT is obviously high when the engine is at high thrust but can also be increased due to long term engine health or due to short term issues. For instance, when flying on an older aircraft, you may notice if one of the engines has been more recently replaced as the EGT will likely be lower on that newer, healthier engine, as it has less ineficiencies and therefore produces the same thrust/N1 using less fuel and lower combustion temperatures, etc. EGT is also a measure of short term engine problems, and is particularly affected by poor airflow through the engine, as this primarily reduces the amount of cooling airflow available after combustion has occurred, so causes a rise in the EGT and TGT (Turbine Gas Temperature), which can sometimes limit an engine's thrust so these temperature limits are not exceeded. Let's go through the answers now: "Because the air is colder, the temperature in the combustion chamber has to be increased to compensate." Incorrect. Cold air is brilliant for jet engines (once running) as the air is naturally denser and more thrust can be produced for the same temperatures, so it is nice and efficient, and reduces EGT for the same thrust output. "Because of the low outside air temperature, fuel density is higher, so more fuel enters the combustion chamber, causing an increase in EGT." Incorrect. The fuel density is higher, but the fuel is introduced to the combustion chamber as necessary to produce the correct N1 or EPR (engine pressure ratio), not just blindly as a volume flow rate. The EGT is unaffected by this difference in density. "Ice is forming on the leading edge of the wings, so more thrust is added to compensate, increasing EGT." Incorrect. Ice may be forming on the leading edges of the wings, and would require increased thrust, however, that would mean advancing the thrust levers, and the question says the thrust levers have not moved. "Ice is forming around the engine intake, causing less air mass flow in the engine, increasing EGT." Correct. This is quite a likely cause, and if the engine inlet is not anti/de-iced, the formation of icing round the intake is likely to cause a reduced airflow into the engine, which will cause increased combustion temperatures and lower cooling (and therefore higher EGT) to produce the same N1/EPR.

content.question: Flat rated jet engines are designed to provide constant maximum take-off thrust up to a certain level of…

options.A: ambient pressure.
options.B: ambient temperature.
options.C: pressure altitude.
options.D: engine pressure ratio.

key_points: When the outside temperature is quite low, the denser air will induce an increase in the air mass flow for a given engine speed, and this will ultimately increase the thrust
Consequently, the denser air will allow the engine to produce the required take-off thrust before the limiting temperature has been reached
The limiting temperature is linked to the maximum available pressure ratio across the compressor and the maximum operating temperature of the turbine
learning.explanation: When the outside temperature is quite low, the denser air will induce an increase in the air mass flow for a given engine speed, and this will ultimately increase the thrust. Consequently, the denser air will allow the engine to produce the required take-off thrust before the limiting temperature has been reached. The limiting temperature is linked to the maximum available pressure ratio across the compressor and the maximum operating temperature of the turbine. A flat-rated jet engine is designed to provide constant maximum take-off thrust up to a certain ambient temperature (OAT). Therefore, on a very cold day, the engine will be able to deliver more thrust than its components can actually safely take. A flat rated gas turbine engine will be temperature limited if the OAT is higher than the flat rated temperature.

content.question: How can a modern jet aircraft, in very rare cases, start an engine, if neither an APU or GPU is available?

options.A: Small engines started by the battery.
options.B: Large engines started by the ram air turbine (RAT).
options.C: Large engines started by the battery.
options.D: Small engines started by the ram air turbine (RAT).

key_points: This is a bit of a strange question, as it is really specific to each aircraft

Some jet aircraft will not be able to start their main engines without an APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) or GPU (Ground Power Unit), and some will be able to start both engines off battery only (Boeing 787)
What it is really asking is for knowledge of the way an engine is started
learning.explanation: This is a bit of a strange question, as it is really specific to each aircraft. Some jet aircraft will not be able to start their main engines without an APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) or GPU (Ground Power Unit), and some will be able to start both engines off battery only (Boeing 787). What it is really asking is for knowledge of the way an engine is started. Turbine engines require a lot of energy to get the compressors spinning up to a sustainable speed, and some engines require air starting (B737 main engines, for instance), whereas some have electric starter motors that can be run off GPU or battery power, if the batteries are high enough voltage. The batteries have to be able to provide a very large amount of output over quite a short time in order to get the engine compressor(s) up to speed. The larger the engine, the more power that is required to start it. This is why batteries are only able to start smaller engines, as the batteries would need to be huge, and very high voltage, to start larger engines (as is the case in the B787, which is an exception). It is also the reason that APUs can be started by batteries alone, as they are very small turbine engines that are easy to start, but produce enough auxiliary power and bleed air to start the other engines and run various onboard systems. Some light jets do not have an APU, to save space and weight, so instead have quite powerful batteries to start their quite small main engines from battery power alone, when a GPU is not available. The RAT (ram air turbine) is a little wind turbine that drops out of the aircraft to provide hydraulic pressure (and sometimes electricity) if there are no other electrical or hydraulic sources available on the aircraft. This is to use essential items such as the flight controls in case of a multiple engine and electrical failure. It is not nearly powerful enough to start an engine.

content.question: When the combustion gases pass through a turbine stage the…

options.A: pressure drops.
options.B: temperature remains constant.
options.C: pressure rises.
options.D: temperature increases.

key_points: In all types of gas turbine engines, the turbine stage follows the combustion chamber
The turbine is fed by high-energy air with high temperature and pressure
The purpose of the turbine is to extract energy from the flow to produce power
learning.explanation: In all types of gas turbine engines, the turbine stage follows the combustion chamber. The turbine is fed by high-energy air with high temperature and pressure. The purpose of the turbine is to extract energy from the flow to produce power. The turbine stage is usually of the same construction as the compressor, comprising of rotating discs with turbine blades and associated stator stages. The turbine generates power from the expanded flow by converting pressure energy to kinetic energy. Initially, prior to interacting with each turbine blade stage, velocity is increased by the converging ducts of the nozzle guide vanes (NGVs). There can be one or more turbine stages for each spool and, to extract as much as possible from the decreasing energy available from the gas stream, each subsequent stage has longer blades than the preceding stage. As the gas expands through the turbine and gives up its energy, pressure, velocity and temperature decrease.

content.question: The main function of the exhaust cone on a turbine engine is to…

options.A: optimise the intake flow into the engine.
options.B: reduce the flow of the expelled cold gases.
options.C: optimise the flow of the expelled hot gases.
options.D: eliminate the flow of the expelled hot gases.

key_points: The exhaust section begins downstream of the last turbine disc and ends where the flow re-joins the external environment
The main components of an exhaust section are: Jet pipe: forms the outer casing for the flow and guides it towards the exit area
The jet pipe continuously withstands flow temperatures in the range of 500-800°C
learning.explanation: The exhaust section begins downstream of the last turbine disc and ends where the flow re-joins the external environment. The main components of an exhaust section are: Jet pipe: forms the outer casing for the flow and guides it towards the exit area. The jet pipe continuously withstands flow temperatures in the range of 500-800°C. Exhaust cone: its purpose is to protect the turbine disc central area from the high temperature flow from the turbine area and control the velocity by the varying cross-section area. Additionally, it aims to prevent flow reversal or turbulence in the axis area by optimizing the flow of the expelled hot gases. Propelling nozzle: turbojets have a propelling nozzle downstream of the jet pipe in order to accelerate the flow. The flow acceleration results in an increased jet velocity that increases thrust for the air mass flow. Incorrect answer options: “Optimise the intake flow into the engine” – the exhaust cone is only influencing the exhaust gases; it has nothing to do with the air intake. “Reduce the flow of the expelled cold gases” – the purpose of the propelling nozzle is to accelerate the exhaust gases, not to slow them down. “Eliminate the flow of the expelled hot gases” – the cone itself doesn’t eliminate anything. It has only a particular (=converging) shape just to modify the flow of exhaust gases to provide a higher thrust.

content.question: On a FADEC jet engine, the meaning of F.A.D.E.C. on a gas turbine engine is…

options.A: FAILURE ANALYSIS / DISPATCH EVALUATION COMPUTER.
options.B: FAILSAFE ADAPTER DUAL ELECTRONIC COMPUTER.
options.C: FULL AUTHORITY DIGITAL ENGINE CONTROL.
options.D: FAILSAFE ADAPTER DIRECT EFFECT COMPUTATION.

key_points: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks
The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby
If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions
learning.explanation: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks. The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby. If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions. In addition to the ECU, all the FADEC peripherals such as actuators, solenoids, electrical wiring, sensors, and fuel metering are also part of the FADEC system and are used for control and monitoring. The system has a three-phase permanent magnetic alternator for an internal power source. This independent alternator is also the electrical power source for all the FADEC sensors as well as the ECUs. By interfacing with other aircraft systems and its own engine sensors, the FADEC system provides the following functions: Automatic thrust rating control. Engine operation within safe limits. Fully automatic engine starting. Thrust Reverser Control. Engine overspeed and/or an EGT protection function. Engine monitoring and help for maintenance and troubleshooting. To make the FADEC’s operation more reliable, the system uses the dual inputs logic. All control inputs to the FADEC system are dual, with the exception of some secondary parameters used for monitoring and indicating (that are single). To increase the fault-tolerant design where the engine will still be able to operate within a required reliability and safety range, the parameters are exchanged between the two control channels (inside the ECU) via a cross-channel data link. Therefore, if one input parameter fails to be delivered, the input parameter from the other channel will be used to allow the correct computation of the engine parameters by the FADEC. This means that the FADEC is a single fault-tolerant, and it will ensure the efficient and correct running of the engine even in case of a detected malfunction.

content.question: A turbofan engine with an inlet air mass flow of 220 kg/s and a HP compressor mass flow of 20 kg/s has a bypass ratio of…

key_points: Formulas: Bypass mass flow = inlet mass flow - HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio = bypass mass flow / HP compressor mass flow Bypass mass flow = 220 kg/s - 20 kg/s = 200 kg/s Bypass ratio = 200 kg/s / 20 kg/s = 10
learning.explanation: Formulas: Bypass mass flow = inlet mass flow - HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio = bypass mass flow / HP compressor mass flow Bypass mass flow = 220 kg/s - 20 kg/s = 200 kg/s Bypass ratio = 200 kg/s / 20 kg/s = 10

content.question: What is the primary purpose of the exhaust section of a turbojet engine?

options.A: To direct the flow rearward and ensure a high velocity of the hot exhaust gases.
options.B: To reduce the velocity of the rearward airflow and ensure a high static gas pressure.
options.C: To create a turbulent flow to reduce harmful engine emissions before they are sent through the exhaust outlet.
options.D: To reduce the temperature of the hot gases and align the turbulent airflow coming from the turbine section.

key_points: GAS TURBINE EXHAUST After the gas has passed through the turbine, it is discharged through the exhaust
Though in a modern high bypass turbofan engine, most of the gaseous energy is converted to mechanical energy by the turbine, a significant amount of power remains in the exhaust gas
The question specifically mentions a turbojet engine, meaning that it has no bypass air, and therefore gains all its thrust from the high velocity airflow from the exhaust
learning.explanation: GAS TURBINE EXHAUST After the gas has passed through the turbine, it is discharged through the exhaust. Though in a modern high bypass turbofan engine, most of the gaseous energy is converted to mechanical energy by the turbine, a significant amount of power remains in the exhaust gas. The question specifically mentions a turbojet engine, meaning that it has no bypass air, and therefore gains all its thrust from the high velocity airflow from the exhaust. After leaving the turbine, the gas is often initially decelerated through the early jet pipe section, due to the exhaust cone increasing the surface area of the jet pipe, thereby increasing the static pressure of the gas. This is to reduce losses due to friction (slower moving air = less friction with the walls). Depending on the engine, the walls of the jet pipe may also contract to keep the gas speed the same, it all depends on the usual gas speed leaving the turbine. The air is then accelerated through the convergent duct shape at the end of the exhaust to decrease the static pressure and increase the speed, making it more useful as jet thrust - the principle of equal and opposite reaction means that the force of the exhausted air drives the aeroplane forward. The output velocity will usually reach Mach 1 and stop there, as this is when the exhaust gas becomes "choked", and cannot get any faster without using afterburner.

content.question:
The following are required to start a turbine engine:
1. The compressor must be rotated to get air into the combustion chamber
2. The compressor must be rotated to cool the turbine blades
3. Fuel must be provided in the combustion chamber(s)
4. Ignition must be provided to start the fuel/air mixture burning
5. The turbine blades must be rotated to extract the exhaust gases from the combustion chamber
6. The turbine blades must be rotated by an APU to drive the accessories

key_points: The main principles of engine starting include providing airflow to the combustion chamber, supplying fuel, and operating the igniters to spark the air/fuel mixture
Igniters are energised by electric power from the aircraft
Air and fuel is supplied by the compressor assembly and fuel pumps operated by the rotation of the spools
learning.explanation: The main principles of engine starting include providing airflow to the combustion chamber, supplying fuel, and operating the igniters to spark the air/fuel mixture. Igniters are energised by electric power from the aircraft. Air and fuel is supplied by the compressor assembly and fuel pumps operated by the rotation of the spools. To start and engine, it is necessary to provide initial torque to rotate the engine. This in turn ensures that air flows to the engine. Typical start sequence of a turbine engine: Compressor rotation (by starter motor) to get air into the combustion chamber; Ignition sparks; Fuel injection; and Starter motor deactivation.

content.question: The turboprop beta-range power level is the…

options.A: range of power-lever positions between the fine pitch ground idle and maximum reverse.
options.B: range of power-lever positions between the fine pitch flight idle and maximum reverse.
options.C: power level required to achieve the best climb angle.
options.D: power-lever positions where maximum fuel efficiency is obtained.

key_points: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight
Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm
The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range, and the power lever positions corresponding to the ALPHA range are between flight idle and maximum power
learning.explanation: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight. Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm. The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range, and the power lever positions corresponding to the ALPHA range are between flight idle and maximum power. However, while maneuvering on the ground, the power required for a turboprop engine is pretty low. Therefore, the controls have been adapted such that the blade pitch angle (therefore the thrust produced) is controlled directly by the pilot, overriding the CSU. This ground range is known as the BETA control range. The flight crew will select a blade pitch angle by moving the power lever fully aft and lifting it up. The first detent of the BETA range will correspond to the ground idle detent that will allow the pilots to produce minimum level of thrust, just enough power to taxi the aircraft. If the lever is pulled full aft of the BETA range, the pilot will lower the blade pitch angle such that the maximum reverse power is produced (=negative thrust). This will usually be the case at landing in order to assist the aircraft’s deceleration.

content.question: An aircraft accelerates to a speed below which air is considered incompressible. The dynamic pressure in the inlet of a turbofan engine (1) _____ and the specific thrust of the engine (2) _____.

options.A: (1) increases; (2) increases.
options.B: (1) increases; (2) decreases.
options.C: (1) decreases; (2) decreases.
options.D: (1) decreases; (2) increases.

key_points: The pressure exerted on any part of the airplane depends on how the air is moving around the aircraft
Static pressure is the pressure that is exerted if the air isn't moving
In this case, air presses equally on all parts of the airplane
learning.explanation: The pressure exerted on any part of the airplane depends on how the air is moving around the aircraft. Static pressure is the pressure that is exerted if the air isn't moving. In this case, air presses equally on all parts of the airplane. This pressure decreases as speed increases. This means that if the fan in the turbine of a jet engine is speeding up the air, then the static pressure would decrease. Dynamic pressure is the pressure exerted by the air because of its motion. If the turbine speeds up the air, then the dynamic pressure of the air would increase. The specific thrust is calculated by dividing the thrust created by the engine (net thrust) by the mass flow rate of the air (meaning how much air is flowing through the engine in a given amount of time). In this case, Net Thrust will remain constant. However, total Intake Airflow increases due to the the higher airflow/speed. Consequently, Specific Thrust decreases.

content.question: Why do large jet engines need a spool-up time?

options.A: Because the engines are controlled by an electronic engine control unit, the calculations required to meter the correct amount of fuel produce a delay in the accelaration of the engine.
options.B: Due to the number of turbine blades in jet fans and the high viscosity of cold blades.
options.C: The engine gearbox requires a significant amount of the energy produced by the turbine; this causes a typical spool up time.
options.D: A request for a rapid acceleration may cause a flameout due to the overly rich mixture.

key_points: Gas turbine engines provide high overall thrust compared to other engines
However, they are much less responsive to thrust setting changes, due to the robustness of the design and the construction of the engine
The high inertia of the engine opposes quick acceleration or deceleration
learning.explanation: Gas turbine engines provide high overall thrust compared to other engines. However, they are much less responsive to thrust setting changes, due to the robustness of the design and the construction of the engine. The high inertia of the engine opposes quick acceleration or deceleration. To accelerate you have to overcome this inertia (resistance to spinning), plus the effort of compressing the air in the compressor - this in itself takes a tremendous amount of energy. Whilst this is happening, the airflow and the air/fuel ratio in the engine must carefully be controlled (the acceleration of the engine is difficult because the fuel has to be injected in increasing amounts for the same air mass flow, and only after this does the turbine extract more energy to accelerate the compressors). If more air was delivered from the compressor than the combustion chamber and the turbine could consume, the engine would suffer a compressor stall or surge. A surge can be catastrophic to the engine so designers have to balance out the need to accelerate without making the engine susceptible to surging. The spool-up time is how long it takes to increase RPM from idle to maximum value (approx. 7 seconds).

content.question:
Which of the following statements is correct about the flow in a divergent (subsonic) gas turbine engine intake?
1. The dynamic pressure decreases in flow direction.
2. The static temperature decreases in flow direction.

key_points: A gas turbine engine free turbine does not drive a compressor, i
e
there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine free turbine does not drive a compressor, i.e. there’s no mechanical connection between the compressor and the power output shaft. The energy delivered by the free turbine stages is only dependent on the rotational speed of the HP spool. In this configuration, the engine will simply act as a gas generator to supply high-energy gases to an independent free power turbine driving a propeller or rotor via a reduction gearbox. This is why this type of turbine is often used on turboprop engines and helicopters. In fact, there will be two major assemblies: one shaft connecting the compressor and the compressor-driving turbine, and a free turbine placed after the compressor-driving turbine that is connected to a propeller. Because these two assemblies are not interconnected in any way, the propeller and free turbine assembly will be able to rotate at an independent speed from that of the compressor-turbine spool. The most suitable control system for a turboprop fitted with a free turbine is the direct control of fuel flow. In this system, the gas generator (the core of the engine) is controlled in the same manner as a turbojet, and the power available to the free turbine assembly is governed by the fuel flow. For instance: If the power setting is increased, the RPM of the compressor-turbine shaft will also increase. However, the free turbine and propeller assembly will be maintained at constant RPM by the Constant Speed Unit (CSU) that will do so by increasing the propeller’s blade angle. If the power setting is decreased, the RPM of the compressor-turbine shaft will also decrease. However, the free turbine and propeller assembly will be maintained at constant RPM by the Constant Speed Unit (CSU) that will do so by decreasing the propeller’s blade angle.

learning.explanation: COMPONENTS OF EXHAUSTS The exhaust is a very important component of a gas turbine engine and a lot depends on its design. The air must exit the engine in the appropriate direction and correct velocity to optimise performance. The exhaust section begins downstream of the last turbine disc and ends where the flow re-joins the external environment. The main components of an exhaust section are: Jet pipe: forms the outer casing for the flow and guides it towards the exit area. The jet pipe continuously withstands flow temperatures in the range of 500-800°C. The flow acceleration results in an increased jet velocity that increases thrust for the air mass flow.

key_points: Due to the nature of FADEC (Full Authority Digital Engine Control) systems, failures must be well protected against
If there is a full FADEC failure with no backup then an engine will usually just stop working, as things such as the fuel supply will stop, or at least stop being regulated in any case
This means that FADEC engines need back up systems for redundancy
learning.explanation: Due to the nature of FADEC (Full Authority Digital Engine Control) systems, failures must be well protected against. If there is a full FADEC failure with no backup then an engine will usually just stop working, as things such as the fuel supply will stop, or at least stop being regulated in any case. This means that FADEC engines need back up systems for redundancy. This can either be achieved with a single FADEC system and a hydromechanical back up, or more commonly with a dual channel FADEC system. This makes the FADEC system 'single fault tolerant', meaning that any one fault on its own cannot stop the engine completely. In the case of this aircraft (dual channel FADEC system), the second (healthy) channel will take over if there is a single channel fault, and the engine itself will not perform any differently. As soon as it is on the ground it will be grounded until fixed, as a single channel FADEC with no back up control system would not be acceptable to run an engine.

Either some lights, or a separate fault panel, or an electronic APU monitoring page will display and announce any APU faults. options.B: increasing thrust as temperature increases above a cut-off value.

key_points: The Flat Rating Concept The rating of a jet engine is the thrust performance that is guaranteed by the manufacturer for a new engine under specific operating conditions such as, take off, maximum continuous, climb, cruise
Some non Prat and Whitney (P&W) engines are rated to a constant compressor speed (RPM)
P&W rates there engines to a constant exhaust gas temperature (EGT)
learning.explanation: The Flat Rating Concept The rating of a jet engine is the thrust performance that is guaranteed by the manufacturer for a new engine under specific operating conditions such as, take off, maximum continuous, climb, cruise. Some non Prat and Whitney (P&W) engines are rated to a constant compressor speed (RPM). P&W rates there engines to a constant exhaust gas temperature (EGT). This is referred to as the flat rating concept. To get your head around this concept you must understand the following principle. The temperature and density of the ambient air vary inversely. Lower temperature = > Higher Density Higher Temperature = >Lower Density The amount of airflow (lbs/sec) through the engine is a function of compressor speed and air density. It is greater when the compressor speed and density are high. The compressor speed is a function of the energy available to the compressors turbine. That energy comes from the combustion or air and fuel, so the turbine turns faster when the fuel flow rate is greater. The compressor speed is also a function of the airflow through the compressor. Higher rates of air flow reduce the speed of the compressor. The compressors rotational speed and the amount of airflow through the compressor are independent, they affect each other though. The turbine inlet temperature is proportional to the energy available to turn the turbine. The exhaust temperature is proportional to the turbine inlet temperature. So a higher EGT corresponds to a larger amount of energy to the turbine so it can turn the compressor faster. When EGT is held constant, or lowered the result is a prolonged hot section life and at the same time provides the thrust to meet the certification requirements.

learning.explanation: The intake geometry is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect. It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed. That’s why the intake is slightly divergent in order to reduce the airflow’s velocity and increase the static pressure and temperature just before the fan and compressor’s first stages. content.question: What is built into the exhaust nozzle of a turbofan engine to reduce the velocity of exhaust gasses?

options.A: An exhaust cone, fitted just behind the turbine.
options.B: A divergent section.
options.C: Fins at the turbines to decelerate the flow.
options.D: A convergent section.

key_points: Turbojet and turbofan engines have exhausts that prove far more useful than just giving hot exhaust gasses somewhere to leave the engine
The exhaust gasses that leave the turbine are hot, high pressure, and still very fast
These are all forms of energy that we would like to "get back" from the air, and the exhaust is very finely tuned to allow us to do this
learning.explanation: Turbojet and turbofan engines have exhausts that prove far more useful than just giving hot exhaust gasses somewhere to leave the engine. The exhaust gasses that leave the turbine are hot, high pressure, and still very fast. These are all forms of energy that we would like to "get back" from the air, and the exhaust is very finely tuned to allow us to do this. Initially, the air leaving the turbine is slowed down by a diverging area, usually provided by the presence of a "tail cone"/"exhaust cone". This has a few functions, including directing the gas to reduce disturbances, but mainly to reduce the speed of the gas, so it can travel through the exhaust without too much friction against the walls. A diverging area reduces speed, whilst increasing static pressure. The gas is now travelling at around Mach 0.5 in relation to the engine, but with high static pressure. Towards the back of the exhaust, we want to regain some of that speed from our excess static pressure. This is where we use a converging nozzle to regain that speed. The maximum speed the gas can reach here is Mach 1.0 without afterburners (we call this the nozzle being "choked"). Sometimes (for supersonic aircraft mostly), we then stick another diverging section on the end to take the extra gain from some pressure thrust and supersonic acceleration (this is now way above the syllabus). Note: This question does potentially have 2 correct answers. A divergent section is most correct due to its vague nature, and that is exactly what we want, but the way that is often achieved is through an "exhaust cone", which is placed right after the turbine. The feedback on the correct answer is solid as far as we can tell, but please inform us of any exam feedback you see about this question in the comments or by emailing us at info@atplquestions.com

content.question: In a compressor stage of a gas turbine engine, if the axial air velocity increases more than the rotor blade velocity the…

options.B: relative air velocity becomes supersonic.
options.C: stall margin increases.
options.D: stall margin decreases.

key_points: Note: This is quite similar to question 211180, and has the same answer, but the wording of the question and the options are different, so we are treating the questions separately for now

Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages
Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first
learning.explanation: Note: This is quite similar to question 211180, and has the same answer, but the wording of the question and the options are different, so we are treating the questions separately for now. Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Usually, this is followed by a compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. Therefore, if the opposite happens, i.e. the axial velocity through the compressor increases, the stall margin will be increased because there will be enough airflow (and more) to avoid a disruption. Caution must be taken in this situation as well because excessive forward (axial) airflow can produce overpressure at the compressor’s stages if its rotational speed is too low. This could eventually also induce a stall of the rear parts of the compressor should the excess pressure persist. That’s why the excessive pressure can be relieved by various means, such as bleed valves that will open at various stages to reduce overpressure and to maintain a more contant pressure ratio, etc. There is another way to think of this question, and that is like a fixed pitch propeller. If the aircraft is travelling slowly (low IAS) but with high RPM, then the angle of attack of the blade is very high and the propeller is likely to stall. If, like in this question, the aircraft is travelling fast (high IAS), then the blade angle of attack will be lower, and therefore further from the stall (i.e. an increased stall margin).

This is achieved through a series of aerofoil section blades called ‘rotors’ mounted on a rotating rotor disc that accelerate the air towards a set of ‘stator’ blades

learning.explanation: The principle of operation of an axial flow compressor is to add kinetic energy to the air and then convert it into pressure energy. This is achieved through a series of aerofoil section blades called ‘rotors’ mounted on a rotating rotor disc that accelerate the air towards a set of ‘stator’ blades. Each set of rotor-stator sequence is called a stage. The transition between the rotors and the stators is shaped into a divergent duct in order to convert the kinetic energy of the airflow into pressure energy. Because of the small pressure increase at each compressor stage, numerous stages are required to achieve the desired delivery pressure at the combustion chamber.

content.question: One of the advantages of an annular combustion chamber in a gas turbine engine is…

options.A: a simpler assembly.
options.B: a higher structural strength.
options.C: a reduced thermal stress on the turbine.
options.D: that fewer igniters are required.

key_points: Can-type (multiple) combustion chamber: consists of several flame tubes surrounded by an individual casing (self-contained)

has only two igniters located in the two lower chambers, even though combustion occurs in every single can separately by interconnecting them via a pivoted tube into a metallic elbow that is connected itself to the next can’s elbow
In this way, the flame is passed through the tubes to every single can, ensuring a uniform ignition
learning.explanation: Can-type (multiple) combustion chamber: consists of several flame tubes surrounded by an individual casing (self-contained). has only two igniters located in the two lower chambers, even though combustion occurs in every single can separately by interconnecting them via a pivoted tube into a metallic elbow that is connected itself to the next can’s elbow. In this way, the flame is passed through the tubes to every single can, ensuring a uniform ignition. Tubo-annular combustion chamber: consists of several tubes radially disposed around the engine between the compressor and turbine section, all sitting in the same annular casing. The advantage of this evolved arrangement is that the airflow is carefully controlled and is more evenly spread over the first stage turbine. Annular combustion chamber: uses the entire annulus casing between the compressor and the turbine for combustion. This helps to provide a better thermal distribution on the HP turbine and reduce turbine wearing. For the same power output, the annular chamber length is 75% of a tubo-annular chamber of similar diameter. Consequently, the wall area is much smaller and the amount of cooling air required to protect the flame tube wall is also reduced by approximately 15%. Combustion efficiency is increased and air pollution reduced making it the most widespread combustion chamber type on nowadays commercial jets.

options.B: Temperature increases, pressure increases and volume increases.

key_points: Note: This is a complicated question and we think it is right on the edge of the learning objectives, but the feedback indicates it exists in this form, and that this is the correct answer
Please let us know if you see this in the real exam and anything you remember about it, thank you
In a turboshaft engine, the same principles of a turbine engine apply, and the air is compressed to be burnt in the combustion chamber, with that hot expanded air then used to drive the turbines
learning.explanation: Note: This is a complicated question and we think it is right on the edge of the learning objectives, but the feedback indicates it exists in this form, and that this is the correct answer. Please let us know if you see this in the real exam and anything you remember about it, thank you. In a turboshaft engine, the same principles of a turbine engine apply, and the air is compressed to be burnt in the combustion chamber, with that hot expanded air then used to drive the turbines. Some of the turbines drive the compressors to restart the cycle, and in most turboshaft engines, the remaining airflow drives the "free power" turbines, which drive the propeller. Once the turbine stages have been passed, the air is still at quite high pressure and high temperature. The exhaust is designed to trade this extra energy for airflow velocity and therefore be able to gain a little extra thrust as the exhaust is pointing backwards, so the back-flowing exhaust air can provide extra thrust to the aircraft. To do this, the overall effect of the exhaust is to redirect the airflow (and smoothen it for reduced noise and inefficiencies), and it is therefore overall convergent (though this is not always shown by the figures due to simplification), to use the venturi effect to increase airflow speed whilst reducing static pressure significantly. This decrease in static pressure is intended to get it close to ambient pressure to transfer all that energy into speed. Static temperature drops due to the decreased static pressure. Volume change is quite complicated in this scenario, and not really mentioned in any reference material for turbine engines, but as the temperature has decreased, the density should have increased, and therefore the volume of air should decrease, but this does not take into account compressibility, etc., which is a factor at the high speeds involved. This increase in density should also be present in the transonic regime as velocity increases, but the calculations start to get very messy at that point.

content.question:
Which of these statements about compressor stall in a gas turbine engine are correct or incorrect?
I. A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at high RPM
II. A compressor stall is most likely to occur when the air flow stagnates in the rear stages of the compressor

options.B: I is correct, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at high RPM
" INCORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the air flow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM
learning.explanation: "I. A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at high RPM." INCORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the air flow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM. As a result, smooth airflow is interrupted and pressure fluctuations are created within the turbine. It occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack (just like a wing). Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing a stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Usually this is followed by a complete compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. "II. A compressor stall is most likely to occur when the air flow stagnates in the rear stages of the compressor." CORRECT As mentioned above, air stagnates in the REAR stages, which results in a lack of air in the FRONT stages with subsequent low axial velocity in front stages. This will lead to a high angle of attack of the rotor blades determining a STALL. To avoid such situation, turbine engines are fitted with VIGV (variable inlet guide vanes) and VSV (variable stator vanes) that ensure correct airflow through the stages of the engine.

content.question: Calculate the bypass ratio of a turbofan engine with the following parameters; an inlet mass flow of 400 kg/s and a HP compressor mass flow of 80kg/s.

key_points: Bypass ratio is the ratio of bypass air to air that flows through the HP compressor

A high bypass engine produces most of its thrust via the large fan at the front, accelerating a large mass of air around the side of the engine core, with a small proportion of the air flowing into the core to provide the power to the gas generator section
The air that flows through the core is counted at the HP compressor section
learning.explanation: Bypass ratio is the ratio of bypass air to air that flows through the HP compressor. A high bypass engine produces most of its thrust via the large fan at the front, accelerating a large mass of air around the side of the engine core, with a small proportion of the air flowing into the core to provide the power to the gas generator section. The air that flows through the core is counted at the HP compressor section. Formulas: Bypass air mass flow = inlet mass flow – HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio = bypass air mass flow / HP compressor mass flow Bypass mass flow = 400 kg/s – 80 kg/s = 320 kg/s Bypass ratio = 320 / 80 = 4 The bypass ratio of this engine is therefore 4:1, also written as 4/1 or just the value 4.

High-pressure fuel ON: after fuel is delivered by the high-pressure shut-off valve (HPSOV) it is sprayed into the combustion chamber by fuel nozzles under high-pressure where it is mixed with compressed air and lights up. Light-up: the mixture starts burning and the flame spreads all along with the combustion chamber (since it is interconnected). The flame becomes self-sustainable. Self-sustaining speed: all the engine’s spools have reached a self-sustaining speed where assistance from the air starter is not needed anymore. The air starter is disengaged by the coupling between engine N2 spool and starter by the use of centrifugal forces. Starter circuit canceled. Incorrect answers: “A combustion chamber, a starter, and bleed air to ignite the air/fuel mixture” – bleed air is not igniting anything. The igniters light up the mixture, not the bleed air. Bleed air from the APU, another engine, or a ground pneumatic unit is only directed to the air starter that will rotate the HP compressor (N2). “A turbine to compress and ignite the air/fuel mixture in the combustion chamber” – the turbine is not compressing the air; it is only driving the compressor that will compress the incoming air mass flow. “High-pressure fuel pumps and a compressor to raise the pressure of the air/fuel mixture for starting” – HP fuel pumps are definitely needed, however, what is wrong with this answer option is that it states that the compressor raises the pressure of the air/fuel mixture. This is incorrect as the compressor only raises the pressure of the air.

key_points: Viscosity, also known as fluid’s internal friction, is the tendency of a liquid or gas to resist flow and is temperature-dependent
When oil is cold, it has a high viscosity and flows slowly, thus making the fluid stream quite difficult
Therefore, when the engine is started on a very cold early morning after spending the night on the parking stand, the oil pressure will be higher than normal during start-up
learning.explanation: Viscosity, also known as fluid’s internal friction, is the tendency of a liquid or gas to resist flow and is temperature-dependent. When oil is cold, it has a high viscosity and flows slowly, thus making the fluid stream quite difficult. Therefore, when the engine is started on a very cold early morning after spending the night on the parking stand, the oil pressure will be higher than normal during start-up. This is normal, and as the oil temperature increases, the viscosity will decrease and the oil pressure will subsequently drop back to more normal levels. This is better for engine lubrication and for lower engine resistance, and the aircraft should not commence engine run-ups or take-off before the oil temperature has risen sufficiently, at which point the pressure will be back to normal. That’s why engine manufacturers impose a warm-up time before take-off. This will also allow the oil temperature to stabilise and increase within the acceptable range, as it will initially be pretty low. As an example, the warm-up time for an IAE V2500 engine, which often powers A320 family aircraft, is 5 minutes (This specifically is a gas turbine engine, but it is exactly the same principle in a piston engine).

content.question: In order to increase the velocity of exit gases, a jet engine exhaust nozzle…

options.A: is designed in a way so that it becomes a convergent duct.
options.B: includes a divergent section.
options.C: includes fins after the turbine section to decelerate the exhaust gasses.
options.D: includes an exhaust cone fitted just behind the turbine.

key_points: The exhaust of a jet engine directs the exhaust gasses aft and regulates the gas streamflow

It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent internal friction and flow separation in order to provide the highest total thrust during normal operation, for lowest noise and best efficiency

Initially, the air leaving the turbine section will undergo a diverging section (due to the exhaust cone), to slow the air down and help to allow the airflow to straighten out (removing some of the air turbulence)
learning.explanation: The exhaust of a jet engine directs the exhaust gasses aft and regulates the gas streamflow. It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent internal friction and flow separation in order to provide the highest total thrust during normal operation, for lowest noise and best efficiency. Initially, the air leaving the turbine section will undergo a diverging section (due to the exhaust cone), to slow the air down and help to allow the airflow to straighten out (removing some of the air turbulence). This slower air has higher pressure, but lower friction with the walls of the exhaust section. The exhaust section is made long to reduce the turbulence, decreasing noise and often increasing efficiency. At the end of the exhaust section comes the [propelling] nozzle, which is usually converging, to induce a decrease in pressure and temperature and an increase in exhaust gases velocity resulting in a higher total thrust. As the question is asking about the exhaust nozzle, and about increasing the exhaust gas velocity, then the convergent section is the correct answer.

learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine is basically a heat engine using air as a fluid to produce thrust. The working principle of the gas turbine engine is comparable to that of a piston engine as both engines use a cycle made of induction, compression, combustion, and exhaust phases. The only difference is the way these phases will be achieved as the gas turbine engine is capable of dealing with much larger amounts of energy for a given size and weight. The other great advantage of the gas turbine engine is that the whole working cycle is continuous and entirely rotational providing an overall smoother operation, whereas piston engine uses an intermittent reciprocating motion which is converted to rotary motion by means of cranks. Summary: Piston engine -Process is intermittent -Combustion is at constant volume Jet engine -Process is continuous -Combustion is at constant pressure.

Refer to the following formulas: Bypass ratio = bypass mass flow / HP compressor mass flow Bypass mass flow = inlet mass flow – HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio is defined as the ratio between the mass flow (NOT volume) rate of air drawn in by the fan bypassing the engine core (bypass mass flow) to the mass flow rate passing through the engine core (HP compressor mass flow). options.B: (1) is not; (2) the turbine

learning.explanation: Note: There are two correct answers here, which vary depending on interpretation. We await further feedback, and the result of any appeals, thank you! Initial feedback gave the correct answer of D ("is not; the compressor"), but more recent feedback has given answer B as correct ("is not; the turbine"). 021.11.01.02.09: Explain the principle of a free turbine or free-power turbine. Free power turbines are turbine engines that can be used for turboprop powered aircraft or turboshaft powered helicopters, and have a variety of benefits over direct drive alternatives. The main feature of them is that the power output shaft (to the rotors or propeller) is not physically connected to any part of the "gas generator", which is the set of compressors fed by the normal turbines. Instead of linking the propeller to one of the standard turbine spools, an extra turbine is added to the engine after the standard turbines, which absorbs most of the remaining energy to use solely for the turning of the propeller, before the air gets sent out of the exhaust. This means that the propeller can be governed to go at any speed the pilots requires, which will mean that the free power turbine will also have to go at the corresponding speed (they are connected via a reduction gearbox to go from the turbine's 50 000-ish RPM to the propeller's 2000-ish RPM), but without making the rest of the engine components go at that speed, allowing the standard turbine-compressor spools (known as the "gas generator") to stay at their optimum speed, where they can be most efficient, and longer lasting. Depending on how you look at this, it also means that the free power turbine can go at the optimum speed for each scenario, rather than having to go at the speed of the gas generator. This does mean that there are two correct answers here, and therefore we await further feedback, and the result of any appeals. The engine (gas generator) then becomes far simpler to operate as well, as it is almost self regulating in its speeds, etc. with no outside influence. All we do is harness the left-over pressure and velocity of the air - of which there should be plenty - to put through our propellers. There must be a constant speed unit to regulate propeller RPM, and particular care must be paid to over-torquing the engine. Another useful feature of a free power turbine is the ease of starting, as propeller drag does not affect the independent gas generator. Propeller feathering is also possible with this format.

content.question: Which of these may be caused by an EGT exceedance due to excessive fuel flow in a turbine engine?

options.A: A sudden increase in N2 RPM, causing an engine overspeed.
options.B: A stall at the HP compressor section.
options.C: Structural damage or metal deformation could occur at the turbine section.
options.D: The turbine engine will continue to operate within normal range, since excessive fuel is drained by drain holes in the combustion chamber.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.04.01.10: Describe the possible effects on engine components when EGT limits are exceeded. Given the wording of the question, we can assume that the engine is either being started (most likely) or already running, and in both cases, the correct answer is still the same. EGT (Exhaust Gas Temperature) is pretty self-explanatory, and if it exceeds its limit, then this is likely due to too much combustion, not enough cooling airflow, or not enough airflow through the engine at all. The EGT is particularly important as it is a strong indicator of engine health, and though it is not great for troubleshooting as so many different things cause an EGT rise, it is excellent for knowing if the engine has an issue at all. The EGT is measured just after the turbine section, so the limit is usually there to avoid extreme heat and stress damaging the turbine blades, which is the highest stress component in the whole engine, due to the high RPM and high temperature. These two effects mean that turbine blades have to be actively cooled and made smaller than their mounting so they have room to expand, as they stretch slightly under load. Whether during start-up or not, damaging the turbine blades is the real issue here. As for the other options: An N2 overspeed is unlikely as this requires significant damage or a sustained overpressure in the turbine that is not replicated in the compressor, which is very unlikely. A stall is related to the compressor blades, and this is occurring downstream of the compressor. The fuel will not drain as it has already been burnt, otherwise how would the EGT have risen so high?

content.question:
Which of these statements about compressor stall in a gas turbine engine are correct or incorrect?
I. A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at high RPM
II. A compressor stall is most likely to occur when the air flow stagnates in the front stages of the compressor

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high-pressure ratio operating at high RPM
" INCORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM
learning.explanation: "I. A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high-pressure ratio operating at high RPM." INCORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the airflow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM. As a result, smooth airflow is interrupted and pressure fluctuations are created within the turbine. It occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack (just like a wing). Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Usually, this is followed by a complete compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. "II. A compressor stall is most likely to occur when the airflow stagnates in the front stages of the compressor." INCORRECT As mentioned above, air stagnates in the REAR stages, which results in a lack of air in the FRONT stages with subsequent low axial velocity in the front stages. This will lead to a high angle of attack of the rotor blades determining a STALL. To avoid such a situation, turbine engines are fitted with VIGV (variable inlet guide vanes) and VSV (variable stator vanes) that ensure correct airflow through the stages of the engine.

In simple words, It limits the system pressure to a specific set level and if this set level is reached, the pressure relief valve responds and feeds the excess flow from the system back to the tank

learning.explanation: A Pressure Relief Valve (PRV) is a form of safety valve used to manage and restrict build-up in a pressurized hydraulic system. In simple words, It limits the system pressure to a specific set level and if this set level is reached, the pressure relief valve responds and feeds the excess flow from the system back to the tank. Therefore, a higher-than-normal oil pressure indication will be displayed on the gauge if one of these pressure relief valves gets stuck and cannot properly regulate the oil pressure. The opposite is also true. If the pressure relief valve does not seat properly, it is probably because it remains slightly opened and dumps too much oil than needed to achieve the necessary output pressure. This will be observed by a lower-than-normal oil pressure indication.

key_points: When the engines are running, continuous ignition can be selected either manually by the flight crew or automatically by the FADEC to maintain engine combustion

The FADEC will automatically turn ON continuous ignition when the engine anti-ice is ON, maximum/flex thrust is selected, idle thrust is selected during approach, or a thrust control malfunction is detected (risk of flame-out), etc

learning.explanation: When the engines are running, continuous ignition can be selected either manually by the flight crew or automatically by the FADEC to maintain engine combustion. The FADEC will automatically turn ON continuous ignition when the engine anti-ice is ON, maximum/flex thrust is selected, idle thrust is selected during approach, or a thrust control malfunction is detected (risk of flame-out), etc. On some aircraft, it can even be automatically activated when the stall warning system alerts of an impending stall. The flight crew will manually select continuous ignition when passing through a heavy precipitation area, moderate or severe turbulence, high ambient air temperatures, or anytime a lack of sufficient airflow or fuel into the engine is expected. The continuous ignition is low-energy-level since there’s no need for such a strong spark as during engine start, but only to ensure combustion is continuous.

content.question: If the flow speed through an axial turbofan compressor is too high, what effect will that have on the compressor?

options.A: The stall margins will decrease.
options.B: The stall margins will increase.
options.C: The compressor will become more efficient.
options.D: The compressor will generate less thrust.

key_points: Note: This is quite similar to question 219019, and has the same answer, but the wording of the question and the options are different, so we are treating the questions separately for now

Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages
Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first
learning.explanation: Note: This is quite similar to question 219019, and has the same answer, but the wording of the question and the options are different, so we are treating the questions separately for now. Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Usually, this is followed by a compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. Therefore, if the opposite happens, i.e. the axial velocity through the compressor increases, the stall margin will be increased because there will be enough airflow (and more) to avoid a disruption. Caution must be taken in this situation as well because excessive forward (axial) airflow can produce overpressure at the compressor’s stages if its rotational speed is too low. This could eventually also induce a stall of the rear parts of the compressor should the excess pressure persist. That’s why the excessive pressure can be relieved by various means, such as bleed valves that will open at various stages to reduce overpressure and to maintain a more constant pressure ratio, etc. There is another way to think of this question, and that is like a fixed pitch propeller. If the aircraft is travelling slowly (low IAS) but with high RPM, then the angle of attack of the blade is very high and the propeller is likely to stall. If, like in this question, the aircraft is travelling fast (high IAS), then the blade angle of attack will be lower, and therefore further from the stall (i.e. an increased stall margin).

That’s why most of the times it is converging, so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature, and an increase in exhaust gases velocity (kinetic energy) resulting in a higher thrust
learning.explanation: The propelling nozzle directs the exhaust gas aft and regulates the gas stream flow. It must be designed to obtain the correct balance of pressure and velocity to prevent flow separation. That’s why most of the times it is converging, so that it can induce a decrease in pressure and temperature, and an increase in exhaust gases velocity (kinetic energy) resulting in a higher thrust. The acceleration of the flow by the propelling nozzle can somehow disturb the airflow, so it is positioned at a distance from the jet pipe where the disturbances won’t cause a flow separation.

learning.explanation: Note: This question is a slightly simpler version on Q213607 and we believe that both have been seen in the real exams recently. The auxiliary power unit (APU) is a small gas turbine engine which is installed in the tail section of the aircraft. Most APUs will be electrically started, using the aircraft battery. options.B: oil filter clogged warning signal.
options.C: oil pressure.
options.D: oil temperature.

key_points: The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts
It is also used as a substance to clean the interior of the engine and accumulate the deposits gathered along the way for removal
In a gas turbine engine, the largest and some of the most important moving parts are the ball and roller main bearings of the main driveshafts, which would also crucially require an oil supply
learning.explanation: The main purpose of lubrication is to reduce the friction between the moving surfaces and dissipate heat from the moving parts. It is also used as a substance to clean the interior of the engine and accumulate the deposits gathered along the way for removal. In a gas turbine engine, the largest and some of the most important moving parts are the ball and roller main bearings of the main driveshafts, which would also crucially require an oil supply. It is one of the most important parameters to monitor during engine start. If you don’t observe an increase in oil pressure the rotating parts of the engine will generate a lot of heat due to friction, eventually resulting in a fire. The oil pressure transmitter is usually located on the lubrication unit outlet line of the engine and oil pressure is indicated on a flight deck instrument.
