content.question:
Consider a turbine engine. When bleed air is taken from the compressor, which of the following items are increased?
1. Fuel Flow (FF)
2. Gas generator speed (NG or N1)
3. Free turbine speed (NF or N2)
4. Rotor speed (NR)
5. Turbine Outlet Temperature (TOT)

key_points: Compressed air is taken from the HP compressor stage of a gas turbine engine and is used for various purposes: de/anti-icing, air conditioning, engine start
This compressed air driven from the compressor is known as bleed air
When selecting the bleed air ‘ON’ some of the air will be sucked out of the normal flow inside the engine and will induce some inconveniences and risks
learning.explanation: Compressed air is taken from the HP compressor stage of a gas turbine engine and is used for various purposes: de/anti-icing, air conditioning, engine start. This compressed air driven from the compressor is known as bleed air. When selecting the bleed air ‘ON’ some of the air will be sucked out of the normal flow inside the engine and will induce some inconveniences and risks. In fact, the mass flow of air will be reduced, which will need to be compensated by an increase in fuel flow and gas generator speed (N1), which will increase the engine’s overall temperature, especially the turbine temperature since less air is available for cooling. You can observe the increase in N1 during descent when selecting the engine anti-ice ON – the idle RPM will be increased. It also increases specific fuel consumption and the EGT and the power output (or thrust) will be decreased, in other words, aircraft, and more precisely engine performance will greatly be decreased.

content.question: On modern jet aeroplanes, (1) _____ engines can be started using the (2) _____.

options.A: (1) small; (2) battery
options.B: (1) small; (2) RAT
options.C: (1) large; (2) battery
options.D: (1) large; (2) RAT

key_points: On modern jet airplanes, smaller engines, such as auxiliary power units (APUs) or smaller turbine engines, can be started using the aircraft's battery
The battery provides the initial electrical power needed to start these smaller engines
This process is particularly common during pre-flight procedures or when the main engines are not running
learning.explanation: On modern jet airplanes, smaller engines, such as auxiliary power units (APUs) or smaller turbine engines, can be started using the aircraft's battery. The battery provides the initial electrical power needed to start these smaller engines. This process is particularly common during pre-flight procedures or when the main engines are not running. Should APU and/or engine-driven generators fail, some aircraft provide an emergency means of generating electrical, and sometimes also hydraulic power. A RAT (Ram Air Turbine) can be ejected from the aircraft and positioned in the air flow around the fuselage. The turbine then drives a shaft, which is connected to a magnet-inducing current in the coils of an emergency generators. These generators are not usually very powerful, and their power can therefore only be directed to the most important aircraft systems. The RAT is typically not the primary means of starting engines during normal operations; it serves as a backup or emergency power source.

content.question: To ensure efficient combustion in a gas turbine engine…

options.A: it must be capable of creating the optimal mixture of air and fuel.
options.B: interstage bleed valves must be fitted to the compressor section.
options.C: it must be capable of utilising different fuel types.
options.D: air must be supplied to the combustor section at a constant flow.

key_points: The main purpose of a gas turbine engine combustion chamber is to mix fuel with compressed air and burn it in an efficient manner
It will do so by providing an optimal increase in the air’s temperature with a minimum loss of pressure
It is of the utmost importance to design the engine so that it creates the optimal mixture of air and fuel
learning.explanation: The main purpose of a gas turbine engine combustion chamber is to mix fuel with compressed air and burn it in an efficient manner. It will do so by providing an optimal increase in the air’s temperature with a minimum loss of pressure. It is of the utmost importance to design the engine so that it creates the optimal mixture of air and fuel. This will improve its overall efficiency, will waste less fuel, and will ensure the temperatures do not exceed the materials’ structural limit. Nowadays, this is calculated and modulated by the Full Authority Digital Engine Control system. Incorrect answers: “Interstage bleed valves must be fitted to the compressor section” – this option refers to the bleed valves that are fitted at the compressor’s front stages to avoid overpressure and a compressor stall. Their purpose is simply to dump pressure by blowing air out of the axial flow of air and therefore, increasing the mass flow through the compressor to ensure every stage receives a proper amount of air. The interstage bleed valves will not regulate in any way the fuel/air mixture delivered to the combustion chamber. “It must be capable of utilizing different fuel types” – this is an odd option since gas turbine engines aren’t usually certified to use a different type of fuels. Besides, this quality wouldn’t guarantee the efficient combustion of the mixture. “Air must be supplied to the combustor section at a constant flow” – the combustion chamber is not always supplied at a constant flow. The mass flow of air is always varied depending on the power setting variations.

content.question: The function of the drain valve in a gas turbine combustion chamber is to…

options.A: check whether the fuel nozzles leak fuel after engine shutdown.
options.B: prevent a wet start.
options.C: vent the combustion chamber after engine shutdown.
options.D: remove unburned fuel from the combustion chamber.

key_points: Ideal combustion occurs when the entire amount of fuel and air supplied is totally mixed and burnt

When this occurs, the remaining air will be expelled with the normal stream flow of gases, however, the unburnt vaporized fuel will form liquid patches and will deposit at the bottom of the combustion chamber
Another situation where fuel deposits can be found at the bottom of the chamber’s casing is after an unsuccessful engine start (wet start)
learning.explanation: Ideal combustion occurs when the entire amount of fuel and air supplied is totally mixed and burnt. When this occurs, the remaining air will be expelled with the normal stream flow of gases, however, the unburnt vaporized fuel will form liquid patches and will deposit at the bottom of the combustion chamber. Another situation where fuel deposits can be found at the bottom of the chamber’s casing is after an unsuccessful engine start (wet start). This fuel will be collected by drain valves situated at the bottom surface of the combustion chamber outer casing. The unburnt fuel will be completely removed and the combustion chamber totally clean for safe operation and a correct subsequent engine start.

content.question:
The electronic engine control unit (ECU) of a gas turbine engine uses data from:
1. aircraft systems
2. cockpit display units
3. its own engine sensors
4. electronic engine control units of the other engines(s)
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks
The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby
If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions
learning.explanation: FADEC stands for Full Authority Digital Engine Control and is basically a digital control system mounted on the engine’s fan case, that performs the entire engine management tasks. The FADEC has a dual channels Electronic Control Unit (ECU) for redundancy, with one channel always active and a second one on standby. If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions. In addition to the ECU, all the FADEC peripherals such as actuators, solenoids, electrical wiring, sensors, and fuel metering are also part of the FADEC system and are used for control and monitoring. The system has a three-phase permanent magnetic alternator for an internal power source. This independent alternator is also the electrical power source for all the FADEC sensors as well as the ECUs. By interfacing with other aircraft systems and its own engine sensors, the FADEC system provides the following functions: Automatic thrust rating control. Engine operation within safe limits. Fully automatic engine starting. Thrust Reverser Control. Engine overspeed and/or an EGT protection function. Engine monitoring and help for maintenance and troubleshooting. To make the FADEC’s operation more reliable, the system uses the dual inputs logic. All control inputs to the FADEC system are dual, with the exception of some secondary parameters used for monitoring and indicating (that are single). To increase the fault-tolerant design where the engine will still be able to operate within a required reliability and safety range, the parameters are exchanged between the two control channels (inside the ECU) via a cross-channel data link. Therefore, if one input parameter fails to be delivered, the input parameter from the other channel will be used to allow the correct computation of the engine parameters by the FADEC. This means that the FADEC is a single fault-tolerant, and it will ensure the efficient and correct running of the engine even in case of a detected malfunction.

content.question: An auxiliary gearbox is driven by…

options.A: compressed air extracted from the high pressure compressor, routed via the engine bleed system.
options.B: compressed air extracted from the auxiliary power unit, routed via the auxiliary power unit bleed system.
options.C: a rotating engine shaft, via an internal gearbox, to an external gearbox.
options.D: the ram air turbine.

key_points: The auxiliary gearbox of a gas turbine engine is (usually) driven by the HP compressor shaft via an internal gearbox to an external gearbox
It provides the drive for a wide variety of services
It can even serve as mounting support for the engine
learning.explanation: The auxiliary gearbox of a gas turbine engine is (usually) driven by the HP compressor shaft via an internal gearbox to an external gearbox. It provides the drive for a wide variety of services. It can even serve as mounting support for the engine. For example, the internal gearbox assembly of the CFM 56 contains a core engine thrust bearing, and a core engine roller bearing. Like all the other engine’s moving parts, oil is used to lubricate and clean the accessory gearbox elements. The accessory units of a turbo-jet engine auxiliary gearbox are the following: AC generator through its constant speed drive (CSD) Oil pumps, Hydraulic pumps, High-pressure fuel pumps.

content.question: Engine temperature limitations of a gas turbine engine are usually imposed due to temperature limitations on the…

options.A: compressor section.
options.B: jet pipe.
options.C: turbine section.
options.D: casing of the combustion chamber.

key_points: The turbine section of a gas turbine engine is the area where materials are under the most stress
Due to the centripetal force, a small turbine blade weighing 50 grams when stationary can exert a load of two tons whilst the turbine is spinning at full speed
On top of the centripetal force which the compressor section also experiences, the turbine section also deals with the heat from the combustion chamber, which can reach temperatures of 1700°C
learning.explanation: The turbine section of a gas turbine engine is the area where materials are under the most stress. Due to the centripetal force, a small turbine blade weighing 50 grams when stationary can exert a load of two tons whilst the turbine is spinning at full speed. On top of the centripetal force which the compressor section also experiences, the turbine section also deals with the heat from the combustion chamber, which can reach temperatures of 1700°C. The combination of the centripetal force and the heat causes creep, which is the slow stretching of the metal. This is the reason why the blades in the turbine have to be replaced to prevent failure during normal operations. Therefore the hotter the gases from the combustion chamber, the more the turbines blades will creep. That’s why the turbine is usually temperature limited to prevent excess creep. Fun fact: In the past, the material used for jet engine turbine blades used to be steel. Steel required a much lower temperature limitation to prevent creep hence why older engines are much more sensitive to temperature. Modern turbine blades use nickel and super based alloys, and even further developments have been made into ceramic materials that allow temperatures to reach the region of 1700°C. Incorrect answers: “Compressor section”: In the high pressure section of the compressor, temperatures can be high enough that nickel based alloys are required, however they will never reach the same temperatures as the turbine. The compressor section is located at the front of the engine and therefore is not effected by the extra heat from the combustion section. “Jet pipe”: Without the use of afterburners, air entering the exhaust system is usually within 500°C and 900°C, hence lower than the turbine section. On top of the lower temperatures, the exhaust is a none movable part so no extra stress is caused by centripetal force. “Casing of the combustion chamber”: materials in and around the combustion chamber allow for temperatures of up to and over 2000°C. Materials can handle the heat because the combustion chamber components are static and therefore do not experience any centripetal force.

content.question: What information is provided by cockpit indications as regards starting and operating the APU?

options.A: Fuel flow
options.B: Fault status
options.C: Bleed air temperature
options.D: Air inlet pressure

key_points: The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is a small gas turbine engine located on the tail of the aircraft able to deliver pressurized air and electrical power
It can also deliver air for cabin air conditioning and for main engine starting
An APU has its own electric starter motor powered either by the airplane’s main batteries or by the Ground Power Unit (if connected)
learning.explanation: The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is a small gas turbine engine located on the tail of the aircraft able to deliver pressurized air and electrical power. It can also deliver air for cabin air conditioning and for main engine starting. An APU has its own electric starter motor powered either by the airplane’s main batteries or by the Ground Power Unit (if connected). The APU uses fuel from the main fuel tanks (the left main tank on the A320) and burns about 130 kg/h on the ground (A320 APU). In order to use the APU in flight, it needs to be certified and guarantee that the starting sequence can be carried out at high altitudes and operate under load at even higher altitudes. A dedicated flight deck APU control panel consists of a master switch button and a start button. The master switch will simply energize the APU system and its internal computer. It will also open the air intake flap and open the fuel isolation valve. The start switch is putting the ignition ON and starts the automatic start sequence. Either some lights, or a separate fault panel, or an electronic APU monitoring page will display and announce any APU faults. The APU will automatically shut down in one of the following cases: Overspeed, No acceleration, Low oil pressure, EGT overtemperature, High oil temperature, Underspeed, Reverse flow, etc.

content.question: Why is there redundancy in a FADEC system?

options.A: To avoid loss of all thrust if one channel fails.
options.B: To ensure that engine parameters displays are not lost should one channel fail.
options.C: So that analogue signals can be converted to digital data even if a single FADEC channel fails.
options.D: To ensure the engine parameter recording for post-flight maintenance purposes.

key_points: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) units are commonly installed on gas turbine engines
The aim of FADEC computer controls the engines by reading all input and output parameters of engines themselves and the required performance requested by flight crew
It controls the engine to run efficiently with full control of the system
learning.explanation: Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) units are commonly installed on gas turbine engines. The aim of FADEC computer controls the engines by reading all input and output parameters of engines themselves and the required performance requested by flight crew. It controls the engine to run efficiently with full control of the system. It also reduces pilot workload by making the engine control and monitoring much easier. Since the authority of FADEC is very extensive, losing the correct operation may cause loss of engine control, therefore to ensure sufficient redundancy, each engine is normally equipped with two FADEC computers, and two of any essential components or sensors, with one channel always active and a second one on standby. If one channel fails, the other automatically takes control and performs the exact same functions. As a result, the engines will continue to operate normally should a single component from one of the FADEC systems fail in flight. Therefore, FADEC engines are "single-fault tolerant".

content.question: Fuel flow information for gas turbine engines is measured…

options.A: in the line between the booster pump and the engine.
options.B: in the inlet of the high-pressure fuel pump.
options.C: in the line between the fuel control unit and the engine burners.
options.D: at the outlet of the high pressure fuel pump.

key_points: The fuel system is designed to supply fuel flow into the combustion chamber, servo fuel for some fuel-actuated systems, and fuel for engine oil cooling
The fuel is ducted from the fuel tanks initially by a LP fuel pump to the fuel-oil heat exchangers
It is then filtered and pressurized under high pressure (by a HP pump) and delivered a number of fuel nozzles that will atomize the fuel into the combustion chamber
learning.explanation: The fuel system is designed to supply fuel flow into the combustion chamber, servo fuel for some fuel-actuated systems, and fuel for engine oil cooling. The fuel is ducted from the fuel tanks initially by a LP fuel pump to the fuel-oil heat exchangers. It is then filtered and pressurized under high pressure (by a HP pump) and delivered a number of fuel nozzles that will atomize the fuel into the combustion chamber. Between the fuel control unit and the fuel nozzles, a fuel flow transmitter measures the instant fuel flow and send this information to the cockpit instruments as a reference for the pilots.

content.question: To provide redundancy in the ignition system of a gas turbine engine, the system…

options.A: is cross-connected directly between the engines.
options.B: has exciter units equipped with internal batteries.
options.C: operates on a continuous basis following engine start.
options.D: is equipped with two exciter units and two igniter plugs.

key_points: Each gas turbine engine has two separate high-energy igniters able to deliver up to 25000 V
The ignition system consists of a capacitance high energy ignition unit and an igniter plug designed to deliver the high voltage, high current discharge from a low AC or DC supply
The most common ignition unit is the DC trembler operated unit
learning.explanation: Each gas turbine engine has two separate high-energy igniters able to deliver up to 25000 V. The ignition system consists of a capacitance high energy ignition unit and an igniter plug designed to deliver the high voltage, high current discharge from a low AC or DC supply. The most common ignition unit is the DC trembler operated unit. The trembler operates an induction coil and facilitates the generation of a higher voltage to the igniters by providing a DC current to the transformer through a high voltage rectifier. The rectifier will avoid any discharge back into the coil winding while the capacitor will charge up to a value that will break down the sealed discharge gap. The current will then discharge through the sealed discharge gap, the choke, and the igniter plugs, which are all connected in series. The capacitor is then recharged, and the cycle is repeated.

content.question: The primary reason for a limitation being imposed on the temperature of the gas flow in a gas turbine engine is to…

options.A: ensure that the maximum acceptable temperature of the turbine nozzle guide vanes is not exceeded.
options.B: prevent overheating and subsequent creep due to centrifugal forces of the nozzle guide vanes.
options.C: ensure that the maximum acceptable gas temperature within the combustion chamber is not exceeded.
options.D: prevent damage to the jet pipe from overheating.

key_points: The turbine provides energy to increase the pressure of the airflow in the compressors and to power, all the accessories needed to the aircraft
The turbine generates this energy, known as shaft power, using the expansion of hot gases, and then by converting the kinetic energy of the gases (velocity) into mechanical work
When the combustion gases pass through the turbine, the pressure drops
learning.explanation: The turbine provides energy to increase the pressure of the airflow in the compressors and to power, all the accessories needed to the aircraft. The turbine generates this energy, known as shaft power, using the expansion of hot gases, and then by converting the kinetic energy of the gases (velocity) into mechanical work. When the combustion gases pass through the turbine, the pressure drops. The higher the temperature resulting from combustion, the greater the gas expansion and energy transfer to the turbine. However, because the materials used in the turbine assembly are temperature limited, temperature limitations are usually imposed on the turbine section to avoid complete damage to the turbine. An additional mitigation to the blades’ expansion due to the high turbine temperatures is the active control clearance. It will provide greater clearances between the blade tips and the casing. This is achieved by managing the clearance between the gas turbine casing and the tips of the rotating blades, referred to as turbine tip clearance. It monitors and varies the diameter of the turbine engine's casing to minimize the clearance between the rotor and the casing, researchers have found that an increase in tip clearance directly results in a decrease in turbine efficiency.

options.B: divergent area at the impeller exit to reduce the air velocity and increase the air pressure.
options.C: convergent area at the impeller exit to reduce the air velocity and increase the air pressure.
options.D: divergent area at the impeller exit to increase both the air velocity and the air pressure.

key_points: The compressor forces the airflow through the engine increasing its pressure
The mechanical energy the turbine provides to the compressor shaft is transmitted to the airflow with the compressor blades
In the stator, the airflow is compressed and has its temperature increased progressively
learning.explanation: The compressor forces the airflow through the engine increasing its pressure. The mechanical energy the turbine provides to the compressor shaft is transmitted to the airflow with the compressor blades. In the stator, the airflow is compressed and has its temperature increased progressively. Before entering the combustion chamber, the last stator vanes must redirect the airflow and the diffuser, a divergent compartment at the impeller exit reduces the airflow’s velocity and increases air pressure for optimal combustion.

content.question: In a jet engine, active clearance control is achieved by controlling the turbine (1) _____ temperature, with the use of cool (2) _____, to adjust the turbine blade to case clearance.

options.A: (1) case; (2) air
options.B: (1) case; (2) fuel
options.C: (1) blade; (2) air
options.D: (1) blade; (2) fuel

key_points: The objective of active clearance control in a jet engine is to regulate the clearance between the turbine and the outer casing by supplying cooling air to the casing
The system is designed to prevent the turbine from rubbing against the casing, which can cause damage to the engine and adversely affect its performance

Active clearance control achieves this by controlling the cooling air flow and maintaining the minimum separation between the turbine and casing, even during changes in engine temperature, speed, and load
learning.explanation: The objective of active clearance control in a jet engine is to regulate the clearance between the turbine and the outer casing by supplying cooling air to the casing. The system is designed to prevent the turbine from rubbing against the casing, which can cause damage to the engine and adversely affect its performance. Active clearance control achieves this by controlling the cooling air flow and maintaining the minimum separation between the turbine and casing, even during changes in engine temperature, speed, and load. To optimise engine efficiency, active clearance control utilises a turbine engine's FADEC to monitor and adjust the diameter of the shroud casing. This process is automatic, and involves tapping off bleed air from the engine's compressor stage and directing it to the shroud casing. This air can be heated or cooled to cause expansion or contraction of the casing, which in turn helps to maintain the minimum clearance between the turbine and outer casing.

content.question: For a subsonic airflow, in a divergent duct the…

options.A: static pressure decreases, velocity increases and static temperature increases.
options.B: static pressure increases, velocity decreases and static temperature decreases.
options.C: static pressure increases, velocity decreases and static temperature increases.
options.D: static pressure decreases, velocity increases and static temperature decreases.

key_points: The intake geometry is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect
It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed

That’s why the intake is slightly divergent in order to reduce the airflow’s velocity (=dynamic pressure) and increase the static pressure and temperature just before the fan and compressor’s first stages
learning.explanation: The intake geometry is designed to take full advantage of the ram effect. It captures the required air mass flow and delivers it to the compressor at the correct design speed. That’s why the intake is slightly divergent in order to reduce the airflow’s velocity (=dynamic pressure) and increase the static pressure and temperature just before the fan and compressor’s first stages. Caution, the total pressure (and temperature) will remain constant - it is only a trade of dynamic pressure for static pressure. Compression (=increase in static pressure) is a process where heat is released, which explains why the temperature behaves in the same way through a divergent duct as pressure. This geometry is also called the ‘pitot intake’, and it has thick, smoothly rounded lips to prevent flow separation under any flight conditions/maneuvers. In simple words, when moving through a Divergent Duct the velocity of the air decreases but pressure and temperature increase.

content.question: The take off of a jet aeroplane may be performed with "reduced thrust" in order to:

options.A: reduce the risk of engine failure during take-off.
options.B: reduce maintenance costs.
options.C: save fuel.
options.D: reduce take-off noise.

key_points: The main purpose of conducting a reduced thrust (flex) take-off is to save engine life due to reduced low cycle fatigue damage, and therefore save maintenance costs
The lower temperatures, rotating and centrifugal forces will prevent the engine components to wear too fast and will prolong their life

Fuel savings are a disadvantage in most cases! In fact, you will have a slower acceleration so you will spend more time on the runway and at low altitude with a lot of drag (flaps) than if you were doing a maximum thrust take-off
learning.explanation: The main purpose of conducting a reduced thrust (flex) take-off is to save engine life due to reduced low cycle fatigue damage, and therefore save maintenance costs. The lower temperatures, rotating and centrifugal forces will prevent the engine components to wear too fast and will prolong their life. Fuel savings are a disadvantage in most cases! In fact, you will have a slower acceleration so you will spend more time on the runway and at low altitude with a lot of drag (flaps) than if you were doing a maximum thrust take-off. The longer time spent at a lower altitude before reaching acceleration to your climb speed will certainly be less economical. However, the financial losses induced from the reduced-thrust take-off will be offset by the reduction in maintenance costs and engine spare parts.

To understand what the cold and the hot mass air flow in a by-pass turbofan is, you need to understand the fan’s purpose
It is the first part of the engine, driven by the rearmost turbine (low pressure), and it divides the incoming airflow into two streams
learning.explanation: In a gas turbine engine fitted with a fan, the by-pass ratio is the cold air mass flow divided by the hot air mass flow. To understand what the cold and the hot mass air flow in a by-pass turbofan is, you need to understand the fan’s purpose. It is the first part of the engine, driven by the rearmost turbine (low pressure), and it divides the incoming airflow into two streams. The first stream is directed to the next compressor stages for further compression and combustion and is called the hot mass air flow. The rest of the airflow is accelerated around the core, providing most of the engine thrust, and is called the cold mass air flow (because it is not going through the combustion stage).

learning.explanation: Most of the engine’s elements are ferrous (bearings, shafts, etc.) and the continuous friction between them will induce gradual wear with time. content.question: An axial compressor in a gas turbine engine operating below its design speed, has…

options.A: a tendency to stall in the centre stages.
options.B: no tendency to stall.
options.C: a tendency to stall in the front stages.
options.D: a tendency to stall in the rear stages.

key_points: Stalls in axial gas turbines engines occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack, just like a wing
This happens when the axial velocity of the air in the engine is significantly lower that the rpm of the compressor stage

This can occur in multiple situations: Disrupted airflow at the engine intake Damaged compressor blades Damaged turbine blades Engine acceleration/deceleration too rapid Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing a stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages
learning.explanation: Stalls in axial gas turbines engines occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack, just like a wing. This happens when the axial velocity of the air in the engine is significantly lower that the rpm of the compressor stage. This can occur in multiple situations: Disrupted airflow at the engine intake Damaged compressor blades Damaged turbine blades Engine acceleration/deceleration too rapid Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing a stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. In other words, the RPM of the compressor stage will exceed the axial air velocity. Therefore there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Usually this is followed by a complete compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. To avoid compressor stalls, Variable Inlet Guide Vanes (VIGV) and Variable Stator Vanes are installed to change the relative flow of the air between the compressor sections, therefore reducing the effective angle of attack of the blades. Also some engine have a bleed in the rear of the compressor section to prevent excessive pressure causing potential back pressure. The other answers are incorrect: “Not tendency to stall”: Compressor blades are built so that they achieve their optimum angle of attack at the aircrafts normal operating speeds, so cruise speeds, for maximum fuel efficiency. Therefore at low aircraft speeds and during engine start when there is little or no axial airflow velocity, the compressor has a high tendency to stall or surge if care isn’t take. Modern FADEC systems combined with the VIGV’s and the VSV’s prevent this from happening therefore it usually isn’t a problem anymore unless a compressor/turbine section is damaged. “A tendency to stall in the center stages”: Axial compressor usually stall first in the front stage of the compressor. “A tendency to stall in the rear stages”: Axial compressor usually stall first in the front stage of the compressor.

content.question: During a reduced thrust take-off, the assumed OAT is higher than the actual OAT. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The Air Data Computer limits the internal temperature of the engine to prevent from exceeding the temperature limit.
options.B: The temperature at which this thrust would be produced can be extracted from the applicable weather chart.
options.C: The reduced thrust value is the minimum thrust value that the engine will produce.
options.D: The assumed temperature is entered in the Flight Management System.

key_points: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude
The procedure can be used any time the actual take-off mass is less than the maximum permissible take-off mass and there is an available distance that greatly exceeds that which is required

The limitation is posed on the engine computer by inputting a flexible thrust temperature for the engine, which essentially tells the engine computer an artificial outside air temperature that is higher than the actual temperature
learning.explanation: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude. The procedure can be used any time the actual take-off mass is less than the maximum permissible take-off mass and there is an available distance that greatly exceeds that which is required. The limitation is posed on the engine computer by inputting a flexible thrust temperature for the engine, which essentially tells the engine computer an artificial outside air temperature that is higher than the actual temperature. This way the engine computer believes that the entering air is hotter than it really is. At outside air temperatures above the flat rated temperature, there is a specific thrust value (variable by pressure altitude) for each temperature. If the thrust requirement for the take-off is known, the associated temperature at which this thrust would be produced can be extracted from the applicable charts. This "assumed" temperature is then entered into the FMS.

content.question: The compressor pressure ratio of an axial flow compressor of a gas turbine engine is primarily determined by the…

options.A: rotor diameter.
options.B: number of stages.
options.C: compressor inlet pressure design value.
options.D: compressor inlet temperature design value.

key_points: The compressor’s main task is to increase the mass flow through the engine by pressurizing the air
Its efficiency depends mostly on the aerofoil sections, pitch angles, and the length/chord ratios of the blades
The thermal efficiency and the work output of the continuous pressure cycle are both proportional to the compressor pressure ratio
learning.explanation: The compressor’s main task is to increase the mass flow through the engine by pressurizing the air. Its efficiency depends mostly on the aerofoil sections, pitch angles, and the length/chord ratios of the blades. The thermal efficiency and the work output of the continuous pressure cycle are both proportional to the compressor pressure ratio. The compressor is an annular duct through which the air passes and across which are arranged a series of small blades of aerofoil section that will compress the incoming air. Because of the small pressure increase at each compressor stage, numerous stages are required to achieve the desired delivery pressure at the combustion chamber. Another reason is that the power output of a turbine stage is higher than the power consumption of a compressor stage, therefore by fitting several compressor stages the power generated by the turbine can be efficiently used. From this point of view, the centrifugal compressor has a maximum pressure ratio of about 4.5:1 for a single stage, and up to 6:1 for a two-stage, single-entry centrifugal compressor. The upper limit for axial compressors is more a matter of stability and complexity, with current values of approximately 10:1 for single-spool compressors, and in excess of 30:1 for multi-spool compressors. Although higher pressure ratios give higher engine efficiency due to improved specific fuel consumption, a balance must be found between efficiency and the power needed from the turbine to drive the compressor. Sufficient power must remain to move the aircraft, and the turbine has a restricted limit to the power which it can generate.

This way, we already have everything to calculate the bypass ratio.

content.question:
Put the items listed below in the correct order to give the typical start sequence of a turbine engine on the ground:
1. High pressure fuel ON
2. Self-sustaining speed
3. Light-up
4. Start selected
5. Ignition ON
6. Starter circuit cancelled

key_points: The typical start sequence of a gas turbine engine on the ground would be the following: Start selected: the start valve admits air supplied by the pneumatic system to operate the starter
In nowadays commercial aircraft, the FADEC controls the start valve electrically and operates it pneumatically with bleed air
Ignition ON: the igniters are selected ON and are ready to light the mixture
learning.explanation: The typical start sequence of a gas turbine engine on the ground would be the following: Start selected: the start valve admits air supplied by the pneumatic system to operate the starter. In nowadays commercial aircraft, the FADEC controls the start valve electrically and operates it pneumatically with bleed air. Ignition ON: the igniters are selected ON and are ready to light the mixture. High-pressure fuel ON: after fuel is delivered by the high-pressure shut-off valve (HPSOV) it is sprayed into the combustion chamber by fuel nozzles under high-pressure where it is mixed with compressed air and lights up. Light-up: the mixture starts burning and the flame spreads all along with the combustion chamber (since it is interconnected). The flame becomes self-sustainable. Self-sustaining speed: all the engine’s spools have reached a self-sustaining speed where assistance from the air starter is not needed anymore. The air starter is disengaged by the coupling between engine N2 spool and starter by the use of centrifugal forces. Starter circuit canceled.

content.question:
Which of these statements about compressor stall in a gas turbine engine are correct or incorrect?
I. A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at low RPM
II. A compressor stall is most likely to occur when the air flow stagnates in the rear stages of the compressor

options.A: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is correct, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at low RPM
" CORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the air flow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM
learning.explanation: "I. A compressor stall is most likely to occur in a compressor designed for a high pressure ratio operating at low RPM." CORRECT A compressor stall occurs when there is an imbalance between the air flow supply and the airflow demand - in other words, a pressure ratio that is incompatible with the engine RPM. As a result, smooth airflow is interrupted and pressure fluctuations are created within the turbine. It occurs when the angle of attack of the blades exceeds the critical angle of attack (just like a wing). Stalls at low speed usually occur because the acceleration of the engine is exceeding the acceleration at which air can move towards the intake of the engine, causing a stagnation of air at the rear of the compressor stages. Therefore, there is a lack of air ahead of the front stage of the compressor, making it stall first. Usually this is followed by a complete compressor stall, and possibly a surge depending on the severity of the stall. "II. A compressor stall is most likely to occur when the air flow stagnates in the rear stages of the compressor." CORRECT As mentioned above, air stagnates in the REAR stages, which results in a lack of air in the FRONT stages with subsequent low axial velocity in front stages. This will lead to a high angle of attack of the rotor blades determining a STALL. To avoid such situation, turbine engines are fitted with VIGV (variable inlet guide vanes) and VSV (variable stator vanes) that ensure correct airflow through the stages of the engine.

key_points: The approach flight idle value is designed to allow the engines to accelerate faster to full power setting in case of go around and facilitate rapid reverse thrust activation
The flight idle would be too high while taxiing, and the airplane will accelerate very fast (unnecessarily)
Therefore, the ground idle has been implemented to overcome this problem
learning.explanation: The approach flight idle value is designed to allow the engines to accelerate faster to full power setting in case of go around and facilitate rapid reverse thrust activation. The flight idle would be too high while taxiing, and the airplane will accelerate very fast (unnecessarily). Therefore, the ground idle has been implemented to overcome this problem. The aircraft knows when it is on the ground or I flight thanks to logic circuits and position switches (landing gear compression, flaps position, radio altitude, etc.). The approach flight idle setting is reversed to the ground idle after a predetermined time lapse after touchdown.

learning.explanation: Specific fuel consumption (SFC) in a jet is the fuel flow per unit of thrust, while SFC for a propeller is the fuel flow per unit of power, i.e. kg/h per unit of shaft power. The SFC is only an engine consideration and is not affected by drag, which is an airframe consideration. Specific fuel consumption varies proportionally to the temperature => If the temperature is increasing, specific fuel consumption increases. In a turbojet engine, SFC is lowest when the air temperature is low and the engine is running at its design rpm of approximately 90 to 95% rpm. It also means that the engine is most efficient at high altitudes where the thrust required to overcome drag is approximately 90 to 95% of the thrust available.

options.B: LP turbine drives both the LP compressor and the HP compressor.

This reduces the specific fuel consumption over the normal axial-flow turbojet as about 70-80% of the total thrust is generated by the fan

learning.explanation: The multi-spool layout of a gas turbine engine allows the low-pressure compressor or the fan to handle a large mass flow, a proportion of which is fed into the subsequent compressors while the remainder is ducted to the rear of the engine. This reduces the specific fuel consumption over the normal axial-flow turbojet as about 70-80% of the total thrust is generated by the fan. In a twin-spool engine, there’re two separate shafts, the LP compressor-turbine shaft, and the HP compressor-turbine shaft. The low pressor compressor-turbine assembly consists of the LP compressor, a fan drive gear system, a LP shaft, and a LP turbine. The LP compressor consists of a fan and several compressor stages, and it is linked to the LP turbine by the LP shaft. The fan drive gear system is a simple planetary gear reduction unit that connects the fan rotor to the LP compressor which will make them both rotate at the same speed. However, because of the converging shape of the compressor assembly, the speed of the LP shaft be will lower than the speed of the HP assembly.

content.question: The turboprop alpha-range is the range of…

options.A: power lever positions between flight idle and maximum power.
options.B: propeller lever positions between flight idle and maximum reverse.
options.C: propeller lever positions between flight idle and maximum power.
options.D: power lever positions between flight idle and maximum reverse.

key_points: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight
Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm
The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range, and the power lever positions corresponding to the ALPHA range are between flight idle and maximum power
learning.explanation: Nowadays turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight. Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm. The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range, and the power lever positions corresponding to the ALPHA range are between flight idle and maximum power. However, while maneuvering on the ground, the power required for a turboprop engine is pretty low. Therefore, the controls have been adapted such that the blade pitch angle (therefore the thrust produced) is controlled directly by the pilot, overriding the CSU. This ground range is known as the BETA control range. The flight crew will select a blade pitch angle by moving the power lever fully aft and lifting it up. The first detent of the BETA range will correspond to the ground idle detent that will allow the pilots to produce minimum level of thrust, just enough power to taxi the aircraft. If the lever is pulled full aft of the BETA range, the pilot will lower the blade pitch angle such that the maximum reverse power is produced (=negative thrust). This will usually be the case at landing in order to assist the aircraft’s deceleration.

options.D: A rotor followed by a nozzle guide vane.

The high energy gasses arrive at the turbine and must be given some rotational speed by the nozzle guide vanes which are fixed in place (called the stator), and then this rotational momentum is harnessed by the actual turbine blades themselves, which are spinning (and connected to the relevant compressor stage), called the rotor
We can, of course, assume that the "direction" of these components for the answer is in chronological order for air flowing through a gas turbine engine
learning.explanation: The principle of operation of a turbine in a gas turbine engine is to take the energy from the hot exhaust gasses (burned in the combustion chamber) turn it into rotational speed, and use that to run the compressor at the front of the engine. The high energy gasses arrive at the turbine and must be given some rotational speed by the nozzle guide vanes which are fixed in place (called the stator), and then this rotational momentum is harnessed by the actual turbine blades themselves, which are spinning (and connected to the relevant compressor stage), called the rotor. We can, of course, assume that the "direction" of these components for the answer is in chronological order for air flowing through a gas turbine engine. Therefore, the answer is, "A nozzle guide vane followed by a rotor."

This increases the static pressure of the air
learning.explanation: DIFFUSER The diffuser is the divergent section of the engine after the compressor and before the combustion chamber. The diffuser increases the cross-section of the duct, for a constant mass flow, the velocity drops. This increases the static pressure of the air. Additionally, it decelerates the 350 m/s flow to a 50 m/s flow before fuel injection. This deceleration is crucial for optimal fuel burning conditions. It prepares the air for entry into the flame burning area of the combustion section at a lower velocity so that the flame of combustion can burn continuously. If the air passed through the flame area at a high velocity, it could extinguish the flame.

content.question: An APU that is certified for use in flight must be able to…

options.A: shed its electrical loads in the air, if all engine generators are available.
options.B: shut down if the APU generator voltage becomes too high.
options.C: shut down if APU bleed requirements become excessive.
options.D: start at high altitudes and operate under load at even higher altitudes.

key_points: The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is a small gas turbine engine located on the tail of the aircraft able to deliver pressurized air and electrical power
It can also deliver air for cabin air conditioning and for main engine starting
An APU has its own electric starter motor powered either by the airplane’s main batteries or by the Ground Power Unit (if connected)
learning.explanation: The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is a small gas turbine engine located on the tail of the aircraft able to deliver pressurized air and electrical power. It can also deliver air for cabin air conditioning and for main engine starting. An APU has its own electric starter motor powered either by the airplane’s main batteries or by the Ground Power Unit (if connected). The APU uses fuel from the main fuel tanks (the left main tank on the A320) and burns about 130 kg/h on the ground (A320 APU). In order to use the APU in flight, it needs to be certified and guarantee that the starting sequence can be carried out at high altitudes and operate under load at even higher altitudes. In certain situations, the APU cabin air supply, and electrical supply could be crucial, so it is important that a large enough operational flight envelope is certified. A dedicated flight deck APU control panel consists of a master switch button and a start button. The master switch will simply energize the APU system and its internal computer. It will also open the air intake flap and open the fuel isolation valve. The start switch is putting the ignition ON and starts the automatic start sequence. Either some lights, or a separate fault panel, or an electronic APU monitoring page will display and announce any APU faults. The APU will automatically shut down in one of the following cases: Overspeed, No acceleration, Low oil pressure, EGT overtemperature, High oil temperature, Underspeed, Reverse flow, etc.

content.question: The pressurising function of the pressurising and dump valve in a gas turbine engine fuel system is to…

options.A: prevent fuel leakage in the combustion chamber after engine shut-down.
options.B: allow fuel to the nozzles only if the fuel pressure is high enough for sufficient atomisation.
options.C: allow oil to the fuel-oil heat exchanger, preventing ice crystals blocking the fuel lines.
options.D: prevent overpressure at the fuel nozzles.

key_points: The pressurizing and dump valve allows fuel to the nozzles only if the fuel pressure is above a preset value that will ensure proper atomization
Upon engine shut down, the dump valve will close and dump the fuel in the drain tank or return it to the fuel tank in order to avoid that the fuel boils due to residual engine heat
learning.explanation: The pressurizing and dump valve allows fuel to the nozzles only if the fuel pressure is above a preset value that will ensure proper atomization. Upon engine shut down, the dump valve will close and dump the fuel in the drain tank or return it to the fuel tank in order to avoid that the fuel boils due to residual engine heat.

content.question: A turbofan engine with a bypass mass flow of 888 kg/s and a HP compressor mass flow of 111 kg/s has a bypass ratio of…

key_points: Formulas: Bypass mass flow = inlet mass flow - HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio = bypass mass flow / HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio = 888 kg/s / 111 kg/s = 8
learning.explanation: Formulas: Bypass mass flow = inlet mass flow - HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio = bypass mass flow / HP compressor mass flow Bypass ratio = 888 kg/s / 111 kg/s = 8

content.question: What is the primary reason for reducing the airflow axial velocity at the inlet of the combustion chamber in a gas turbine engine?

options.A: Decrease static pressure and prevent the flame from extinguishing.
options.B: Increase static pressure and prevent the flame from extinguishing.
options.C: Increase static pressure and cool the combustion chamber.
options.D: Decrease static pressure and cool the combustion chamber.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.02.03.04: Explain the reason for reducing the airflow axial velocity at the combustion chamber inlet (snout). The air leaving the compressor in a turbine engine is usually very fast, somewhere around the speed of the aircraft, meaning that 500 feet per second is an acceptable number to use. This is not a viable speed for the airflow in the combustion chamber, as the flame front of Jet A1 travels at around the region of 2 feet per second, so the flame would be extinguished immediately in a 500 ft/s airflow. Therefore, we have to use devices to slow this airflow down. The main device used is a diffuser, after the final compressor stage (and stator vane to straighten the airflow), the diffuser increases the cross-section of the duct, and given the constant mass flow, the velocity drops significantly. This also increases the static pressure of the air, gaining some of the energy back from the lost velocity, and which is excellent for intense combustion. furthermore, there are other speed reductions built into the initial combustion chamber that are used for slowing down the primary air (the initial air which is mixed with fuel and burnt) around the area of the "snout", where the air is split into primary and secondary air, and these all help to reduce the speed of the airflow to a more manageable speed which will allow the flame front to burn continuously.

content.question: Which of the following correctly describes the beta range of a turboprop engine?

options.A: From just below flight idle to maximum reverse.
options.B: From ground idle to maximum ground power.
options.C: From ground idle to flight idle.
options.D: From flat pitch to maximum negative pitch.

key_points: Note: This question appears to be very similar to Q211957, with a different layout and different options
Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Note: This question appears to be very similar to Q211957, with a different layout and different options. Learning Objective 021.11.04.01.05: Describe the terms ‘alpha range’, ‘beta range’ and ‘reverse thrust’ as applied to a turboprop power lever. Modern turboprop engines deliver very high power in flight. Through the Constant Speed Unit, the propeller controls the power output by varying the propeller blade pitch angle to maintain engine rpm. The blade pitch angle range required in flight is known as the ALPHA control range, and the power lever positions corresponding to the ALPHA range are between flight idle and maximum power. However, while manoeuvering on the ground, the power required for a turboprop engine is very low. Therefore, the controls have been adapted such that when on the ground, the blade pitch angle (therefore the thrust produced) can be controlled directly by the pilot, overriding the CSU. This ground range is known as the BETA control range. The flight crew will use the beta range by moving the power lever fully aft within the normal (alpha) range to the flight idle position and lifting it up. The power lever will then be able to move backwards further, and is now in the beta range (just below flight idle). The first detent within the BETA range is the ground idle detent that will allow the pilots to produce minimum level of thrust, just enough power to taxi the aircraft. If the lever is pulled further aft of the ground idle detent, the pilot will lower the blade pitch angle such that reverse thrust is produced, and the stop at the end of the beta range is where the maximum reverse power is produced (= maximum negative thrust). This will usually only be used during landing in order to assist the aircraft’s deceleration. Therefore, the beta range exists between flight idle ("just below flight idle" is actually more correct, as flight idle is included in the alpha range, not the beta range) and maximum reverse power.

content.question: In a gas turbine engine, other than the main function of providing pressurised air for combustion, which of the following is an additional function of the compressor?

options.A: Driving the associated spool turbine.
options.B: Expelling the hot gasses from the combustion process.
options.C: Cooling the intake air to allow for better combustion.
options.D: Increase the engine airflow for better turbine cooling.

key_points: This is an odd question, and somewhat deviates from the learning objectives
Nonetheless, in its current for directly from exam feedback, it is answerable and has a "most correct" answer in our opinion
Of course, the main function of the compressor in a turbine engine is for compressing air to feed more of it into the combustion chamber and therefore burning more fuel/air mixture
learning.explanation: This is an odd question, and somewhat deviates from the learning objectives. Nonetheless, in its current for directly from exam feedback, it is answerable and has a "most correct" answer in our opinion. Of course, the main function of the compressor in a turbine engine is for compressing air to feed more of it into the combustion chamber and therefore burning more fuel/air mixture. Other functions, in our opinion, include providing bleed air ducts to remove air for pneumatic systems on the aircraft, and as in this question, increasing the cooling of the turbine through secondary and tertiary airflow. One of the big issues with high power turbofan engines in particular is that their combustion chambers burn ridiculously hot, and no materials can really withstand these temperatures, so whilst some of the high pressure air is used of combustion in the chamber, more of the air becomes secondary air that flows around the combustion area and is introduced later to cool the hot gasses just after being burnt. On some engines, unburnt compressor air is also fed in just before the turbine (tertiary air) to avoid overheating the turbine blades as the TGT (turbine gas temperature) is often the most limiting temperature in gas turbine engines. Notice on the figure above that some air avoids the combustion chamber, this is cooling air. Going through the options: "Driving the associated spool turbine." - Incorrect as the turbine drives the associated compressor, e.g. the LP turbine powers the LP compressor. "Expelling the hot gasses from the combustion process." - Less correct, as this is not really the job that it is doing. The hot gasses have to go somewhere after expanding, but that has to be in the direction of the turbine, where there is no back pressure, and the compressor provides enough "back pressure" to avoid the air being shot out forwards. The secondary air is for cooling, not directing airflow. "Cooling the intake air to allow for better combustion." - Incorrect, the compressor heats up the air naturally through compression. "Increase the engine airflow for better turbine cooling." - Correct. The secondary and tertiary air are used in this way.

content.question:
Both gas turbine and piston engines use a cycle made up of induction, compression, combustion and exhaust phases. Which of these statements about a gas turbine are correct?
1. The process in a gas turbine engine is intermittent
2. Theoretically the combustion occurs at constant pressure

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.
options.D: Both 1 and 2 are correct.

key_points: A gas turbine engine is basically a heat engine using air as a fluid to produce thrust
The working principle of the gas turbine engine is comparable to that of a piston engine as both engines use a cycle made of induction, compression, combustion, and exhaust phases
The only difference is the way these phases will be achieved as the gas turbine engine is capable of dealing with much larger amounts of energy for a given size and weight
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine is basically a heat engine using air as a fluid to produce thrust. The working principle of the gas turbine engine is comparable to that of a piston engine as both engines use a cycle made of induction, compression, combustion, and exhaust phases. The only difference is the way these phases will be achieved as the gas turbine engine is capable of dealing with much larger amounts of energy for a given size and weight. The other great advantage of the gas turbine engine is that the whole working cycle is continuous and entirely rotational providing an overall smoother operation, whereas the piston engine uses an intermittent reciprocating motion which is converted to rotary motion by means of cranks. Summary: Piston engine -Process is intermittent -Combustion is at constant volume Jet engine -Process is continuous -Combustion is at constant pressure.

content.question: Labyrinth seals in the lubrication system of a gas turbine engine are designed to provide a seal that is…

options.A: not completely tight, allowing some movement between rotating and static parts.
options.B: completely tight, allowing some axial movement between rotating and static parts.
options.C: completely tight, allowing no movement between rotating and static parts.
options.D: not completely tight, allowing only some radial movement between rotating and static parts.

key_points: Internal sealing of the lubrication system is provided by using cooling air
The air, under pressure, is directed inwards towards the bearings or oil supply, thus preventing the escape of oil from the bearing surface
Various types of oil and air seals are used
learning.explanation: Internal sealing of the lubrication system is provided by using cooling air. The air, under pressure, is directed inwards towards the bearings or oil supply, thus preventing the escape of oil from the bearing surface. Various types of oil and air seals are used. Labyrinth seals are widely used in gas turbine engines. This type of seals are mechanical seals providing tortuous guidance to oil lines to prevent leakage. They are composed of small grooves that are tightly fitted inside the axle and have long guides for oil, making it impossible for the oil to escape. However, considering that these seals are used between rotating and stationary parts, there needs to be some flexibility so that they can allow free movement of the various elements.

content.question: The function of a vibrator (trembler mechanism) in gas turbine ignition systems is to provide…

options.A: a DC current if the ignition system is fed by AC voltage.
options.B: a DC current to the transformer to facilitate the generation of a higher voltage to the igniters.
options.C: a pulsating AC voltage in order to generate a more powerful spark.
options.D: an AC voltage in order to facilitate transformation to a higher voltage.

key_points: Each gas turbine engine has two separate high-energy igniters able to deliver up to 25 000 V
The ignition system consists of a capacitance high energy ignition unit and an igniter plug designed to deliver the high voltage, high current discharge from a low AC or DC supply
The most common ignition unit is the DC trembler operated unit
learning.explanation: Each gas turbine engine has two separate high-energy igniters able to deliver up to 25 000 V. The ignition system consists of a capacitance high energy ignition unit and an igniter plug designed to deliver the high voltage, high current discharge from a low AC or DC supply. The most common ignition unit is the DC trembler operated unit. The trembler operates an induction coil and facilitates the generation of a higher voltage to the igniters by providing a DC current to the transformer through a high voltage rectifier. The rectifier will avoid any discharge back into the coil winding while the capacitor will charge up to a value that will break down the sealed discharge gap. The current will then discharge through the sealed discharge gap, the choke, and the igniter plugs, which are all connected in series. The capacitor is then recharged and the cycle is repeated.

content.question: With regards to a turbine engine, what does the term “engine seizure” mean?

options.A: Engine seizure is a type of failure of a gas turbine engine in which a mechanical process physically stops an engine from turning and jams its rotating motion.
options.B: Engine seizure is a sudden stoppage of the engine due to a lack of fuel, caused by a blockage of the fuel pumps.
options.C: Engine seizure is a situation where the engine RPM is suddenly increasing and exceeding the operating limits.
options.D: Engine seizure refers to the size of the engine and describes the outside dimensions of an engine.

key_points: Engine Seizure is a type of failure of a gas turbine engine in which a mechanical process physically stops an engine from turning and jams its rotating motion
Seizure may be caused by a damaged component inside the engine that disengages from its position and blocks the rotation
Turbine seizure must never occur under normal design conditions; only in the case of a serious malfunction of an engine
learning.explanation: Engine Seizure is a type of failure of a gas turbine engine in which a mechanical process physically stops an engine from turning and jams its rotating motion. Seizure may be caused by a damaged component inside the engine that disengages from its position and blocks the rotation. Turbine seizure must never occur under normal design conditions; only in the case of a serious malfunction of an engine. Therefore, seizure can be avoided by preventing engine failure conditions, which is possible by regular maintenance of engines.

content.question: The EPR (Engine Pressure Ratio) is…

options.A: the difference between the compressor inlet total pressure and the turbine outlet total pressure.
options.B: the ratio of the turbine outlet total pressure to the ambient total pressure.
options.C: the ratio of the turbine outlet total pressure to the compressor inlet total pressure.
options.D: the ratio of the compressor outlet total pressure to the compressor inlet total pressure.

key_points: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow
On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR
The EPR is the ratio between the low-pressure turbine exhaust pressure (the engine’s last stage) and the engine inlet pressure (the fan’s pressure)
learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The EPR is the ratio between the low-pressure turbine exhaust pressure (the engine’s last stage) and the engine inlet pressure (the fan’s pressure). It is a very precise parameter, so very gentle adjustments on the thrust levers must be made to achieve the desired power setting. EPR indicator pressure sensors can either be of the electromechanical type (bellows) or systems that transform a mechanical movement into an electric signal (transducer).

content.question: What should the pilots do if they observe an engine limit exceedance during flight?

options.A: Only an engine temperature limit exceedance needs to be reported in the aircraft's technical logbook.
options.B: Any exceedance of engine limits in flight must be reported and documented in the aircraft's technical logbook.
options.C: Only an engine overspeed condition must be reported and documented in the aircraft's technical logbook.
options.D: If engine parameters return to normal values within a short period of time and NO special instructions are given in the flight manual (AFM) for such an exceedance, no formal entry in the aircraft's technical logbook is required, and the engineers should be informed directly at the end of the day.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.11.04.01.11: Explain why engine-limit exceedances must be reported. When critical values are exceeded, even briefly, the PIC needs to report them in the aircraft's technical logbook (ATL - or Tech Log). In fact, every night the engineers will check and work on the aircraft, if necessary, and the first thing they will do is check the Tech Log to see any reports written since the last check. Subsequent inspection, testing, and maintenance will be conducted. The exceedance of any engine parameters such as the EPR, EGT, N1, N2, TGT limits will allow the maintenance to conduct the necessary checks to analyse whether the exceedance has damaged any components or not.

content.question: In a gas turbine engine, the Inlet Guide Vanes (IGV)…

options.A: direct the airflow at the optimal angle into the diffuser.
options.B: increase the velocity of the air entering the compressor.
options.C: direct the airflow at the optimal angle to the compressor`s first stage.
options.D: reduce the velocity of the air entering the combustion section.

key_points: Variable inlet guide vanes (VIGVs) are fitted to engines which have a particular problem with inherent compressor stall at low rpm or during engine acceleration or deceleration
At low compressor speeds, the VIGVs are angled to impart the greatest amount of swirl to the air, thereby directing the relative airflow to obtain the optimum angle of attack over the rotor blades
This optimum angle of attack allows a smooth and rapid engine acceleration
learning.explanation: Variable inlet guide vanes (VIGVs) are fitted to engines which have a particular problem with inherent compressor stall at low rpm or during engine acceleration or deceleration. At low compressor speeds, the VIGVs are angled to impart the greatest amount of swirl to the air, thereby directing the relative airflow to obtain the optimum angle of attack over the rotor blades. This optimum angle of attack allows a smooth and rapid engine acceleration. The vanes are fitted in front of the first rotor stage, automatically pivoted around their own axis to vary the path of the airflow going into the compressor and maintain the proper relationship between compressor rotational speed and airflow in the front compressor stages.
